Some background: I am an avid coffee drinker. I bleed coffee. My blood probably tastes like coffee. Coffee is my life. Being a Seattleite - I drink more coffee than I do water. I love ALL coffee shops (Starbucks doesn't really count). I love places with a simple and clean feel where I can sit and mind my own business and or chitchat with a friend. Being able to go here and drink this amazing coffee... I think I went to heaven and came back. My friend from the Bay Area knew of my deep and passionate love for coffee and brought me here during my little adventure in California last summer. 

He recommended that I get the Kyoto Iced Coffee and I did... hands down, BEST coffee I have had thus far (sorry Seattle... I mean there's one place I can think of off the top of my head - but truthfully it only comes second to this TRUE coffee shop gem). 

Truth be told, I paid no attention to the customer service... I was distracted and in awe at how amazing the place was and how amazing the coffee tasted. My friend and I were able to chat and catch up on projects we were working on and our plans for school. Great atmosphere, great coffee, and cute neighborhood. 

I definitely recommend this place to ALL coffee lovers. If I ever come back to San Francisco, I'm going to bug my friend to bring me here again. 

I miss this place.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
So I had gone for drip, siphon and a latte and been blown away with the quality... The siphon is a ritual that I suggest everybody watch once... And it's quite a way to really explore the bean.  Everybody knows they're good for their coffee, what more to say!?

I feel the major need to talk about the latte. Ok so it's not the purists drink but I thought... Well, if they get the coffee right, what about the other drinks.  I am blown away.... I mean this isn't just a latte, this was a smooth yet rich, tasty, give me more right now, kind of drink.  The perfect flavor, the right milk, a fun art on top of the perfect foam.  


Ok so go get some coffee.... But also try the latte, and I'll take another please!
author: Mike S.

description:
This place it a little out of the way and a little difficult to find but totally worth it! My fiancé and I came to SF for his birthday and a friend recommended this place to us. We are quite the fans of "hipster" coffee houses. We're from SoCal and we have a favorite spot in our own city and we wanted to find an alternative while we were here.

The only downfall was that they don't have flavors. We are used to cinnamon-honey, caramel, vanilla, etc. and they only seemed to have sugar and simple syrup as sweeteners.

The coffee is just as good as we are used to which is FAR better than Starbucks... Good coffee is not bitter whatsoever, and should be paired with milk and be milky. The coffee here has a great flavor profile and was delicious. Its strong, good quality coffee. 

We ordered a hot cafe latte and an iced New Orleans 

We also ordered pumpkin buckles which were soooo good! They were like pumpkin muffins with a crumble on top.

I highly recommend this spot for any coffee connoisseurs or anyone who wants a good mug of coffee made by people who really know what they are doing.
author: Rachael Z.

description:
Nice espresso but I don't see what all the fuss is about.
If I had to pick one local place it would be Philz for their coffee and I actually prefer espresso drinks.
author: Jim G.

description:
This place is beyond amazing. For the price and quality, and flavor Blue Bottle is definately the best coffee.

I was first introduced to it in Atlanta, and happy to find it in SF, and too go and experience this place and all of it's glory.

The fresh brews are amazing along with their staff.

Do yourself a favor and have a cup of joe here. You'll coffee taste buds will never be the same after.
author: Amy L.

description:
Found this little gem thanks to a friend who was with me at the time. The hype for this place is well deserved. The menu is not overly massive, or exotic. It's very simple, and they focus on what they do best - coffee.

Three of us had the cappuccino, which was the best cappuccino I have had in years; while my friend got a mocha which was just as good. Every drink they make they add a small design with the froth, which is always a plus in my book, and they literally treat the coffee they make here almost as if it's an art. Just a fare warning - the line here gets mighty long at points so be patient. It's well worth the wait and they are pretty quick at what they do.
author: Michael L.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is exactly what you expect it to be.

The coffee is superb, the store is clean and modern with ample seating, the service is prompt and helpful. 

But for me, this brand of hipster is juuuust too uppity. Even a dab of cozy/friendly/mellow would make this place five stars for me.

Come for really great coffee, do come. But know that you'll inevitably leave feeling a bit superior to anyone who hasn't walked in, wrestling with the tension of whether or not your love for quality lattes has made you a coffee snob.
author: Danielle G.

description: Aside from the crowds extending out the door of the shop, this place is great. Expect to pay a bit more but have an excellent coffee experience. There are all kings of varietals and blends and a myriad of preparations from which to choose. The service is friendly and efficient. The baked goods are unusual and well prepared. And of course the coffee is great.
author: Philip S.

description: One of my most fav coffee brands!  This location was hidden in the mint plaza.  It's a fairly small location, but serves yummy food.  They have the standard blue bottle coffee menu, with my favs being the macchiato and the regular coffee of the day.  There's a tiny parking lot along the side of the coffee shop.
author: Jenn T.

description:
Nice coffee, nice pastries. But keep it in mind, nothing takes longer that a regular coup of drip coffee here. They make it up to order.  
What also sucks is that people smoke on the patio so you can't actually enjoy your breakfast.
author: Milla E.

description:
Didn't know what real coffee was till I tried a latte at Blue Bottle. Mind blowing. Epic. Earth shattering. 

Since then I've gone on to cure children's leukemia, save the rain forest, invent the next big thing since the internet, all while driving a hybrid. No joke folks. This place will change your life.
author: Jeri B.

description: Very unique coffee shop! Located around many shops and restaurants off one of the piers.  Ordered two iced coffees and was not too impressed, but maybe I will try something different next time. Great customer service and prompt delivery.
author: Michael C.

description: Great coffee! I got latte and a coconut macaroon with coffee fudge (I think) filling. Both delicious and definitely worth the short wait on Thursday afternoon (1:30PM)! I'm coming back!
author: Karolina C.

description:
It was a long hot summer day in the city and it was a long time that I wanted to try this place. So I ordered a decaf iced coffee and I really enjoyed every single sip of it! Good job!
Nice coffee, cute interior design, friendly and polite staff.
author: Shirin Z.

description:
Nestled in the corner of Mint Plaza, the simple Blue Bottle on the wall lets you know that you are steps away from a heavenly cup of coffee that will satisfy your palette and leave you yearning for more.  it's like Batman's beacon of light letting Gotham City know that all is well in the world again.  If you time it right, you can avoid the plethora of people turning Mint Plaza into a sea of Blue Bottle feigns surely thinking the same thing as you.  With every cup made to order, it offers a wonderful sense of individual attention, and catering, providing a pleasant experience time and time again.

This location also provides  a certain historical value with its ages machines on display, looking like half laboratory brewery, and half modern age coffee bar.  The lines are clean, deliberate, and styled for fashion, yet as you stand waiting for your cup, you smell the fresh roast, take a deep breath, and plunge in to the overwhelming aroma of cappuccino, soy latte, hot chocolate, coffee goodness (or whatever the order may be), you're taken to a world full of mouth fulfilling satisfaction.  And pay special attention to the intricate details as they turn your cup of coffee into a drinkable work of art just before your very eyes as you're getting ready to pay.

And don't forget to compliment your liquid treat with a sweet treat from the food display.  There are plenty of delectable pastries, cookies, and finger food snacks to accompany your cup of gold.  I'm pretty partial to the ginger molasses cookie, it's rich and deep and smoky in molasses, like it had been churning for weeks before added to the batch, the slivers of ginger add just the perfect amount of added texture to the thick, tongue grabbing molasses, and the natural sweetness it blends to the dough itself makes it a well rounded accoutrement.  

Don't just stand there, get in line, no matter how long, no matter how you have to brave the elements, get a cup and find out what you've been missing.  You'll thank yourself for it.
author: Myke Y.

description:
I'm not a huge coffee person, so purists might spite me for my review.

I actually don't like my coffee scorching hot. I want to be able to drink it and not burn my tongue on the first sip. 

The affogoto on its own is worth the 5 stars. OMG!!! Espresso with Humphrey Slocombe ice cream. They just go together so well. Its a good thing I don't live in the city, or I would have one everyday!
author: Benny N.

description:
Came here two months ago because the Food Channel recommended their Kyoto Iced Coffee.

What a mistake. Time consuming, and it tasted like a Kona Coffee that I could brew myself.

Long wait. Rude staff. 

Totally overrated. Much like the food channel's reviews at times.
author: Jack R.

description: The coffee is good, better than Starbucks of course. The price is reasonable, and the store is clean and bright. Is a good place to gathering with friends. But not quiet enough to have biz talk or do something needs to be focused.
author: ChingYi H.

description:
I like coffee.  I drink coffee almost everyday, but I can not call myself a coffee connoisseur.  I know what I like and that is dark roast coffee.  Ask me to tell you the difference between a coffee bean from this region or how they roast this or that in another and you might as well ask a 1st grader.  I'm not that much of a caffeine snob.

That being said I do appreciate a good, bold, clean tasting cup of joe.  Especially if i get to experience something as cool as this. At this place they something called Siphon (look it up, it's kinda neat @http://www.bluebottlecoffee.com/preparation-guides/siphon).  When my girlfriend told me about it, I knew I would have to give it a try.  

Other people have complained about the price and other things, but it's something different that you don't see everyday so I was willing pay a little extra. It takes a little long but hey, this isn't Starbucks.  I sat there and watched the process like the nerdy engineer I am.  

The employees were super nice and answered all our questions since we didn't know exactly what we wanted.  The place was pretty small but we got lucky and found a couple seats.  It was simple and very clean in my opinion.  Parking was the only problem....i had no idea where to park!  The streets were all packed so we ended up parking on a kinda sketchy street a couple blocks away.  

Was this the best cup of coffee I've ever had?  Couldn't tell one way or another.  Was this a VERY good cup of coffee?  Hell yes!  It was very clean and smooth tasting to me.  You get 2+ cups of coffee from one order so I think it was worth the amount charged.  Did I mention it was cool to watch?

If you're a caffeine junky like me this is definitely a must try on your next trip to SF!
author: Robert A.

description:
So, I found this place by accident. When I stopped there was a line from the counter all the way out the door onto the sidewalk and then literally around the building. Usually, with a line like that I wouldn't even consider waiting, but as you can see from the other reviews many people believe this to be the best coffee in the world.

However, I did wait , and I'm glad I did because the total time from getting in line to walking out the door with my coffee with less than 10 minutes. I got my coffee faster than when I am the only customer at a Starbucks.

As for the coffee itself - I ordered the Frozen New Orleans coffee , and while I cannot comfortably saying that it was the best coffee in the world, I also can't think of a time I've tasted better coffee.

So yes, wait in line, it won't be that bad , if anything you'll at least get a great cup of coffee at a fair price.
author: Edwin B.

description: New Orleans iced coffee!! Plus you get to pick whatever milk you want at no extra charge (well at $4, let's hope that there wouldn't be an extra charge). I always got soy and it was perfect!
author: Jade L.

description: Amazing coffee. I got the latte. The caffeine didn't make me gittery at all, and it definitely gave me the energy I needed. The people who work here are super friendly, and they are all very passionate about the coffee. The man who made our drip was fantastic. Great atmosphere and ambience for a nice, relaxing Saturday afternoon. Definitely recommend it!
author: Nadia H.

description: Cool place next to some government buildings. This coffee house obvious has a following from how good it is because it is a little off the beaten path from the bustling downtown streets. Its behind this anticlimactic square and sits on the corner of an alley and another dead end street. The team has great service, the shop is clean, modern, and serves delicious coffee. I wish they served some larger sizes, I believe the largest is 12 oz. We did not grab breakfast here, however, the food looked good especially the Chia pudding, and they had some other larger dishes with eggs- all for an acceptable price. They also have fully compostable paper/plastic goods which is super cool to see plastic lids as 100% compostable. Keep up the good brew and smiling faces!
author: Zachary M.

description:
OK, I have a confession. I'm not a coffee drinker but observing my Yelp friends, I gather that coffee is a big deal. Coffee drinkers not only have a favourite coffee company but a specific branch of a specific coffee company

My good Yelp friends Tammy C and Peter L brought me here after a yummy brunch at Farmer Brown. This is the poshest/coolest/most pretentious coffee shop I've yet been to. Not being a coffee drinker, I don't feel qualified to differentiate between the 3 adjectives above

They have a range of beans from different parts of the world and the knowledgeable staff were keen to tell me the different characteristics of the beans from different regions. To my untrained palate, the coffee, served up neat, just tasted bitter to me

However, it was the most fun coffee I've seen being brewed. They boil it up in what appear to be giant light bulbs. Definitely funky but I still decide whether it's cool or pretentious

A big thank you to Tammy and Peter for the Tcho chocolate that they gave me as a present
author: Yee Gan O.

description: The best coffee I had in San Francisco area. I had it take out and also bought coffee beans. Very good coffee.
author: JS k.

description:
Came here on a weekend when brunch was being served.  I only ordered a latte since I came after breakfast.  The decor was super cute in a part of the neighborhood that made this feel like a real neighborhood joint.  The food looked spectacular and I wished I had the appetite to get something.  The latte was pretty solid but nothing necessarily exceptional about it.  

I would come back for the ambience.  It's a bit of a hipster oasis in a tucked away alley.  Tip: this isn't your typical sit-with-your-laptop type of place.  It's designed more for 1 or 2 people to sit and chat and can get crowded because of this.  I'd love to come back and try some of the more unique parts of their menu - perhaps a latte simply wasn't the right thing to get to really enjoy the place.

Update: Came back for a second take.  Got a siphon from El Salvador.  I saw how artfully they were making it.   As a quick tutorial (because I honestly didn't know what I was ordering), a siphon utilizes water vapor and a vacuum to brew coffee.  The water is boiled with a heating light which vaporizes it and moves the water up through a filter into a top container.  Then coffee is stirred in slowly to that top chamber.  After careful timing (which the guy making this was watching closely), it is taken off the heating lamp and the coffee filters back down to the bottom chamber.  Pretty cool.  What came out was a very delicate coffee but it wasn't worthy of $7 in my opinion.  It was entertaining and educational, but the coffee was an exceptional $4 cup of coffee.  I think this place is slightly more hype than quality, although the coffee is.... solid.
author: Thomas C.

description: Amazing. Coffee is my first language, no matter the method and blue bottle is known in SF for a reason. I've never had an off or bad cup from here and the baristas were very helpful to the first timer next to me. A definite go to if you're in town and want to be pleased!
author: Emmy B.

description: Affogato perfect!  Breakfast sandwich...the bun and bacon to die for.  I love this place!!!
author: Jayce O.

description: Beautiful location at the ground level of what looks like an office building. Order on the side closest to the door and pick up around the corner. Personally, I find their coffee a little bitter but thats not what the review is about. It is about the amazing delicious crispy sweet buttery nutty (with no nuts) liege waffle. Only $4. It comes piping hot and the size of your face. Feel free to share with a friend.
author: Tammy T.

description:
One of my favorite Blue Bottle Coffee locations to visit with my BFF while in the neighborhood to catch a bite, taste varietal coffees, and catch up on each other.

Unlike the Ferry Building location, Japanese style slow brewed coffee is served here as well as several breakfast dishes. The waffle here is served on a plate with chutney versus a Belgian waffle like in the Ferry Building.

Like the Ferry Building, coffee goods are sold here - beans, and brewing tools.
author: Grace G.

description: I'm a bit of a coffee snob and this is my favorite thus far. Very cute, hipster setting with nice service and excellent coffee. I ordered a soy latte and a double chocolate cookie. Both were excellent and I can't wait to go back
author: Christine A.

description: Love this coffee shop, and always visit it multiple times when we visit SF and Union Square. The coffee is always so fresh, bold, and rich. Service is quite good. Never eaten here, so I can't really comment on that.
author: Ryan S.

description: One of the best places for coffee in SF. I visit this Blue Bottle at least 1-2x a week and have never been disappointed. Latte art is beautiful and their espresso is always delicious. There is always a long line to order but the line will move fast and they make drinks fast! The burnt orange pound cake is absolutely divine! They have restrooms but ask the baristas for the key. Highly recommend stopping by for delicious espresso coffee! The next thing to try on my list is their affogato which i hear is amazing!
author: Diana F.

description:
It's not every day that you meet the owner of the Yelp business while in line, but that's just what happened when we visited Blue Bottle Coffee Co.

Based on Yelp reviews, my wife had recommended making a special strip to the Mint Plaza location and trying the Kyoto iced coffee. The first thing I noticed was that (1) there was a line out the door, and (2) a pigeon was engaged in targeted arial bombing of the patrons in line. I was just remarking on the threat posed by the San Francisco Pigeon Air Force to the lady standing in front of us when a man came and joined her in line. I made a joke about cutters in line being prosecuted to the full extent of the law, and we had a pleasant exchange. He seemed like a nice enough bloke, plus he & his companion knew their way around ordering, and following their lead I ordered a Cappuchino along with the steel cut oats, both of which turned out to be fantastic.

It took a few minutes to find a spot to seat at the communal tables, but we ended up seated next to the same couple. By this time, my wife was discovering that the Kyoto iced coffee is not a good choice for someone who does not like the taste of coffee (I know, I know...). Our new friends asked how we liked our food & coffee, and when my wife said, while she loved the Eggs Benedict, she wished she had ordered a different drink, he graciously volunteered to switch it out for us, explaining that he worked at Blue Bottle. By this point, I had noticed that he seemed to be on a first-name basis with all of the staff, but I did not make any connection until we had parted company and had gotten into our Uber ride where a quick Google search made me realize we had just played part in a real-life episode of Undercover Boss.

The next time we are in San Francisco, we will definitely stop by to try some of the other menu items (everything looks so good).
author: Jonathan G.

description: I have to admit that Blue Bottle is no longer as exciting as it once was. I somehow find the layout in this location kind of awkward - even when there's not a ton of people, it still feels crowded and difficult to move around in. But, sometimes it's still the best option for the area.
author: Lisa K.

description: Great coffee! But oatmeal and avocado toast with that coffee? You got yourself a perfect breakfast. Just go to Mint plaza location. Not every location has hit breakfast option, but excellent coffee everywhere. It is not sour, it is just right!
author: Masha M.

description: Outstanding coffee - well-balanced and flavorful. Prepared well and not burnt or acidic. Totally recommended.
author: Martin G.

description:
Hard to go wrong with a coffee shop whose "house" coffee is still a pour over. A pour over is often the highest quality you will get in most coffee shops, but its rests near the bottom at Blue Bottle. This specific shop features a variety of method including their Siphon Bar.

The coffee was top notch and they even offer a variety of breakfast food. The line was out the door when we arrived around 7:30am, so just make sure you plan your time accordingly.
author: Dave M.

description:
Pros: tasty, bitter, rich coffee.

Cons: being alive here. 

Claustrophobic space, and nothing I'm actually paying the $5 for included. No almond milk left, no WiFi, no outlets, no seating left. 

ABORT MISSION.
author: Rachel R.

description: This is the one of my favorite coffee spots. The popular menu is new orleans iced coffee, but I recommend cafe latte. It is just amazing!
author: J P.

description:
I Love this coffee and highly recommend getting the New Orleans Iced Coffee. They use a cold water extraction process which brings out all the notes and piquancy of the beans. In addition, they also add chicory to assure that all the notes vibrantly appear with each sip. I do not recommend using a lid as the memory of the coffee hitting your lips becomes more of a vivid nostalgic experience when looking back. Craving. 

Blue bottle is widely known amongst coffee connoisseurs and is a MUST try when near by. Also try Philz coffee and get the iced mojito.
author: Ben G.

description:
I love coffee. I love all kinds of coffee. I especially love trying new kinds of coffee and finding new favorites.

I've known Blue Bottle for about 2 years now, but have never written a review of their outpost on Mint St in SF.

This little spot is a treasure. Its small and seating can sometimes be challenging, but the vibe is fantastic. 

The staff here really do make it for me. Any time I am in the neighborhood, I make a point to get my coffee here.

I'm addicted to their latte - but am eager to try the drip w/au lait to switch things up a bit. 

Most of the time, I grab the coffee to go, but enjoy sipping from a proper coffee mug whenever I have the time to stop and sit for a bit.

On top of the fantastic coffee, this spot has some pretty fantastic treats to eat. It is all super good and super fresh. Pastries are amazing too. 

They also have a good selection of gifts - keepsake mugs, tote bags, coffee sampler boxes, etc. So, if you are looking for a unique gift idea from SF - check it out.
author: Wendy P.

description: On a visit to SF, we visited the Blue Bottle for the first time.  It was right next door to our hotel.  There was a line to get in.  Wasn't sure how to order, but when they took our order they gave an overview of the options available.  The cool factor is very high.  Had a great breakfast and cups of coffee prepared by what looked like chemists.  The coffee was the smoothest I have ever had.  Enjoyed the time with my wife and we would come back.
author: Mike M.

description:
Having read very positive reviews of this place we decided to try it out for breakfast. We were certainly not disappointed. Very friendly staff and very quick service considering the place was full to the max.
We both had waffles and a cappuccino with a peanut butter cookie. I think the proof is in the photos as we demolished it within seconds! Coffee was delicious too! Going again today to try some eggs as they also looked fantastic on nearby tables.
author: Paul B.

description: Don't understand all the hype about this coffee place.  However, I 'm not a coffee expert so I can't say anything.  My husband got a regular small coffee for $2.50. It tasted just like coffee.....
author: Rena H.

description: You can't leave San Francisco without going to Blue Bottle cafe. Saw them on Buzzfeed on YouTube and had to go when my dad and I were planning our trip. When we got there, they were busy but it felt relaxed. We ordered an iced mocha, iced latte, water, and their roasted orange pound cake. The mocha was a equal amount of chocolate and espresso and better than any mocha out there. The latte has ruined me because it is the best latte I have ever had. Starbucks has nothing on Blue Bottle. The pound cake was out of this world. I would do anything for another slice of that pound cake. Blue Bottle is the best and every time I go back to San Francisco, I will always come back to Blue Bottle.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
If you are a true coffee lover the Blue Bottle is for you.  One of the best coffee bars in San Fran... The coffee is the freshest coffee you can get. 

Roasted within two days of you enjoying it, speaks for it's self. 

Great open atmosphere and a must have for those who truly want a 'GREAT" coffee experience!
author: S C.

description:
BF: "How do you pronounce Cafe Au Lait?

Me: "Ow Lay....?"

BF: "What?"

Me: "Owwww Lay...."

BF: "I give up."

The BF and I made sure to make Blue Bottle Coffee a destination on our most recent trip to SF. Lucky for us it was just a few blocks away from our hotel, so what turned into a single visit turned into our morning coffee for every day we were in the city! 

As other Yelpers have mentioned, location is in an alley. Not a typical city dweller, I found this a little sketchy... Just a liiitttle. Lines are long, but they do move steadily. On average the wait is like, 10 minutes? Not particuarly a deal breaker, but I probably wouldn't come here if I needed to be someplace.

The BF is a huge coffee addict. Me? Not so much. I couldn't tell you the difference between "good" coffee versues a 99 cent cup at the gas station because I dump so much cream and sugar into it. The coffee from Blue Bottle though, is a definite game changer. On vacation mind, I decided to forgo my regular order of drip coffee piled with sugar and decided to order something a little more uppity. As a result, I lost my cappucino virginity here, and I loved every sip of it! The coffee here smooth, rich, and flavorful. For the first time, I actually enjoyed the simple taste of the coffee without any added sugar. While I didn't stray from my cappucino for the next three days, the BF deviated and tried multiple types and approved of them all.

The only downside is that the people working here can be pretentious, with a capital P! The BF wanted to get an order of Cafe au Lait. But for the life of him, he couldn't get the pronounciation down. "Just order a coffee with milk", I told him. "It's essentially the same thing." 

In the world of Blue Bottle, this is so not true. 

"You mean 'Cafe au Lait'", says the barista. 

"Yes"

"It's called Cafe au Lait". 

Blank stare.

Fab coffee. Just remember to order correctly so to avoid the coffee police!
author: Donna M.

description:
This is a cute coffee joint located in SOMA.  I managed to get here quite early in the morning on a Sunday so the lines haven't gone out the door at that time.  If you wait any longer and stroll in after 11AM, the lines will definitely go out the door!

I got a latte here.  I asked for vanilla but they don't have any syrups of any kind - is this a coffee snobbery thing?  So, I took my latte plain.  The latte wasn't bad but as of this writing I really don't remember what it tasted like enough to comment on it.  

Their hot mochas are decent but they definitely are not as sweet as most mochas. If you like non sweet mochas, this is the place for you.

I do remember that a customer wanted a drink to go and the barista told him that he could not get that drink to go - it had to be consumed in house.  What.

I also tried the Belgian waffle.  It was pretty tasty but quite expensive.  $8 or so.  And it takes awhile for them to prepare food since there are so many orders.

You can pay via Square here.

The seating here is super awkward and cramped.  Mostly long tables/bar table style so be prepared to sit next to people you don't know.  I do not recommend bringing in a large group of friends.
author: Danielle C.

description:
It's everything I wanted in a coffee and more!! Worth every penny.

We purchased a New Orleans iced coffee, Kyoto, Olive oil short bread, maple pecan pastry, snicker doodle, and molasses ginger cookies.
author: Tonya P.

description: This place was just ok. The main reason being is because there was this pretentious douche bag with terrible service working the cash register. I should've called him out and tell him to watch his attitude. It was as if he was looking down on me for being a bay area native that hadn't ever tried Blue Bottle Coffee. The product in all honesty is good, but I'd rather go to Philz or Coffee Bar because of this sleezy bearded loser who served me.
author: Aaron C.

description:
The hype is real!  This place is legit.  

Expect to wait in line though.  It moves quickly, but no matter what time or day there always seems to be people craving their coffee.

They make one of the best cappuccinos in the bay!  Their barista team really focuses on quality, not quantity (So don't expect a super-sized Venti drink).

The place inside has several, long community tables with a lot of stools.  So expect to get close to your neighbor!  It's a casual atmosphere with energetic conversations going on at once.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Adrian R.

description:
The 5 stars is for the affogato (espresso + ice cream). It was drool worthy with the right balance between creamy and coffee. I was talking with friends and I killed it within 5 minuets on a cold day sitting outside. I wanted seconds. 
This location isn't really out in the open but there was still a decent amount of people lined out the door. One down side is that there isn't that much sitting room so do not expect to be able to sit down with coffee and work all day there.
author: Maybo H.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend on a Saturday for Brunch. I found out that this Blue Bottle location offered food selections and I was excited to try it. We got here around 11:40 AM and there was already a line forming out the door and around the corner. We had to wait probably around 20-25 mins in line before we were able to order. 

Their brunch menu is very organically based and offer farm raised products. In the end, I ended up ordering Poached eggs on acme bread with a tomato puree on top and my boyfriend the popeye's toast. We also order drinks, me a soy latte and my boyfriend a mocha. The drinks are always good. I've always been happy with their coffee, smooth, nutty, and delicious. The food was ok. I didn't love my meal, but I didn't hate it. I will say that the butter on my boyfriend's toast was delicious. I would go back just to eat bread and butter.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Came here after seeing its rating (top rated in about 2 miles radius of our hotel). When we walked in, we were intrigued by the laboratory-ish apparatus (I swear I saw bunsen burners and burettes)....i thought these guys are serious about their coffee.....what a good sign. 

Ordered a regular black coffee (i want to taste the coffee in its simplest form) and a New Orleans iced coffee. I liked my coffee, in the first 5 minutes. It had good balance of bitterness and coffee aroma. HOWEVER, the coffee quickly cooled down (we sat by an open window on a chilly day) and turned acidic. It was so bad that I had to add lots of cream and sugar to counter it. 

The NO iced coffee is ok....slightly sweet, refreshing, subtle coffee flavor, and bold H2O flavor. Yeah, it's definitely watered down and surely not worth the price. 

At this point, I would say this place is over hyped....I'd probably give it another shot because I don't think a cafe would be that well reviewed by serving mediocre coffee.
author: Kin N.

description:
Ok, everyone is crazy over this coffee. Maybe it's just me but I thought it was just ok- nothing stood out as superior. Yes, I heard about how they brew their coffee, the extra steps, and the high end machines they use to make that superior coffee. Honestly though, what matters most is the end taste. I feel like this is just the newest coffee place that everyone is flocking towards. One less corporate, more hipster, and more cool.

Coffee has become a status symbol- what kind of coffee do you drink? Starbucks and Peets just don't cut it anymore and Blue Bottle simply fills that void and the people are willing to line up to have a taste. 
I just don't buy it.
author: Kim P.

description:
Totally rude girl barista with the dark pony tail and blue eyes. :/ So many eye rolls for a simple question about the New Orleans coffee sweetness level. Damn. There also nobody else in line at the time, so the attitude was most def. unwarranted.

Get a different job if you hate people so much. Will be avoiding this location from now on.
author: S ..

description: This place was very busy, but the staff still made an effort to make you feel welcome even as your standing in the back of the line outside. I got a latte and it was outstanding. Also got the Blue Bottle Breakfast sandwich and it was the best breakfast sandwich I've ever had. The busgirl was on her game, and was running around keeping the place clean as well as helping people find seats since seating is very limited. But if you give it a few minutes a few will open up. Great place!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Very tasty cappuccino. Normally I always order cappuccino with no sugar. Blue bottle coffee is smell very nice and smooth.
author: Surada L.

description:
This place doesn't deserve the hype it's getting! The lines are always long but it is not because of the quality of coffee or the food, its because of the staff who is slow and unfocused. 
It takes the exact amount of time to prepare espresso and their signature breakfast sandwich which is about 20-25 minutes. By the way the food is dry and flavorless and coffee is burned and bitter... Like my review. 
So, to sum things up, this place is the sane as any starbucks around the world, no flavor, no class and no good coffee! Avoid it at any cost!
author: Alex G.

description: I'm a huge fan of Blue Bottle, and this space is larger than just a counter. There's plenty of seating in a large well lit open room. The location is also conveniently located in fidi. The only issue I have with this location is that there's no free wifi.
author: Cynthia X.

description: Hard to find for a tourist, but worth it. Super friendly people and the coffee and home made granola were great . Pricey
author: R H.

description: Got the New Orleans which is a iced coffee with a touch of sweetness. Quite bitter and tasty but not quite up my alley. If try another though if in the area.
author: Joshua F.

description:
Now I know why everyone has been recommending this place for coffee.... because it's really that good.

The smoothest, frothiest, creamiest latte I've ever had in my entire life. In addition to that, the barista that made my latte me was waaay too nice to me at 7am in the morning. (he's the guy with the mustache, mostly on people's pics here as well). Why didn't I know this location was just a couple blocks from my hotel... le sad.

little protip though: they don't serve food until 8am... which is understandable. but I was a tourist and needed some food on our trip back home, so we headed to starbs after haha

now... how am i going to get my blue bottle fix in LA/SD? :(
author: Chesca L.

description: I stumbled upon this place on Instagram and wanted to give it a try myself. I asked for a recommendation on iced coffees and was introduced to the New Orleans Iced Coffee. To be quite honest, I do not think it was an impressive drink for my taste. I did not taste any signature flavor from it, plus it was sort of watered down.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Extremely nestled. Maybe even hidden. But you want a coffee that's well brewed by knowledgeable staff.. Try to make your way here. 

There's an outside tent that's set up for convenient if you just want a quick drip/fix.. But just across the way you have their inner coffee shop. Get in there and sit a while. You won't regret it. 

Set up in a communal fashion. Long wood tables and bar stools. Don't be shy to talk to your neighbors! The ambulance was meant to be enjoyed.. If you're jonsing to get their brand of coffee? They sell it too. Lots of accessories. 

stirFood, light and fresh heck... They make a quinoa salad in a mason jar! Shaken. Not stirred.
author: Joy L.

description: 4 stars for the price, but 5 for the taste. Loved the iced latte here, one of the best out there. The only downside is the price for how small the cup is. But definitely would recommend
author: Monika H.

description:
I like many others waited in a 40 minute line, in high hopes I would consume the best coffee ever. Did I? Not really.

The design of the space itself is modern, open and hip. The staff at BBC is beyond friendly and helpful and will go into detail describing the blends and such. There is indoor seating, but most are meeting up for "coffee dates" and will be there until the end of time. Minimal stand at the bar area and some outdoor seating. The location is cute, nooked in the back of a hustle bustle business/shopping area - a great courtyard area is outside, but there are bums... so eh. 

And the coffee. Well, perhaps I ordered the wrong thing? I've never been a fan of bitter/floral coffees and thats what I had here (aside from the cappuccino which was fine). My beau and I could barely finish our drip coffee... granted some might find it the best coffee ever, I somehow find that it's the "HYPE" that brought me here. I was a tourist in the city and I love coffee - -  I had much better drip at Philz and Reivelle. My cousin suggested one of their overpriced waffles, but I didn't get around to those.

I suppose if you're on vacay and are hitting the "hot" spots, you will want to check this place out. Be prepared to wait in a line and defnitely get recommendations from others.
author: Juanita D.

description: Amazing!! The poached eggs are incredible... the acabado toast... the cappuccinos!! This place is phenomenal and a hidden gem.
author: Bianca V.

description: Staff is overly patient with slow tourists, makes the line take longer than it should be.
author: Chase E.

description:
I love Blue Bottle Coffee! 
I ordered the cafe mocha and it taste really good! I love the foam in there and  I just Love the environment. Never had any coffee like this place. If your in the Bay Area.. YOU HAVE TO TRY BLUE Bottle CO
author: justin s.

description: I'm not a big coffee drinker (go tea!), so I really couldn't tell you the difference between "good" or "bad" coffee. However, my friend is, so we decided to stop by Blue Bottle Coffee Co for a pick me up in the morning. It's tucked away in a corner of a little plaza, so it might be a bit hard to find. Even on a rainy day, there was a line out the door. However, the service is fast (and really friendly), so you won't be waiting for long. Coffee prices are around $3-5 a cup. There's seating at the long table in the middle and some along the windows, but they were all filled by the time we got there.
author: Christine S.

description: The taste of the  coffee was nothing special.. visiting the area and decided to try something different.. didn't want to buy the usual SB.. not worth it!
author: Norma L.

description:
Really great coffee, cool vibe and friendly staff. The selection of coffee choices and styles of drinks was superb. This is a great, quiet coffee shop. 

Want a quite corner coffee shop to visit, come here. It was a great place to try Blue Bottle with friends for the first time as we all visited San Fran.
author: Sam H.

description: Conveniently located. Ate here several times over the past few years, loved the food and drinks for Breakfast .
author: Amanda B.

description:
Very nice place to stop. Staff is very friendly and welcoming. Coffee is great. I keep coming back.
Highly recommended.
author: Ana K.

description:
First time I tried Blue Bottle was back in New York. I was visiting a friend for Thanksgiving weekend and I was jetlagged. He knew as soon as I stepped out of the plane, he had to take me to get coffee, or else I will throw a tantrum like a 3 year old. Half an hour later, there it was. I stepped inside Blue Bottle and I suddenly felt safe. Lol I ordered the Cafe Mocha (my usual) and it was such a delight. I will never forget that day! So just imagine my excitement when I found out that there's Blue Bottle here in San Francisco. I was absolutely thrilled!!! 

I first came in this location on a Sunday afternoon (4-ish). Not a lot of people yet. The line was not too long. There were seats available. By the way, they have outside seating, so that's cool. Again, as soon as I came in, I felt safe. The smell of their coffee + the ambiance + unbelievably fabulous customer service just totally captured my heart. The parking is pretty tough, but it  won't stop me from coming. I came in the second time last Saturday lunch time and IT WAS PACKED! But I just had to get my Blue Bottle Cafe Mocha regardless.

I'm planning to try their food and Siphon brewed coffee next time I visit. So there will definitely be a Part 2 to this review! : -)
author: Dàra H.

description:
I heard a lot about Blue Bottle Coffee, so I wanted to give them a try when I was in San Francisco. I'm a huge coffee snob (like huge), and I was expecting most of the coffee in San Francisco to be subpar to the places I go in London (which weirdly has an amazing coffee scene these days).

My real test for coffee is how well they do filter coffee. So I ordered one. It's twelve ounces for $3, so I was expecting heaven in a cup given the ridiculous pricing. And honestly, while maybe slightly better than your average cup of coffee in the city, it was nothing special. The coffee had no complexity, just a bit of bitterness. Which made me sad. I was yearning for my London coffee. Or even my Santa Cruz coffee which I fell in love with while living there.

I can't recommend this place given the lackluster coffee. Apparently they do "amazing syphon coffee". Whatever. If you can't make a decent pour over coffee, you haven't won me over.
author: Grant T.

description:
Blue Bottle Café
SF: SOMA
10am Wednesday 14th August 2012 
Five Stars

I come to SF for great coffee and Blue Bottle Café delivered.  I ordered a short Cappuccino, Kyoto Ice Coffee and New Orleans Style Ice Coffee.  The Cappuccino was great - the espresso had a bold flavor but was not overly bitter & the Clover's Organic Whole Milk made amazing micro foam that had a nice natural sweetness to it.  The Combination of New Orleans Ice Coffee + a healthy portion of milk was like sipping on velvet and honey - Simply amazing!  The Kyoto (black) was Strong & Bold but lack any trace of bitterness - it's clear taste with the absence of acidity highlighted the chocolate and whiskey notes of this sensual slow drip coffee.
author: Leonard L.

description: I stop by Blue Bottle every time I'm in SF. The coffee is delicious and the pastries are amazing. Be prepared to wait 10-20 minutes in line during peak times. I'd say it's worth it!
author: Samantha W.

description: Amazing food and coffee. The waitress is so friendly. Everyone is friendly. Love it. First meal in SF
author: Mark T.

description: Came here on a Sunday for a family brunch. We ordered an ice coffee, caffe mocha, caffe latte, and a caffe macchiato. We also ordered poached egg with sausage on corn bread. DELICIOUS as well. The egg yolk just melts into the corn bread and the saltiness and sweetness just blend together. The sausage just adds a nice kick to the breakfast, and the small mixed green salad on the side is amazing as well. The grill cheese is amazing as always and goes perfect with the dijon mustard. Delicious coffee and amazing food, and the coffee art is beautiful. Customer service is wonderful. All in all, I'm a fan!
author: Hoyan L.

description: I've heard a lot about this place and it didn't let me down! I had a simple black coffee and a piece of think cut toast and jam. Seating seems to turn over fast, so I was able to snag a seat. I sat back for a while enjoyed my coffee and toast. A little crowded and crazy but it's because the coffee is that good! So don't be discouraged by the line it's worth it.
author: Brittany M.

description: Its pity, you can't enjoy coffee in a comfortable way in store. It's noisy and lack of seats... Coffee is good, no wonder it gets good reviews. Anyway, if you are stopping by, it's best place over all blue bottle store you could find in sfo! Just get in and enjoy! Your blue bottle coffee.
author: Mefi T.

description: Trendy cafe with a hipster-ish vibe. Not a bad breakfast stop, but my espresso drink had an under-extracted sourness. Not what I expected from a place with so much fancy equipment on the counter. Oatmeal with jam and cream is a good menu option, though. A bit off the beaten path, so less likely to have obnoxious lines at morning rush time.
author: Rob N.

description:
It's been a few years since I last had Blue Bottle and my palate for coffee has definitely become more refined. I am no longer satisfied by mediocre coffee chains. I am weary of holiday-themed gingerbread or peppermint lattes. Good coffee doesn't need to be dressed up in artificial flavors. I just want good, simple, coffee. And this is why I love Blue Bottle so much. Freshly roasted coffee at its finest with the best ingredients. 

The espresso here is heavenly. The mocha is well-prepared with TCHO chocolate (serious dark chocolate enthusiasts). It's the perfect balance of chocolate and coffee without being too sweet. The latte is just as good. A look around the Mint Plaza location shows that they're serious about their coffee, from the drip coffee sets to the perfectly-made latte art. This location is also a nice getaway from the bustling streets of downtown.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I tried this place 3x since the first time I was completely disappointed (based on all the reviews).

The first time I tried their New Orleans iced coffee with soy. Tasted weird. My friend told me to get it how it's done originally, so I decided to go back a 2nd time.

Second time I ordered a latte (instead of retrying the New Orleans iced coffee). It was good, but not 5 stars worth.

Third time I got the New Orleans iced coffee (with whole milk). It was good, but again, not spectacular.

Not sure what the hype is about. Philz beats this place hands down.
author: Ellen C.

description: Good coffee, no question.  But the new shop on Bush Street is just slow.  They charge $.50 more for a cappuccino.  That's OK but the 15 - 20 minute wait in the morning is not worth it.  The cappuccino is better than Peet's but not 15-20 minutes and $.50 better.  I actually left today after waiting 15 minutes and left my cappucino behind.  I went to Bernie's close by and bought another one.   Blue Bottle is good but not that good.  Maybe it appeals to elitist.
author: Ralph B.

description:
Well, the perfect coffee place. Snap and punish attitude but with a nice flair. After all they master one of the best coffee in the city. 

The location is not too bad. If you are lucky with weather you can sip and sit outside.

Sipping and sitting inside is not bad either. Very modern minimalist decor .... but quite stylish... like the fab lady who served me with a perfect hairstyle from the 30s!!!

They have some snacks also to mingle with your coffee which can be a plain espresso or one of those alambiccus made one.

Not cheap.
author: Gianguido G.

description: The latte was one of the best I've had in San Francisco. The service was good the baristas were super nice! This is definitely one of my new favorites. Although it isn't the most spacious there is Such a cute interior and there's some outside seating as well :)
author: Kathlena H.

description:
Yes I am a HUGE Blue Bottle fan. I absolutely love their New Orleans Iced Coffee, I could drink that all day. Most iced coffees loose the strength and flavor of the coffee but that doesn't happen here. Try that out for sure. 

But genuinely blue bottle is one of those places you can't go wrong no matter what you order. I have been to various locations countless times and have never been disappointed. 

Only downer is there is ALWAYS a line. But that's just part of Blue Bottle.
author: Sara P.

description: Excellent place!!! One of the best caffe lattes I've had. It's off the beaten path in a small space but super cute. Friendly staff and wifi. Won't disappoint
author: Laura T.

description:
Okay, so we all love blue bottle coffee, but a dollar extra for almond milk? You've got to be kidding.  Where's the logic here? It takes a lot of water to make almond milk....but in the bigger picture it takes A TON of more water to raise cows. So much in fact that cow farms have been directly linked to water shortage and groundwater depletion by scientists...


When I pointed this out to the counter person he says:

"Well it's not my decision, and it's not yours either".

You're right.  But it is now my decision to go elsewhere for my coffee.

Stupid rule.
author: Bret O.

description: Redefine the meaning of laid-back slowwww service. Maybe it is just too much of the Hipster West Coast lazy attitude. Coffee at least is good but this is not a justification for such laziness.
author: M B.

description: I am addicted (period). Both their cold brews and hot espresso beverages have a strong kick with beans sourced from all over. Yes, it is a bit expensive but if you appreciate coffee as much as I do, it doesn't matter. Great quality coffee starts the day off right in my books.
author: Anthony J.

description: Second time here in 2 days! The Americano is the way it should be string and smooth! You must visit if you're in San Fran!
author: Donna L.

description: This is the best blue bottle location - they provide an outdoor kiosk in the plaza with quick cold brew service. Their new almond milk goes great with their signature New Orleans style iced.
author: Joe M.

description: Be warned - if you're looking for your flavored, syrupy latte, you won't find it here!   Delicious coffee, looked like they had food/pastries as well, wish they had some gluten free options. There's no visible sign outside, but look inside the windows and the long line and packed room will give it away. Stopped here around lunch time on a Monday, it was packed but was able to find a place to sit after a few minutes.
author: Saifra S.

description:
Hard to find, no sign out the front. Not a single blue bottle inside a place called Blue Bottle... My hipster warning alarm was ringing loud and clear, but I ignored it and went in. Had numerous recommendations to come here, had to be good right?? 

MEH. I got a tiiiiiny little Americano. Yes yes size isn't everything, but this was finished in minutes. Ordered a ginger  molasses cookie, super strong taste, left a strange aftertaste. I was just super underwhelmed :/

I give 3 stars to a place that's average but that I know I would return to. Sadly I wouldn't return here :/ Sad not to have got caught up in the hype.
author: Trudi C.

description: This place serves by far the best Aussie style flat white I've had in the USA. Bit of a long wait in line, but that was just a testament to the quality of the coffee. Great ambience and vibe and centrally located.
author: Nick M.

description:
So glad to have my work close to this place. I'm a fan of their coffee and even though I quit drinking it on a regular basis (took me two months of withdrawal and hard work) this coffee definitely satisfies my occasional  craving.

My only comment is the service could be faster. Maybe add another coffee machine? It took me 30 mins to get a cup of joe and the line wasn't even that long.
author: Learnee L.

description: This place is wonderful. A true coffee enthusiasts paradise. Their history of dedication to the taste of coffee is exemplified by the quality of drinks that every gathers here to receive. Having tried their espresso doppio and their latte, I can say without a doubt that this is one of the best cafes in America. They are passionate about coffee, and letting you taste coffee the way it should be, not with pumpkin spice, white mocha, raspberry, eggnog etc. The last time I was there I also picked up a bag of beans to take home to Idaho, which have been delicious to have in a French press in the mornings. If you love coffee, and actually care about coffee at its true flavor, you will love Blue Bottle. I recommend just trying a latte or espresso doppio, and you will see what I mean. Cheers.
author: Patrick S.

description: Love this new spot. Coffee is excellent. Fun location. Lots of happy people. Great staff. Very cool place. Meet people sharing tables. Nice architecture and an enjoyably experience.
author: Eric D.

description: Look for the little blue bottle on the side of the building, it's right by the stop sign on corner of Mint Place and Essie. Not much seating so don't expect to kick back and relax, but the coffee is so worth it. Iced Mocha is $5. Yum!
author: Bianca R.

description:
long line, charming atmosphere, super nice baristas! and holy shit dude go try the coffee from those fancy dripper machines, Kyoto. AMAZEBALLS.

also, one gripe, the creamer+sugar white things on the tables is horribly designed, i went to go pick it up and the top creamer thing nearly fell off because i grabbed it by that...not a good design
author: Ellie B.

description: First time to this location.  There was a super long line for the store, but they must have realized this and created a pop-up location across the street in the Mint plaza to serve more folks.  The pop-up stand only had 2 choices (a blend vs single orgin), and you could only pay with a credit card.  But the coffee was good as usual.
author: Logan C.

description:
I'm so disappointed because I absolutely love their product. The coffee quality is amazing here and they have very good little goodies (my personal favorite is the pretzel knot). So onto why I gave this location the 2 star review....

I commute from Sacramento via Amtrak at least 5 times a week...thanks to a friend's party, I stayed up way too late and decided that I needed a cup of coffee. Since I was dropped off about 35 minutes early into San Francisco, I decided that I would treat myself to a latte. 

I always check to see how long the line is and today (probably because of the holiday), the line was shorter than normal. Typically, I wait in line for about 10 minutes on a busy day....today, it took 15 minutes and the line was half as long as usual. I got to the front of the line, and the girl behind the register said that she would be right with me. I said ok and waited while she refilled this granola bar display that had products that no one was buying (AKA it was pretty full). The cashier, a barista, and another worker then started having a conversation about something (I sure hope it was a work related topic, but didn't seem like it). They finished their conversation and then she came back to the register. 

So I thought it would be my turn, but the barista then told the cashier to ring up this person who had not been standing in line (and at this point I was waiting for over 10 minutes while watching everything taking place). She finally took my order (a latte, a pretzel knot, and some other pastry) with no apology for delay.

So at this point it was about 7:45ish (give or take a few minutes) and I began waiting for my latte...considering that the baristas work in a place full of caffeine, they sure do work at a snail's pace (I swear, my grandmother that has to use a walker is faster than these baristas). At 7:56A, I am still waiting for my latte and ask the baristas if my order is coming up (I had work at 8AM). They said mine was next. At 7:58A, I got my latte...

I do get that quality product takes time...I love their coffee and will happily pay the extra money and wait a few minutes longer for a much better product. However, I feel they need to recognize that their customers do include people that have to get to work and don't necessarily have the luxury of waiting over 30 minutes for a cup of coffee. I don't know if I will go to this location anymore, as there is a small cafe near Macy's that also sells Blue Bottle and are faster in service...if the cafe understands that this, I don't understand why this Blue Bottle Location can't.
author: Lynelle M.

description: Came here around 9 am on a Friday, there was a line that went pretty quick. I was really excited to try this place out however, although the coffee was good and the affogato was great, the food was eh.. I found it pretty overpriced for what they served, my toast had two poached eggs on top that were hard boiled, I saw other ppl with the same order except the yolk was runny and looked awesome.. Mine and my bfs came out really dry.. Maybe you have to ask specifically for eggs to not be hard boiled?? Not only that but they only gave my bf one egg and forgot the bacon.. Not sure how the miscommunication happened but that wasn't what we ordered and it was too chaotic and crowded to try and get the order fixed.. We didn't bother and ate and left quickly.. Would like to come back again but only for coffee and not food.
author: Kacey D.

description:
Hidden in the corner alley is this little gem of a coffee shop. Friendly staff, fresh coffee, yummy pastries. 

there's no real downside other than there's just always a line. but that just shows how awesome they are! 

Andrew made my mocha this morning and holy crap it was heaven in a cup. SO smooth, so buttery, I think he may have sprinkled some fairy dust in it. Definitely coming back for more! ;)
author: Judy P.

description:
Blue bottle...  Where the coffee comes first..  Trying to hard to look cool making coffee comes second and customer service comes third. 

It's ok,  doesn't matter if there's a long line..  You deserve to walk away after every transaction and go take a nice long sip of water while you bask in your glory and look out towards all the people sipping your art. 

Then come ring me up when I'm nice and ready,  entry the two bags off coffee I'm purchasing,  ask me if that's it (no eye contact required),  swipe my card and walk away..  I'll finish the transaction by myself.  That funny story that popped into your slow drip mind just half a second ago needs to be told to your coworker. 

Thank you..  Enjoy. Your coffee!
author: S F.

description: I love that this location serves breakfast items and there's enough seating for most people. Their tomato baked eggs is off the charts delicious and super filling. Of course, the coffee here is perfection as always.
author: Lynn C.

description: Coffee is so good I think I got some weird named iced coffee last time. It took me forever to finish a small one and ... tbh I didn't finish it. Coffee here is so great. Strong blends and they make each cup for you. I am not an avid coffee drinker so ... maybe you shouldn't take my word for it. I love it though :) Their iced coffee (New Orleans Iced coffee? i'm not sure what its called) that comes in a carton is good too. You can buy them at your local Whole foods which is nice. :) THey're pretty hipster and a little hidden. You can find them easily around lunch since they tend to have food trucks outside their store. People can also buy their coffee from a little kiosk they have outside by the food trucks. People buy coffee and lunch and sit outside to enjoy the weather.
author: Michelle Y.

description: The breakfast sandwich was yummy! The waffles were perfect and not too sweet with the syrup ( they syrup it for you ). The wait in the long line freezing your ass is totally worth the food and the coffee! Do not miss it if you are in the area! Along with the golden gate, this is a must do in SFO
author: Abhi B.

description: Great coffee! A little crowded at times but overall I think this place makes great cappuccinos and everything else.
author: Conchita L.

description: I didn't get to try their food but the coffee was solid. Great atmosphere and great coffee but very crowded
author: Cc H.

description:
Although it's very crowded, this is my favorite Blue Bottle location. You can find parking in the alley or nearby streets. Keep circling and believe!

I can't get over their egg salad with shallots on toast. So simple but great! We also got salad, but their vinaigrette is a bit too sour, so I'm glad I had the toast to balance it out.

Their New Orleans iced coffee was delicious, as expected. I'm sad I couldn't try their affogato! Next time.
author: Karen L.

description: The Blue Bottle Coffee in the Mint Building was a little surprise a few blocks away from the hotel that I stayed in. The coffee shop offered a unique kind if coffee in their menu called "Affogato." It's vanilla ice cream with espresso poured over it and it's probably the best unique coffee I have ever tried. I did not have to put any extra milk or sugar in it since the ice cream has enough of that already. I came to this coffee shop with a group of friends and everyone in the group including myself all thought that it was great. I would definitely want to go back to try another Affogato. However, the place seems small and it was difficult to fit an entire group of people in the coffee shop not including other customers who come by the coffee shop.
author: Junisa V.

description:
I'm so glad my friend told me that there was a new Blue Bottle location at the Mint Plaza - close to the UN plaza/Market St area. It's kinda secluded and it's  a nice alternative to the Blue Bottle locations at the Ferry Building (where there's usually a long line, crowded, and not too many seats).

This location actually has a small food menu. They serve sandwiches and soups for about $8-10.

Service:
-Everyone was friendly.

Food:
-Soup and sandwich combo - Grilled cheese and roasted tomato soup. The grilled cheese had Beemster, Ham, Piquillio Pepper & Grain Mustard on Acme bread. The bread was nicely toasted. I liked the flavor. The roasted tomato soup had Roma Tomatoes, Shallots, and Basil Olive Oil. It was ok. It tasted pretty good when you dip the bread in the soup.

Drink:
-Latte: I love their latte! Nice strong espresso with pretty latte art.

Seating:
-They have a decent amount of chairs/stools so you can sit and enjoy your coffee and/or meal.
author: Lily Y.

description:
Get the New Orleans Iced Coffee. It's cold-brewed, the perfect amount of sweetness, and so, SO smooth! Best coffee I've ever had, and I do love my coffee.

The Mint Plaza location is absolutely lovely, both inside and outside the shop. It gets crowded at times, but the coffee is worth the wait (and the money). I'm looking forward to coming here again and trying their full food menu :) Definitely my favorite cafe in SF!
author: Leanne C.

description:
Not like my being from Seattle will make you believe this review over anyone else, nor am I trying to wave some special card here, but I like to think I am blessed with living around good coffee that's accessible and (gasp!) not Starbucks. 

So due to this, you can imagine my excitement when trying Blue Bottle. I didn't know what to expect. Having tried coffee locales from Kona to Costa Rica, from 7-11 to Dunkin Donuts, I definitely know BAD coffee, but other than screaming OH FECK YES in my head when I take the first sip, I can't really describe why good coffee is amazing more succinctly than that. But I'll try.

I tried the New Orleans style iced coffee. I screamed FECK YES in my head and resisted chugging it so I wouldn't hear colors. Chicory. Richness, earthy, nutty, cold and creamy. Get it with whole milk, weirdo. This isn't the time to diet. 

I still 5 star you despite the line and lack of a place to sit. Cause you're that good, Blue  Bottle. Bring home beans to impress your Starbucker friends.
author: A.J. S.

description:
Awesome staff - nice simple interior.

Really delicious breakfast sandwich - arugula was bright and peppery, had a nice dressing - bacon was perfectly chewy, and the toasted brioche bun was mmmmmmmmmmm.

Espresso was quite good. Very consistent with the Blue Bottles in LA.

Siphoned coffee was a tad slow, but full, nutty, and bright flavors kept me sipping.
author: Jason A.

description:
Iced New Orleans coffee is where it's at.   
Great staff, though a bit slow.
author: Morgan C.

description:
Great cafe au lait but I could have bought one just as good at other places.  The breakfast sandwich was underwhelming the unexpected over $18 price tag for the bill just not worth it.  Disappointing visit.
I'll go back to getting their regular coffee and skip the food.
author: Suzanne S.

description:
I was in town for a wedding and left to my own devices while my other half was busy with bridesmaid affairs. I meandered upon this small BB outpost and had the most amazing solo breakfast experience.

Their coffee is always good, as various tourist lines will attest, but when I put the first bite of their poached egg on toast in my mouth I knew I was about to have a full body experience.

I took a photo. I posted it. I was that person. And yes, dear beautiful poached egg, I still think of you.
author: Jean P.

description: New Orleans Iced Coffee is the way to go. The Mint Plaza location is always packed, and for good reason. My mom and I came here when the line went out the door, and the seating was super limited. But it was worth. My mom's a lot more of a coffee connoisseur than I am, so when she says she approves of something (which she rarely does), that means it's hella good. Which it is.
author: Katherine Z.

description:
Great place! I was in town for a conference and was excited to try new places - but I ended up coming here multiple times. I highly recommend their ham tartine and the iced New Orleans coffee -- fantastic. 

The downside? The wait. Every time I visited there was a significant line.
author: Joe L.

description:
just got the betablend and i am sorry, can't recall the s.o. blend i just tried. neither of them is nearly as good as the 3 africans blend. Betablend is just plain bad. I am drinking right now, some peruvian blend that i bought at aldi's for like $4-5 for 12 oz and it is better than the beta blend by far.

So to sum up, when 3 africans is available (it usually is) and you can get free shipping, jump on it, skip the beta blend, 1 star; the single origin...can't recall it but it was not as good africans. so, maybe 3 stars, 3 africans, 5 stars. 

if you are in the raleigh nc area there are a couple roasters that are almost as good. I'll post reviews for them separately.

3 africans = 5 stars.
author: Gregg G.

description: Whenever I am in San Fran, I make it a point to visit here. The breakfasts are amazing and the coffees are just as good. Try the waffles, the eggs benedict or any other concoction that they have on the menu for that day - everything is so good and it will leave you wanting to come back.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Blue Bottle is an SF staple. One of the places I take all of my out of town visiting family.  They do beautiful latte art, solidly good coffee and that deadly combination of cream and sugar in the NOLA ice coffee.  It is hard to go wrong with the pastries. My personal favorite is the ginger molasses cookie.  

I hear rumors that there are webcams you can check to know what the line looks like at the mint plaza locale to see how long the line is, though I haven't verified this.  Also they sometimes have a coffee cart across the street doing a limited menu.
author: Maureen B.

description:
Excellent cappuccino. Lovely flavour and the perfect temperature. Could compete with some South African places: reminds me of SteamPunk in KZN.
Pricey tho!
author: Jonathan S.

description:
I doubt I'll ever stop being a fan of Blue Bottle.

There are plenty enough good reviews.

I can tell you about the space. We would have loved to enjoy our coffee inside - to see the action, but it was really hot, so we opted to sit outside. Picked a spot just a few steps away - it was as pleasant as one can get in downtown.
author: Kali F.

description: I love the place, I was first here in 2011, and it was amazing then! My cappuccino this time   was perfection, and the very little wait even with the long line. The service was fast and friendly. I love this place!  I had the seeded bar as well and it was delightful.
author: Victoria N.

description:
I came specifically to try the Kyoto-style iced coffee since I haven't seen a drip system like this in the states, ever. 

As I waited, I felt a intimidated... afraid I would use the wrong coffee lingo. I survived and got a cup of the Kyoto and asked for some milk. The staff didn't recommend it and suggested I drink it plain.

Hey, I figured they must know their stuff so I wimped out and downed it. It was insanely strong, but smooth and full bodied. (FYI they were right. I ran back to my hotel and secretly added milk. It was awful.)

So did I enjoy it? I guess so. I also got heartburn and had a caffeine high for 4 days. I probably wouldn't go back, there are plenty of other great coffee shops in town.
author: Tina C.

description:
Their coffee is so SMOOOOOTH. 

I yelped this place and I noticed how popular it was in SF, so naturally I just had to try it. They have a few locations and I decided on the mint street locations because I was closest to it. It was a little difficult finding the place, it's kind of located in alley and you wouldn't think there's going to be a trendy coffee shop but there is with outside seating too! Parking is hard because you have to find it on the street.

The place is cute! I like how it's open. There's usually a line but it goes by rather quickly. The service was great, and everyone was friendly :) The baristas give great suggestions if you need it!

WHAT TO GET:

1. New Orleans Iced Coffee: On a hot day, iced coffee is just the way to go! Their iced coffee was spectacular! It was so smooth and silky. I am in love with how it taste and feels in my mouth. I usually need it a little bit sweeter because I like things sweet. But the quality of this coffee is insane, worth the price. 

2. Mocha Latte: Love this drink! It had a nice chocolaty taste to it but it wasn't overpowering, you could still taste the coffee. It was nice and smooth. This is definitely a drink to get when you want something nice and hot. Perfect for those cold winter days!

If you love coffee, you MUST try this place out when you're in the city.
author: Jennifer H.

description: I like this place most for its location. Its always been a great place for me to camp out and grab coffee with family during the holidays after shopping. The space is bright and the lines are never too long. I'd go here again.
author: Katherine D.

description: Came to visit from Las Vegas, I can't wait till the next time I'm San Fran to visit this spot everyday I'm there. Cappuccino please! I can't explain the perfection of this coffee you just have to try for yourself
author: Lili G.

description: Professionally executed coffee. Hands down. These guys are serious. Amazing coffee source with excellent baristas. This ain't Starbucks folks. This is how coffee should be done. Italian baristas would be proud.
author: Dominic B.

description: It pains me to poorly review my beloved Blue Bottle. This place is awesome, the workers are amazing and friendly. This review is really for the company, I don't understand why they don't have an air conditioning system. SF summer is in full effect and the mint plaza blue bottle gets super hot, like walking into an oven. I am really concerned about the employees who wear mostly, if not all, black attire and have to bust out shots of espresso and beautiful latte art back to back in front of a hot espresso bar. I should not be sweating as I wait for my affogato, that's absurd.
author: Onyinyechi I.

description:
After trying to find this place and not finding it a couple of times, it turned out really easy to find the third time around as we saw the long line outside!
Went there for brunch on saturday with a friend. about 15mins wait in the line and we found a spot inside. good food and nice ambience and you can watch all the different ways you can make drip coffee ! fascinating. A nice spot for brunch.
author: Hemant B.

description:
If you had a weekend packed with alcohol, bar hopping, deafening club music, and  occasional after 4am events of  'Where the HELL Am I !?!?'  I believe a shot of espresso or a traditional macchiato the following morning will assist you in becoming functional human being once again.

Without question, if you are coffee snob or a person who just enjoys quality coffee 'Blue Bottle' is the way to go.  To be clear, there are many Blue Bottle Coffee Cafes in SF and if i had to choose one blue coffee cafe, i would probably go to the one in the Hayes valley area (9315 Linden St.San Francisco, CA 94102). This place can be crowded and jam packed, but their coffee is super consistent and the baristas are top notch.  If i worked around this area i would definitely make this my default hang out spot.

NOTE: If you want blue bottle coffee and want to have it a nice quiet area go to the linden one, and if you wanna meet up with friends go to this one because it does have food options and a little more seating.
author: Erwin B.

description: Self-proclaimed Seattle coffee snob.  Blue Bottle is a must visit when I travel to San Francisco.  The coffee is amazing, service is great and the cafe has an insanely cool vibe (maybe even too cool for me).  Breakfast menu is fantastic too.  Can't say enough good things.  Love this place - move on up to Seattle, Blue Bottle!
author: Mike G.

description: Great all around. The menu just needs a few more items for variety sake, but overall had a good experience.
author: Brian C.

description:
So I live in Seattle and have gone to many good coffee shops and Blue Bottle in SF was suggested by a friend familiar with the coffee industry. 

I had a slight difficulty in finding this place but was loving the vibe once I stepped inside. Very bright from the natural light from outside and like the simple decor. Seating seemed a bit cramped but it wasn't packed when I went so it wasn't an issue.

I ordered their latte using their 17 Ft. Ceiling blend and was blown away! Very smooth flavor, no bitterness to it at all. The baristas there were nice as well. I have now found my go-to coffee joint for whenever I visit SF. Two thumbs up!
author: Veronica G.

description:
It was a little hard to find this place.

New Orleans Iced Coffee: At first it tasted really light but after a while the coffee and the sweetness started to intensify for me.  
Afforgato: This was the first time I've ever had this, and it was amazing...A scoop of vanilla ice cream with 2 shots of espresso.  That really woke my ass up and it was delicious.

The store was very comfortable with a decent amount of seating. Seems like a good place to get some work done.

I would totally recommend this coffee house.  It was quick, fresh, and delicious.
author: Jackie N.

description:
Ordered the New Orleans Iced Coffee

Pros: Nice decor and displays of coffee technology. Since I was sitting by where all the plates that were ready to be served, I definitely had some good food candy. Convenient to Powell/Union Square. Cool to-go coffee cup designs.

Cons: Majorly disappointed. Didn't even finish my coffee. It was on the bitter side. Reminded me slightly of Vietnamese coffee but then it didn't have that strong coffee bean taste. The workers didn't seem happy to be there. Didn't leave me with a sense of joy.

Verdict: Philz Coffee over Blue Bottle Coffee Co anyday.
author: Kathy W.

description: Great for breakfast!! Coffee is gooooodddd! Avocado sandwich and breakfast sandwich was jammie! I don't know whether that is inherent to every place in sf, or just to the places which serve good food, but there is a continuous line of people for ordering! Although service was relatively fast!
author: Nienke A.

description:
Best almond milk available anywhere... and a kickass avocado toast to boot. 
This very understated joint is more about substance than fanfare. 
A must try!!!
author: Giovanni G.

description: I'm not a coffee aficionado by any means. But this was a pretty interesting place. Line was out the door. My coffee was one of the best I've ever had. Will go back for a Siphon later. Looks pretty interesting. I highly recommend the experience. The pretty woman at the counter was very nice and calm.
author: Joan E.

description:
:(

HOW MANY YEARS HAVE PASSED?! WHERE IS MY ESPRESSO CON PANNA? Apparently, they don't offer espresso con panna at this location anymore. *gloom*


There is literally not another coffee shop in the city that served this. Not with THAT quality of salted whipped cream at least. 


The guy that took my ordered tried to offer me affogato. Like its the same thing. *glooooooooom*


Come back.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Getting Blue Bottle definitely made my day, and will probably be one of my must-go spots whenever I spend the day at San Francisco.

As many other Yelp reviews say, Blue Bottle is kind of hidden across the Westfield Valley Fair. Normally I'd complain or make some kind of remark about how clearer directions (ie a sign that says "BLUE BOTTLE THIS WAY") would significantly improve its business, but that is definitely NOT the case for Blue Bottle.
