Since I was already shopping at Westfield, it didn't take me too long to find Blue Bottle with my handy smartphone and maps app, but it was still confusing and quite the adventure!

The employees were super nice and friendly - you can tell they really love Blue Bottle and have fun working there. They recommended I try the New Orleans since I wanted an iced drink, and lo and behold, it was delicious and definitely quality coffee (vs. chain coffees that are all sugar and milk). I ended up staying at the cafe for about an hour and a half, just enjoying the drink and my time with my friend, until the cafe closed.

I know that my review has little to do with the coffee (which was amazing anyways), but the point is that I had an overall great experience :) Definitely a place for coffee lovers.
author: Frances W.

description:
We walked to BBCC to get Adam some good coffee. It was Saturday this past weekend and the weather was so different from Fridays. It was cold and windy.

It was a long line to get in to this very unassuming place with very simple utilitarian decor. There was a bunch of people there attending the comic con with their lan yards around their neck.

When our turn came we were greeted warmly, order processed and whoa  it's true their coffee is strong like bull and tasty! 

I was staring at their sandwich menu and made a mental note to try them next time. Adam said that the coffee drip is somewhat pricey but agree that it was excellent!

Bookmark list minus one...more to come!
author: Janet D.

description: Got to come here once during a trade show. Good coffee. Loved the Waffle, crispy outside custardy inside.
author: Thaddeus L.

description:
Stumbled upon this blue bottle coffee while wandering around the city

I had a mission. Which was too bring back 4 bags off coffee for 'Toonces drinks coffee a lot'. Money in hand I asked for the medium to strong roast. The girl at the counter recommended a good flavor or two and then I added one. The 8oz bags range from 8-9 bucks each

My BF had the iced new orleans coffee. He enjoyed it a lot

Long line but went by fairly quickly

I don't drink coffee but the beans sure do smell good
author: Rachael C.

description:
I was not a fan of this Blue Bottle Coffee's location -- it was a little bit difficult to find, and the area seemed kind of dodgy. That said, I came pretty close to closing time, so it might be better earlier in the day.

I ordered the affogato, which was two scoops of ice cream with an espresso shot. It was much more like dessert than coffee, but I did really like it. Next time I'll go back and order a real coffee! :)
author: Kelly R.

description:
Do they need another outstanding review? YES! 

Coffee here is so good and simple. My boyfriend got the drip coffee (which are individually made everytime), and I've tried the cappuccino (my favorite) and the New Orleans style Iced Coffee (which is not for me. It's the sour kind of coffee. I'm not sure what the technical term for that is). I've also ordered their lemon pound cake, which was delicious. Moist with just the right hint of lemon. 

The line is always out the door, but the overall wait is not too long. They also have really clean bathrooms.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I never got this place until recently.  It seemed to be cool because everyone said it was cool.  I tried a variety of the items and they were good, but not mind blowing.  I mean, I could have been as easily pleased with a cup of joe from McDonalds.

And that was the problem.  I started drinking coffee when I was volunteering at a retirement home (and you know they make that stuff so inhumanely weak for the poor old people), so I clearly didn't know good coffee. And I didn't care. If you don't care about good coffee, you won't care about this coffee.

But then I got a bit older and mother nature's gift to me for my birthday was a slower metabolism. This made me start removing sugar from my coffee. Then I removed milk.  Then I started to really appreciate the flavor of coffee, the balance, the acidity, the bitterness, the body, etc.  Then I got it.  

This is effing delicious and high quality coffee.  10/10.  I buy the beans and grind it at home.  I just can't get enough.

Also, should I splurge, the mocha is unbelievable.
author: Christine E.

description:
Hipster Coffee...SAY WHAT?

DRINK IT BLACK. Yes. Actually. It's smooth, flavorful, aromatic, without a hint of bitterness. You know how shops are adding tasting notes? When the roast is done correctly, the black coffee exudes all those wonderful undertones of caramel, toffee, chocolate, and earth.

Although Blue Bottle can get crowded and the coffee is pricey, it's worth it. Every penny. Every drop. The baristas are friendly, and even if it's your first time around the hipster coffee block, they'll guide you through a bean selection and method you'll love. Plus, the vacuum coffee is just plain fun to watch and drink.
author: Kaylin B.

description:
Hey ya'll ... coffee noob here.

Why would I call myself out on this?  Because after I had Blue Bottle's mocha, I was jittery with a slight headache and in a weird daze afterwards.  I'm so used to inferior coffee with lots of cream and packets of equal sugar... don't think my system was expecting anything like this.  

I don't doubt that my coffee-junkie bee-eff and any coffee junkie at that would like this place.  Tried their coffee cake, which was tasty but nothing to write home about. 

Okay, so mini story:

Decided to get an extra order for a girlfriend.  Roommate and I made our way to the mini side table where the cream and sugar were chillin.  As my roomie poured the cream (just a little!), the entire lid burst open (spout-like) and a little cream turned into a cup and counter full of it.  Luckily, the baristas felt sorry for us and gave us a fresh brew.  

Delightful morning.
author: Kat C.

description:
Amazing. Prepare yourself for a line, but the people watching and chemistry happenings behind the counter will keep you entertained. If you get the eggs and toast, be aware that it will come with two eggs and two thick slices of bread. My aunt and I both got an order, but we could've easily split. Our cappuccino was amazing and the food was good too. 

You can't go wrong here.
author: Joy W.

description: I walked in and there was no wait. I placed my order, hoping they could make it before my Uber arrived from Nob Hill. No joke: it took over 15 minutes for them to make one piece of avocado toast and a cappuccino. After my Uber arrived, I went outside to let them know it would be just another minute. Once I came back in, I saw a coffee on the bar. I asked the barista "is this for number 9?" She retorted "no it is not". I really don't need the attitude on top of the lackadaisical and lethargic work ethic. It was amazing that this place had no line, at least 6 people behind the coffee bar, and couldn't work with any sense of urgency or basic customer service skills.
author: Christopher M.

description:
I love blue bottle coffee!  They serve it at my favorite coffee shops in LA.  I hadn't thought it visiting while we were in SF until I was yelping for some coffee and lo and behold there was a blue bottle right by us!

We came once around 11 am on a Sunday and once around 12 on a Monday.  On Sunday there was a line of probably 12 people by the time we got there, but the line moved pretty quickly.  The bummer was that the breakfast sandwiches we had wanted to order were sold out by the time we got to the front of the line, but we got other items instead.  

The standout from my visit was the New Orleans iced coffee.  It had a great smooth flavor and was slightly sweetened so it felt like a treat rather than just regular coffee.  You can order it with almond milk, which depending on what day you go can cost either $1-2 extra.  That's right, weirdly all the food and add ons like almond milk cost EXTRA on weekends... Kind of annoying, but I enjoyed my drink enough not to care too much.  Their iced coffee had such a nice smooth taste to it that I didn't even notice t wasn't espresso.  Normally I don't drink regular coffee because the acidity makes my stomach hurt, but blue bottle didn't do that to me.

If you only want a drink, they have a kiosk in the middle of the plaza that shouldn't have a line most of the time.
author: Ruby Y.

description:
I'm giving their coffee 5 stars, because it was definitely the best latte I've had. 

The people working were friendly and really seemed to love coffee, too. 

The line out the door moves quickly, but there is limited seating, which was a tad annoying when you want to enjoy a cup of coffee and chat with a friend. 

Overall, I was happy with my experience and will be back.

Definitely a lot of hipsters in there!
author: Kelli H.

description:
I came for the coffee but ended up getting the steel-cut oats as well and it turned out to be the best part. Boy let me tell you the oats is de-li-ci-ous! Warm and comforting. I got both the jam and brown sugar as toppings and they are absolutely fantastic. Definitely recommend. 

The coffee is decent. I normally like my bean robustly aromatic, but here it's not as much as I would like. Anyway it was nice, but for me it was overroasted. (Not saying it  was bad, other people may be okay with it tho) My company got a mocha and she said it was more watery than she would like.

Staff was friendly and really helpful. I would return next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Mai K.

description: If you are looking for true coffee prepared to world standards.  Very enjoyable espresso,  the atmosphere is classic new style cafe relaxed with hipster baristas.  Food mainly finger. Coffee score espresso 6/6
author: Rob F.

description: Ok, I see what all the talk is about. The coffee is smooth (I ordered a cafe latte) and the egg brioche sandwich, which for the life of me can't find the name on the website but will place a picture, was so delicious. I fell in love with the meal and the experience as one of the barista was making coffee which seemed like a chemistry experiment. However, I loved it so much I had to ask if there was one in Los Angeles. To my delight there are 2 locations, thank goodness. But either way this will be my coffee go to whenever I'm in San Fransisco again.
author: Neaicia K.

description: Love Blue Bottle, I try to go as much as I can during my work week. Really helps get me through the 3pm push to 5!
author: Bianca M.

description:
When I went to San Francisco, one thing that was on the top of my "San Francisco To-Do List" was to try the coffee at Blue Bottle Coffee Co. I have heard that it has great coffee and it has over 1,000 Yelp reviews. I am a huge fan of coffee, so my San Francisco trip would not be complete without a visit here.

There are two locations in San Francisco. We originally went to the one in Hayes Valley and the line was out the door. We were in a rush to get somewhere else, so we decided to try it at a later time. Later that day, we went to the one near Union Square. It was a little hard to find since it is located in an alley and has no signs. Similar to the shop in Hayes Valley, the line was out the door. As we waited in line, we were ale to look around the shop and get a good feel of it. All the seats were filled since it was Saturday. When we finally made it up to the front, I ordered the drip coffee, one of my friends ordered an iced coffee, and my other friend ordered the hot chocolate. The staff was not very friendly. They seemed stern and only focused on getting your order taken care of so that they could move on to the next customer. I didn't get the best vibe from this place and I did not feel welcome at all. My coffee was good, but it wasn't exceptional like it was hyped up to be. 

I am glad I tried the coffee here, but I have to disagree with all the people that claim this place has the best coffee in San Francisco. Yes, the coffee is much better than what is offered at chain coffee shops, but it is far from the best.
author: Roxanne F.

description: The affogato was amazing! If you like espresso and ice cream, the affogato is the perfect combo; it is brown butter ice cream with espresso poured over it. They use the ice cream from the ice cream shop across the way, Humphrey Slocombe (which was also equally amazing)! My husband got the Ethiopian drip coffee and was a great pick-me-up too!
author: Nikita P.

description:
[this note applies to the operation generally, not to this particular location]

BB is overpriced.
BB is overly pretentious
BB coffee isn't any better than most coffee in town
author: S K.

description: I know that in California Blue Bottle is pretty common and kind of trendy but to me I was just happy to find a damn good latte! And, they use science to brew their pressed coffee! Or at least I think that's what he's doing. Well done good people!
author: Ida S.

description:
Unbelievably horribly managed. There's a little mean manager lady that manages yhis place who needs to be retrained. Any time there's even the smallest problem she bolts out like a boxer from his corner, once the fight bell rings.

The products are great although grossly overpriced, and the pitbull manager lady, needs a sedative....

Overall, this place SUCKS!
author: Senario J.

description:
I love a great rivalry!

Here is a short list of my favorites:

Cal vs. Stanford
Bacon vs. Sausage
Seinfeld vs. Newman
David Chang vs. Figs

When I hear about a Blue Bottle and Ritual rivalry, though, I just scoff. Where there is no competition, there is no rivalry. That is absolute. Like without respiration, there is no life. 

Ritual is to Blue Bottle as the Texas Rangers are to the Giants. Not in the same league (literally!).

The Japanese five-light siphon bar? The Tim Lincecum of machines.

A gibraltar later? You'll be hitting home-runs out of the cafe!
author: Joanna M.

description: Ehhh...the portions could of been better. Each of my friends and myself ordered something different and we were all disappointed, especially for the price.
author: Michael M.

description: Truly the best soy mocha I've ever had.  I've been a die hard Starbucks fan until now.. Smoother and tastier coffee served in a fine ceramic cup rather than a paper cup for dining in.  The line is long but it moves fast.  Great food as well.  Try the avocado toast.  Excellent seasonings and a hint of lemon.  My husband enjoyed his cappuccino and breakfast sandwich too.  Interesting siphoned coffee apparatus and tiny yet efficient kitchen is fun to watch.  Neighborhood isn't the best but the coffee is worth the adventure.
author: L P.

description:
Best coffee. Really neat and friendly staff. Their siphon coffees are really interesting. They're smooth and still maintain the rich earthy tastes of their origin blends. 

If you do get a siphon coffee, remember that they are only "for here". That said, I'm glad I stayed. This location has a great din in experience. It's surrounded by windows, so you get some good sunlight, despite it IS located in an alley way. (But that's ok) 

They have breakfast and brunch food options as well. So settle in and enjoy the company. 

(Most people you ask say that it's worth the wait in line) 

Cheers.
author: Mike G.

description:
The iced coffee was among the best I've ever had - and I drink a TON of coffee! I had the New Orleans iced coffee. It was incredibly smooth and already sweetened, so I did not need any sugar or cream, it was perfect with just milk. 

We also loved their homemade raspberry jam, which was delicious with the thick-cut and fluffy bread slices. Butternut Squash soup was pretty good, with sweet and crunchy pomegranate seeds on top. 

It was consistently busy, but definitely, absolutely and surely worth the wait.
author: Ashley S.

description:
Yelp tells me I didn't review Blue Bottle. I don't even understand how that can be true. Coming here was a life changing event.

I left the city three years ago to an area of the world where sadly it is impossible to get a decent cappuccino.  I returned to the Bay Area looking forward to simply getting back to Peet's for their traditional cap.  That is until a friend turned me onto the phenomenon that is Blue Bottle.

I came every day.  Sometimes twice a day during my visit to get espresso drinks that blew my mind.  Blew. My. Mind.

If you make espresso this good, and texture milk so precisely, you could kick me in the shin every time I walked into the cafe and it wouldn't stop me from going.  Long slow lines, service that isn't particularly courteous (although I've never found it rude), and a cramped space are a small price to pay for a taste of what espresso can be.

And if you haven't tried it yet, you must order the Gibraltar.
author: Daniel B.

description: Coffee is good/great.  The attitude of the staff can be a little trying if the place is busy and the people are just too cool to get the drinks made.
author: David J.

description:
This was some of the best Hot Cocoa I have had -- it was perfectly foamy and had a little design at the top! It was absolutely delicious and tasted pure. Be warned though, as this is not a place to get a sweet drink.. The price was not too bad, it was maybe a little higher than Starbucks! Four dollars for a cup of cocoa heaven? Yes please! 

The staff was very friendly and kind to me. They are also very quick and efficient.. 

Blue Bottle Cafe is a hidden gem in a bright alley of San Francisco!
author: Rachelle V.

description:
Come here for the siphon coffee!  You do have to wait quite a while, but it is well worth it.  I have had their regular coffee before which is fantastic, but after trying their siphon coffee, I really can't wait to come back!  When I got the coffee, the waiter suggested first trying it black, I was a bit skeptic, but it has a smooth flavor that leaves no bite whatsoever.  The coffee also had a complexity that really changed and improved after each sip.  It really felt comparable to wine tasting in some ways.  

Their breakfast is also amazing here as well.  I had their poached eggs with a tomato based sauce on some toasted french bread, something seemingly simple, but the whole thing put together was just full of flavor.

They also have your usual coffee here as well, you really can't go wrong.  Just be prepared to wait in line as there always is one.  It is well worth the wait though!
author: Bryson L.

description: I freaking love this place. Yes, it's a little pricey and the lines can be absurdly long, but it's so worth it. I stopped in for breakfast recently and treated myself to a latte (not my usual coffee shop order, but honestly, one of the best I've had) and a chia pudding--which was SO. GOOD. The marmalade and dukkah topping was so amazing I've been trying to figure out how to recreate it at home. These people know their coffee (and their breakfast foods, apparently!); I can't wait to come back and try more.
author: Carrie R.

description:
Absolutely amazing coffee, great staff and lovely atmosphere! Prices were slightly high, but the quality of coffee was amazing. So much better than your typical Starbucks on every corner! Would definitely come back again.

The place is slightly hard to find.
author: Heather T.

description: Very hip coffee and tea spot in the city. Great coffee, but more importantly great location.
author: Chris W.

description:
Coffee was very good, service was friendly, but the location is questionable. It can be a little tricky to find, with nary a sign along the main road. Not to mention the plethora of homeless folks milling about nearby, but that's San Fran for you. 

Once you find it, the interior is a little tight, and not particularly conducive to the coffee shop workaholics. But location aside, the real star is the coffee. Whether you like a standard drip or espresso, or go for the fancy (and pretentious) siphoned coffee, this place has what you need, all for a good price.
author: Ho L.

description: i had to try this place because so much buzz about how great the coffee is.  I do have to say it is good coffee and the atmosphere is extremely trendy.  But is it worth all the hype...still undetermined.
author: Susan M.

description: Great coffee, super cute vibe, always busy and filled with tourists or hipsters (which means it's a great place to people watch) . Blue bottle is a total fad, which is not a bad thing. It just means it's cute, delicious, and overpriced !
author: Chelsea S.

description: Good but touristy and overpriced (by Seattle standards). If you get a chance and are really into coffee, check out Sightglass instead!
author: Pat ..

description: WORTH the walk from Financial District, SOMA, Union Square.  Great coffees, nice snacks, great employees.  Definitely gets crowded, usually a line out the door, so don't come in a hurry and sometimes it's hard to get a seat if you aren't looking to have a quick espresso shot standing and head back out.
author: Mike W.

description:
New Orleans: Mmmm yum! (Rating: 4.5/5)
Afoggato: Two scoops of brown sugar Humphrey Slocombe ice cream with double shot of Blue Bottle espresso! (Rating: 5/5)
author: Jenny W.

description: This place can be tricky to find. At first i didn't realize they had a shop and assumed it was just a coffee cart outside. I only had a pour over and it is probably the best pour over i ever had. My friend who is not even a fan of coffee loved it. It was not to light, burnt, sour, but a perfectly balanced cup of coffee.
author: Jason C.

description: Gotta give credit where credit is due. They put a coffee only bar outside this location where the line moves fast. Great coffee. Thanks for caring about your customers.
author: Josh F.

description: Absolutely love their coffee and their breakfast. They have a very good poached egg and toast in the mornings that I would recommend. I come here every time I visit San Francisco and regularly have their coffee shipped to my home in Texas!
author: Babak Bobby Y.

description: My cousin always stops in when he's in town from Australia. He raved about their coffee. To be honest it was my first time really trying coffee and was recommended the New Orleans Iced Coffee. Have to say it was exceptional!
author: Dianna N.

description: This was a really good breakfast place. I recommend the eggs with cilantro sauce. Very good cappuccino too.
author: Meghan N.

description:
Pretentious. I work in the area and decided to come here during my lunch break.

My lunch break is 30 minutes and the line itself was almost 20 mintues.

I ordered the New Orleans Iced Cofee. It literally tasted like Starbucks iced coffee.

With the ridiculous line, pretentious atmosphere and clientele and the novice drinks, I'm never going back.
author: Leslie M.

description:
This location in particular is one of my favorite coffee shops that i MUST go to for coffee and breakfast when I'm in SF. It's tucked away and you have to go through an alley to get to it, but it's definitely a "hidden" gem. 

The line can be long, so prepare to wait in one. the seating is minimal and communal, so best not to come in a super big group. The food is amazing and pretty much, farm to table. The menu varies on what's in season, which is awesome! I usually get their poached eggs on toast, yum! 

But let's talk about their coffee... I love blue bottle. I have ventured many craft coffee shops in SF, but blue bottle is my absolute fave. Maybe there is some nostalgia effect to it, but I always get sad if I don't at least visit it once and grab an affogato. Their coffee is so good, my fave roast is probably the three Africans. I always end up buying a bag when I go. However, they just opened one in LA, so I probably won't need to go to SF to buy my coffee! 

If you have never had an affogato... Blue bottle is the place to get it. The combination of their espresso with fresh made Humphrey Slocomb ice cream is AMAZING. And if you go to the Pier 1 location, you can have that affogato with their amazing waffle. It makes for such a great snack/dessert.
author: Claudette B.

description:
There aren't too many places I know of that still offer siphoned coffee.  Come in before 3pm and they will kindly brew some up for you.

Blue Bottle does offer a few variety of beans.  I believe it depends on the day or week, but I tend to see a lot of African beans.  All their coffee is freshy brewed regardless except for the iced coffee, but in my opinion the best method and flavor comes from the siphon method.  If you don't cope with coffee well or get the jitters you might want to stick to the drip or iced coffee.  The siphon really extracts the caffeine out of the coffee and the rush is pretty amazing compared to your basic drip style coffee.

Mmmmmm caffeine =)
author: Jun Y.

description:
Maybe this is silly, but I really look forward to foam art on my lattes. That's probably the reason I love lattes in the first place. When I ordered one at BB, the art was "abstract" to put it nicely. 

It was a decent latte, but it was lukewarm from the first sip. After all the hype that surrounds Blue Bottle Cofee, I guess I expected a bit more.
author: Nina M.

description: Awesome place! Good coffee and yummy avocado toast make for a scrumptious breakfast :). The place is always packed, and for a very good reason!
author: S D.

description: What is not to love about Blue Bottle.  My friend knew where their cafe was which was good because it is a little hidden in Jessie Square.  Once you get inside, the menu is clear, it's bustling busy but tables turn over quickly enough that there are spots to sit.  It's a good place to quickly catch up, have some coffee and maybe a light meal like a nice salad or dessert.  I am a big fan of their New Orleans iced coffee with soy milk - I order it every time whether it's warm or cold outside.  Friendly service too.  Blue Bottle rocks!
author: Maile N.

description:
My favorite BB location.

Clean, open space with lots of natural light. Bright, lively atmosphere. This location is the only one that does the single-origin Siphons and Kyoto iced coffee. I recommend getting a siphon coffee, kyoto or new orelans iced. You really can't go wrong with anything here. They also serve breakfast; the Acme toast with poached egg is fantastic. Enjoy!
author: Ashley K.

description: The latte I had here was really good.  And I liked how this place was kind of hidden away from the main street and was really quiet, but it was kind of hard to find.  A bit pricey, but pretty standard pricing for small coffee shops nowadays.
author: Nina H.

description:
The Blue Bottle Coffee place at Mint St occupies a really cool space as does the other Blue Bottle outlets I visited. The cafe is in a large airy space and has cool feel to it. There is a large range of different Blue Bottle Coffees on sale but not all are served there. When I was at this place they had the espresso, a regular filter as well as three or four made to order on the siphon. We tried two different on the siphon and those were both very good (one of the Ethiopians as well as Guatemalan Maya), executed to perfection in both cases. Did also have some of the food and this was also very good. Both coffee and food is however priced a bit on the higher end of the scale and service was a bit rushed (even though they were not particularly busy)

Would have been great if it would have been possible to select any coffee and get it brewed there. I bought some different coffee and at $15 for 150 grams it would be nice to be able to try a cup first.
author: Mathias H.

description: Have only been here once but it was so memorable! It's such a gorgeous space that's almost entirely windows with white walls. Everything exudes freshness and purity, it's beautiful. The open bar-type area is so cool too. I ordered a latte and it was probably the best latte I've ever had. The service was also amazing! Everyone is so cool and kind. 10/5 stars!!
author: Kyle D.

description: Stopped in for coffee twice and a breakfast sandwich once. Coffee was great, breakfast sandwich was a little boring and the bacon was over cooked. Go for their coffee. Bought 2 bags to take home (giant steps) and was VERY happy! Delicious. Wish I would have gotten more! Yum!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
True Coffee Shop - I was recently on a business trip in the S.F. Bay Area and came across this coffee shop. The concept is amazing, the coffee is so delicious and the baristas are just awesome. I was more shocked to know that we have some of them in Los Angeles and will be definitely visiting - 

I asked the Barista to show me how to do some art work, she invited me behind the counter and showed me how to use a specific technique ... that was really nice... enjoyed myself a ton when i was there... bought a couple of bags of coffee... came home with some good medium roast that's not too acidic which is the way i like my french-press.... 

Also - had the waffles for breakfast... looked like everything is done from scratch - WOW - those were well worth the CARB intake! 

Awesome spot - will be back! 
JJ
author: Joseph J.

description: This place is fucking delicious! I just didn't like how stuck up and not very friendly the service was. I am big when it comes to costumer service and I'd be less than eager to go back based on that.
author: Johnny A.

description:
I drink coffee all the time, so I knew that I had to go to this place.

I've heard great things about it so I decided to drive to SF just to try it!

I got their special which was the "Cuban Iced Latte" and also a Creme Brûlée bar! 

The Cuban Iced Latte was awesome! It was sweet, but not too sweet, and had a great taste of coffee!

The Creme Brûlée Bar was really really really sweet and it was pretty hard eating it in one sitting, despite its small size.

Overall, I'd give it 4 stars. It would've been 5 but the pastry knocked it down one star!

Anyone who likes coffee should try this place! I personally find it better and more authentic than Starbucks!

However, it was sad that they ran out of the "Chocolate Milk" because it sounded like a very great drink!
author: Jacob B.

description:
I always feel so out of place going to all these hipster coffee shops bahaha.

But i don't even care and would totally come back here because I really love their New Orleans iced coffee.

Its for those people who don't like those ridiculously sweet coffees. Its slightly sweetened, very light. I could actually finish the whole cup, not like when I get usual coffee which is usually too much to handle. 

My friend just moved to the area so I will definitely be back!
author: Rachel C.

description: This place whoops up a mean Americano.  Or anything made of coffee means for that matter.
author: David C.

description: Definitely a hipster place and busy at peek times. Drip coffee was good and my wife said the mocha was great. The food was AWESOME!  The oatmeal was the best I've ever had with cherries, strawberries, pistachios, and strawberry sauce. The "breakfast sandwich" was great too. Hard to find visually as the just have a small plaque of a blue bottle.
author: Kyle T.

description: Upscale coffee bar. Descriptions on some of their specialty coffee was a little misleading, if you are the type to need room for cream SAY SO! They fill the cups to the very tippy top. I had an amazing cappuccino.
author: Jordan S.

description: Loved the old 1800's alley and it felt old in a historically cool way after going to a coin show next door at the US Mint! The cappuccino I had was excellent! The service was excellent and sitting down on a stool I had some conversation with two vegan women that was very interesting as well.Place is great!~ Would go often if i lived in the city for sure!~.
author: Brian D.

description:
Hands down by far one of the best coffee places I've gone to. We ordered a caffe latte, some snickerdoodle and gingersnap cookies, as well as an affogato! And boy the mixture was out of this world -- SUPER DELICIOUS! I probably could have eaten maybe 5 more orders of that -- yep their coffee was that GOOD!!! :) 

The location was a bit hard to find --- to locate the place you need to look for an image of a blue bottle on the side of the building.

Anyways I would DEFINITELY COME BACK HERE for more of the good stuff! ;D
author: ANHDAO N.

description:
Blue bottle definitely gets a 5 star! Their coffee is delicious! Strong and smooth. Blue bottle has been my favorite coffee for a while now and they're made perfectly every time I've had it so far! 

The price is fair for awesome coffee; ranging from $3-$5 depending on what you get. The Iced New Orleans coffee is amazing. The coffee has a naturally slightly sweet finish to it. I also love their cappuccinos and latte. The percentage of milk they add to cappuccinos v. lattes is spot on every time; which makes me super excited. I'm always up for a cup of Blue bottle whenever I'm near one ;)
author: Jennie X.

description: Very good latte + food there ! I highly recommend it, worth waiting in line for few minutes !
author: Julien F.

description: The line was out the door & the place was packed!! I asked the barista which of the drinks was sweetest because I'm a bit of a sweet tooth. He recommended the New Orleans iced coffee. WAY too much milk! But I guess that's what you get for a 1/3 of milk drink. Wasn't that great. Cool to try, but I don't plan on coming back!
author: Amy P.

description:
Kept hearing about this place from what seemed like everyone and their mom, so I was excited to be at a conference in the city and try it out!

Naturally, the day I pick to go is raining cats and dogs.  But it's not like the Moscone Center was far anyways, just a few blocks.  You could smell the aroma from outside (well I could!) and it smelled amazing. Went in and it was busy, and so to-go it was! I ordered a New Orleans Iced Coffee; for some reason the combination of a rainy chilly day and iced coffee seemed like the right idea.  So it happened.  $4 and they only have 1 size.  

Upon first sip, I was expecting it to be sweet, since the description says slightly sweet.  I'm not sure there was any sugar in it (which is fine), but my mind was a little confused.  But the coffee flavor was great! It wasn't bitter, it went down smooth like good liquor, and just had an overall full-bodied taste despite the addition of milk and invisible sugar (still slightly disappointed by the lack of sweetness lol).  This has heightened my expectation for good coffee and I already feel disappointed thinking about the ground coffee that I have at home; I am already anticipating the mediocrity and acidity........

And the barista man was really nice too. Good all around experience.

Try it!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Just like how I use Yelp stars to review a business, I use the hipster clientele to judge a coffee shop (just kidding...sort of). 

Sometimes you just have to appreciate a business that understands quality over  quantity. Blue Bottle's menu is very simple, and while I've yet to appreciate the taste of drip coffee, I can appreciate the simplicity in things (looking at you, PSL...). For those who can't fully appreciate pure black coffee just yet, I wholeheartedly suggest the New Orleans iced coffee. They also offer affogato, which I can't wait to try out next time I'm back. 

The shop itself is kind of hard to find, since it's kind of tucked away in the building behind the church. It looks rather questionable as you're walking down the alley and the crazy pigeons are flying around, but as you walk towards the back of the alley, you'll see the Blue Bottle sign to the left of you around the corner.
author: Emily Z.

description:
When it comes to coffee, I'm a grab n' go coffee from the deli or Dunkin Donuts, kinda girl.  You would never, ever catch me standing on a line that snakes the corner for a cup of joe. It's just coffee ferchissakes! 

Right. So that whole attitude of mine was quickly tossed out the window after I downed a latte @ Blue Bottle. During my short and sweet visit to SF, a friend of mine swore to the heavens about the coffee at this place so I figured, what the hey. The 15min wait in line was annoying but that tres delicious latte quickly tempered my impatient disposition. And because there is only one Blue Bottle in all of NY/NJ, I scored a bag of Three African coffee beans - "a blend of Ugandan and two different Ethiopian coffees that produces a big, chocolately aroma." Ummm yum?!? I hope that bag will hold me over until more locations open up on the East Coast.
author: Juliette J.

description:
The Belgian waffle is very good: I don't know how they get it to be so tasty.  Maybe they add lots of vanilla flavoring?  http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/lNbKeOfCMTNkoihZHqrbrg?select=faixHjogPjNUo07T0RBRFw#faixHjogPjNUo07T0RBRFw
The New Orleans coffee is great, too.
author: Scott F.

description:
The Gibraltar and Kyoto style iced coffee!  These are what blew my coffee brain and made me fall in love with Blue Bottle.

When I lived in the east bay, I used to make a special effort to go on a weekday afternoon to pick up beans to brew my mocha-pot espresso at home. When I worked on Mission st downtown, this was the out-of-the-way coffee spot we were always thrilled to come to.

I still stop by from time to time and the food is delicious too--the egg salad sandwich and the toast with poached eggs, especially. 

Can't wait for their cookbook to come out next month!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Last coffee stop before heading out of SanFran and I wish I would have known of it sooner.
Nice little place to just relax. Not much for scenery because it's by an alley, but great spot to enjoy your coffee and chill.
Will be my spot next time I'm here.
author: E H.

description:
This is a hidden gem in between some alley way type of streets, hidden away from the Mission and Market street. You would not happen to come across this place if you were to just walk by on the main streets, but do your due diligence by looking up coffee places on Yelp or have a great recommendation from somebody. Luckily, yelp has been a great friend to me during my first time here and the interest of using a siphon to make coffee is something you don't normally see at a coffee shop. 

The line is familiarly long like you see at standard coffee shops early in the morning, but these workers are hard at work like a well greased assembly line. There's nothing like standing in a long line, writing this review (hey, I'm a woman and I like to multitask). I happen to splurge and with time constraints get a Siphon Panamanian coffee. The Ned drip did caught my attention, but with 30 mins of brewing time, it was no Buenos. However, I could imagine how yummy the coffee could be.  Nonetheless, with my siphon coffee ordered, I was cautioned not to add any cream.  The caramel colored coffee was a kin to a dark steep tea.  It had a wonderful flavor to it, with a lot of complexities and I was so glad to heed the advice of the barista to have it plain.  

All in all, I believe that the price is up there and the line is too long, but if you're a coffee aficionado like me, it's worth it.  Next time with more time on hand, I think I'll get the Ned drip and won't blink an eye at the price because coffee is that important to me.
author: Mary S.

description: I enjoyed a cafe au lait and was not disappointed.  My friend suggested this was the best coffee in SF. I have to admit it was a soothingly smooth and comforting cup!
author: Melissa G.

description: Visited from San Diego and originally from the east coast... Love the coffee! I love pour overs, and it's really a hit or miss with most coffee shops, but this place is doing a great job! George was my cashier both times I visited, and he was excellent at his job and very welcoming.
author: Trevor F.

description: I am never coming back again. My coffee tasted ok but the problem was that the cup was filthy. When a coffee shop disrespects their clients by serving a coffee in a cup that has not been washed in years then the best to do is just to look for another coffee shop that meets  basic sanitary conditions. Two stars though because the staff members were really nice and helpful -- they did not really know what they were doing but they still tried pretty hard to be nice to the clientele.
author: Pedro S.

description:
Searched for a roaster for my stay in SF & I nailed it! I'm spoiled coming from Riverside & having Augies, but Blue Bottle proved to be a great substitute during my stay in SF! Congrats!

Like:
Iced coffee! That's how I take it & it's hard to come by a memorable one.
The Catalan style poached eggs! Never thought I'd enjoy cornbread!
author: Hector M.

description: Very cute location in the Ferry Building. They're under construction, but still open. The staff is very friendly and the long line moves pretty quickly. I ordered the mocha--cute cup and coffee art! It was ok, not great, but I did appreciate how it wasn't scaldingly hot when it came out.
author: Kira W.

description:
I love macchiato and mocha here 

My favorite one is Parmesan cookie. They do not make it anymore I miss it
author: Pim H.

description: One of the best coffee places in San Francisco. I usually get their new orleans style iced coffee. Have also tried their cappuccino and it was really good as well.
author: Varun A.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! 

My second favorite coffee shop in San Francisco! Service was great, friendly and fast!
I ordered the Cappuccino and purchased the New Orleans coffee in a milk carton for togo. The coffee was still fresh the next day after refrigerating. Both, the Cappuccino and New Orleans Ice Coffee was strong, bold and just delicious! I might try something on their breakfast menu the next time I'm here.

Beware there may be a line at the door, but don't be intimidated because it will move quickly. 

I would definitely recommend Blue Bottle Coffee Co!
author: Kathy N.

description:
The coffee here is the best in San Francisco, and the one on Mint has a gorgeous outdoor eating area where you can enjoy your breakfast and amazing coffee.

My wife had the breakfast sandwich which is AMAZING. The brioche was fresh, the bacon perfectly cooked and the fritata was delicious. I had the steel-cut oatmeal with raspberry jam and soy milk (I have a dairy allergy, which they were quite good about respecting). If you add that to a pleasant breeze and bright  sunshine, there is no better place to have a breakfast than here.

Fantastic!
author: Frank A.

description: Really great place heaps of character and funk, takes coffee art to a whole new dimension. Deffantly be back to explore more.
author: Justin T.

description: Love BB and the Adffogato! Watch out for the crackheads outside though.
author: E T.

description: I ordered the New Orleans iced coffee and my friend got a regular black drip. It was just okay. Nothing special. Don't really understand why this place is so hyped up. This location was bad too. It was so crowded and wasn't a nice place to hang out. We sat on stools and chilled but I wasn't very comfortable and definitely didn't want to stay long.
author: Samantha H.

description: It's incredible to see its team and menu change as Mint Plaza changes around it as well. I will swear by their Eggs in a Basket toast and New Orleans. Affogatos with Humphry Slocombe for the splurge.
author: Abel L.

description: Blue Bottle was a great find. Friendly service. Great food. I ordered the poached eggs with tomato, it was delicious. The sugo like sauce between my eggs and the high rise soft toasted bread was awesome. It was great to grab a bench and watch coffee be made unlike anywhere else I've seen. Even a tea drinker like me could really appreciate the craft.
author: Lisa P.

description:
best cappuccino ever! delicious and perfect temp!
ginger black pepper
cookie was freaking amazing and the unusual
flavor
combo makes it the best treat
author: Marci A.

description: The iced coffee for $4 was one of the worst I've had. There were no seats available also, so I was standing right by the door and using the wall outlet to charge my phone, and the employee made a big deal about it saying that I'm technically outside the store (right by the door), so I can't use the outlet to charge my phone. Worst coffee and service.
author: Caroline P.

description:
Oh, Blue Bottle....coffee that lives in infamy within my cerebellum and, more appropriately, my taste buds. Trendy, quiet, hospitable, and flavorful all rolled into one. 

This joint churns out craft lattes and coffees for those seeking freshly roasted beanery. Siphons, Chemex pourover cones, and mounds of fresh pastries/breakfast-friendly items. All pair dreamily with any choice of coffee/espresso. The Kyoto iced coffee is a wonderful morning drag kicker. 

Tons of mixed and multi origin roasts available. I recommend Giant Steps. 

Like a mad scientists laboratory of caffeinated greatness, Blue Bottle Coffee Co is now my go-to when in SOMA, or any part of San Fran, rather. Bottoms up!
author: Benjamin G.

description: New Orleans iced coffee, best iced coffee I've had! A little confusing to find the location but worth it!
author: Jess N.

description: Yes the coffee here is very good... But the main attraction for me was the toast with honey butter. So good!
author: Bahar S.

description:
I suppose if I'm a coffee aficionado I should be very happy that a Blue Bottle is just around the corner. Well, I'm not a coffee aficionado but it's still nice to have something nearby, even if there's always a ridiculous line. 

I come here about once a week and always try to get something new. Definitely have liked everything I've gotten, but the service isn't always the same. The last time I was there one of the baristas was incredibly rude when I asked a question about my macchiato and that was enough for this location to lose one star from me.
author: Rowena L.

description: Coffee is good. A bit overrated in my opinion. Good but nothin special. I wouldn't drive out if my way for it.
author: Steve J.

description:
Breakfast and coffee will run you 40 big ones!

The line is out the door so people must know something.  Had a sausage platter something and grilled cheese...both were Outststanding. Expensive to me but it seemed really unique.
author: Joe S.

description:
Came here for the first time with a group of 4.

There was no line when we came this afternoon, and no pressure from the barista to order. He was friendly and unhurried with the service, but made my drink quickly and well. Seating was quite full but it was a beautiful day so we just went for a walk with our drinks instead. Love their use of Square for cards.
author: Mimi S.

description: Very trendy , just the way you want a coffee shop to be! Their New Orleans style iced coffee was perfect , not too sweet , herbal tea was amazing too .  I thought the service was friendly ..but more on the serious side .
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Guys, you can not cut two thick slices of bread, spread mayo on them, and then sprinkle tuna and celery in between and call it a sandwich. This is San Francisco.
The coffee may be ok, but it is the food which really needs the caffeine.

Edit: After a complaint on Square they actually refunded me for my "ham and cheese" sandwich, which I expected to be grilled, but was not. That is some great customer service I must say!

Sorry, still no extra star since the sandwich itself was so unlovely. It was like the rectangular ham you get in packets at the grocery store, and shredded moz, like you get in packets at the grocery store...Being in trendy SOMA it should be so much more. Fresh moz, and prosciutto at least! How about arugula instead of bright purple pickled cabbage? 

I can tell you, their coffee is great, but their venture into food has dented my image of them. They have great customer service, so I am sure they will turn it around soon. For now, just get coffee there and pick up your sandwiches elsewhere.
author: Paul H.

description:
Blue Bottle makes one of the better Mochas to be had in the Bay Area.  It's smooth, creamy, and just what the doctor ordered for those icy cold summer mornings in SF.

My only complaint - no matter how many times I ask, I can never get them to serve my Mocha hot enough to suit me :-(
author: Glenn G.

description:
I had Blue Bottle once in the Oakland location and thought this coffee was nothing special.

I had to give it another shot especially since it is #28 of 100 Thing to Eat Before You Die. I came for the Gibraltar but since I wanted to-go, the cashier said a cappuccino was the same except that the Gibraltar means it is served in a glass. 

The cappuccino was just the way I like, strong and bold. Not sure if I would wait 15 minutes.
author: Kien M.

description: Amazing selection of single origin coffees.  My friend and I wanted to take back some locally roasted coffee during our San Fran visit and this was a great Yelp! find.  Service was excellent--the person who helped us patiently navigated through all their coffees because my friend is a relative coffee novice.  Also, a nice array of snacky baked goods.  Tried a delicious flaky Parmesan shortbread during my visit that was a nice complement to my iced coffee.
author: Anna S.

description: Stopped in to buy a gift. Place was crowded. i don't drink coffee so I was not familiar with what to look for.  Asked for help to find a particular single origin and service was rude. Wont be back.
author: Julie T.

description:
Oh man, I think I had my first coffeegasm at Blue Bottle. That first sip was life changing. I'm breathing in the aroma of the espresso and mocha, the warm cafe mocha touches me tongue, and it goes down so smooth. I felt something, mightve been in my pants, but I'm not sure. 

I had a caffe mocha and it was PERFECT. Espresso was smooth and the flavor nicely accompanied by the mocha. The drink was really well balanced and I really enjoyed every single sip.

The barista's were really friendly and helpful. I'm an avid Starbucks drinker only because it's convenient so it was really refreshing to have experienced Blue Bottle.

Decor is really simple and yet still retains a hip and modern feel. In the middle there are a few tables in a row with stools to sit on and along the wall is a counter with stools also.  The only sign they have outside is a little blue bottle. I missed it the first time I walked by.

I will definitely be back for some delicious coffee. I will probably try to the iced coffee next time because the little contraption they use to make it looks so kewl!
author: Harry T.

description: Amazing coffee!  Ordered two caffe latte and one iced coffee. Came here for a study session with two of my girls. The place is kinda loud since there are two entrances (wind draft = chilly study) they make a simple leaf latte art on their caffe latte. Probably seats around 15-20 people around the seating area (bar seat kind of setting)  located close to the sf chronicle building and hidden away just a block shy of the powell Bart station and Westfield mall and Nordstrom rack.
author: Anita L.

description:
I love Blue Bottle. I wish so much that they would come to Pittsburgh. Their Coffee is so reasonably priced for a hand poured coffee. You can't beat 2.75 for a hand dripped coffee. They also have cool a 300 watt bulbs that heat their Siphon coffee makers which is a pretty cool experience. Something that is commonplace in Japan, but we are far away from Japan. 

I will say that even though they offer food it's not the best in the world. Some might find the french toast to be a bit much on the hugely thick pieces of bread they deliver it on, but the few things I had will put something in your stomach for your walk to work.
author: Will B.

description:
I'm not a big coffee drinker, but Blue Bottle may have a new convert! =)
Whoa, the New Orleans ice coffee was super delish, and I loved that I didn't have to add any sugar in it. It was fine by itself. LOVE!! 

The New Orleans isn't too strong of a coffee drink and they pour about a 1/4 of whole milk (you have the option of soy milk) into the cup. For about $3.50, the cup size is a bit small. It doesn't seem like you have the option of upgrading the size. Bf also got the kyoto style ice coffee. Wow. It is served black and STRONG. I had one sip and it was enough. He had to add sugar and cream to temper the strong coffee flavor a bit. The flavor was unique and it is hard to describe. Just be prepared to be overwhelmed by the first sip. =P

This Blue Bottle location is a bit hidden and both times I went, there was a line out the door. It wasn't that much of a wait though, probably 10-15 minutes. The inside is really cool. Industrial with a communal table in the table. Food looked delish, but it was a bit pricey. At least $10 for some poached eggs and toast.

Maybe it's a good thing that we don't have a Blue Bottle in SoCal, or else I'd be in a daily caffeinated high. =P
author: Julie L.

description: Great coffee joint! These are the places that make the city so unique. It's truly about the coffee experience and enjoying - living the art of cafe!
author: Leah A.

description: I enjoyed the service and the cup of coffee hit the spot. I see what the fuss is about.
author: Ranell S.

description:
If you like modern coffee in a modern atmosphere with uber trendy wait-people, then brave the lines at the Blue Bottle Coffee Co.!  You get ultra-fancy coffee with ultra fancy designs on top! The coffee is as rich and as hot as they come! If you like it clean, try the "siphoned" coffee with hardware straight from Japan! It is clean, it is fun, and the staff is SUPER nice and attentive, even tho' during "coffee hours" (in the morning) it gets kind of crazy.

As for the food, we were there on a normal weekday...we heard the weekend brunches were killer! On a normal morning, you can order waffles (the thick and rich kind), inch-thick slices of bread, frittata, and oatmeal. I usually think of steel cut oatmeal as a "healthy" food - with nuts and nonfat milk, but at the Blue Bottle, you can get it with cream, brown sugar and whipped butter! It was luscious and decadent and positively yummy!

I would recommend this to anybody wanting authentic San Francisco - we enjoyed our breakfast at the Blue Bottle!
author: Catherine W.

description:
Ohhhh love this place. Definitely stood up to expectations, although was a little overwhelmed by the hipster staff and customers alike. 

Have also navigated American coffee - yes I wld like a soy latte with an extra shot. Thanks. 

Great atmos, great coffee and service, good snacks, no meals and high turnover so maybe not a quiet coffee and relax venue?
author: Adrianna W.

description:
At this point I've spent a lot of dough on super high end coffee options trying both BB's siphon cup and Ritual Roaster's clover and honestly neither is so remarkable as to justify the $4+ price tag for a cup of coffee. But alas it's still quite fun to fetish-ize things you enjoy and I'm happy to blow some disposable income here and there, plus it sure beats smoking a cigar of rolled twenties. 

I like their science class coffee pots and glassware. I enjoy the clean lines of their space and the outdoor tables. I also appreciate they had to clear out a lot of heroine addicts to make the alleyway hospitable. That takes bravery, some might even say balls. I personally gave up on gentrifying sketchy areas of the city in 2001, but hats off to the crusaders that still carry the flag on my yuppie behalf.

For coffee I'll go here over Peets or Starbucks any day, it makes me feel less like a schmuck. But doesn't that make me a schmuck? Uh oh.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Delicious coffee; hands-down my favorite latte in the city.

But do they really need to work so slowly? Does each serving of steamed milk need to be steamed individually? Does each bean need to be coaxed gently from the bag into the grinder, and then massaged Kobe beef-style into delicious powdery form for expressing? 

I feel like the staff is purposefully trying to keep everything slow for fear that their precious coffee might make it into the sinister hands of a hurried too-uncool office worker (like me, I guess). I would come here more often and gladly pay their inflated prices if I knew I wasn't going to blow 30 minutes standing in line.
author: Andrew M.

description:
As a barista I don't mind waiting for GOOD coffee. But what I got at blue bottle was not that. My boyfriend took me here as a surprise because he knows my obsession with coffee but even he was disappointed.
To start this place is hard to find. If it hadn't been for the line we would've never known it was there. We waited in line for 30 minutes and got to the counter where we were met with what I can only describe as hipsters providing "we're too good for you" service. No vanilla syrup? Really?
I get a latte and he gets a mocha. 
His is just fine (for him coffee is coffee is coffee) my latte has great texture but zero taste like I was drinking warm milk- disgusting.
Not worth the time and it's alarmingly expensive for the bad service and product.
author: Rachel L.

description: New go to coffee spot in San Fran. Great tasting coffee! Such bold and rich taste and the barista was very helpful when it came to recommendations my first time, allowing us to have samples of different drinks before ordering. Can't go wrong here!
author: Megan E.

description:
From coffee to food, this place is fancy and really good.

The only thing I did not like was the expensive crazy blend of coffee thing that they serve in some scientist looking object. I probably am not an extreme coffee taster so I cannot taste the science behind it, but it was kind of like drinking tea. But other than that, the normal coffee and lattes were great, ESPECIALLY because they make those little leaf things with the cream, so fancy and good.

We ordered a Belgium Waffle and Poached Egg with cornbread and sausages. SO GOOD. The waffle was extremely flaky and soft and the texture was perfect for a waffle. The Poached Egg was poached perfectly, with a slight runny yolk, just how I like it. The sausages were really good as well, and I do not normally like cornbread AT ALL, but the cornbread they served here was SO GOOD. The dish also came with a side of salad, it was kinda of sour, but complimented the rest of the plate well.

There is always a line here, and parking is pretty difficult at times, so be prepared to wait a little bit, but it is worth it for sure. Definitely would come back here and try out some other food and get some more great coffee.

The atmosphere is terrific too, there isn't that much seats, but it IS a coffee shop so most people get coffee to go. There is also space outside to seat on a corner thing if the weather is good, so that is also a plus.

One of the best coffee spots in the city for sure.
author: Benjamin W.

description: Great customer service! I ordered a Siphon (fanciest coolest coffee I've ever had-and I'm not talking 10 different sugar flavors)but as busy as they were they missed making it after I ordered. No biggie, they made up for it! I went up to the bar to ask about it, and the very nice lady looked into it, apologized, and credited me back for the coffee with the nicest smile! Due to the delay I had to take it to go, and got my coffee in a glass bottle with a description and fun info on what I had ordered. It was neat! I would say more about the coffee, but I'm no connoisseur. I'm sure to those who know coffee better than I do it is immaculate and wonderful. Just the experience and watching the ...brew master?... make it was cool, like some sort of coffee sorcery. I think for my next visit I'll stick to what I know and get my regular ol cappuccino and enjoy the coffee sorcery from afar.
author: Amanda M.

description:
They take coffee SERIOUSLY here.  Line out the door.  Worth the wait.  Packed house, so we sat outside.  Cafe mocha was perfect, as was the hot chocolate...not too sweet.  Latte art happened.  If you need a fancy coffee maker, see the retail section.  

I wanted to take some of this legendary coffee home, so I grabbed Three Africas.  I asked the cashier if that was a good choice, and she advised me to purchase Giant Steps which is specifically made for Blue Bottle beginners.
author: Sher M.

description: I'm sure everyone knows that the coffee rocks here. It's made with detail and care, and each cup is delicious and full bodied, and never burnt.  This review however is about the breakfast that they only serve M-F from 8am-11am. The eggs benny! WHOA are they delicious.  First of all, I love Acme bread and the use of Acme bread on any plate elevates it. Next the eggs are perfectly poached. The whites are solid, and the yolk is just runny enough. Nice golden color. topped with bechamel sauce which isn't too heavy and then grated gruyere is sprinkled. Every bite is just magnificent!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Came here on the randomest of random Tuesdays.

Stood in a line for 30-40 minutes.
I do not actually drink coffee.

Received Hot Chocolate.

Too thick and not melted all the way but had good flavor.
author: Winè C.

description: Completely non-descript but has some of the best coffee in SF. That's why Blue Bottle has no sign, is difficult to find, and remains full for most of the day. My favorite thing here is the New Orleans iced coffee.
author: Charlie M.

description: Expensive but amazing best coffee around and great snacks and breakfast awesome service fun and nice people.
author: Alex M.

description:
I cannot get this coffee out of my head!  I'm ruined!  I think it was my favorite place we visited our whole trip and so glad we made it back for a second visit.  
Besides being delicious, everyone who works there were extremely friendly, sweet, and amazing!  They made everything so pleasant!  It will be my first stop next time I'm in town!!!
author: Erica N.

description:
With Mint Plaza being so close to where I stay, I find myself moseying on over to Blue Bottle quite often. The lines are usually insane and the wait time usually leads to roughly half an hour, but once you get your order, at the slightest first sip, you know that it was all worth the chaos. Deep breath. Exhale. Ahhhhh... Love a New Orleans Iced Coffee with soy or a nice smooth latte.

With coffee equipment resembling wicked flasks, warped beakers, and experimenting test tubes, the Japanese imported siphons are an interesting sight to see. 

The quality is definitely on point and all their brewed coffee blends are certified organic. 

With Blue Bottle Coffee Co., I'll gladly continue to brave the stampede of coffee addicts in order to suffice my own fix.
author: Ann S.

description: Tried several different local small coffee shop type places for breakfast while in town. This was the best. Unfortunately out of avocado when we went. Otherwise great. Be sure to try it when in San Fran.
author: Steve C.

description: This particular location makes the best coffee I've had in SF- perhaps the country! Three visits in one week. I loved this spot. There was a line out the door every time! Totally worth it and the line actually moved faster than expected. While there is seating inside, it's quite limited and definitely gets packed. Luckily, there's plenty of outdoor seating the neighboring plaza. I'm a cappuccino type of gal and theirs are perfection.  I'm a fan of their macchiato too. We came here for the coffee, but their breakfast looked delicious.
author: Isabella J.

description:
There is an aura of superiority in specialty coffee shops that I don't understand. Does your education in the science of coffee preparation entitle you to snobbery? 

Regardless, the coffee has no indication of bitterness and the latte prepared with nonfat milk is rich and decadent. 

I have tried their coffee on two separate occasions and both times the coffee was lukewarm.  Maybe this is the new trend.

I prefer my coffee to be hot!  A repeat customer I will be not.

Namaste!
author: MiYun C.

description: Came in and ordered the Kyoto iced coffee which came in a shot glass to my surprise so I was almost tempted to tell the guy he got me the wrong order. The cookie and the coffee went perfect together because even though I'm a big coffee lover it was almost even a bit overwhelming!
author: Jose R.

description:
Possibly the best craft coffee you can find in San Francisco.
Yes,there is a queue- yes, it is worth the wait.

Highly recommend the drip coffee and the New Orleans ice coffee.
author: Ace T.

description:
First timer to this place.  Though the place in ferry building was awesome, they close much earlier, so it brings the crowds here when people have a crave for good coffee in the afternoon.  

Although, I have to say, why do these good coffee places not have wifi?? Or are they just way too popular and crowed that they don't want to keep the crowds??
author: Ariel Z.

description:
If Philz coffee had a slower idiot little brother who also tried to roast and brew his own coffee, his name would Blue Bottle Coffee. 

I must be in the small minority here when I say their coffee is disgusting. I must also mention that this if my third time at this exact location. I wanted to try it several times before I passed judgement. First time I had a slow drip, second time I had the Vietnamese coffee (offensive they would even call it that) and just now I had the slow drip again. My wife shops in this plaza and I'm forced to choose between this guy or Starbucks... I think I've chosen wrong 3 times.

But of course, I must also mention that the service (aside from the register person) is on par with quality of the coffee, mediocre all the way. My advice, if you need a cup of coffee that badly, I think there's a vending machine in the Nordstroms break room that would have the same quality coffee for about 1/8 the price.
author: Shaf O.

description:
I had the cafe au lait, and it was reaaaaaally good. Not very strong, but had a clean and smooth taste. I think what makes this a unique experience is the different way in which they brew coffee, the service, and the ambiance. I loved the location. It was small and crowded, but some stools rotate quickly. I was able to find a seat after a couple minutes, and my hubby a couple more minutes later right next to me. It was worth the wait for the seats to be able to sit down and enjoy the first sips. 

Fortunately, the line was short when we came mid-day, but the baristas told us that the line was out the door all morning and just died down when we got there. So, not being a fan of long lines, I did not return when I wanted coffee in the mornings.
author: NY C.

description: Talk about cliche staffing: the edgy tattoo covered barista with "attitude" and to off-set her, the "pretty" demure, coy barista. Like other reviewers, I experienced the same service nepotism: the barista serving her friends first. Unreal. I ended up alone while others who arrived after me were served with a familiar smile and greeting. After about 10 minutes I was served my $4.00 cup of coffee with nary a "thanks". The demographic is what one would expect of the area, take it or leave it. I think I'll stick to Peets, Philz, and even SB given the level of pretentious service, over-priced over-filtered bean, and central casting gentrification set piece. I just wanna a cup of honest coffee, third wave or not.
author: Chad R.

description:
Best coffee in downtown.

Little hidde on a back street makes it more cool and selected to visit.

Was here almost everyday day at my visit.
author: Patrik D.

description:
Sometimes you just need an escape from the rigors of everyday life. My prefered way to escape consists of reading stacks of Nabokov and Bukowski while sipping drinks from Blue Bottle and forgetting the troubles of the outside world. While I can't spend all of my days lost in literary paradise, I try to make it here as often as possible. 

Blue Bottle's drinks go so far beyond other coffee shops that there is no real comparison. The food here is as fantastic as the coffee, order both and you will never want to leave. 

Bring a book, order a drink, and enjoy some much needed alone time ... you deserve it.
author: Tom L.

description: super cute little cafe. keep in mind it is VERY little but prices aren't bad and everything on the menu is delicious - nearby seating outside too. has a super cute and aesthetically pleasing san francisco feel!
author: Natalie B.

description: This was my first visit and was taken there by my client....all I can say is that it's well worth the wait and the $$'s....best coffee ever!  I had the mocha latte and it was smooth, not bitter but yet not sweet.  I will admit, if you blink, you'll miss the place but definitely make it a stop in your morning...will definitely repeat!
author: Tony C.

description:
Oh, the slow drip gets me every time. I can't imagine a more harmoniously roasted and perfectly brewed cup of coffee. I was wooed by their infusion of chicory (a personal favorite since moving to the Big Easy) and had to try their version of a New Orleans coffee.  If Blue Bottle existed in NOLA, I'm pretty sure everyone would have a raging caffeine addiction simply because of this drink.
 
Somehow, we came at a quiet time because we were the only ones there outside of a couple already enjoying their treats. Although, I've heard the line can be daunting, so plan ahead if you're looking for a taste of a Blue Bottle treat.
author: Kelsey G.

description:
Love this place. I'm there at least once a week. I am not a fan of their lattes, but their espresso and iced coffees hit the spot. The staff are nice and efficient. The shop can get a little busy, but you can always find a chair somewhere. 

Definitely my favorite coffee in SF! : ) I'll have to try their pastries sometime.
author: Sneha P.

description: If you're walking around SF doing the tourist thing, do yourself a favor and make a pitt stop to a local favorite. San Franciscan's are pretty serious about their coffee, and Blue Bottle is easily on top of the list. It's a small shop with a line usually out the door. Don't look for frappyicedsugarblended drinks here. Order a cappuccino or a latte and melt away with how coffee should really taste like.
author: Bevi K.

description:
I had a bit of a love/hate thing going on with Blue Bottle during my visit to San Fran. It was the best coffee convenient to work, so that was a plus and while it wasn't amazing, it was consistently good. 

The cafe itself is confusing. So much space for people to sit and drink, yet the majority of clientele are there for takeaways and are crammed into one area (in the way of all amenities and lids arc), forced out the door. The people making the coffee also take orders by just asking up the line. Someone else eventually takes your money and I felt like an awkward tourist every time, like they were speaking some kind of language and queue process that I just didn't understand.  I thought maybe the trick was to order and enjoy at the cafe. Only I ended up taking a seat and having to go back and collect my order...which was in a take away cup. C'mon guys, my accent isn't that bad. 

4 stars for consistent coffee, 2 stars for overall experience.
author: Mel P.

description:
Vibe: Consistently busy and bustling. This is definitely not a place to open your laptop and do work at (check out Sightglass for great coffee and a nice working space). This location reminds me a lot of NYC from its crowd and atmosphere. The outdoor seating is a nice touch, if you want to get some fresh air.

Coffee: Say what you want about Blue Bottle being a semi-chain, they make great coffee and are very consistent with their quality. I'm always satisfied with my lattes (though Four Barrel's espresso tastes more unique) and I've heard great things about the New Orleans Iced Coffee.

Service: Though their nice and speedy, they always seem rushed and somewhat behind. Overall, it's not a big deal, but sometimes it can seem a little hectic behind the counter. Don't expect to have conversation with anyone behind the counter beyond telling them what you want.

Value: It's pretty fairly-priced when compared to Ritual, Four Barrel and Sightglass, and you'll likely gain more cred from your out-of-town friends for Instagram photos here than at other coffee shops in SF, for whatever that's worth.
author: Luke B.

description:
Solid coffee with amazing baristas who know their coffee & always make great recommendations. Lattes or macchiattos, both were super smooth and well-balanced in the creaminess + coffee flavors. Special coffee beans with strong, bold flavors.

This place is always busy/packed, but it has a very nice, clean, modern feel. Their coffee crumble cake was also bomb.
author: Nina K.

description: Fantastic coffee and great Batista's. Having just relocated from Sydney to the US and having turned into a little bit of a coffee snob in the process - blue bottle fills the void. The Americano is close to perfect and the large table in the middle provides both good opportunity for conversation as well as great people watching.
author: Phillip S.

description:
One of the better tasting lattes I've had.  My husband's cappuccino tasted even better.  The latte art isn't half bad either.  Popeye toast was a safe and pleasing choice for brunch. 

Would go back to this locations despite finding a place to park is challenging.
author: Michelle T.

description: The staff is extremely friendly and to a dumb question like what would you suggest for a first timer I got a reply of "anything because it will all taste amazing." Wish I was in San Francisco more often so I could come to this place more often. The coffee itself is delicious and the designs are beautiful.
author: Natalya K.

description:
I'm going to re-rate this and give it 4 stars. Originally, I wasn't a big coffee drinker. However, now that I am becoming more of a coffee drinker, I LOVE how strong the coffee is over here. Their iced coffee is really good (New Orleans Style!). 

However, I'm not giving it 5 stars because it is still a little too bitter for me, but if you are a real coffee lover, you need to try this place at least once. It has become one of my guilty pleasures in SF (and not to mention I feel really cool carrying a blue bottle cup around when I do buy one).
author: Andrea X.

description: location was pretty hard to find; overhyped in my opinion.
author: Marie N.

description: I highly recommend. Love the coffee and amazing  staff. Service is on point - fast and courteous. Love the concept behind the place. Would love to get a franchise :)
author: Robert F.

description: Out of the Main Street and all the noise, extremely nice environment. I personally don't drink coffee so there isn't much I can say. But, if you're looking for a nice place to relax for an hour. Come here!
author: Ziv B.

description: Love this spot.  The coffee is amazing and lovingly prepared.  And the big surprise is that the food is great, too!   If Starbucks is the Marriot, Blue Bottle is the Four Seasons....
author: Julia K.

description:
Try the expresso and cappuccinos 

Great service, great atmosphere, great coffee. 

Try something different then your daily Starbucks fix, and walk down across the street and try something that tastes like it's worth more then that $5 cup but isn't as pricey. And enjoy :)
author: Rohil J.

description:
Oh coffee, how I love thee! Let me count thy ways:
A- affogato
B- breve
C- cortado
D- de caf?
E- espresso!
F- flat white
G- Gibraltar 
Ahhhhh, the sweet taste of java crafted professionally, there is no other that makes my day wonderful! Los Angeles has great indie coffee such as G&B, Intelligentsia and the such, I was interested in Blue Bottle Coffee up here in Frisco...ooopps! So sorry! I can feel the tension! I meant San Fran!
Blue Bottle is a great little place right behind the old US Mint building. Known to have invented the Gibraltar ( a drink that is taller than a macchiato, but shorter than a latte, the Gibraltar was named for the four-ounce glass in which it's served) I was excited to try this place eventhough there are Yelpers who have thumbed it down!
I arrived at about 7:45 am and didn't have to wait in line too long. I ordered a latte and a peanut crumb cake, both delicious! The latte rivaled that of both G&B and Intelligentsia. I was in coffee heaven! The barista was so awesome as I ordered one to go for my wifey who stayed back at the hotel, I also wanted to bring back some whole beans to Roland L and she recommended their Giant Steps.
Went back the next day and told my wife that we needed to be there before 8 am otherwise there would be a ginormous line. Ordered a Gibraltar with a Snickerdoodle cookie, again, both were amazing! You can always measure the quality of both the coffee and barista by the espresso and let me tell you, it is FABULOSO! By 8am, they start serving breakfast and because I was in line earlier, the barista told me to hop in front and order! Ordered the waffle for the wife, it was so moist, crunchy and tasty! Also, the line went out the door by this time, so if you are in a rush, please make it before 8 am!
Should I return to SF, I am definitely coming back! Oh, just brewed 2 cups of the Giant Steps, man o man, it is soooooo good!
author: Loren L.

description:
I like the idea of single drip coffee, but i can only get it on vacation because i personally hate getting anything other than regular coffee because i don't like to wait for it.

I had some time by myself in the morning so it was a great place to just sit and drink my coffee and read the news. I like the location because Its a quieter place right in the middle of the city.
author: Johnny C.

description: How can you not give blue bottle 5 stars? It's perfection. Their mocha and lattes are soo good! This is definitely a top notch coffee experience. My family even knew about blue bottle and they live in Indiana so I  guess it's well known. I prefer the Hayes Valley location because it seems so much quicker and it's a few blocks from where I live.
author: Allie M.

description: A great coffee shop and this location is wonderful. The menu is simple and you will not get any added junk in your coffee... so just order a latte or an espresso and enjoy it the way it should be.  They also have pour over coffee which again if you are into the taste of coffee you will really enjoy.   Not a cheap place, but average for most coffee bars around town.
author: Frank C.

description: Closest to Intelligentsia coffee that I've found anywhere in the country. But Intelligentsia knows how to get through a 20+ line quickly
author: Kc W.

description: Came by for a Sunday breakfast on my own. This seems like a place better to come for a cup of coffee than for breakfast. I waited about 20-30 minutes. To me a long line is a good sign. The breakfast menu is sparse - don't come here for omelets and eggs benedict. I got an almond milk cappuccino and the waffle (or, as they spell it in Dutch, wafel). Both items were great, but my waffle came up before my coffee. The syrup and butter were of high quality and the service was friendly. I'd definitely come back for coffee, but not breakfast.
author: Josh R.

description: This place is a very unique coffee shop and def. nothing close to what we have here in LA. We tried to come early because we heard the line gets pretty crazy and as we expected our wait was about 45 min long! But of course we sucked it up and waited haha.
