They only had a few options for their coffee selection but each coffee seemed to have a lot of thought and quality in all of them because the machinery they use to make the coffee was unbelievable and time worthy. We ordered the coffee ice cream, which I never had before but wow it blew my mind! It was amazing! I'm mad i haven't tried something like this before :(.  We also ordered the New Orleans iced coffee and it was def. something I never tasted before and def. gave my taste buds a trip haha. The only sad part is that there is no location in LA! Get a location in LA please!! :)
author: Lanka W.

description:
Atmosphere is great, ginger snaps = awesome, and their coffee is pretty consistently great, especially anything with TCHO in it.

Except the drip coffee. Maybe I just don't like that style at all, because I've not liked any drip coffee at any other supposedly good coffee places either. I just decided to get this on a whim and really regretted.

Should've stuck to my espressos.
author: Alice C.

description:
10am Thursday, it was not so crouded.I bought hole bean for souvenirs though, they don't provide mill bean.
Ceiling is high.
Resister is Square.
People looks tourist.
Only 22 chairs in the shop.
author: Mizuto K.

description:
Good deals and interesting place.  I was a bit skeptical with the long line and somewhat hard to find location, but it turned out to be a pretty cool place.  Great tasting coffee (the latte was a good choice) and good service.  Thought the prices were pretty reasonable too.  

Don't go if you're in a hurry, but good spot for a relaxing coffee break with treats.
author: Scott N.

description:
If bitcjmis my coffee, ee get surrieus!   

This is the gold standard, mecca in the west
Get the french toast  or waffle and some beans Giant Steppes to go.  Oh siphon sitdown you peasants!
author: Ned N.

description:
After trying a couple of the other Blue Bottle Coffee locations, I would have to say this is my favorite one so far. It's got a nice place to sit down in and the coffee is done quite a bit quicker than the other areas. Quality-wise, I would say this place is the same as the other places. There's usually a line here that will take around 30 minutes so be prepared to wait. It's not a short 15 minute coffee break with Blue Bottle.

What's there not to like? Individual dripped coffee and very well made espresso based coffee. There's no way you can go wrong here. The prices are more expensive than other coffee places, but it is definitely worth the price! Blue Bottle is hands down one of the best coffee places in SF!
author: Steven B.

description: Amazing Lattes and New Orleans Iced Coffee here (even a fancy leaf on top)!!  Always a big line, so you know it's good!  Only downside is not a lot of seating - the embarcadero location in the ferry building has wifi nearby at least :)
author: Ubz D.

description: Came at a good time, so the line was short. I have a Cafe Mocha and it was extremely good! Only con is that the tables are really close together, but other than that I recommend this place!
author: Emily N.

description: This quickly became one of my favourite coffee shops in SF. My hotel was close by and I had heard great things about it so I went to give it a try. The place is packed in the morning! My friend used Square Order to skip the lines but there were plenty of people braving the line for their coffee fix. Their coffee and lattes are strong, rich and flavourful. Only downside was how packed the place was but I came back in the evening and it was less busy and was actually able to find a place to work. Delicious coffee, beautiful laid back decor, and a great alternative to Starbucks.
author: Jen H.

description: Hands down one of the best coffee I've had so far! I see myself coming back often. My group of 5 tried their Latte, Mocha, Macchiato, Cappuccino, New Orleans Ice Coffee and all were very good. We also ordered their Egg Benedict, Cinnamon French toast and Belgian Style Waffles. The Egg Benedict's are so addictive and the Waffles are so soft and fluffy even after they have cooled down.
author: Jeanette T.

description: Best coffee in San Fran and great Egg & Bacon on a Brioche Bun. Visited twice in our 3 days stay in SF.
author: Sally S.

description: Awesome coffee! Just a little on the pricey side and a bit of wait as it is usually quite busy and not so easy to find a table.
author: Snowdrops C.

description:
I've been to Blue Bottle twice - once at this location, and once somewhere else in SF. There was a line out the door both times, but I don't feel like I had to wait too long. The coffee is WORTH IT! (and I'm from Seattle.) The locations are gorgeous too. 

If you like milky iced coffee, get the New Orleans style cold brew. I don't like these types of drinks to be too sweet -- if I can't taste the coffee then it's no good. This one was made perfectly both times.
author: Bonnie F.

description:
The closest thing to a 'real' coffee (read: Australian coffee) we have found since moving here. 

What we would call a flat white is their cappucino.  And it is pretty damned good: nice roast, served at the perfect temperature, not too much froth (what is with that over here?).

Only complaints: not serving cooked food before 9am on a Saturday! 
Also, just making one cup at a time, and incredibly slowly at that, seems a waste of (customers') time. There is a reason they invented 2 cup spouts for espresso machines!
author: BIGBOB K.

description:
Taste of San Francisco.
It's a must try if you like that kind of rich flavor,
author: Cecelia W.

description:
Great quality and the best coffee shop in SF. 

Great atmosphere with very friendly staff as well. Perfect for a quick cup!
author: Greg R.

description:
Cute coffee shop - I loved watching all the baristas work their magic with their unique brewing systems. It's a must-go if you're ever in the area.

I ordered a cafe au lait and it was smooth and strong but not overpowering. The lineups are always long so I sometimes have to resort to buying their iced coffee from whole foods (which is also delicious).

I'll need to come back to try out their brunch but from the pictures and from what I smelt in the cafe, it should be delicious!
author: Brenda C.

description:
Awesome coffee. Super nice baristas.

They serve espressos as God dreamt them to be served.
author: Paulo K.

description: Located in a perfect spot, this is the place where I would love sit all day. Mostly, I order Macchiato and grape perfectly paired.
author: Lillian D.

description:
To sum it up: Good coffee
Returnability: Every month
Superstar Factor: This A-list actor has some gritty, indie cred and is enjoyable to watch

You're gonna get decent coffee. This place is a great first stop if you're looking to start taking a few steps off the Starbucks path. Great space, nice baristas (when you consider most of the assholes that work in this City), and a good caffeine buzz.
author: Jess C.

description: I'm not much of a coffee drinker but my friend wanted to come try this place out. It was a bit hidden but extremely close to the Westfield Mall. The New Orleans iced coffee was perfect for the hot day with the perfect amount of sweetness and was smooth. The service is quick and though it could be considered a bit on the pricier side, you are getting your money's worth. My friend said she loved her New Orleans iced coffee but had wished that there was more. They have stools that you can sit on to chat with your friends. It's worth a visit if you love coffee and want to try something that isn't Peets or Starbucks.
author: Olivia C.

description:
OF COURSE THERE'S A LINE. Srsly? It's popular AND one of the best coffees anywhere.

Adorable coffee nook interrupting the traffic flow on an adorable little side street. There's not much to say here that hasn't already been said. Maybe, if you come here for the first time and you've never been to a craft coffee shop, come with a friend who has. It's just crazing confusing if you're not a straight cappuccino or latte drinker.
author: Mari H.

description:
This place is decent, but I think a little overrated.  All the coffee drinks are good, and pretty to look at.  The food is presented nicely as well.  However...

My daughter's french toast was done poorly twice.  The first time, I sliced into it, and it was completely undercooked.  We're talking runny raw eggs in the middle of the bread.  Salmonella anyone?  I'm glad I didn't feed it to my 2-year old yet.  The problem was that the toast was so thick, it didn't cook through.  I sent it back, and the second time, they overcooked it.  They barely dipped it in the egg and then they burnt it, probably out of spite, since I said it was undercooked the first time.  It was dry as heck.  But I wasn't about to send it back again.

The eggs benedict looked gorgeous, but my egg was a little overcooked for a benedict.  Usually you expect the yolk to be runny, but this was only slightly runny, with most of the yolk being solid.  Somebody needs to check on their quality control!

Wait staff was very friendly and very accomodating, considering we were in a party of 10, with 4 children.

I think with the LOOONG wait, and the lack of seating, this dining experience was not really worth it.
author: Emily J.

description:
I'm older and wiser. I know now that "iced lattes" are not a thing that need to be consumed. I respect the craft. 

I also respect poached eggs on toast, which is the game-changer at this Blue Bottle. 

The line is still wack, however.
author: Maria D.

description: Pleasently surprised by Blue Bottle at this location! We ordered a Kenya on Syphon and a Nel. The barista Heather spent a good 15-20 minutes with us explaining the process and reason for doing things the way they do. Place was jam packed, line out door and yet we received her full attention, very impressed. We did not eat food but it looked delicious!
author: Julia P.

description:
I am definitely no coffee connoisseur, but the coffee here was pretttty darn good! 

I've only tried the New Orleans Iced Coffee, and it was a good cup of coffee. Only one size, $4. I got mine with soymilk :D

If you are familiar with Phil'z Coffee, I would say that the iced coffee w/milk here is much creamier& a little sweeter than Phil'z. 

The plaza/alley that this location is located in is pretty nice and quiet. There was still a line to wait in, even around 02PM in the afternoon. The setup of the shop is nice and simple. Not exactly rooomy though ... so I don't think this is a coffee shop to be studying at.

They also serve some lunch items here, but the prices seem kinda high for what they offer.
author: Ashley N.

description:
Is love at first sip a thing? Because I think it happened to me.

Although there was much talk about the New Orleans Iced Coffee, I decided to go for my usual Iced Americano because I'm not a huge fan of sweetened coffee. After ordering it, I wasn't sure if I'd be happy with my decision but upon receiving my drink, I finally understood why everyone loves Blue Bottle. 

The place itself is also very pleasant with a clean, minimalistic interior. The workers were friendly as well and helped me choose some coffee beans to go which I am satisfied with. I fear the day I run out because I know I will feel the full effects of Blue Bottle withdrawal....
author: Jaimie L.

description: Yeah I know, I'm gonna get tomatoes thrown at me. My order was a simple mocha latte. It was somewhat watered down, not much of huge flavor. I could have gone to Starbucks for this type of coffee! The lines are long, which tells me that its reputation is great, but maybe it was the hype that I had huge expectations. I can't say that I won't come here again, as it is very close to my job for a quick cup of coffee but not if I'm trying to sneak away for a little bit due to the long lines.
author: Sharon B.

description: Just tried this place for the first time. Ordered the New Orleans and also tried the affogato. So delicious and worth waiting in line :D
author: Nacine B.

description:
Was guided to this location by a friend because we had to meet some people at Westfield Mall. Didn't know this place was here and probably would've gotten lost to get to this location because it's a bit off the main path. Parking here also REALLY sucks since it's downtown. You'd have better luck parking at the paid lots nearby than finding street metered parking. We were lucky and came when there was only about 3 people in line, so the wait wasn't bad.

I had the caffe mocha but it was a bit watered down. They have a more extensive menu at this location. Hope to come back to try some of the food items!
author: Kitty K.

description:
TLDR:
- Round brew that features an accessible palette of flavors.
- Not as inspired as other 3rd-wave coffee competitors in the bay.
author: Christopher L.

description:
As pretentious as coffee gets, but quite good! The place clearly takes their coffee seriously...it results in great taste. My latte was sweet and smooth.

The line was long, but the wait was worth it.
author: Drake L.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is the best coffee I have ever had. Seriously. Ever. For Real.

Their roast is the most perfect. It is strong and delicate at the same time. They have a no-nonsense menu. If you go to coffee shops to order drinks that are not coffee or want something flavored like toffee, Blue Bottle may not be for you. However, they still have novelty items on their drink menu like New Orleans style iced coffee with chicory, artisan mochas, and a special Kyoto style espresso shot that runs itself through a system that comes straight out of Willy Wonka's factory. They have a simple pastry selection, which includes made-to-order $3 waffles.

I pulled up a recent Travel & Leisure "Best coffee in America" list and was surprised to see that Seattle  was not on the list, while San Francisco/Oakland was. Blue Bottle was why! If you are a coffee purist looking to be impressed in the Bay Area, you need to get yourself to Blue Bottle.
author: K M.

description:
I cheated on Starbucks for you... and it felt GOOOOD.

I love the smell of coffee, but it smells extra good at Blue Bottle. It's like a teaser as you wait in the line they probably always have. 

I went for their New Orleans style iced coffee. It's just the right amount of coffee to sweetness. Totally refreshing. Strong without being overpowering. It's the pick me up you need if you're missing something from your day. 

I wish there was a Blue Bottle around where I lived. I would be a Blue Bottle addict! For now, the Blue Bottle coffee gelato bar at Whole Foods will have to hold me over until they open a store here. =P
author: Daisy T.

description:
My SIL was visiting us for the weekend so we decided on a trip of gluttony in SF for one of the days. We started out with Blue Bottle Coffee since she's a coffee drinker. Hubsters was nice enough to sit and babysit his car outside since parking was a pain in the arse. We stood in line for a good 20 minutes before we could order our drinks. 

Since I don't regularly worship caffeine, I opted for the hot chocolate. SIL ordered the New Orleans... 

The drinks were AMAZING. Hot chocolate was flavored with luscious thick chocolate ganache and her coffee was right on par. 

Life was good.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Disclaimer: I'm probably one of the worst people to be writing reviews about coffee.  They all kind of taste about the same to me...somewhat.

With that said, I was totally looking forward to Blue Bottle since I heard a lot of Nor Cal folks rave about it.  I thought that going at a random post-lunch hour would mean no crowd, but I was wrong.  The line was out the door, with me being the last person who was able to stand in line inside the tiiiiny coffee shop.  

I got a tiny cup of joe for a pretty penny and was done with it in minutes because the cup consisted mostly of ice.  I think I really liked Blue Bottle more when I had it from The Drip Cart in Echo Park in LA.

Anyway, I did notice that BB doesn't taste burnt like Sbucks, but the brew I had just didn't make me crave it like when I had it in LA.  Maybe the novelty wore off or maybe I wasn't as thirsty as I was when I was in LA.
author: May W.

description:
Admittedly I'm no coffee connoisseur, but I know I can't be alone in my usage of coffee/coffee breaks to a) be social, b) prescriptively wake up, or c) as an alternative to eating a cookie or an ice cream cone. 

Blue Bottle is *great* for all of these things.

a) This location is very well set up for people watching. All of the businesses chairs oriented such that they look out at Mint Plaza (where there are frequently interesting goings ons) or the line of coffee-orderers (who often have some level of exchange with the barista staff). There's also guaranteed to be some line/slowness of service so you can hang out for awhile.

b) Well, it is caffeine.

c) If it weren't for the somewhat surly service I'd give this place five stars just for the mocha. I LOVE a coffee that integrates great chocolate and there are none better than the Blue Bottle and Tcho combination.

So, go, people watch, hang out and drink up that sweet dessert bevo.
author: Stephanie T.

description: If you are a coffee snob and haven't been here, well you are missing out on some world-class brew.  I had the Ethiopian done Siphon style.  So good!  Super nice and knowledgeable staff too.  It will be missed.
author: Prince M.

description: Ordered a cappuccino and a breakfast sandwich.  Tasted great!  I would give it a 5 star but deduct one for the price.  It's kind of pricy to spend $18 for a breakfast.
author: Angela L.

description:
8/13/13 

Ive had Blue Bottle Coffee before  from Danville's Sideboard. However everyone told me it was better here. So on this day when i was running some errands i decided to come to what SF considers as "crack coffee". I have to stay the location is in a very sketchy area and tucked away in a corner. When i arrived the line was out the door. After 20 minutes wait I ordered an ice coffee with cream and i have to say it was the best coffee i have ever had. The art work on the coffee was also extremely pretty. Theres just something they do different here that makes the coffee sensationable. Every time im in the area i always pick up a cup. Do note they do serve food here but its not worth the price.
author: Andrew W.

description:
Hidden gem of SoMa!

Cappuccino is tops and this location is in a very inconspicuous corner between 6th and 5th ..

Staff friendly and ambiance nice
author: Nelce S.

description: First time trying blue bottle coffee co. And I got their caffe latte for drinks. Waffle and eggs Benedict for food. It was very yummy. Someone took my latte twice so I had to wait a little bit. I got coffee mugged!! But the lady gave me a free cookie (snicker doodle) and it was very yummy! Thanks blue bottle coffee. I'll come back when I visit SF again.
author: Eunice P.

description: I like hot chocolate made with actual chocolate.  Was a bit difficult to find and there was a line but my hot chocolate was good.
author: Rena A.

description:
For coffee quality Blue Bottle gets 5 stars from me.

I am deducting a star because my favorite kind of coffee shop is the kind where you can sit in a big cozy leather chair for hours reading while you sip your drink...

That is not what Blue Bottle is - it's a different kind of coffee shop but I still love it. 

My favorite drink here is the New Orleans Iced Coffee and if you've got some dollars to spare the ginger cookie is he best cookie I've ever had... 

Enjoy!
author: Alex W.

description:
Dear blue bottle,

Please improve your assembly line.  It would greatly help if you had one employee manning the register, one making espresso drinks, and one taking care of all iced, dripped and food items as this would be the most optimal way to deal with long lines.

Not: stopping in the middle of taking a $20 bill to pour artsy foam on a latte, then forget how much you entered previously into the register, then give the wrong change back.  Not: skipping handing out the iced coffee first because there was an order of 5 espresso drinks ahead, while the ice melts senselessly in the cup next to the steam out of the espresso machine.  If you have one person dedicated to taking money, you would have all the drinks paid for and handed out based on what is ready to go, instead of insisting on the order in line in fear of missing anyone paying.
Not: hipster baristas with unwashed hair chatting and doing nothing behind the counter while the line coils out around the block.  If you're on your break, go chill outside instead of distracting your coworkers as well as infuriating customers with your idleness!

You implemented square, hire multiple employees for each location, and provide self water station.  So my assumption is that you do care about efficiency.  So why not go for it all the way?  

Sincerely, 
Fan of your coffee, not your service
author: Jiajia C.

description: Best coffee place for an affogato. Not everyone knows how to properly prepare one, but these folks always get it right.
author: John S.

description:
Line is rarely never out the door... get used to waiting in the cold with everyone else ;)  Customers are friendly.  Pretty siphons to look at on the inside.  I guess they serve food here now which I wasn't aware of before and I don't see a menu for it.  There are some good snacks here INCLUDING..... the SNICKERDOODLE cookies made with REAL vanilla bean.  MMmmmmmMMM.  They also have a coffee with a scoop of ice cream in it if that sounds like something you're interested in.  I get the hot chocolate usually as  I am not a coffee drinker.  And of course, the designs in your drinks are enough to make you check it out... thats besides the amaze-ing coffee.  

Oh, there is a parking lot up the block if parking is scarce.  And don't park on the side of the building right in front.  You will get your car towed if a police car comes by and they won't let you intervene.  Important things to know!  Yeah!
author: Christine K.

description:
I don't see what the big deal is. Plain drip coffee was very lackluster for $2.75. Maybe their extra-fancy stuff is better, but I wasn't willing to pay $7-12 for coffee to find out. For pricey made-to-order drip coffee, I would go to Philz instead. At least there I feel it's worth the price. 

We did not actually eat the brunch (ended at 2 PM), but we got to see the menu as they were just taking last orders when we arrived. Rather expensive ($5 for toast??) and apparently the only style of eggs they believe in is poached.

Husband said he enjoyed his iced New Orleans ($4), but they didn't have any straws (!). One of our party was so disgusted with the taste of her hot chocolate that she sent it back.

Outdoor seating is limited, only 3 tables for 2 people each. Indoors was crowded, very loud, too warm, and the arrangement of the furniture made it impossible for 4 of us to sit together.

No wi-fi is a big minus.
author: Lisa H.

description:
There's such a strong coffee culture in SF that it makes us a little jealous now that we are back home in Chicago. Blue Bottle Coffee Co does it right in every way with its excellent concept and execution at its espresso spots and arguably offers the best coffee in SF. 

The siphon coffee is only available at this Mint Plaza. They have espresso drinks such as latte or cafe au lait, but orders for siphon coffee are prepared by one employee whose sole duty is to siphon the coffee. Sure was interesting to see the funky-looking siphon apparatus that makes coffee seem like an exciting scientific process in itself.

This location features an industrial space with high ceilings and a communal table which we really liked. We were there early on a weekday morning and a long line gradually formed with people stopping by to grab coffee on the way to work.
author: Teri Y.

description:
I had their New Orleans iced coffee and yes it was very delicious gave me a nice jolt. lol
But it wasn't mind blowing honestly....I tried it to try it b/c I heard it was an amazing coffee shop. Next time I'll have a latte or something.
author: Diana P.

description:
I really liked their cool lil hidden shop vibe, and their new orleans iced coffee.

the ginger molasses cookie was also pretty tight.  

smaller line than at four barrel!
author: Kate W.

description:
It took me weeks to say this out loud: I don't like Blue Bottle.  There, I admitted it!  

I really don't see what the big deal is.  Sure, it's better than Starbucks, but it's definitely not worth the ridiculous price.  An iced coffee will cost you about $4.  I'm sorry, that's just not appropriate.  The coffee is also super strong and bitter. And the staff isn't very friendly.  

The cafe is very gorgeous and has outside seating.  I work right across the street from  it and see people going to and from every day.  I dunno, maybe it's just me.  But I still prefer Verve Coffee any day of the week.
author: Rose D.

description: My uncle brought me here saying its a San Fran must. The way they brew their coffee is a very different, much slower process, but as my uncle puts it "it all makes a difference" the cafe itself is very hip, it's crowded but there is space to relax and chat. I just got a hot chocolate, probably the best I've ever had-very rich and creamy. Due to the long line it's not somewhere I would get coffee regularly but definitely great for a tourist!
author: Michelle K.

description: This place is a coffee experience!! Very modern feel inside ! They have some strong coffee!! It sure packs a punch! Also they do cold drip coffee there where they slowly drip cold water on the coffee grinds leaving an extremely strong smooth coffee with ALOT of caffeine! You want a wake up call? That will do it!
author: Brianna L.

description: This is one of the best cups of coffee I've ever had. They take their time brewing, and the effort shows. I also had oatmeal with butter and brown sugar. Outstanding, which it needed to be given the price. The butter alone was worth it. I'm not proud of my actions, but I ended up eating some of the butter like a little kid would do. Highest possible recommendation.
author: Ed S.

description:
This is the go-to place for coffee and coffee addicts. Located in Mint Plaza it's a decent sized spot for a coffee shop with Wi-Fi and bar-style seating to meet or do some work while drinking your coffee. 

Only thing is good spots attract good amounts of people and this is no exception! Beware of lines but the coffee really is the best.

If you want a snack they also offer baguette sandwiches, pastries, and pretzels.
author: Allison R.

description:
Love this place. I work nearby and the staff is consistently friendly to everyone. 

A lot of tourists pass through and always have questions about coffee or some of the other items they sell. Staff is always greeting them with smiles and being insightful. 

Food is limited in selection but is made fresh and right in front of you. It's delicious and a must stop if you're traveling through SF.
author: D M.

description: Love this location!! Obviously the coffee is great because it's blue bottle. This location is in a cute little square/alley? But v nice ambience etc. when it's a sunny day in the city
author: Vishal B.

description:
On a recent stay in SF for the ACS National Meeting, Blue Bottle was my first stop on my way into the morning talks.  A cup of Kyoto iced coffee and a double chocolate cookie got my mornings started off right!

If I had time, I would have chilled here for a bit, the interior is very modern and an oasis in the midst of the downtown SF hustle and bustle.

However, subsequent mornings, they were out of the Kyoto, so I resorted to the slightly higher priced alternative iced coffee.  For this I deduct one star.
author: Daniel T.

description:
Coffee: the gibralter which always makes me think gargoyles for some reason (the cartoon anyone?), and the new orleans ice. take note, they don't make the gibs to go. 

Food to pair: their snicker doodle, a biscotti, or if you're early and lucky, their delicious breakfast. 

Beans: I like big bold coffee so I went for Giant Steps first and later their Bella Donovan. Giant Steps is, as the name implies, big and bold. Bella was creamier, lighter, and had a touch of vanilla flavor. Sooo good. 

Blue bottle isn't just a fad, it holds true to it's reputation. I don't need to claim I'll be back, I'm already a regular.
author: Alesia T.

description:
I remember the days when we europeans visiting the US had to live with coffee out of a glass jug that has been sitting on a stove for hours.
Compared to those memorable times this place is from another universe.
Italians don't even make better coffee.
The italian way of enjoying a quick "Cafe" is impossible at BBC though since you have to stand in line for at least five to ten minutes.
I still love that place! 
Thx guys for your devotion to a wonderful product
author: Andre G.

description: Place is BEYOND AMAZING. Line is always long, but it's worth the wait. If you're in a rush, tell whoever's waiting to wait longer because you're about to taste heaven. I'm serious. Blue bottle coffee puts coffee on a different level. I can't even put Starbucks, Peets, and Coffee Bean in competition with BBC. I'd say places like Stumptown, Verve, Temple, Intelligentsia, and Forge is probably in competition, but even then BBC is the BEST!
author: Gabriel C.

description:
Mmmm! I love me a fine cup of coffee, and this was one of the finest. Their Bella Donovan blend is smooth and complex with a great after taste. I enjoyed it so much that we stopped by another one of their store in the afternoon and got another. My wife and I got some crazy concoction of vanilla ice cream with espresso poured over it and they were raving about it.
I shall return.
author: Scott H.

description: I had been looking forward to trying their coffee. Unfortunately,  I arrived at one of their peak morning hours. They had a line wrapped around the building. Fortunately they have a permanent tent set up ready for pour overs and iced coffee. I wanted a pour over but the poor barista was slammed. I got a cold coffee since it was quicker. The coffee was just okay. I would return again for a pour over.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Went there on a recent sunny afternoon for a pick me up.  I got the NOLA Iced Coffee.  Overrated, but pretty good.  A little too sweet for me.  Drinks seemed expensive for the quality.
The crowd was trendy and snobbish, so it may be good for you if you're trying to "keep up with the Joneses."  Customer service was excellent.
author: Neil S.

description:
I've been in Seattle the last two years - we have good coffee here. So of course I'd stop by Blue Bottle, after hearing it lauded so much by people. In fact, this was my second taste of Blue Bottle, with the first time being at Dash Cafe over in Inner Sunset, several months prior. I wasn't impressed then, and figured I'd give them another shot, on the off-chance that it was the cafe's fault.

But no, this was not the case. At Dash Cafe, I had ordered a New Orleans iced coffee. Here, I tried a Kyoto iced coffee. And you know what? Both had the same issue of being incredibly sour coffee - enough so that I threw away both drinks after forcing myself to finish half. Being at the actual store this time, I asked the baristas about it, and was told that their current batch of beans comes from a region where the beans are known to have sour notes. So, it's not an issue in the process, but with the raw materials itself. While I know there are some who appreciate sour coffee, I myself am not one of them. 

I'll stick to other coffee shops like Philz when I move back to the city. That way, I won't find myself waiting in line for a a painful 30 minutes, for a cup of sour coffee.
author: Johnny W.

description:
While not a "sit down and get waited on" kinda restaurant, you will have a great brunch here! We waited in line for approximately 45+ minutes outside in a line that wrapped around the building, but I'm not going to complain about that because the place is just really popular. It's not their fault.

Anyway, this was a one time thing for us. Sort of a bucket list item to eat there. We really enjoyed the food and coffee. 4/5 stars.
author: Eric B.

description:
Blue Bottle has really great coffee...but I am not either enough of a connoisseur or a South of Market hipster to wait 20 minutes in line and 15 more for my coffee in the middle of the day when I need to get back to work.  And to make matters worse, the place has the gall to tell me that I can't get the coffee to go because it is served in a Japanese contraption and "needs to cool because it is piping hot."  But that's okay, because the barista suggested I smell the coffee as it cooled.   I find such a process to be obnoxious.  What's the big deal about serving me my coffee in a to-go cup IF I WANT IT THAT WAY?  I already paid around $7 for the coffee!  And why would you serve coffee that is so hot it is not drinkable for five minutes?  The pretension is over-the-top.  It's coffee, not caviar. 

If the atmosphere was less hipster/pretentious and the lines were shorter, I'd be here every day.  I'd get my coffee and my acme bread and I'd love it.  Somehow I think that won't ever happen.
author: Anon M.

description: I'm trying to determine the hype with this coffee shop and coffee. I've heard good things but it's pretty expensive coffee with a crowded shop("excuse me, pardon me"). I got a cup and a bag of Three Africans roast. It may be for other folks but for me, this is not a 'go to' coffee...
author: Chris A.

description: I stopped by here this afternoon to try the coffee a friend had raved about.  After my first sip of the drip coffee of the day, I started raving myself.  Each cup is individually crafted, and it shows in the results.  I am proud of the French press coffee I brew at home, but this was clearly a cut above.  The crowd seems to ebb and flow, and luckily we arrived when the line was relatively short; if you arrive at the wrong time, be prepared to wait.
author: Robert M.

description:
Love love love their New Orleans coffee. I don't even drink coffee, but my friend suggested me to and I loved it!! Will go back even just for the coffee. 

Super clean and compact place. It can get crowded during the weekends, but it's okay. 

For brunch, I had the New Orleans coffee and the Poached eggs on acme bread with tomato purée. So delicious! The bread is amazing. Highly recommend this dish.
author: Sue K.

description: Amazing coffee in the heart of San Fran. If you're an Aussie looking for good coffee- check it out!
author: Kimberley C.

description: I am in love love love with this place. Best coffee I have ever had. Boyfriend and I had a latte that just melted into my mouth. In addition, I also got the Kyoto.......no additions needed....and I am from the SOUTH. The food here is pretty neat too. However, their all star is their coffee OF COURSE. what tops this off is the people that work here. They have some serious passion and knowledge about coffee. This isn't just some college school kids trying to make a buck and counting down their hours they have for work, no they are good, they are friendly, they are fast. My order was missed and they were so kind about it. LOVE LOVE LOVE them. warnings: a little hard to find, but think of it like a treasure hunt. Totally worth it.
author: Angel L.

description:
If you are going to SF and you want good coffee , this is your destination. Good quality, fair trade , nice people, cool hipster atmosphere.
I am all about nice coffeeshop and bookmarked this place long ago. 
And now i am really happy that i got to go there, and will go back whenever i am in town.
author: Sepide S.

description:
Been here a million times...big fan of their coffee and the brunch food.

Recently, it seems as though some changes have been made. Gone are the line around the block and the slow-as-molasses hipster baristas who both take your order and make your latte. In it's place is an efficient setup (register in front with a half wall to keep people in queue) that is much more akin to a Starbucks, complete with baristas yelling out customer names as they complete an order.  Whatever the reason behind this, it's a nice change.

However, the quality of the coffee seems to have lost a little something on my most recent visits.  Basic lattes seemed overly milk and not the right temperature. Hopefully just a random occurrence and not a sign that this place is going downhill.

Still one of my favorite coffee spots in SF.
author: JOHN C.

description:
Don't be a lil' bitch. Wait in the line.

The baristas are efficient. The menu is light and to the point. The coffee hits your lips and you're all like, "Yeah, today is going to be alright."

New Orleans Iced Coffee was where it was at for this girl 'cause I'm a little sweet, a little creamy and always ready to get things up and moving. You bet. *High five*
author: Katie C.

description: Great atmosphere! Try the New Orleans Iced Coffee and the waffle!
author: Sheila L.

description: Blue Bottle is classic. The coffee is incredible but I love the coffee contraption in the back- so cool!
author: Suphada R.

description:
New Orleans ice coffee lives up to the hype!

I was so excited to try Blue Bottle Coffee Co because I had heard so many great things about this place. Walking up to the location, I knew I was in for a treat because there was a lite of about 10 people waiting just for coffee! I noticed that they also serve brunch so the next day, I knew I had to stop by once again. I had their new orleans ice coffee both days and my cousin had the soy latte on the first day and the syphon coffee the second. She loved the soy latte but felt that the syphon was a little too strong for her liking. For brunch, we ordered their famous belgian waffles. They were so light and fluffy! Their egg dishes also looked scrumptious but we were so full. As a non-coffee drinker, I can say that I am so obsessed with Blue bottle coffee, their decor, their baristas, their new orleans ice coffee and their waffles that I cannot wait to come back to SF and add this to my morning routine. Everyone is so friendly here and I cannot say enough good things about this coffee shop.
author: Marvel Z.

description: A hidden gem in the unlikeliest of locations. The latte was great. Beautiful setting. Quirky, nice staff. YAY!
author: Andrew K.

description:
For those people who gave this place bad reviews: Yes, the line can get long (you must wait for the best things in line), yes it is in the higher end price wise - but please, don't compare it to Starbucks. This place belongs in a different category. 

I am a coffee connoisseur. This is shade grown, organic, single origin, well sorted, evenly roasted coffee. Excellent beans. The brewing process is unique as it is entertaining. It brings the full body, intense yet smooth flavor of coffee without the acidity. Your are tasting the true essence of the coffee bean. 

The food is pretty good as well, and seems to be changing constantly. 

Still, I respect people have different tastes. If you are craving a triple mocha vanilla crapuchino with whipped cream then Starbucks will probably be best for you. For those who enjoy the flavorful experience of french press coffee, you must check out Blue Bottle.
author: Gerardo D.

description: BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE SOOTHES THE SOUL. The location of this Blue Bottle was difficult to find. It's in a rather random alley square thing near the Westfield mall, but it's always crowded. The line is always out the door. This Blue Bottle is cute though. The open windows really make it a nice, calming coffee place to chill at. That is... if you can find a seat. It really is crowded. Don't bump into someone and spill your coffee! The display of coffee making utensils is nice decor to see as well! And the service is niceeeeeee!
author: Kim N.

description:
A lil challenging to find this place but it's behind a big building on mint plaza when you're coming in from  5th st.
There's a good amount of seats inside. It's your typical coffee shop size I guess. Definitely bigger than what I assume was their main headquarters in Oakland. We went there a couple of days after. It was a small section for ordering and a tiny bar seating area inside. About 3 or 4 outdoor tables. The other half of the inside was a bunch of coffee laid out on long tables where the workers were tasting them.
I had such high expectations of this place coz of what I heard of it. I got my usual drink of choice...a latte. Unfortunately, I forgot to mention I want non-fat milk. Probably wouldn't have made too much of a difference but I didn't think it was that great. The design on the top was so pretty tho.
author: Avril N.

description: Their coffee is great and has a very unique flavor and very unlike any other coffee I have ever tried. I was pleasantly surprised at how robust the Kyoto was, and wanted to trade my affogato for my bfs kyoto! Haha! They have this huge contraption that makes the concentrated kyoto, which is reminiscent of those old chinese siphon filters for coffee. It's funny since my expectations for this place was lowered since the people that I talked to didn't seem to rave about it as much, but these people aren't coffee conniseurs so what was I thinking? This place is hipster central and there was even a food truck parked outside. The servers were very friendly and seemed genuine and loved what they were doing.  I kind of wished we had blue bottle in socal. I would definitely visit this place again and again!
author: Will T.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee, I love you! 

My friend and I were craving something cold and delicious, so we Yelped for a place around Union Square. We thought we'd come across mediocre places since it's a rather touristy area.. however, we were pleasantly surprised to find Blue Bottle! It's hidden and tucked away near the Old Mint building. It's not marked, but has the Blue Bottle logo on the front. With open windows and bar seating, this is the perfect place to enjoy some iced cold coffee and snickerdoodle. I got the New Orleans iced coffee, which has just the right amount of sweetness and cream.
author: Cassy H.

description: I tried the cappuccino, unfortunately it was too strong for me. Good service not opposed to going back, just have to find the right blend for me.
author: Irene C.

description:
I'm a converted believer. The coffee is truly superior. It's beautiful black and still stunning mixed with a splash cream and a dash of sugar. As Liz C. said, Blue Bottle Coffee is an experience for all the senses.

And the waffles are pure carbolicious heaven. Perfectly fluffy and warm with a creamy swirl of butter and mini pitcher of syrup.

I may not have been offered the job I interviewed for a few weeks ago just across from Blue Bottle Coffee in Mint Plaza post said enlightening coffee and waffle experience, but I'll be back. I think I'm addicted.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
Good atmosphere, great food, and a great cup of coffee. I had the house coffee & a Belgium Waffle which gave me a nice start to the day. It was so good that it didn't need syrup. So ono!
Apart from the food, they employ a siphon style means of brewing coffee; rare in the states I am told. It's fascinating to watch. 
Definitely worth a stop while in the city.
author: Daniel B.

description:
Got my sister to come here with me since I love to drink coffee. Read a lot of good reviews and saw the fancy Siphon pictures. So, we decided to try it out. We had the New Orleans iced coffee and a small Siphon of the African coffee. The iced coffee is ok. The coffee in the Siphon is watery. Disappointing. $7, right? Thought it's super special, but it's not worth it. Also had the Popeye Eggs. Disappointed that one of the eggs was super overcooked. The staff delivering the order was nice. He explained the coffee and Siphon since he asked if it's our first time there. Of course, we said yes :) For the cashier, she didn't even say a word after I tipped her 15% on Square. I could have chosen 'No Tip.' $25 breakfast order (+tip), yo. Not a 'thank you'?
Anyways, won't be going back. Don't like the location, cashier, and price. The coffee in the Siphon is nothing special unless you are there to admire the coffee equipment.
author: Ervi L.

description:
In case you didn't realize that I love Blue Bottle Coffee... I guess I should give a review to where I first discovered this beautiful awesomeness.

This SF location might be my favorite of the SF locations + well generally Blue Bottle Coffee locations. I love that it's tucked away, but the light in this area is always super gorgeous. There is also plenty of seating, just as long as you're open to cozying up to people, saying hello and enjoying a solid cup of coffee.

Again, the coffee here is probably my favorite. I don't think that I've had a bad cup here, and the baristas are always up to listen to my feelings for the day before making some recommendations. 

That's probably the best part of this place. The baristas and staff generally are very helpful, and while people have indicated lines in their reviews, I have dealt with longer lines and nastier people at Starbucks. Here, I feel all the warmth from the staff, who actually keep the place going pretty smoothly. Love!
author: Lala L.

description:
What a novel concept this siphon coffee! O_O WOOOOoooooooow! My brother told me about this place and we had to make a stop before we left San Fran. 

The whole siphon experience seemed a bit like being in apothecary, you have this round flasks bubbling away drawing hot water up to another container where finely ground beans were mixed in. Then as it was pulled away from the heat, the coffee was filtered back down to its flask. Eh don't know if that was a good description, but I guess you can search YouTube for a video of the process. (Kinda like a reverse French Press? ) Very unique and handsomely served I think it is well worth the price in taste and quality. Each order is individually made! 

Fun to watch, beauty in it's simplicity. Well filtered there is no sediment in the bottom of the flask, so smooth for coffee. Do recommend the Kyoto Iced Coffee that's made very, very slowly in this dripping contraption that screams SCIENCE!
author: Karen C.

description:
The coffee? Excellent as hell.

As a Minneapolitan, I feel lucky to be well-versed in "third wave" coffee shops. The kind that never burn the beans or the brews. The kind that take a few extra moments to do a perfect pour-over cup with some fun gadgets. The kind that make you into a coffee snob. 

Blue Bottle is an SF chain that feels nothing like a Starbucks. It feels third wave.

I actually tried to come here on a Sunday afternoon, the line was around the block so I turned right around. However, come Friday I was glad that Misti Y and I had some time before our flights to grab lunch and coffee here. We lucked out and there was no line!

I went with an absolutely smooth and strong Kyoto cold press and the mixed green salad (baby greens, blood oranges, carrots, turnips, artichokes and a sherry vinegar dressing). I wanted to add some protein to the salad, so I asked if they could make some bacon to put on it too. They were a little hesitant about this for some reason and had to "check with the chef" who was standing just three feet away so the whole thing just felt kind of awkward. They charged me a bunch of extra dollars for the bacon and it wasn't all that great... so joke on me I guess. The salad itself was terrific though. Blood oranges make everything amazing.

It's not a sit-and-get-work-done-and-siphon-free-WiFi cafe, so don't bring your laptop. The space is gorgeous, very sunny and tucked back from the Financial District buzz.
author: Annie D.

description:
My first taste of San Francisco.  Worth the wait.

I recently made my first trek to SF this past weekend.  I ate here around 10am on a Saturday.  It's sort of tucked away in an alley, which I liked, because you did not have to deal with the hustle and bustle of Market Street.

The line was out the door, but moved fairly quickly.  I ordered the Poached Eggs on Cornbread with sausage (A MUST TRY!!) along with a mocha and bread with jam.  I think the total was around $25?  The eggs were absolutely delicious.  I never thought of having eggs with cornbread: great concept!  Also, make sure you try the toast with jam.  I mean, it may sound silly, but it was the best toast with jam I've ever had.

The only downside was the wait FOR the food.  After ordering, I had to wait almost 30 minutes before being served.  I noticed that the kitchen is very tiny, and it appeared there were only 2 burners on a stove?  I kind of felt bad for the cooks/preparers, because there is no room to cook.  It reminded me of trying to cook in a kitchenette.

This was definitely the best meal I had while in San Francisco.  If you have an hour or so for breakfast/brunch and are staying near Union Square, I would recommend trying Blue Bottle. I am fortunate that I chose this restaurant to start off what was an amazing weekend in an amazing city!
author: Jammy S.

description:
Over the years of late nights doing homework and early mornings rushing to class to A's calculus exams I've become a coffee snob/addict....

So when girls are like I love startsucks I remember most people don't taste their coffee after adding a gallop of cream and a few spoonfuls of sugar. 

While I'm one of those fools who likes purity thus drinks my coffee back as night. So when my other coffee snob friend showed me this amazing coffee shop my world became much more wired in the best tasting way possible. 

They care about how there coffee taste! therefore making the best expresso I've ever had; and one dark well roasted cup of coffee to keep my happy for hours. I recommend this place with a passion for coffee lovers or people who need to learn how coffee should taste. 

The only reason they don't have five starts is that it's out of my way in life thus it requires more walking, well worth it though, to get my fix. So if your looking for a great coffee house with amazing baristas this is the place. I'm hoping this review gets more people to go there thus expanding their customers making more money so they can expanded into more place and open more shops. 

Next time your at the faery building in SF grab a expresso you'll become a coffee snob then too.
author: Nicholas J.

description:
Great atmosphere~ hard to find if not a San Francisco native. 

Had the du jour drip coffee.

The lighting is great in the evening :)
author: Sally K.

description:
Came here for the belgian waffles (on 7x7 list). I don't even like waffles and I enjoyed it. It's kinda pricey though, $7.5 each (yes just one), but its worth it, even to try once!

We ordered a cappuccino and they take their time in making it pretty (with the hearts) in each cup. I liked that :)

Oh and FYI - no signs in front. Just look for #66!
author: Rosie W.

description:
Ive always wanted to visit here
Theres none in LA when i lived there
Heard theres one in downtown la and others in venice beach
Got latte and love it
Very unique and sweeet

Hard to find parking..
author: Kristine S.

description:
Out of all the famed coffee spots in SF (Ritual, Sightglass, 4 barrel, etc. etc.) Blue Bottle has claimed my heart with its soy latte.

The bad: parking is awful at this location, and the service is a little slow. but-

The good: I had previously only gotten my blue bottle fix at the Ferry Market building (horrible lines) and the Village Market (horrible latte art, not that it matters that much). This location at Mint St is a charming little corner cafe with sturdy wooden benches, large sunny windows and generally a great place to start your day. Although our food took a little while, my friend's grilled cheese was delicious and buttery, and my belgian waffle was fluffy and topped with sweet strawberries. And as aforementioned, even if you're a diehard Mocha or black coffee drinker I think Blue Bottle's secret weapon is their soy latte- if it's the way they make their foam or the soy they use, it is friggin delicious. 

Ambiance: cheerful morning cafe with stylish baristas, good for friends and family

Overall: this is a blue bottle flagship kind of place I'd bring out of towners for a morning brunch before hopping over to downtown to shop
author: Jackie T.

description: I had coffee and french toast. Both were really great. I'm sure that I'll come here whenever I can. 5 stars without any hesitation.
author: Evan L.

description: Best cup of coffee I've ever put my mouth to. The barista was superbly knowledgable as I asked him about the siphoning process. The setup is superbly fancy and they make a mean cup of joe (yes, that's pretty disrespectful). A bit overpriced but I respect the hell out of detail and quality.
author: Tri T.

description:
The novelty factor is high at this place, but be prepared to wait in line, pay a lot, and wait some more for your order to come out. 

FYI the $7 coffee comes in a cool pot and they ask you how many cups you want with it. My husband and I shared one and it was a perfect amount (small and strong). 

The highlight of this place for me was the fantastic brunch options. It's always one of my biggest complaints about coffee shops that they don't feed you real food. We each ordered a plate and everything was really fantastic- poached eggs, greens, sausages, roasted tomato, cornbread, Yum. We had to wait a while for the food to come out (and our coffee for that matter), but it was hot and fresh when it arrived. 

The staff at the counter and at our table were all very friendly (I guess I was kind of expecting snobbery- sorry, guys!). I'll definitely go back on my next visit to SF, but I'll be trying an espresso drink next time. As much as I love a well-brewed cup, I think I prefer an espresso or extra-short Americano to taste the real distinction factor. 

I'm giving as many as four stars because it's a must-try while in SF and because of that delicious brunch!
author: Rach N.

description: Worth the long wait but wish there were more seating for its customers. The queue was long during our visit (4pm ish). I love the cafe mocha and macchiato - rich and just extraordinarily great. This is real coffee and would definitely be back here again when I visit SFO.
author: Marie Michelle Y.

description: The affogato here is amazing! Line was out the door..seems to always be busy. Definitely worth the wait!
author: Teena B.

description: Good coffee, probably better than I can comprehend, since I dont often notice a great cup of coffee. They have fantastic presentation with both food and coffee. Something I really appreciate. The staff did feel a little stuck up, and less friendly, but their coffee is supposed to be good. I will go back, but I am not in a rush to go and deal with the crowds.
author: Cee Cee L.

description:
This is unbelievably delicious coffee.  They do artisinal coffees and lots of other specialty coffee beverages.  My friend had an iced tokyo coffee (something like that) which he said was hands down the best iced coffee he'd ever had.

At blue bottle, most coffees are organic and you have your choice of various preparation methods.  Paper drip, single origin and some preparations for in house consumption only.  I'm just so psyched there's a Blue Bottle in Brooklyn because I can't wait to head over there to check it out!
author: Gloria F.

description: Definitely a must in SF. I had a great egg and cornbread with greens breakfast. Not to mention an amazing siphon coffee. It's steep at 7 dollars for a small pot but definitely worth it. Watching him make the siphon coffee was amazing! Never seen anything like it before.
author: Kinsey A.

description: A very good cappuccino. Seating isn't terribly comfy. And no wifi which is a huge bummer.
author: Charlie L.

description: Seriously the affogato is the best espresso anything I've tasted before. Part the amazing espresso part the rich vanilla ice cream it is poured over. Came back the next day to try the New Orleans - highly commented on and pick up beans for a friend. So the New Orleans as good as the hype. Go with the whole milk. Go big or go home.
author: Ellen H.

description: Excellent place! Friendly staff and great coffee. I got the best latte ever and a ginger molasses cookie. It's worth the walk to find it!
author: Kristin M.

description:
I got hot chocolate. Coffee is too strong for me. 
The place was busy, but there is a seating place inside and outside. The views are: buildings, cars, people or pigeons. The inside has a very tall ceiling. Therefore, the windows are huge. There are no art pieces on display just coffee beans, mugs, thermos and tea. The menu is simple. 
It is located on a corner, west of westfield mall and the mint plaza. 
There needs to be more bike parking. It is close to market street. Car parking is limited. Jessie St is an one-way road from 6th St.
author: Kristal C.

description: A coffee bar for true coffee lovers. I first tried their coffee (cappuccino) in NYC 2 weeks ago ironically, and I have to say that this cafe is really more in its element in SF.
author: Agent W.

description: This is a trendy little place to grab a great cup of java. I am fast becoming a loyal fan of this place. If it were not for the lines I would be here every morning.
author: Charles B.

description: My favorite place for coffee. They've really established a great product, brand and even more so a culture for coffee lovers. I always order the giant steps coffee beans when I'm not in SF. Their coffee has an exquisite taste. You can actually taste their coffee flavors it's not just super bitter and taste like shit like the sumptown coffee. Blue bottle is the best. If you're not able to come order online.
author: Sam N.

description:
Being that I don't drink coffee much, I opted to try their Hot Chocolate with TCHO chocolate (which I was told by my friend that it is a local chocolate made right in SF). That was one damn good hot chocolate for $3.50 and they made a heart tulip design in it with the milk! 

My friend ordered the Kyoto Iced Coffee which he said was very acidic and different than most other coffees. This may not b the best choice if u have a sensitive stomach.
author: Grace C.

description: Was visiting SF and heard about this place. Went into the Ferry Building after lunch and it was a hot day! Had the iced New Orleans brew- so refreshing! One of the best coffees I've ever had. Wish they had one where I lived
author: Racquel P.

description:
Not only do they serve one of the best cups of coffee in the city of San Francisco, they sell the best snickerdoodles that I've ever had! Goes perfect with a cup of gibraltar.

Did you know they served brunch/lunch? I had no idea! Not sure if they do that in all locations but they do at this one.

Two most recommended drinks: the gilbatar and the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee. 

Love this location!
author: Karen C.

description: I was just there a few weeks ago and managed to go into the city to get it. I had never tried their New Orleans drink and was pleasantly surprised with it. It wasn't too sweet and it wasn't too strong. Admittedly, I don't drink a lot of coffee but for this sometimes coffee drinker it was delish!
author: Cindy H.

description: Flying from NY, i was pretty jet lagged and my first cup of coffee in SF was blue bottle coffee. It was really a good choice!
author: Aya N.

description:
Great coffee, one of the original Blue Bottle locations. 

Well documented that it's one of SF's original and best pour over coffee places.

Their food selection is small, and could benefit by some more diverse selection. 

Typically long lines, and moves slowly given pour over takes 2-3 minutes per person.
author: Arvindh K.

description: Big, open, airy atmosphere. The line was long, but didn't take too long considering the coffee offerings are slow drip primarily. We use a chemex to brew our coffee at home and wanted to experiment with BBs non traditional brewing methods. Since it was our fist time here, we let the barista know and she walked us through their Siphon Brew and Nel Drip blends. We treated this like a tasting and got one of each. The brew process took about 15 minutes and was fascinating to watch. The siphon brew was extremely aromatic and the taste was quite light and sweet. The Nel drip was like a chemex espresso - caramel taste and definitely a slow sipping drink. The Mixmaster who served us our brew was very friendly and seemed to genuinely enjoy walking us through the intricacies of each process before serving us. This is not your typical coffee shop. Plan to make your stop here a tasting adventure!
author: Jaymes C.

description: Ridiculously delicious.   amazing coffee  awesome service   best soundtrack ever   blue bottle you're the best thing ever
author: G F.

description:
Flew in from out of town and had heard so
Much about this place that we had to try it! A lil tricky to find but just look for the line out the door. (It's that good) We stopped
By a little before noon on a Saturday for some coffee and were excited that they offered good as well. Line only took about 10 min. We ended up getting 2 of the drip coffees and had the Popeye eggs and toast, and a bowl of their yogurt compote with granola. Both were exceptional. The bread used was delicious along with the apple butter and the compote was to die for if you like yogurt bowls. We didn't finish the yogurt because we demolished the Popeye and were too full but we ate as much as we could. We watched a few other dishes come out and honesty they all looked amazing. The line is actually not too bad, plus if it's your first time it gives you time to think about what to order. We will probably go back for coffee every morning of our trip. A definite must do for any coffee aficionado. 
Ps. Service was amazing. The girl who rang us up was so friendly which definitely added to our experience!
author: Francelia R.

description: My first visit to Blue Bottle was in NYC where I sat at the bar and had the siphon coffee with the brioche. Their coffee was great and they even threw in a tasting of another coffee. The Mint Plaza location was my first visit in SF. It's at the cusp of dodgy as its bordering the gentrified area. There was a short line in the morning. I got the Kyoto iced coffee. It was solid coffee.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Conveniently located near the Powell St. BART station, tucked away in fairly quite alley, and such a great atmosphere. Plus the lattes are among the best I've had.
author: Jessica S.

description: If you weren't a coffee snob before you tried this place, you are now! Their minimalist design and pursuit of perfection are evident in every cup.  Their customer service is also outstanding.  I emailed Blue Bottle to inquire about the roast I had at their Mint. location, not expecting much, but to my surprise, Adam took the time to discuss tasting notes with me in order to narrow down the blend I had that day.  Their subscription service also allows me to enjoy outstanding coffees at home.
author: Justin G.

description:
Blue Bottle is my favorite place for a great latte. They spend quality time making each drink one by one, which produces a smooth, rich, and creamy concoction for my caffeine hungry taste buds. However, this  quality time usually makes the line really slow, so one has to weigh the value of time versus quality. With that said, you will most likely find me standing in that line since I usually choose quality.

I have also come here a few times for their Brunch and have tried their Belgian Waffle and a 'Poached Egg w/ organic Sausage, Greens, and Pepper Cornbread' dish. I am a fan of their waffles, as their batter has a unique flavor that I have not found anywhere else. It's really good. I was also happily surprised with the 'poached egg' dish, because when it came to the table it wasn't the most presentable meal. However, once we started eating it the flavors worked so well together and as a combination it was very satisfying. 

I am happy that their latte is delicious. I am happy that their breakfast/brunch is delicious. Mmmmmm....I'm just happy with anything related to Blue Bottle.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Like most people, a great cup of coffee is hard to find.  Everytime I come to San Fran, I make conscious efforts to stop into Blue Bottle usq.  The New Orleans iced Coffee is so good, I always order two. Matched with their stone cut oats, butter and brown sugar..... I say no more!  Keep it up and see u next time.
author: Dee J.

description: Hallelujah, not Starbucks!   As an avid coffee drinker, I'm constantly searching for the small coffee shops serving great cups of coffee.  On a business trip in San Francisco, I stumbled across Blue Bottle while checking out a nearby food truck, and I was pleasantly surprised with the coffee I ordered.  Their description of the coffee was spot on.  It was exactly as described and delicious.  I was super happy to find an alternative to the Starbucks-on-every-corner!  That Blue Bottle cup of coffee really made my day.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I've been here a few times, every time I visit the city. I love the mocha! I've had it a few times, and the mocha flavor is amazing each time, unique from other places. I love how the baristas work together on making the same drink, one brews while the other pours the milk creating a beautiful design of leaves and hearts. 

This time I followed the advice of my fellow yelpers and ordered the New Orleans iced coffee. Omg, so good! I really loved this drink. 

I know that SF is into recyclables and compostables, but my cup always gets soft before I finish my drink. I feel like my drink is getting soaked into the cup. This worries me every time. Can I get a thicker cup please?
author: Theresa D.

description:
Of course, like all Blue Bottle locations, the coffee here is delicious.  And, of course, like most of San Francisco, there are plenty of homeless people and beggars at Mint Plaza and parking sucks.  At least there is a large public parking garage nearby at 5th and Mission,

This small store often has a long line going out the door.  To their credit, however, the wait is not that bad given how long the lines are; the line moves fairly quickly.

They also serve hot food, bites and desserts, on real plates.  The menu is small but the food is quite good and the staff is always nice.
author: Evelyn K.

description: This is a great coffee shop! The staff are friendly and the coffee is great. The only thing is that the location is a little weird.
author: Cassidy H.

description: First of all, the coffee is not that great(cold brewed one) is very acidic, just like baristas demeanor of this specific place.
author: Tatiana G.

description:
After hearing so much about Blue Bottle Coffee, I decided that it was finally time to go out and try it.  My boyfriend and I came here around 3:00 p.m. and there were about 5 other people there.  We didn't know what to order so we asked the employees about some of the drinks we had heard/read about on Yelp.  The employee explained to us some of the different drinks and why each one was special, in terms of how they brew the coffee and for how long.  It was interesting, but I just chose the one that he said was the sweetest.  We ended up picking the New Orleans Iced Coffee and a Latte ($3.75 each)

Our drinks were made within minutes and we went to sit down next to the Kyoto-Style Iced-Coffee apparatus.  Blue Bottle Coffee has two of these $20,000 machines!  

The latte was really smooth and the foam art was pretty.  A solid latte and fairly priced.  

The New Orleans Iced Coffee was really good.  They first fill about half the glass with ice/milk and then top it off with the coffee.  In the initial description, I believe the employee said it was "hazelnut-ty."  Whatever it was, it tasted good.  The drink was fairly sweet and full flavored.  It was a nice change from the usual coffee.  

Looking at the menu online now, http://www.bluebottlecoffee.net/locations/mint-cafe/coffee-menu/
I definitely want to go back and try their Affogato.  They use Humphy Slocombe's Secret Breakfast ice cream!  

Notes: 
-Metered parking in the area can be expensive (more than your coffee will cost you!)  If you get lucky, there is free street parking on the alley around the corner, I believe it was Stevenson Street.
-They have free water that you can help yourself to.
-They have a clean bathroom, but you need to ask them for the key.
author: Samantha L.

description: My husband and I took a coffee class in Chicago and they mentioned this place as a must-go in SF. Luckily this vacation was already planned so we went! Waited in line that went out the door and eventually warped around the corner. Worth it because the poached eggs on their sourdough bread will forever change the idea of having eggs on toast. I had a great latte and my husband had the siphon experience. Sitting by the window and having a chat with this meal is how I wish all my breakfasts could be like...
author: Stephanie J.

description: i travel full time and try every coffee i can get my caffeine driven hands on! maine to seattle to sedona. this place is top 5 hands down. hands DOWN. so you best try it. watch out for the homeless ppl though. one guy tried to take my americano out of my hand as i passed him on the street. NO JOKE! lol
author: Jen H.

description:
After hearing about this place for the last 3 years I had to make a stop when I was in SF last week.  When I arrived there was a line out the door, down the block, around the corner, and into the street, but hey - I wasn't turning back now.  

45 minutes later....

I got their regular drip coffee and yes I was kind of wow'd with how amazing it tasted.  No burnt Starbucks flavor and enough natural sweetness to not need any sugar.  Unfortunately I'm not accustomed to the quality and was completely bug-eyed for the rest of the afternoon.  

If you're a coffee connoisseur this place is gold.  I'll have to work on my caffeine tolerance before my next visit.
author: Lindsey G.

description: My review is purely for the breakfast sandwich. I'm not a coffee drinker so I can't help anyone in that regard. My husband and I stopped here to get some breakfast before heading out of the city. We ordered the breakfast sandwich, and it didn't look too amazing. It looked like any other breakfast sandwich, really. We were both pleasantly surprised! The arugula had some kind of vinaigrette on it that gave the sandwich a nice acidity to it. The fritatta was also very flavorful with the cheese and herbs they put in it. My husband got the coffee and said it was good, but I'd go back here just for the breakfast sandwich!
author: Christina P.

description:
A great start to my long day of class. Absolutely love the coffee here especially the lattes and when they brew giant steps. Yumm! Gotta try their food one of these days looks pretty tasty.

Also love how they changed all their lids and to go cups to biodegradeble material. =]
author: Katie M.

description:
Best coffee in the city. And this location is the best location in which to get the best coffee in the city.

The coffee is smooth and delicious. Their beans are not burnt or anywhere close to over-roasted. They take care to steam their milk correctly which so many places overlook. And this location makes great food (so this is a great brunch place) and is in general just a really nice place to sit and have a cup of coffee.
author: Mariko F.

description:
Visited SF last weekend and my friend recommended that I try Blue Bottle Coffee so this was our first stop of the day. It was a bit difficult to find but we were able to find it eventually. One thing I learned about San Franciscans, they sure LOVE their coffee because every time I passed by a Blue Bottle Coffee establishment, there were lines out the ying yang! 

I ordered their caffee latte and my friend ordered a caffee mocha. I was really considering ordering either the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee or the Kyoto Style Iced Coffee but wanted something hot to start the day. =)

The coffee was smooth and bold. It didn't make any sense to me, though, as to why the only person ringing everyone up was also the only person making all the coffee... There was a whole bunch of other workers but they were doing something else. It just totally slowed down the line. 

I do like the ambiance of the establishment and it seems that many people go there to hang catch up with friends or etc. It's not like Starbucks down in SoCal, where most people are just alone and it's like "dead", but with loud music. 

The oatmeal did look delicious! Or was it something else... I also like how they use sustainable cups/lids and etc. Looking out for the environment!

I do wish that we had Blue Bottle Coffee down here in SoCal but will most definitely get some more when I visit up north!
author: Lesley C.

description: I've heard a lot about Blue Bottle & was very much looking forward to it but my expectations might've been too high for the coffee which didn't blow me away but it's right on par with intelligentsia which isn't a bad thing at all. It's tasty. Staff was good & the line gets long but they do a good job of moving it along. Definitely worth your time and money.
author: Adolfo V.

description:
I'm not a coffee snob, I am a Gold Card toting Starbucks visiting kind of guy.  Every now and again, I spice it up with some CBTL.  But this place completely blew my mind.  I've only had it twice, being a So Cal resident and native, but it's really ruined the chain coffee shops for me.  In fact, now I can understand why the hipsters here are always going on and on about these small, independent coffee spots, because Blue Bottle has definitely converted me.  

Both times I've been there, I've gotten the New Orleans Iced Coffee.  The first time last year, I may or may not have partaken in the local medication of SF, but all I added was milk and it simply blew me away.  I usually need sweetener in my coffee, but milk was all I needed here.  It was sweet enough with just milk, and it had subtle notes of dark chocolate at the end.  When I got my usual iced coffee the next time at Starbucks, I almost couldn't drink it.  

I went again for the second time about 2 weeks ago to try it again, and got the New Orleans IC and streusel:  Just as good. One of the baristas mentioned that there was going to be a store opening up in Culver City or some other hipster area in So Cal, and I'm eagerly anticipating that.
author: Bernard S.

description:
Don't you think the owners of Blue Bottle should hire Barbara Eden to be their spokesperson? Never mind that she's in her seventies now (and still looks great, mind you) and forget that her bottle wasn't blue...c'mon, she could wear her Jeannie outfit, blink her eyes and make that magical macchiato appear... 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLgeZ8OPJ-g

Any time there is a Blue Bottle or a Philz within my sight line, I don't let traffic lights, panhandlers or careening MUNI buses stop me from getting my caffeinated libation. Such joy, such rapture to find a new Blue Bottle close to my home. At the moment, it has no signage, so you would likely miss it unless you're looking for it...or happen upon it on a weekend when the line goes out the door. It's in the refurbished Provident Loan building across from the Old Mint.

It's an actual cafe versus the kiosk over in Hayes Valley. That means they have a sparse menu of a few savory/salty dishes and a few sweet ones. It's still in an alley, sorta speak, but it's part of Mint Plaza, which signals either welcome urban renewal or an extended playground for the Sixth Street spillover of shopping cart-wheeling screamers. Time will tell...I wonder how many of those orange plastic chairs will be there a year from now.

The inside of Blue Bottle is nice and pristine clean with a tall ceiling, a wrap-around counter and a community-style table in the center. I went full gonzo and went for the monumentally priced $4.50 Mocha with, get this, Recchiuti chocolate. I watched the goateed barista make it through some Turkish-looking carafe carefully melting the chocolate into the cup. A smoother cup could not be found anywhere else.

The staff is alert and courteous. Gee, what's that about? Maybe they could be subservient and wear harem outfits and say things like "Yes, Master". Somebody find Barbara Eden's agent.

COFFEE - 5 stars...oh yes, it's very expensive...but it is the best
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...very nice digs, even if urine-soaked Sixth Street is within shouting distance
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...sharp and customized to order
TOTAL - 5 stars...worth a splurge, though not an everyday indulgence for me
author: Ed U.

description: The best breakfast in SF. The kids were hungry, the place was packed and no one was leaving as it was very rainy outside. I was ready to order and stand to eat, but soon someone left and the food came wonderful and so was the coffee. My kids, my mom and I could not be happier. I wish they had one in Chicago...so good!
author: Flavia A.

description:
SOOOOOOOOOO SLOOOOOOOW! 
I never go to Blue Bottle because I know they are slow and they only reason I was there was because my friend wanted to go there and I gave in. 
It takes 10+++ minutes to get a cup of coffee...are you kidding me? and the people that work here look miserable. 
And the coffee is mediocre to boot! 
Never again...I would rather suffer through starbucks than get annoyed by this place.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I really like blue bottle! This location is generally more convenient for me to get to, and staff have always been so kind. If you have time to sit in, I recommend the kyoto iced coffee (which they don't offer to-go). It's really strong!

It's worth mentioning they serve brunch and lunch here, and I went here for a quick brunch Saturday morning.  I got a poached eggs dish which came with kale... I really didn't enjoy the kale/ the way it was cooked that much, and everything else was pretty standard.  I imagine they do basic things here pretty well (my cousin was very happy with her waffle), and of course the coffee is always good :)
author: Richa A.

description:
After my friend surprised me with a bag of their coffee beans, I knew I had to try their coffee at one of their SF locations. 

The place was hard to find -- marked only by a blue bottle and a long line of people. I would've gotten the new orleans style coffee or kyoto coffee but it was a bit too cold for me to drink iced coffee. I instead ordered the mocha latte which was SO FRICKIN' DELICIOUS. Everything about it just worked perfectly. I think I drank it in less than 15 minutes. 

Their breakfast items sound delicious as well but I was running a bit short on time so opted to not get anything. Next time I will definitely try their poached eggs on acme toast. 

If you love coffee, you definitely need to try this place out when you're in the city.
author: Chantelle T.

description:
It's kind of awkward to find but you can do it! You have to turn into a small street. Between 5th and 6th and market and mission. If you are out of that perimeter...you are getting colder.

Skip the drip coffee and just get the latte. Regular drip coffee is not that special.
