But the latte- Not only do you get a special piece of art dec on top of your latte, but deliciousness is right under it. Make sure to watch them make the design...it's part of the show. Also, hot chocolate is really good!! If you like chemistry and coffee, this is the place for you.
author: Patricia P.

description: This location is a bit tough to find since it's on a weird street, but once you find it you get the same fantastic Blue Bottle experience. I always get the New Orleans Iced Coffee. I should probably try something else at some point, but the iced coffee is so good I can't convince myself to switch.
author: Richie Z.

description: I love the simplistic design of the coffee shop. Ordered an iced coffee. Even when the ice melted, my coffee didn't taste watered down. Just creamy enough, not too sweet. Definitely a must stop if you are in the area. Unfortunately, Montreal doesnt have a Blue Bottle :(
author: Michelle V.

description:
AMAZING COFFEE goes without saying but also a really great breakfast menu now too - great poached eggs!

The line around the corner is worth it - as is braving the slightly dodgy part of town
author: Olivia J.

description:
I was pretty disappointed by BBC. I'd read all the reviews on how great it was and was really excited to try it out during my stay in SF. 

I tried ordering the siphon coffee and was told they stop serving it after a certain time. No biggy, I ordered the New Orleans iced coffee since it seemed to be another popular coffee item. 

This is where I became instantly disappointed. A great coffee shop adopts a cold brew method for their iced coffees. This allows the coffee to be cold and have a purer coffee taste. It does not taste watered down as a hot coffee would when poured over ice. 

BBC does not appear to adopt this method. I can only speak for the iced coffee. I was not a fan. It tasted watered down. If I'm in town I will try out the other coffees but I'm really not looking forward to it.
author: Keesy S.

description: The best coffee in the city. Over ten years of enjoying. Favorite. New Orleans iced coffee forever.
author: KK L.

description:
Hard boiled is the new poached. Unless of course what you had ordered, and wanted, was in fact, a poached egg.

We ordered the poached eggs and toast however the eggs were borderline hard boiled. We requested they remake the dish and the waitress and counter staff were very courteous and helpful. Unfortunately when the remade dish came out the eggs were even more over cooked.

The staff is awesome, the coffee is amazing, the food...eh.
author: Christian S.

description: Best waffle I've ever had! Also tried the ginger molasses cookie and it was delicious! Expect to see a line out the door and no seating at this location but well worth the wait!
author: Alisha W.

description:
Good morning !!! 
Checking out the top recommendations of my favourite Montreal Barista Tony at Pourquoi Pas Espresso Bar. He has mentioned Wrecking Ball and Blue Bottle . 

It's my first stop at Blue Bottle on Mint Plaza! Nice people , very urban and fun atmosphere and a good latte ! 

Enjoy everyone !!!!
author: Benjamin K.

description: Blue Bottle always does it right. This location is pretty cool inside. It will probably be busy. Coffee in this location is best consumed inside or on the run, as the scent of human urine is pretty strong in the surrounding area.
author: Marcus C.

description:
One of my friends who visited San Francisco often (before I moved here permanently) was all about this "blue bottle coffee" place, or that's what I thought it was - just hype - before I tried it for myself, I would say that I am a fan of this coffee place. Please keep in mind that I also like the coffeebeans iced coffee with half a scoop of hazelnut flavoring and am not a fan of peets (I know, shocker - I would say my old company's not so delicious tasting coffee has scarred me and I assume all coffee from peets will taste llike that). This place is short and to the point - there are about 5 options of coffees you could choose from to drink (can't speak for their food because I did not eat here).

What I got: The new orleans iced coffee - delicious! It's their coffee thats iced (yes another shocker) and they put this special milk into it with just a tad bit of sweetener - I convinced my co-worker I was with to get this as well as she despises the strong taste that coffee can have sometime - and she liked it as well!

Handy Tip: Even if you're trying to skimp on the calories, go for the new orleans iced coffee the way they would normally make it - without substituting for a skinnier milk that is so that you'll get the full experience. I'm an iced-coffee type person, only when it is really cold will I bust out my order for a hot coffee!
author: Melissa L.

description: Literally the only thing not to love is the line.  Obviously the coffee is fantastic, but the waffles and breakfast sandwich are too!
author: M H.

description: What an interesting coffee experience! They make coffee in several different ways, using various types of interesting and fun-to-watch equipment. The coffee itself--I had espresso--was delicious and well prepared. Baristas are friendly and competent. Finally someone who knows what a machiato really is! Reservations: price and noise level are a little high. An interesting and different coffee experience, which I recommend for the ambiance and the experience.
author: Ann S.

description:
Blue Bottle is a nice, hipster coffee place. I'm so glad that they have many different shops in San Francisco. It has some of the best coffee I have ever tasted, and whenever people ask me to suggest a place in SF to visit, I always mention Blue Bottle. During my first visit to Blue Bottle, I asked them what is good. They said, "Anything you usually get, it'll taste better here." Confused, I ordered my usual latte. And sure enough, it's my usual latte....10 times better. 

Black coffee is usually not my thing, but without adding sugar or cream, their drip coffee is definitely worth trying.
author: Gina T.

description: I am a coffee lover since I was a youngin' and my coworker recommended I tried Blue Bottle Coffee if I was ever in the city. It wasn't until now that I had a chance to try it. My boyfriend and I headed for some coffee before both of us were heading to work. He was familiar with the place and it was my first time here and like everyone, I went to double check that it was the right place. It definitely did not look like a place that served coffee. A long line, of course, which I hesitated to stay, but the line moved pretty quick. The workers were nice and gave both of us suggestions on what to order. Completely fell in love with their mocha latte! I definitely want to come back to try the siphon. Wishing I didn't have to head to work because I would've stayed to grab more delicious coffee! I will be back, Blue Bottle
author: Victoria K.

description:
Whenever a new Blue Bottle Coffee place unexpectedly opens up, there is no escape, because I'll be on the lookout and somehow find you. And being the earlier Yelper to review this newest coffee-shop, I thought I start reviewing before any other of you do. (BLAH!)

(AM Review)

I drove the rest of the Fantstic-4 members to work and school respectively to get our "pick us up" fuel to warm us up on this current frigid day. Finding the newest Blue-Bottle Cafe is no cake-walk. Just like the Hayes Valley location, this is coffee shop resides in a revamped alley behind the Old Mint. Don't' worry, the neighborhood is slowly becoming a safe and less jagged atmosphere. 

We managed to park our van at a red-zone on Jessie St. (Not recommended). At the early morning, Wife and I got the $2.00 coffee drip to start our day. The coffee was brewed fresh in a 12 oz. cup and was very strong just like the Hayes Valley location. The coffee was powerful enough to get us dancing to any music played on KOIT. There have actually seating at the newest location, unlike the Hayes Valley sister-location.

When I told the kids that there is a new Blue-Bottle Coffee place opening up, they were very excited about the great news. And yes, it did pay off. They each ordered a cup of Hot Chocolate. The $3.50 Michael Rechueti drink was very rich and chocolatey. Even with the heart-shape on their foamy drinks made the gloomy and chilly day into a bright and warm day for the happy kids. A smile on their faces is proven evidence.

The four of us are very delighted that the local Blue-Bottle Coffee franchise is growing. And the Fantastic-4 is very happy and alive to experience a great tasting coffee place. I hope this coffee shop is a great indication of a positive facelift to a better atmosphere from a once serrated neighborhood. And yes, we're definitely coming back here to get our coffee, considering that there are many coffee places in the Downtown area.

(PM Review):

Later in the evening, I came back after work to buy a half pound of the beans to take home. There are so many different kind of beans to choose from and I bought the "17 ft. Ceiling" Blend, in which seems like a practical chose for me. That half-pound bagged whole beans costs $7.60. I have my own coffee-grinder and grind my beans every morning. I can't wait to wake up with Blue Bottle Coffee in my own kitchen.
author: Matt G.

description:
i went there for the first time and absolutely like it!! i can say that their cappuccino is better than starbucks (and im a starbucks loyal customer) lol

i cant say anything else, it's just so good. creamy and light, cant really describe it but it makes you smile.

i only give 4 stars because the line is ridiculous and it's kinda pricey ... but i totally will come back again and try their different recommended specialties.
author: Miss G.

description:
FYI:  This is their only location with the Kyoto cold-drip brewing system (which is hard to find anyway).  The system looks like a chemistry set & it uses room temperature water over eight hours, so it's a slow process.  Try it, the Kyoto-style iced coffee is great on a hot day.  Yes, there are hot days in SF.  They do run out of it though; I've been there before when they've run out.  :-(  Then, I get their New Orleans style iced coffee.

Of all of their locations that I've been to (in SF & Oakland), this has the largest seating area, with counters lining two walls & a large communal table.  If it's nice out, go enjoy the weather outside by sitting on the plaza.

Apparently, they serve meals (breakfast, lunch, & brunch) too, but I've never tried them.

They take credit cards, including Discover.

If you drive, & can't find street parking, the Mission & 5th garage (my go-to garage in that area) is really close by.

Located on the northwest corner of Mint Plaza.
author: Linda T.

description:
Great coffee... coffee made with great care and attention to detail, served in proper china cups.....taste was delicious....no super sizing in styrofoam cups. 
Small selection of good quality treats to supplement this great coffee....
Queuing was worth it!.
author: Mick A.

description: I don't get the infatuation with this place. Perhaps it is just the hipster thing to do, but the coffee / espresso itself is mediocre at best. Having owned a coffee roasting business in the past, I've been to coffee shops around the globe and know what it takes to be deemed "excellent" - Blue Bottle does not fit that profile by any means. Couple the so so product with an uninviting staff and excruciatingly long wait times and you have the perfect storm. Don't waste your time.
author: Brian M.

description: Cappuccinos were luke warm the crowd in there is rude when I tried to carry two cappuccinos out people wouldn't even move in the over crowded place. Cappuccino to go is double the size than the one you get for dine in. Food tasted good but it is overprized. The ham sandwich comes with a salad for breakfast could put a different side on it for Breakfast than for lunch...
author: Frank K.

description:
Since my first review years ago I've actually moved to SF *and* my office is less than a block away, soooooo... I go here often. 

Lines can be BRUTAL, so be prepared for that especially during peak "coffee" hours or during a nearby convention at Moscone. 

However: In my opinion, Blue Bottle is the best espresso you're going to get in San Francisco.  I've been to ritual, four barrel, bicycle coffee co, etc.  Blue Bottle is simply the best.  Note that there's noticable difference between this Blue Bottle and other Blue Bottles, and especially place that "proudly serve Blue Bottle coffee."  The technique and preparation of the drink is just as important as the beans, and this place does it the best.  

The New Orleans iced coffee is a great alternative if you aren't feeling like espresso or want something cold, but it's sweetened.  I'm not always in the mood for a sweetened drink.  

If you like good coffee, go here.  End of story.
author: Jace P.

description:
The first time I came here, I didn't realize they were cash-only and I didn't have any money, but the kind lady behind the counter said I could have a latte on the house as long as I vowed to come back. I was taken aback by that. It took me a few months to come back since I'm a college student and I live pretty far from blue bottle, but I finally fulfilled my promise. (When I finally came back, I noticed they had gotten square :) 

And the latte they prepared - both times - was incredible!
author: Grant M.

description: They got way better, I've been here a few times and damn they make a mean latte. Yes I still think it is slightly overrated but I'm happy with my coffee here and it is a special treat when I make the trip to the famous coffee shop.
author: Anna K.

description:
Really amazing coffee, friendly staff, and cool vibe.
The space gets really crowded, so if you don't have time to wait in line i suggest going somewhere else.
I still waited because it's worth it!
author: M K.

description:
belgian wafel is sooooooo goood best wafel i've ever
latte is fantastic, get the latte
staff is super zen
you go blue bottle
author: Roxy M.

description: Very nice place, coffee is great. But very busy most of the day!
author: Sofiane F.

description: Had the cafe latte. It was awesome. Very full with texture and perfect crema. The art was a nice touch!
author: Brian A.

description: People are lined up out the door for coffee that has reached celebrity status. It's damn good. I had "Three Africans", black, with a snicker doodle. Nice, bright, clean coffee goodness.
author: Cory K.

description:
Blue Bottle does have a very good latte. And, in general, I think the coffee and pastries are pretty good. 

But the line and speed of service make a visit regularly not worth it. So save it for when you have a bunch of time and want to meet up with people.
author: Chris T.

description:
I really REALLY didn't want to like this place. I take joy in being able to tell people: "stop drinking the Kool-aid, that over-hyped place you always talk about is not so great." So you can imagine my disappointment when I actually ended up liking this place. 
My 15 to 20 minute wait in line was not a good start, but once I got inside: 2/3 of the baristas were extroverted and friendly, and the soy latte was DAMN GOOD. Like, almost worth the $4.25 I paid for a mere 12 ounces. 

Overall, the wait is a little ridiculous and definitely not manageable on a normal basis, and the prices are pretty steep for what they offer (for coffee AND food.) 

I don't picture myself waiting in line for a 7 dollar serving of siphon coffee or 5 dollars' worth of plain toast, but I can definitely handle the occasional $4.25 splurge for a really killer latte.
author: Monica M.

description: Average. Not sure what anyone would open another coffee shop chain in the age of Starbucks. Didn't find anything different about them. I saw some people getting their coffee in actual coffee mugs. But for some reason we got ours in paper cups.
author: Gulshan I.

description:
Mint Plaza is kinda Blue Bottle's flagship shop and one of the originals, although they seem to be opening up new ones at a brisk pace.

There are three things that put this shop at the top of the list for me:

1. The coffee is excellent.  Although it doesn't always suit my tastes (often BB's roasts are just a hair too dark for me), they put a tremendous amount of effort into the coffee both roasting and behind the bar.  The espresso drinks are fantastic - the shop has its own signature espresso blend designed for that location, which I like significantly more than their Hayes Valley blend which is more common around the city.  The milk quality is top-notch and the pours are often epic.  

While I've had some of the best coffee of my life at the siphon bar for the most part I feel Blue Bottle's siphon technique doesn't always get the results I like.  Maybe it involves too much stirring - some of the other siphon shops I've been to stir less and I like the results more.  Anyway, it produces a cup that's very astringent and boozy tasting - sometimes kinda, I dunno, musty?  Every now and then they'll be serving a coffee for which that treatment is perfect but in general I am a little disappointed by the siphon bar.  I'm going to chalk that up to me having different preferences because I know they have planned their methods very carefully.  If you do get the siphon coffee let your coffee cool a good bit before making conclusions - it comes out very hot.

The iced coffee is outstanding and will definitely crack you out.  There's not much better than one of those on a hot day.

2. Killer food.  You have to come here for brunch.  Their waffles, soups, and compotes are really wonderful with high-quality ingredients.  It's on the pricy side for what you get but it's generally well worth it.

3. Professionalism.  You just get a much more professional treatment from Blue Bottle as compared to places like Ritual and Four Barrel.  I mean, that's not the end-all-be-all of coffee service - sometimes the casual grit of the Mission shops is fun; I like to think of Blue Bottle as the shop that does everything Starbucks says they do but in reality fails miserably at.  If that sounds up your alley you'll love this place.

Mint is third-wave coffee at its best with a certain Japanese-inspired minimalism and a bourgeoisie attention to detail.  I should also note that Blue Bottle benefits from a tight integration with the SF foodie scene that some of the other shops don't have.

My criteria for a five-star review is: if someone were visiting the city for only one day would I send them there?  If the person loves coffee then yes for Mint Plaza.
author: Dan C.

description: The lattes are the most incredible I've ever had, and I love the waffles as well - if they don't run out!
author: David H.

description: Might be the best latte I've ever had.  The servers even finish topping off the foam by the register so that you can watch them create a foam design.
author: Kristen H.

description:
Being from Reno, I realize I may not be as spoiled when it comes to coffee, however I know amazing coffee when I have it. 

Whenever I return to SF I look forward to coming here.
author: Todd I.

description:
The platonic conception of coffee. 1970s lever pull La San Marco espresso machine pulling single origin shots and macchiatos. Unreal. 

Best poached eggs on thick cut toast one can imagine. Would eat all three meals a day here if possible.

Rating Scale:
1 Star: Avoid the town in which this place is located just to be safe.  
2 Star: With so many great places to choose from, why risk this one?
3 Star: I'll try it again or consume here in a pinch.
4 Star: I go here regularly if financially and/or calorically feasible.
5 Star: I look forward to taking my wife or friends here.
author: Michael T.

description:
Wonderful strong cappuccino.  Must be one of the best in SF.  

A great place to sit and sip your coffee, especially at the high tables near the window.
Prices are what you'd expect for good coffee, a bit high, but then, this is SF. Totally worth it in my opinion. Also, I had an apple buckle with my coffee which was great.

Come, enjoy a cup. You won't regret it!
author: Hagit K.

description: Really good coffee. This location had a line up out the door at lunch time. I would choose this over Starbucks any day! It is slightly pricier but worth it if you like coffee. A lot smoother and a cleaner finish with a nice after taste.
author: Derwei C.

description: Really love the spot here. Coffee is good, poached egg was great. Was not really a fan of the bread. Always a line...
author: chris t.

description:
Coffee was good: Three African drip coffee. I wish there was more selection.
Lemonade was okay, but not as good as lemonade made at home. A little pricey too.
author: Poiuytrewq A.

description: Their mocha tastes like a bar of dark chocolate, probably my favourite mocha in the city. We bought a bag of beans to send back to a relative in England.
author: Nick B.

description:
This Blue Bottle is in a quirky little place but it's fully loaded with all of the best whistles and bells of the Blue Bottle brand.

They have beautifully made glass siphon systems created by mad coffee people from Japan. It make the place looks like a fun lab for coffee--- like Willy Wonka's Coffee factory. Generally I don't order siphons unless I have someone with me, it's best for two! The flavor is much more floral and light, it's brewed more delicately and has a tealike consistency. I've never had a siphon I didn't like here, they take their time to make it and test the flavor as they brew like an obsessive French chef that's making an important sauce.

It's really impressive the care they take into making a cup of anything in this store. I've tried all of their drinks and I'm the big fan of their pour-overs when I'm feeling serious, their cappuccinos if it's lazy weekend morning, and of course, their siphons if I'm sitting down for a long conversation with a friend.

Their New Orleans Style Iced Coffee is just pure indulgence, even people who don't like to drink coffee will love this ice cold sunshine. The bright fruit flavors of the coffee will delight you as much as the cream will sate you. This is what I'd serve an out-of-town friend to get them hooked on the blue crack.

Be prepared to wait in line. I promise you it moves fast and it moves even faster if you know what you want to drink!
author: Lisa Q.

description:
I'd never gone to a coffee shop and felt compelled to try a quarter of the menu before, but that's what happened with Justin C. at Blue Bottle.  We got to Mint Plaza and faced quite the caffeine-seeking line, and by the time we were ready to order we wanted it all.

The place is small and very cool, with a white and blonde wood color scheme and laboratorical chrome and glass coffee contraptions making up the decor.  The staff is friendly and talkative, and the place actually offers a coffee shop experience you're unlikely to find elsewhere.

We ordered a cup of the daily drip and a pot of siphon coffee, along with an affogato and an olive oil shortbread cookie.  We also bought a couple bags of beans as souvenirs - it ended up being quite the spendy coffee stop.  Thankfully, everything we tried was top notch.

We attended to the affogato first.  We weren't planning on consuming too many calories when we walked in, but as soon as we saw that Blue Bottle made an affogato with Humphry Slocombe's Secret Breakfast, we had to try it.  This bourbon and cornflakes ice cream blew our minds the day before, and it was fantastic with a strong pour of espresso.  I've never had a better affogato.

With dessert out of the way, we turned to our brews.  The daily drip was the Bella Donovan.  I'm not a coffee expert, but I do know that I usually like my joe loaded with cream and sugar.  Not so this one - it was tasty black, smooth and light.

The main event, though, was the siphon coffee - it was what drew us to this location of Blue Bottle to begin with.  The Mint Plaza location has a seriously expensive and seriously impressive siphon machine that churns out individual pots of coffee through a complicated process that involves glass globes and bamboo paddles.  The resulting coffee - we chose the Honduras Marcala - was worthy of the posturing.  It looked different from regular coffee, almost watery in its clarity.  There was nothing watery about its flavor, though.  It was delicious black, with a silky, almost chocolatey richness.  I was pretty moved by this stuff, so I'd say it's a must for anyone who's passionate about coffee.

We munched on the olive oil shortbread with our coffees, and it was a great accompaniment, with a nice buttery crumb and a pervasive note of rosemary.

Anyway, there you have it.  I just wrote an essay on my visit to this wonderful coffee shop.  I'm not even a coffee person, and I was bowled over by Blue Bottle.  Between the affogato and the siphon coffee, I'd say it's worth a pilgrimage.
author: Steph C.

description: My introduction to blue bottle is in San Francisco. It was love at first taste. I made it a mission to try all of the different locations blue bottle has to offer.
author: Iris G.

description:
Blue bottle coffee is the shiz. 

Really neat decor; very spacious and modern feel. Ample seating for chit chats over a nice cup of coffee. Baristas are chill. It's neat to see the siphon pot process too.

The mocha is divine. It is absolutely perfect. I would get this every time.

The lunch items are mere niblets. It's good for people that enjoy something light to snack on, but it's not considered a meal. Not worth the money. Just stick to the coffee and you're good to go.
author: Desmond T.

description:
Looks like a coffee-shop on the inside. Sorta. Plenty of seating for such a small space. Recognizable baristas. Coffee-looking type machinery is scattered about. 

But. Wait. There's no "coffee" on the menu. You can order a "New Orleans Style" iced coffee. Or a "Kyoto" style. Kyoto, of course, has been known for its coffee for centuries. But no plain old "coffee." 

Or maybe there was, and I just didn't know what they were talking about. 

I have been to a few coffee shops in my day. I have even visited coffee plantations in other countries. So, I know some of the terminology. But this place feels like you need a coffee dictionary to make an intelligent choice. Or you have to be 'in the know' about what's on the menu. I pretended. 

I think everyone else was pretending, too. Also, bad acoustics. Kind of loud in there.
author: Rob R.

description:
I used to live at Mint Plaza and I can see Blue Bottle from my bedroom. My every-weekend routine was:

1) get out of the bed 
2) go to the windows and pull the curtains aside 
3) check out the line outside of Blue Bottle. If it's: 
a. long --) go straight back to bed --) set my alarm for waking me up 15 mins later and repeat from step 1. 
b. short --) grab my shades and baseball hat --) run downstairs 
4) run to Blue Bottle 
5) order a cup of latte and a muffin meanwhile try not to speak with my mouth wide open or stay too close to the cashier to avoid the embarrassing moment of being told I have some pretty bad morning breath when I have to rush down without brushing my teeth. 
6) check out the 4 or 5 choices of breakfasts they offer that weekend and try to find pop-eyed egg toast - it's the best! 

Their coffee was the only thing that could get me outta bed on the weekends. It's the real deal!  Though, beware of long lines and occasional bums from 6th Street.  I give them 4 stars because it could smell pretty bad when you eat outside in the alley and try to soak up the sun.
author: Vivienne A.

description:
Good coffee. Good food.

You can only place your breakfast order after 9am, so don't try to place it before then. Not at 8:58am. Not even if you don't need to see their menu (because you're ordering one of their standard items). Instead, please exit the line with your coffee order only, and then move to the back of the long line so that you may arrive at the front after the menu "arrives" at 9am. It's unfortunate that someone at Blue Bottle feels that this bureaucracy makes more sense than providing good customer service.
author: Colin R.

description:
DRINKS:
Blue Bottle Drip Coffee

SERVICE:
Good

ATMOSPERE:
So cute! I love how it's in the little mint street walk way, tucked away hidden in the corner off 5th. Inside is small, modern, industrialish decor, great place to stroll on by to catch up with an old friend over a cup of drip coffay ;P
author: Angela L.

description: Yesterday my local cousin said she wanted to take me to the best coffee in SF, perhaps the entire country. Skeptical, I followed her into this crowded little corner artisanal coffee cafe. The takeout lattes were amazing. Smooth and rich, delivering the caffeine-induced euphoria that gives me a reason to drink coffee in the first place. I came back this morning, husband in tow, and enjoyed a fresh waffle. Husband had eggs with chard and roasted cauliflower. To die for. Everything organic, locally sourced, executed perfectly. Love this place!
author: Michelle O.

description: Had the Iced coffee New Orleans style. It's true to its description: slightly sweet. I love my coffee not too sweet but this coffee was STRONG! Delicious but strong. I also got the brownie because, why not? At first you're like, "Do I like this? It's weird with peanuts on it and sea salt, am I right?" Then, you pair it with the iced coffee and you can't get enough of it! It's as if they were made for each other! One of the better coffee experiences I've had (and I love coffee)! I can't wait to get back to try some of the other bags of whole beans.
author: Patti F.

description: This coffee is really a bit too strong for me, I prefer philz, but I have to give a bonus star for the awesome shapes they make in the coffee
author: Nikita K.

description:
I've learned an important lesson this morning: Never go to the SoMa Blue Bottle at 9am on a week day. At least, not if you're in any kind of hurry.

I waited a half hour for a luke-hot, they-only-have-small, pricey, very pretty latte.

The line wrapped out the door, the new cashier didn't know how to work the register, a couple staff were leisurely making coffee drinks and chatting with their regulars. Customers swarmed around the counter, standing shoulder to shoulder, trying to give their order to an inattentive staff. 

The scene was dysfunctional to the point of comical. People waiting for drinks were in the way of people trying to order, people waiting to order were in the way of people trying to get to the milk and sugar counter, the staff was slow and disorganized, and everybody was grumpy from standing in a 30 minute line to get their caffeine fix.

BlueBottle has a cult following in SF. I'm a foodie and a coffee lover and can understand the attraction to excellent coffee, but today's experience left a sour taste in my mouth.
author: Aaron M.

description:
Heard so much about this place - tried the SG 120 after waiting in the queue for a quote a bit... But the coffee was worth the wait and the price. Plus it came in this neat lil tumbler almost like something out of the chemistry lab...I'm regretting not getting any breakfast though.. Everything that people around me are eating looks delicious ...

I give 4 stars only coz the wait is a lil too much and thr isn't enough place to sit..

But this place is not just about the coffee it's the EXPERIENCE!! 

Absolutely recommended!!!
author: Nisha D.

description: I cannot believe I am saying this, but there is such a thing as taking coffee too seriously. This coffee is absolutely amazing, and the shop is undoubtedly on the cutting edge of all things coffee. That said, it is better described as coffee lab or haute coffee palace. The average tourist or commuter may not appreciate or have time to appreciate everything that goes into a cup of coffee here. You should know what you are committing to when you go here: bow down to the coffee gods.
author: Andrew P.

description: I came back to Blue Bottle despite having not really enjoyed it my first time and I am really glad I did because I LOVE BLUE BOTTLE now! hahah The first time I came, I had tried the iced coffee because that is what they are known for, but this time around, the barista had suggested to my friend that she order what she usually likes. If she likes a cappuccino, then get that and they will make the best cappuccino she has ever had. I took this advice for myself as well and ordered my usual drink, a latte. It was really one of the best lattes I've ever had. It was just as good or better than the other best latte I have ever had (at Seattle Coffee Works in Seattle, WA). So, if you come here...just order what you usually order and it'll be the BEST version of that drink you've ever had.
author: Christina T.

description:
A large part of Tour de Mom involves waking up at 7am and eating breakfast somewhere close by, and downing copious amounts of coffee. 

This morning we hit up Blue Bottle.

We split a waffle (and I say split like it was 50/50, no- I had 99% of that waffle because I am a 300 lb fat man masked as a 5'3" ginger girl) and a frittata (again, I say split like it was 50/50- no, I ate all of the maple bacon and a good corner of her frittata because I am teh fats.)

All I have to say is Wow. Wow, wow, wow, wow, wow. Wow! Next time I am getting the poached eggs and cheese, or the french toast because I don't want to fit into my law school chair anymore.
author: Emily D.

description: New Orleans iced coffee, we've been apart for so long.  I miss your deliciousness and can't wait to see you again.  Next time I'm in SF, it's a date!
author: William L.

description:
This was my first time visiting Blue Bottle. Maybe my expectations were too high, but the impression I left with is that Blue Bottle is just over-hyped. 

My buddy and I ordered their siphon brew. I was actually surprised to see that they give you the bottom part of the siphon, which I thought was nice. The glass was thicker than I expected, so I didn't have to fear breaking it. So I had the Columbian and he had the Sulawesi(sp?). Both coffees were blander than expected. We could tell that the Columbian was milder in the acidity (that seems to be the case with most Columbian coffees I've had), but other than that, the two weren't all that different, and we couldn't distinguish anything special about the two coffees, even as the cup cooled over the course of an hour.

Anyways, I figured I'd buy a bag of coffee and try it out with my Aeropress at home. I thought, maybe the coffee beans are quite decent, but the brew was just not up to par. Well, it's better, but I still expected more out of Blue Bottle. 

The place was a bit small and crowded, but it's the city. They could use some more windows, because it was a hot day, and the place was a bit stuffy. 

Problem. When I was in line to buy a bag of coffee, the one cashier seemed to be busy chatting with a customer. There were a couple other people working behind the counter, not doing much, but didn't bother to help, despite a line growing behind me. Someone eventually came to help out, but didn't bother to thank or apologize to me for waiting patiently.

Overall, I am not impressed, and the prices are too high for what you get.
author: Steven L.

description: Best iced coffee I've ever had. They have coffee down to a science and an art. New Orleans Iced Coffee is the one to get!
author: Craig A.

description: Excellent coffee and breakfast. The waffle was just the right crispness on the outside and delicate and light on the inside. the butter and real maple syrup make it a home run.
author: Molly M.

description:
I'd heard about this place before, but when I got a chance to go here today with some friends, I was really excited. I didn't know what to expect, and was totally blown away the minute I walked in. There was no sign on the outside save for a little easel, but the aroma led you right in. The place almost looks like an Apple store, so clean and bright, and high-tech. I kinda liked how there were a couple seats that had open windows to the outside so you could totally watch people walk by and accidentally spill coffee on them too.

I'm not an avid coffee drinker, but I LOVED this place! I think it's the best cafe I've ever been to! We ordered the siphon bar coffee, and watched it made in the interesting (and apparently $20,000 imported from Japan) contraption. It was seriously amazing. They even personally served us. I loved everything from the clear glass plate and the glass cup down to the unique double-stacked cream & sugar pitcher. And the little piece of candy too! The siphon coffee we had was enough for 3 people and cost something like $12.

My friend got a latte, and the design in the foam was beautiful. Everything about this place screams 5 stars.

A few cool articles about the $20,000 siphon bar imported from Japan (and the only one of its kind in the US, at least since January when the article was written):

http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/dining/23coff.html?_r=1&oref=login&pagewanted=all (use bugmenot.com for a quick login if you don't have one)
http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2008/01/23/dining/20080123_COFFEE_SLIDESHOW_index.html (awesome photos better than mine)
http://theshot.coffeeratings.com/2008/01/blue-bottle-mint-plaza/ (nice review)

A notable quote from my friend: "It's like drinking from a science experiment" This same friend also noted that, "It leaves a good taste in your mouth even after you walk out of the cafe!"
author: Esther Y.

description:
A reasonable coffee place should offer drinks that you enjoy having in an environment that welcomes you to enjoy said drink. An awesome coffee place, on the other hand, should offer drinks that exceed your expectations, while providing an environment that welcomes you to contemplate your surprise. Blue Bottle is an example of the latter venue.

PS. On a side note, thanks to Blue Bottle for spreading the myth of the off menu Gibraltar and as a consequence introduce the true (Italian/ 5 ounce) cappuccino to those of us used to the overly milky American (12 ounce or larger) cappuccino.
author: Beethoven C.

description: Simply the best. Love their creamy lattes and delicious baked goods. My favorite coffee.
author: Sarah T.

description:
This location can be a little inconspicuous. If you're cruising down Cyril Magnin (which turns into 5th Street) after crossing Market Street, look for a small alley, Mint Plaza. It's not even made for cars, so you can easily miss it if you're looking for a street. There are two other ways you can approach the coffee shop as well by using Jessie or Mission Street.

The store is located in the middle of tall buildings in a 3-way alley. The area is dead as hell during the weekend in the daylight. When you finally reach the place, you might notice that there are no "Blue Bottle Coffee Co." signs. All I saw was a 66 Mint sign but it became obvious that you were in the right place after you see coffee goers coming out of the joint.

Once inside the place, you feel like you've been transported to NYC. Everyone is hustling their way through to grab a quick cup of joe except those exec types that can afford to have long lunches and chill out with the morning paper or bluetooth to their ear. Modernize, glass, lightly colored decor.  A seemingly mirage of open space.

We ordered the Kyoto Iced Coffee which was recommended served black. If you're sleepy and/or in love the rich & bold coffee taste then this would be your drink. I dumped a kilo of brown sugar to compensate.

The winner between the two drinks I ordered this day was the New Orleans Iced Coffee (w/ soy). This NOLA bad boy hit the spot. It'll make you wish they served it in a venti size. Not too strong, not too light. Quite refreshing. Both drinks were about $3 something.

I also grabbed a Snickerdoodle for $1.50 on my way out. Simple little treat but I think the NOLA Iced Coffee was sufficient.
author: Smitcha B.

description: This place is amazing. The affagato is heaven sent. There no place in socal that has flavors like this. Glad my buddy recommended it to me!
author: Jeffrey T.

description: Excellent coffee, great toast and a very friendly service. Up there with New York's best.
author: Janny S.

description:
Love the hipster vibe. Great location right by Union Square. Line was out the door when we arrived for breakfast, so plan on spending some time.

New Orleans Iced Coffee was delicious. Can definitely tell their coffee is quality, and the contraptions inside looked interesting. Waffle was divine, melt-in-your-mouth! One of the best I've ever eaten, seriously. And, it was huge. I shared it with my companion and it kept us full.

My only complaint: pricey.
author: Farheen Q.

description:
It's a comfortable place with a decent amount of seating, especially if you don't mind the person next to you being so close you're almost touching. Good coffee, great sweets. Don't skip out on the cookies! Sadly, they sold out of most of them by the time I got there, but the ginger cookie I had was light and amazing, leaving me wanting more.

It deserves all the coffee snob attention this place has been getting, just be ready to wait in line, and feels less pretentious than, say, Philz.
author: Alexander J.

description: This place is legit. I love Blue Bottle coffee and knowing my money is going towards a local business. I never order anything fancy, but they're Americano's are delicious.
author: Michael H.

description:
SF Coffee Tour

THEY DO SIPHON! That is the bestest.

Overall, didn't have great atmosphere compared to others I went to. There was not the ambiance for you to sit  and chill. 

But good coffee, not a place to chill.
author: Susan J.

description: Delicious coffee and food! The staff is friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable! Definitely a place to stop while in SF!
author: Heather B.

description:
Amazing coffee. Friendly baristas. The lines are out the door! But it's worth it. I bought beans from them a couple months ago and they STILL taste great after using them now. 

Great environment, though it can get a little loud, and difficult to hear when your name is called. Very minimalist and had a great selection of coffee related tools and drinking devices. Baristas were also great at recommending which coffee to purchase.
author: Ginger S.

description: This is still the best coffee!!!!!!! I have always gone to blue bottle in Oakland so I wanting to try it in SF just because it's San Francisco. And like always Blue Bottle didn't disappoint. I will alway recommend this place if your looking for a cup of coffee that beats out all the others.
author: Sean B.

description:
Look, I'm from Melbourne where coffee and cafe culture is seen as a right, not a privileged. So to have to wait 20 minutes in a line to get a coffee ( which, yes, is expertly made) just seems ludicrous to me. 

I really enjoyed the five or so coffees I had over the course of a week here, but the actual experience of lining up forever and receiving mediocre service just took away some of the pleasure. A few tweaks to the service design and flow of ordering (I mean, why is the the dude pulling shots also taking money?) would really improve the situation here.
author: Tresna L.

description:
I have just returned from a Sunday morning visit...no line when I arrived about 8am and the most I saw were 10 people in line...but about 6 were together in a group.  My first time visiting so I wanted to see how good the coffee is.  I ordered a bowl of oatmeal (with strawberries, cherries, pistachios) for $7 and a  for $3.5  First, the oatmeal was awesome!  VERY filling and healthy...real oatmeal...the $7 was worth it for a filling breakfast.  I ordered a Machiatto as I wanted to really taste the coffee and not milk.  The Machiatto, which is in a small espresso cup, was strong and very flavorful; I could really tell the quality in the flavor.  As I was leaving I decided to try their Drip coffee which was Three Africans and I ordered it Au Lait...it was excellent and the flavors were just as it said on their board (fruity, creamy).  I also got two Espresso-Chocolate Macaroons for $2 each to go (one for my wife!)  Fabulous!  I saw someone eating a breakfast sandwich which looked great...next time!
Overall, excellent coffee and food.  A bit pricey but in this case you get what you pay for.  If you are a "frappucino" type coffee drinker you may want to try the Latte but there are no "foo-foo" sugary high calorie milk shake coffee drinks here.  Come for the coffee and have a bite too!
I also had my Auburn hat on and got "War Eagled"!!  : )
author: Jmarc P.

description: Excellent hand-crafted coffee, fun special drinks, but the tried and true staples sing loudest, showcasing a great roast. Also delicious, their oatmeal and waffles. A nice snacky option with your morning brew.
author: Joe A.

description:
I have not tasted every coffee in the world. That said, I'm confident the New Orleans iced coffee is the best in the world.

Let me explain. Another blogger mentioned the iced coffee here and it caught in my brain. I love a good iced coffee, and I made a resolution to visit this place while I was in town.

This shop is not easy to find. It's down an alley and tucked behind a corner. But your diligence will be rewarded with a brief line to take a seat in a cozy yet modern shop.  The store itself is a bit small, but the super tall ceilings, minimalist decor and giant windows make it feel much larger. 

After a brief wait, the time came to place my order. My husband got a latte and watching it being made was far more fulfilling than actually drinking it. The artistry that went into illustrating the top of the brew was fascinating, but I've had better lattes.

The iced coffee, however, was unparalleled. The flavors were complex and subtle, and the texture of the coffee was entirely different from any other. It was thicker, more viscous and fragrant, imparting hints of vanilla and caramel. Each sip was a bit different, and tasted almost alcoholic.

It's a good thing I don't live nearby, or this place would get all my money.
author: Kelly M.

description: Tried a few things here, but you have to try the Gibraltar, its not on the menu but fantastic preparation. Tried the Kyoto as well, wasn't a fan of that.
author: Jonah K.

description: Looove the lattes! Such a small cup, but its filled with smooth happiness mmm. I would never wait in a line for any other coffee. If you haven't, you gotta try this place!
author: Miss C.

description: Great espresso, these guys know what they're doing.  And even better service.  It's a bit tight for long term posting up, but great for a pit stop or socializing.
author: Mullet R.

description:
This is coffee for the coffee lover. Absolutely to DIE for. Maybe some of the folks who are frequenting here are doing it because it's the "hip trendy" place to be, but I'm just here for f*cking coffee. To those who merely say the coffee is "heavy" word to you: Peet's drip coffee is just plain heavy. Blue Bottle is in my mind, much more "full-bodied" which means the coffee is strong but that doesn't detract from the rich taste (sometimes Peet's is on the heavy side for the sake of being strong tasting).

The New Orleans coffee also is absolutely to die for. Sugar? Why in the world is anybody on Yelp who is reviewing coffee talking about ruining a perfectly good cup of coffee with SUGAR. It's a CARDINAL sin when I see people throwing in enough sugar to bake a cake into their poor cup of coffee.

If you want to murder a cup of coffee, go get McDonald's or Starbucks. Me, I actually like to taste my coffee, thanks.

I had the Kyoto style coffee too, not bad either.

Altogether, this is coffee for people who actually like coffee as evident by the long lines. I really believe this place will simply continue being popular.

The only downside is the portions are a little small and petite. I wish they had larger cups available.
author: Doug R.

description: Stopped by here pretty much daily while at Dreamforce and the line was always out the door. Plenty of chemistry-lab style coffee-brewing gadgetry to check out while you wait though, and most people were getting their coffee to go, so I never had trouble actually getting a place to sit (and enjoying magazines left by previous patrons - guten tag, Deutsch Vogue). Amazing espresso and cookies, and friendly staff who know their coffee beans -  I got several excellent recommendations for what to take home.
author: Alyx K.

description:
BBCC almost got bumped down to 3 stars today all due to the cappuccino I had this morning. Why then the 5 stars? Read on!

With all that was happening this week in SF, the long line at BBCC was to be expected. This morning, it was a 20 minute wait in line. When I got my cappuccino to go, it had the nice latte art as usual but flavor-wise, somewhat blah. Still superior to anything from Starbucks for sure but nothing special either. What happened to the richness and complexity? 20 minutes in line for this? Disappointment was setting in. Was BBCC getting too complacent and losing their quality?

Fortunately, my answer came in a second trip in the afternoon. BBCC redeemed themselves big time. This time, I went with the single origin expresso from Tanzania...whoa. Single origin is served between 9-11 and 1-3pm daily if memory serves me right and made on a different espresso machine by a different barista. This guy is the God of baristas. He must've weighed the coffee 3 times on the scale to get the right amount of coffee and the attention to detail in making it is phenomenal. The machine is some Italian monster that requires hand press for the pressure. I ask the barista God if this machine makes better espresso than the plebeian version and he says it's just more temperamental and the shots can be less consistent. Hmm. kinda reminds me of an Italian Supermodel. Some days they treat you well, others, they're uber high maintenance with tons of drama. No offense to Italians or Supermodels.

With the Blue Angels thundering overhead, I down the espresso and my mouth is filled with chocolaty flavors and other wondrous and complex flavors. Espresso by God indeed. The Supermodel was good to me today. On that basis, they get the bump to 5 stars. Yes, it's that good.
author: Norman S.

description:
This is one institution in which the hype is thoroughly warranted. My friend mentioned that other coffee in the city has been better heralded at this point, but I'll remain loyal to BBC every time I'm in SF. 

The soy lattes are simply perfect. The soy offers a slight sweetness to the smooth yet robust espresso. No additives necessary.

For brunch, my friend and I shared the poached eggs with potatoes au gratin and sausage. The portion was huge, and more than enough for us two. The eggs were superbly poached (with nicely under cooked yolk that I love), potatoes delightfully creamy, with a pretty spicy andouille sausage. It was altogether just right.

For good measure, we added an order of toast, in which the two slices resembled refined pieces of texas toast. The accompanying raspberry preserves and butter tasted very fresh and homemade. Dangerously delicious.

The seating situation is kind of annoying, as it's fairly tight and limited. Otherwise, this is a great breakfast/brunch location.
author: Karen T.

description: Great coffee! Got a drip brew. It was very strong and woke me up from my 4pm slump. Go here.
author: Zack M.

description: I had an outstanding experience at the both the Mint building and at the Ferry building.  Both locations made a stellar cappuccino. This is the real deal - great coffee from people who take pride in their product. Expect a line out the door and a crowd inside. Everyone from the barista to the other patrons was friendly. We all made room for one another, and I never felt hurried. Will go back often.
author: msue A.

description:
This blue bottle location is in an interesting little intersection in SOMA, that's fairly devoid of traffic, and full of parked bikes.  

There was a decent size line to wait for coffee here, but I figured what the hell I'm on vacation, so there's no real hurry.

This place has plenty of seating unlike the kiosk location in hayes valley which has none to speak of.  But what it wins in space, it may lose in vibe.  The place is a bit sterile honestly.  The colors are very vintage 50's doctors office, which makes me feel like I'm waiting for surgery.  

Then again you do what ya gotta do to get a good espresso!
author: Sean S.

description: Found this place on yelp and was happy I did. Good coffee, simple menu and a clean space. I'll be back for more!
author: T D.

description:
This review still stands. I took a train over 2.5 hours to have a couple of single-origin shots on a day off. Going back, there was a one-hour delay. It was all worth it. 

***

Blue Bottle is still the modern model of coffee. Here's why: the baristas and the business. 

Why?

Because every good cafe has the right machines and grinders. Every good cafe has the right beans--sure, we could debate whether Ritual or Stumptown has more earthy espressos, or if Intelligentsia pulls sharper, lemony shots, or if Barismo has more balance--but we can't say they're better. You or I may like one flavor over the other, but that's really a matter of taste. And we can even certainly say that the best cafes have great baristas. 

But Blue Bottle has at its core a fundamental business philosophy that lets these baristas really practice at perfection. I've seen them toss shot after shot if it's not pulling right. I've seen them stare into the grind of the beans to see how they're getting churned out. I've seen them level the tamper elegantly like a slow-dance partner getting dipped at the end of a choreography. I've seen them deal with the impatience (and wave away the excitement) of the inevitable line. Nothing disturbs these guys in their habits. 

I've never seen a place so clean of an errant ground. I've never seen a place so methodically wiped down and re-calibrated after every shot is pulled. 

Blue Bottle is the king in a wave of new attitudes that treat coffee as a fruit rather than a bean (which it is). But it's really because their business model puts the baristas ahead of even their beans. They train and develop their baristas and then really let them conduct the business of brewing. It's why I can pull awesome shots at home with a semi-professional setup but why these guys pull God shot after God shot, even in the radically changing weather and humidity of San Francisco. 

It's why Blue Bottle remains the model the rest of us are trying to follow.
author: Z S.

description: My Cap was delicious and perfectly foamed. Art was good. Environment was busy and a bit noisy but the service was friendly, knowledgable and very quick. In short: these guys know what they're doing, you should go here
author: Alex A.

description:
Yuck!  Homeless guy snatched a toast off the counter. Barista chased him down the street and grabbed the toast back  Then the barista came back, put it on a plate, and tried to serve it to me! Hell no!

Syphon coffee was excellent, but how about some lessons in food safety?
author: MsMargo M.

description:
I'm back in Los Angeles, and I'm sad that I can't get New Orleans iced coffee here. 

The New Orleans iced coffee is a must. It's smooth and full bodied upfront but it's slightly sweet and mellow at the end. So amazing. Any iced coffee after this cup will be disappointing.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I ADORE this coffee shop! Yes, its trendy, and yes, it's expensive, but every drop of their perfectly made soy lattes are worth the expense, and where else can you get an affordable, personal siphon coffee in such a cool space?

I took my old-school chinese parents here, people who scoff at paying more than 50-cents for a cup of coffee, and even they loved it. 

Parking's not too bad, but it's also walking distance from the Powell St. station which is nice. Sometimes, there are even food trucks just outside. Try to come during off weekday hours when there's barely a line, and you will have an improved outlook on coffee and life. Seriously!
author: Ting S.

description:
(1000th review for Blue Bottle Coffee Co...Yay BBCC!!!)

My coworker introduced me to Blue Bottle earlier this week as we were walking back to work from lunch and decided to stop in.  Talk about a hidden gem yet, there was a line out the door!  I had good vibes about it and decided to stick it out.  

I wasn't sure what to get so I asked the barista/cashier, who was so pleasant and he described each beverage I had a question about, even if the line was out the door.  I decided to try out their New Orleans Iced Coffee.   The barista asked me if Whole Milk was okay, I politely said no and asked for Half & Half, to which he then pointed at the counter towards the door telling me to help myself.  Okay, if I wanted that kind of service I would've gone to Starbucks but honestly, it didn't rub me the wrong way as he was demeanor was so pleasant.

When I was handed my New Orleans Iced Coffee, I thought it was a mistake as it was a small cup and not a hughmongous Venti sized cup, which I figured it would be for $3.75 but I kept an open mind about it, put Half & Half, stirred it a bit and took a sip.

I'll tell you, I'm a coffee junkie and my coffee consumption is out of this world but in this case, size did  not matter!  It was the smallest and most amazing Iced Coffee I've ever had!  I think the most akward but good thing about it is that I didn't even have to sugar it up.  It was very smooth and a sheer joy to my palette to take little sips as we walked back to work.  I enjoyed it so much that I went back the next day.   My pleasant barista boy wasn't there but still had a wonderful experience and intend to make it a regular lunch hour stop.
author: Nick D.

description: It was one of the first in the start of hunt for best coffees. This place was beginning of being a coffee snob. Hahaha  Once you've had good ones ....
author: Chelle P.

description: I'm sorry, I've converted to Philz. After the drip, the New Orleans iced, the Kyoto iced, the mocha... I've realized that Blue Bottle coffee is fine, but it's a tad too strong and bitter. I do really enjoy this location in Mint Plaza (as opposed to the kiosk in Hayes or at the Ferry building) because there is seating as well as snack options. You can easily grab a seat outdoors in the courtyard if you're not in the mood to deal with the hoards of people inside the cafe. It's a legitimate option for bringing friends from out of town just because of all the hype. But I still prefer Philz...
author: Shirley L.

description: One of my favorite coffee places in San Francisco.  The coffee is amazing and the interior design is unparalleled. Hands down a wonderful experience overall.
author: Andrew U.

description:
Okay.....So today I went coffee shoppe hopping. Being new to the area & obsessed with coffee I wanted to experience the best San Francisco has to offer. I loved this place. Customer service was great! i love this place. The pour over, though not conventional, was phenomenal. The espresso, to die for. The Siphon coffee, (we got El Majahual from El Salvador?) Was rediculous. & even the double chocolate Rechutti cookie was pretty badass. 

The Customer Service was fantastic. Normally, as a barista, i get to spark up conversation with the fellow baristas. I LOVE hearing everyone out of on coffee & coffee theory...to see how they are doing things & what new things they have learned.  Here i was treated more like a guest then a customer. I ordered and then the manager (Chris?) hooked it up for free. (Dude, you are pretty Badass!) The man on Register was so cool, super kind (& i know how it is to put up with San Francisco's best). The guy who made my espresso shot knew what he was doing. It was so good! i will be back, often! i loved it!!!

All on in all.... pretty much one of my favorite shops & i will be returning often...
If you love coffee...do yourself a favor PLEASE GO HERE!

The end
author: Joshua D.

description: A must-try if you visit San Francisco. The New Orleans style iced coffee is to die for!
author: Matthew L.

description:
Really great coffee and the staff is really helpful and friendly. Not the typical snobbery you might expect from places serving this kind of quality.

The building is tucked away in a little alley way just blocks away from the main shopping center but it might as well be miles away. Aside from the construction down the block, it's a nice, quiet spot. 

I wanted an espresso and a cappuccino and the barista was kind enough to help and offer suggestions. Definitely recommend and I will be coming back next time in SF.
author: Anthony O.

description:
If I lived in the SF area, I would be here every day.
I went to visit a friend and the first thing we did was came here. I'm a coffee lover and supporting a place like this is well worth it. My favorite test drink at any new coffee shop is a mocha, and Blue Bottle knew how to do it right. By the way, the snickerdoodles are fantastic. Before leaving, I was sure to buy a pound of coffee plus a few souvenirs to brew their coffee from my place on the East Coast (not to mention a couple of snickerdoodles for the flight!).
author: Caprice S.

description: The coffee is good but the wait time in line and to actually get a drink is ridiculous. I waited 20 minutes to get an iced coffee, who really has time for that? Lol
author: Tyler K.

description:
It's all already been said, but as a coffee snob I can say their coffee is amazing. I had their cappuccino which was phenomenal and also the New Orleans iced coffee which was amazing! The people who work there are friendly and knowledgeable about coffee ~ a rare combo these days!
Can't wait to go back to SF and hit up this place again!
author: Katie G.

description: This was my first time trying Blue Bottle. I had heard a lot from my San Francisco friends about how amazing it was, and I must say that it truly lived up to its hype. The New Orleans iced coffee was so delectable, and I enjoyed that it was not too sweet. The yogurt with granola that I had was just the right amount of filling, and paired well with my iced coffee. The atmosphere was really inviting, and you can tell that the people that work here are passionate about what they do. When I come back to San Francisco, I most certainly plan on returning.
author: Christopher N.

description:
Kind of disappointed today. A lot of people looked like they were here just because it was the "cool" place to be. I have had excellent drip coffee here but the espresso I got here today was kind of watery.

Regardless the beans - a half pound of Retrofit Espresso, were amazing.
author: Vivek K.

description: A very nice coffee at affordable prices. I would recommend anyone in SF to visit Blue Bottle.
author: Ryan B.

description: Exquisite coffee! Had the Burundi Iced Coffee...so good! Bought 4 1/2 pound bags of coffee and a drip system...can't wait to brew at home!!!
author: Terri S.

description: AMAZING coffee! So much better than Starbucks (and I drink Starbucks everyday, but that's about to change)  The folks at blue bottle are so kind and welcoming. Love the modern atmosphere. Fantastic!
author: Dario L.

description:
I'm not sure why there is such a cult following here, but that being said, the coffee was good.

If you can wait in the line that extends out the building (it takes about 15 minutes) for your turn to try Blue Bottle, then you'll be ok.  I was told to get the New Orleans iced coffee so I did - it was very tasty and couldn't have been any better.

As I watched other patrons order their coffee, I realized that a lot of the excitement here was the "coffee art" made on most of the hot coffee drinks.  The white foam was turned into art, from hearts to flowers, it is a random flip of the coin (you never know what you're going to get).

I did enjoy Blue Bottle Coffee, I just will probably not walk and extra 20 minutes to have my morning coffee next time.
author: Daniel A.

description:
Would love to actually comment on the coffee: however, consider this a comment about the atrocious service. Despicable. Disgusting. 

Wandered into the Blue Bottle location on Mint. Expecting great things....

The shop was completely crowded with patrons happily sipping lattes and jammin' to the music. Two girls in front of us (there were 2 of us) had not ordered yet...One of the girls went to order, and just after she ordered this was said to us by the "barista": "the reason why our front door is closed us because we are closed". (Insert snide attitude and eye roll. A quick look at the iPhone shows 7 pm on the dot. And, FYI, 'lady' your store has 2 entrances!!  We did not materialize into the storee--we walked through an OPEN door!). Wait, there's more: the girl in front of us still got to order. Grrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr.  

So rude. We came in to take a coffee to go. Blue Bottle, your illustrious store was chock full of folks meanderly sipping along and, yet, you rude-self-indulgent-wanna-be-hipster-but-actually-just-wearing-trendy-old-navy-threads cannot be bothered to help us??!!

We hit up coffee bean & tea leaf on Market and, guess what? Better service and a damn great latte. No attitude and a bold flavor. 

Shame on you, Blue Bottle.
author: Dawn M.

description: Dropped in for a much-needed coffee. Was thinking about a cake to go with it, but the two remaining sad-looking unsold ones (albeit one made from olive oil - I hope it was locally sourced) in the display cases had fruitflies all over them because there were no backs on the display cases. I said to the hipster behind the bar, "there are flies on your cakes." After he ascertained I wasn't asking for one, he said, "yeah, it's the city", as if to provide some justification, or to point out something otherwise obvious to the awkward out-of-towner I must have appeared to be. There are flies in the non-city too, hipster - less fey ones, indeed - but cafes I am familiar with there usually don't try to advertise them as a means of selling their cakes. Being a hipster coffee bar in "the city" is no excuse for poor hygiene. The latte was nice though, for $5+. So I suppose I'll be back one day.
author: Stephen W.

description:
Since I live in the south bay, I always have to make sure I have directions when venturing into the city.

What a nice surprise when I turn the street onto Mint and recognize that it is right across the street from mezzanine!  (see Bootie review!)

It looks so charming in the day time.  There are some lofts right across the street too and some street parking.  

Blue bottle coffee is such a cute place.  They brew each coffee individually and the presentation is picture worthy.  The way they brew it is a show in itself, too!
author: Christina C.

description:
Came here to see what all the hype was about, and left not really finding out. I'm not really a coffee person, so I judge coffee places a lot based on their atmosphere. A lot of people on here say that it's "cute" or welcoming, but I feel like it can't really be cute when there are so many people in a small space. I would say it's more hectic.

This place is a bit hard to find, given that the entrance is located behind a corner in an alley. The two giveaways were people walking down the street with blue bottle coffees and the customers sitting at two awkwardly positioned tables outside.

The chairs in this coffee place are all high chairs and made me feel dwarfed when I entered (I'm already short to begin with). The line was very long, but it did move pretty quickly. The baristas work fast, and seemed to encourage you to take your drink to go, but it made me feel rushed as they were working to get you through instead of providing friendly service. The place was pretty crowded (3 in the afternoon) and there were a lot of people trying to get passed other people, yet customers still asked to get their coffee "for here". I guess they like drinking their coffee in a crowd(?)

We took our drinks to go. The place was too crowded and somewhat loud. My sister likes dark coffee, and I like sweet drinks, but we were both just neutral about our choices (New Orleans Iced Coffee and Caffe Mocha). I suppose if you like acidic-tasting coffee, you would enjoy it because it was unique and good quality coffee. The price was decent, a bit on the higher side ($8.50 for two small drinks).
author: Angela W.

description: knowlegeable and surprisingly friendly staff. Normally i find the staff a bit pretentious but on this occasion they were helpful. Am happy to come back provided there isn't a line. Be sure to avoid peak hours as the wait can sometimes be 30 minutes. Make note that there are many peak times. I haven't been enough times to have the peak hours fully down yet.
author: Pilar M.

description: Got out of line at Starbucks because my friend suggested Blue Bottle. We walked all the way from union square while i anxiously wait to get my daily dosage cup of coffee. The cafe-tender recommended the New Orlean Style Iced Coffee. .... it was DISGUSTING ! there was a sour tasted to it that still haunt me until now! It coffee itself tasted horrible and there was nothing about it that makes me wonder why everyone loves this place. I dont know if its because it's a saturday and they dont try their best at satisfying their customers or what the deal was. All i know is that I missed out on my cafe latte at starbucks for something i can barely take 2 sips of. disappointing!
author: Tiffany T.

description: Customer service is great. The waffles are yummy. Great place to go if you want something small,and not to heavy
author: M A.

description: Blue Bottle really does know how to make coffee. Great atmosphere, nice people and great coffee.
author: Rob B.

description:
2 Blue Bottle in 2 states in 1 week...now that is the life.  On my first visit to the Williamsburg, New York, location (read my review) I was disappointed that siphon was not served.  Good news: there is siphon here!!

I got a small pot of the Sertara lot 5.  The brewing process was awesome to watch.  The coffee had a light & delicate flavor which was perfect for drinking as is.  I didn't notice this at all but the boyfriend noted a slightly sour after taste.  He got himself a New Orleans style iced coffee which (we later found outer) is brewed from the giant apparatuses in the rear of the shop.  My impression of the drink was that it had a lot of milk but not too much ice.  Overall it was not all that special.

I absolutely LOVED my first siphon experience as well as the quality of the coffee served.  Can't wait to be back!
author: Karen S.

description: My husband and I went here everyday in our trip. Great pour overs. Almond butter toast and oatmeals were amazing. They also do siphoned coffe which is just as amazing as watching them make it, great attention to detail. Phenomenal coffee. Wish there was one on Long Island.
author: Amanda U.

description:
As an avid fan of Blue Bottle Coffee (and a new San Franciscan), you can imagine my surprise when I discovered that Blue Bottle Coffee existed outside of the Ferry Building! 

This location is pretty hidden and it's actually not in a very safe neighborhood (anything past 5th and Mission is sketchy). However, just look for the small sign that says "Mint Plaza" or look for the old SF Chronicle building and you know you're going in the right direction.

It's a pretty small space, but compared to the Ferry Building, it has room for coffee aficionados to sit and enjoy their espressos. There are some high top tables, and it's in an enclosed space, but it's tight. It's more of a grab and go kind of place, but you could probably sit down and read a few chapters from a novel.

The only downside is that there's no wifi here...

Great place for a quick coffee break during your afternoon shopping spree, just don't hang out outside the coffee shop, unless you want to get panhandled!
author: Krystie M.

description: I was sorely disappointed here today. This was my first time at an actual BB location; I've had their espresso and coffee before from other businesses and enjoyed it, so I expected this to be even better. Yet, I ended up with one of the most mediocre shots of espresso I've ever had. I don't know that I'd call myself a connoisseur, but I'm a barista and have tried shots from Santa Cruz to Seattle, so I'd say I know good espresso. This shot's crema was pale with no mottling whatsoever, and it was SO bitter. I tried my boyfriend's mocha, which looked beautiful but tasted like there was about a teaspoon of chocolate in it. Also tried my friend's straight up coffee, which wasn't nearly as strong as I think an artisinal cup should be. It reminded me of hotel coffee. I'd recommend Sightglass or Verve if you're looking for quality espresso.
author: Shannon P.

description:
This was my first time at this Blue Bottle location. I liked the high ceilings, natural feel, and artsy vibe. Oh, and of course the espresso! 

I kind of wish there was a way to sample their other espressos. I know it'd be near impossible to make all the varieties in one store, but the descriptions alone are not necessarily enough for me to trust [myself] and buy a bag of beans.

With that said, Blue Bottle is obviously a place where coffee and espresso are taken seriously. (There's a complex filtering process going on in the back.) 

This Blue Bottle also has a great selection of coffee/espresso making products, all a little hefty on the price but obviously top quality.
author: Jess L.

description: BBC taste is nice. I love coffee and it drink everyday! It was heard "if you'll have plan to travel in sf , you must be go BBC!  I'm in sf now ! I went to BBC today. Many people did waiting from morning, i never wait what for something to eat and drink ^^ , one reason what cause of travel  i did take in line :) BBC ocffee Aftertaste was clear in mousefeel !
author: Joo A.

description: I thought it was a little overpriced and they didn't have wifi so I ended up getting it to go. The cashier was nice and friendly, but they were definitely coffee snobs.
author: Megan F.

description: Has to be the best breakfast I've had in San Francisco. The iced coffee was really good. I loved the poached with piquillo pepper cornbread. The sausage was spicy and juicy! And the outside seating was very relaxing.
author: Hala S.

description:
Fabulous coffee brewed to near perfection. The roast is bold and aromatic. The coffee shop had a long line in the morning but service was relatively quick. Store has gigantic windows from floor to ceiling which lit the place with gorgeous natural light.

We also had breakfast here, the toast is just right with delicious berry jam and whipped butter. Benedict portion was a bit small (no salad or any side), but the hollandaise sauce was delicious.

Overall a lovely cafe in downtown San Francisco.
author: Chris Z.

description:
This is my favorite Blue Bottle location. I love to come for breakfast - the ACME toast with the poached eggs is always such a treat. And of course their coffee is just wonderful, though I occasionally get a latte that's on the lukewarm side.

My favorite place to sit is the far back counter - you can watch them cook the eggs (I'm in awe of how they poach so many perfect eggs in a row!).

The only negative is that the staff can be a little pretentious. We asked if we could get the beans we bought ground there and had eyes rolled at us. Okay, fine that you don't do that, but it's okay to be nice about it!
author: Laura Z.

description:
Came here for after shopping downtown, and glad I came to this store! I've been to the ferry building location a few times and locations that serve blue bottle but I think they make the best new orleans iced tea out of all other locations (yes, I can taste the difference). 

The new orleans iced coffee ($3.75) was delicious. I think they make it slightly sweeter at this location to the other ones, but I like it! The store is very clean and well lit. There are seats if you want to sit down. They also have a lunch menu available. Staff are very friendly and asks if I whole milk was okay with my coffee (I think you can also ask for low fat milk). There are also little glass cups on the side that you can pour yourself some water while you're in line. 

Bathrooms are available if you grab the key on the counter (labeled 1 and 2 so use the right key for the right bathroom!)

Might come back to get another cup of coffee and try something on their lunch menu! (overheard someone talking about the grilled cheese sandwich....)
author: Whitney W.

description: Wow, crazy lines even at 2pm!
author: Jess C.

description: Crafted coffee worthy of the highest praise. In my top 3 coffee houses in the country. Great menu, awesome ambiance, and it looks like your coffee drink comes from a steampunk laboratory.  There's usually a decent line but it's well worth the wait.  This is a go-to for me every time I am in SFO.
author: Mark F.

description: This place is serious about espresso.  As an Italian barista I appreciate that.   They have a few different roasts and are crazy busy.  Killer menu.  I have been a few times, the last one the barista slightly over pulled the shots which was disappointing.  However, it's the best San Fran alternative for serious espresso lovers!!!
author: Chris H.

description: Always amazing at the blue bottle - NY or SF can't go wrong. Order the cortado - or as they say in SF the Gibraltar (cause its in a rocks glass). Amazing. Smooth, perfect, no sugar, ever!  Don't need it when the coffee is this perfect.
author: Michael K.

description: Amazing attitude. Ordered a cappuccino which was burning hot, to the point that the milk was scalded. As someone who knows coffee and a home barista I sent it back as even I wouldn't have even produced garbage like that. I got immediate attitude from both baristas. The female barista pulling shots made snarky comments and looked like she had eaten a bag of lemons. Shouldn't work there if you don't like it there lady. I waited 15 minutes for a replacement. Took 50 minutes to get 2 coffees and a waffle. By the way the waffle wasn't a patch on WC Morse. I've been to Blue Bottles all over SF an Oakland and won't be wasting my time at this one again.
author: James D.

description:
Steph and I stopped by here yesterday in the afternoon, cause who works a full day on Thanksgiving eve????  Took a break from the hustle and bustle of Union Square and the Westfield Mall for some coffee therapy. 

Being Southeast Asian, I think I've ben addicted to Ice Coffee since my first sip of Vietnamese Ice Coffee at the age of 6 or 7.  I put up with iced drinks at Starbucks because its everywhere and easy to get to.  They aren't really iced coffees tho, more of iced sugar drinks.  Blue Bottle on the other hand makes an iced coffee in its truest form.

This particular location has two types.  The Kyoto style and the New Orleans style.  I had the Kyoto back in June, and it was decent.  However, the star of the show is the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee.  Smoother than the Kyoto, you get a complex roast flavor with a hint of what can only be brown sugar.  Just enough sweetness to activate the sweet pallette of your tounge, but not overpower it.  The organic whole milk used completes the iced coffee!
