The place is nice.  An old style downtown bulidling in an alley.  You almost feel as if you accidently found this place.  The line out the door tells you that you didn't.  The customers are a bit on the hipster side, but thats expected in a coffee house in closer proximity of the Mission.  I prefer the hipsters to be making my coffee, but it went well the feel of the building.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Blue Bottle is my favorite brand of fancypants coffee in SF. Their drip coffee is so good, I never have to add cream or sugar or anything to it. I often take home a bag of beans for a fine cuppa at home. 

Having said that, the service here has got to be the slowest of any coffee shop in history. If there's even a hint of a line (and even when there's not!), expect to stand around waiting upwards of 30 minutes for your caffeine fix.

The person who makes the espresso is often the same person who takes the order and rings customers up. Just hire more people! I mean, it's Blue Bottle, they've got to be good for it, right?

They always seem super relaxed, too, even during peak hours. Alls I know is, I want whatever they're smoking.
author: Anna H.

description: If you've waited out the lines, that so often find themselves snaking out of this capsule cafe and earned your spot to order a coffee, then congratulations, my friend. In an alley way just off 5th, this Blue Bottle outlet is no secret to city dwellers and workers. It's a popular choice for the caffeinated set and friends and I made pilgrimage to it on several occasions during a recent trip to San Francisco. The location means it is one of the better coffee choices in the area (although, personally, not my favourite). Their service order needs a little polishing - I mean, the barista shouldn't be taking orders when the poor  guy has an order log a mile long to brew and froth. Still, for a reasonably quick moving line, affordable coffee never smelt so good.
author: Lani P.

description: Maybe the best latte I've ever had! I lived in the Seattle, Washington area for 11 years, so I've had a latte or two. Small place right off riff-raff row but the line is out the door while it is open. Only larger size options would make it better.
author: Ken W.

description: The hype has a reason: Blue Bottle Coffee is the BEST coffee I have had since leaving Germany 6 years ago. I am a true coffee snob, so it is hard to please my coffee taste buds. This is a little gem--little as there is not a lot of space. The line is usually long, but it's worth the wait. Personally, I don't understand the hype about their Iced Coffee, but their Latte is amazing! Yummy cookies as well. Loved it!
author: Bibi R.

description:
Have you ever had a drink that tastes fairly unremarkable at first, yet gets better and better with each subsequent sip?  Interestingly enough, that's what my first ever cup of Blue Bottle tasted like.  Being a hot coffee person myself, I opted for the drip coffee and it was very, very tasty - low acidity with smooth & crisp body.  Having gotten used to Peet's though, it did taste rather weak and bland upon first sip...so it took some time to notice the character.

I tried some of my friend's Kyoto iced coffee as well and that was really nicely done.  It had a thick, velvety texture that I've never seen in any iced coffee and an almost winey flavor.  

I can't say that I was blown away, but I would absolutely come back to try their espresso drinks and have more of the drip.
author: Eric F.

description:
A coffee connoisseur? A lover of pure, rich coffee, unadulterated by the likes of Starbucks? Then this place is for you! 

After waiting in a long line, we ordered a cafe mocha, finished with a beautiful leaf design. The coffee was strong and delicious, and what coffee really should taste like. 

The service was good, the ambiance is simple but welcoming, and I can definitely see what all the hype is about! 

I'm going to take all my coffee-lover friends here!
author: Julia H.

description: The New Orleans style iced coffee is the best way to start my weekends in San Francisco; I am really just leaving this review to remind myself that I enjoy coming here.
author: Dove N.

description:
I've walked right by this place a few times while on my way to Mezzanine (Across the street). I had no idea that a cute little coffee shop existed here. I ordered a simple latte, which was solid. 

The workers are pleasant and there's plenty of seating. The high ceiling windows allowed a lot of natural lighting and ventilation. 

The best part of my experience was watching the barista use the infrared siphon pot system. As the water was boiling in the contraption, the theme song of "Weird Science" came to mind :)
author: Agent X.

description:
First off, I am not a coffee drinker, I usually drink coffee when I have a severe lack of sleep and normally it's just straight black coffee.

I love the smell of coffee however, and like the environment most coffee shops have.

Being ever the explorative consumption machine that I am, I ordered the weirdest thing they had on the menu, the Kyoto style iced coffee. It didn't even smell like coffee, and kind of smelled like alcohol.

I tried my friend's New Orlean's style coffee and it was cheaper and better than mine.

The cheapest coffee of the three of us looked, smelled, and tasted the best, and it was the standard drip coffee, which I am led to believe is what most coffee drinkers have come to love.

However for all its grandeur one of my friends, who is a regular coffee drinker said, "ehhh".

I don't like the environment this coffee shop has either, it resembles the inside of a new home's kitchen mixed with an on sale version of IKEA's floor models and the sign outside is just a picture of the blue bottle. The sugar and cream containers were more complicated than they needed to be and seemed less functional/hygienic than other coffee places.
author: Thanh T.

description:
Staying Downtown SF on Market, a great place to get some Morning Mud is at Blue Bottle Coffee.  And if you can tolerate the long lines, throngs of unruly, caffeine deprived zombies of the SF Chronicle apocalypse (people..please get over yourself...)  you will surely be rewarded with a most excellent cup of fruity, robustness that will jolt your body for the rest of the day!  

I'm just amazed at how many people can fit into this somewhat compact, almost claustrophobic space; were it not for the soaring ceiling heights and beautiful oversized windows looking over the picturesque street corner, it wouldn't be as great as a destination hub.  But thank god, it's got it all, location, space and goods.

With all the different methods of the coffee process, it's kinda of a blessing that there's a line to register, it's truly hard to make a decision on what kind of coffee to get.  And it's always fun to see what other people have ordered.  We ended up going on a weekend morning, and they had a Brunch Menu, which made it particularly busy and chaotic, with wafts of warm savory smells permeating the interior like breakfast perfume...

I had finally opted for a regular cappuccino, the coffee  is extra great here, but it has a way of over jolting me to the point of caffeine coma, which spells trouble...  So instead I ordered a gentler beverage that my body would better receive, which was just right!

Always an experience to come to this location and we will always love Blue Bottle Coffee!

Ratings (Out of Five Stars)
Food:            5
Ambience:    4.5
Service:        4
author: Alan M.

description:
Mmm I love Blue Bottle Coffee especially the New Orleans Iced Coffee ...!!!

Great shop and its fun to just watch the technique in brewing.. Good Times
author: Anthony S.

description:
I haven't noticed that corner in city until I yelped Blue Bottle, if you live in the city and never walked thru the Mint Plaza, then you should. 
Can't go wrong with ice cream and espresso ! I adore the affogato !
author: Shadi K.

description:
Wow, this place is more expensive than Philz.  That says something!  I've had the latte (excellent, but nothing special) and the Kyoto iced (this is the only place you can get it, outside of NYC in the US).  

The Kyoto iced machine is esthetically insane, and the coffee that comes out is incredibly concentrated and flavorful.  The day I went, the roast in the Kyoto machine was a bright, lemony Ethoipian bean.  I would have preferred something with more of a carmel undertone, but when it takes 12 hours to brew a batch, you can't exactly specify!

I was foolish enough to drive down here, but I did find parking, and there are 3 parking spots right outside (in the alley) where you can park before 6pm (when it becomes a passenger loading zone for the club across the alley).  

I would come here again because the Mint plaza location is beautiful and a great place to hang out, but I wouldn't get the Kyoto iced again.
author: Olivia L.

description:
I waltzed in at lunch time yesterday.  There was no line, and I got a delicious macchiato in about 3 minutes.  This place is gorgeous, and it has good vibes.  There was no problem finding a seat for me and table space for my laptop.  I got a friendly WiFi network in about 10 seconds (though I'm not sure that it was provided by Blue Bottle).  So why only 4 stars?  First of all, the famous vacuum coffee wasn't available -- the operator was taking a break.  Secondly, why did my drink cost $3.01 and not, say, $3?  You'd think that these guys would have figured out a system in which prices came out to be round numbers after the tax got figured in.

Great place!  I hope to be back in the next few hours.
author: Kenneth R.

description:
* So happy right now *

I think this is my favorite blue bottle location.  The indoor seating makes up for the less than pleasant walk on Mission to get there.  If you can, it's worth eating there and not ordering to go.  Being able to enjoy your perfectly crafted drink out of their paraphernalia really adds to the experience.  Also, this location offers brunch and siphon pots! The Hayes Valley location most definitely does not have either. 

In terms of food/drink quality: their latte has been consistently sweet, creamy, perfect.  And their brunch is awesome; everything is made to order.  The belgian waffle came out hot; it's incredibly sweet and goes perfectly with a cappuccino.  Their poached egg dish flavors complement each other and the portion-size left me full, but not stuffed:  fresh mixed greens coupled with sweet cornbread, spicy sausage and two poached eggs.  It was amazing despite the fact they overcooked my egg (and that's saying something!)

I will definitely go back - it was raining so the line wasn't that long (15 minute wait max).
author: Kimya P.

description:
SO overrated.

Sometimes people want to clinch onto something because its so different from everything else and if they like it then they're cooler than you. Forget that. If something sucks, then it sucks. 

Blue Bottle your coffee sucks. Chicory in my coffee? No thanks. Two stars for having a cool setup though. Everything else is a gimmick.
author: kareem r.

description: Came here for a quick sit down breakfast before giving a conference talk nearby. While the line was out the door, it went by surprisingly fast. If you're planning on sitting down, the turn around rate is decent. The location is large, spacious, well-lit, and clean. I ordered a cup of coffee and the plain poached eggs (caution: other accompanying sauces contain red meat). The price was good. The coffee is some of the best as usual. It definitely helps that all the coffees are prepared single cup pour-over. The poached eggs was very well prepared, although I wish it could have been a little more peppery.
author: Silis J.

description:
Heavenly coffee again! Right next to Bloomingdales. How convenient it is for your sober shopping experience. Buy things that you really need! 
Unlike the one in Linden st., this one you can actually dine in. There's a small collection of food you can choose from. And the siphon bar in the end was very impressive, like what you see in the chemistry class, looks like they are damn serious about coffee. And never forget about those free pour coffee art, they are just simply beautiful. 
I love coffee and I love blue bottle.
author: Serena H.

description:
3 Stars only because I'm disappointed that they would serve quality coffee but not accept Amex. 

But otherwise, the baristas here definitely know how to brew the ever popular Oakland coffee. I definitely appreciate their care in generating the appropriate taste for drip/siphon coffee. If you normally work in the city, there's no crazy line early in the morning during weekdays.
author: Leah J.

description: Love their coffee. I would say this hipster joint slowly grows on you. The first time I tried their coffee I wasn't that impressed but I found I slowly became addicted. Great place to hang out with a clean minimalistic ambiance. I love the design aesthetic of their store and menu with carefully chosen typography and illustrations. Cute place!
author: Jennie C.

description:
My coworkers brought me here one day after a meeting. This place is quite a walk away from our office, and then when we got there the line was huge.

I'm not a huge coffee drinker, I wanted to order tea but the item I wanted they could not be madeTo-go, so I ended up ordering a mocha. It was good, but not amazing. It was more bitter than I was expecting. They did a fancy leaf design in the foam so that was neat. 

I don't think I will be rushing back to this location as it is out of the way. However, if I was in the neighborhood and had some time to kill, I would defiantly stop by to try some of their tea.
author: Stephanie T.

description: I love their coffees and all, friendly staff, and now a convenient outside tent that let's customers quickly order to-go single-drip coffees.
author: Amit J.

description:
What a great place to get your morning started!

A coworker of mine had mentioned it to me so I felt I had to try it. I went early on a Sunday morning, around 8/9 and it was relatively slow. Breakfast had just ended so we ordered our coffee while we waited for the brunch menu to come out around 10.

The coffee was absolutely delicious and the interior has high windows and ceilings. The staff is also very friendly, even though places like that might give off the impression of otherwise. It's also a great place to bring kids as they have kids options on the menu.

I managed to get back in line to order food items but the line QUICKLY WRAPPED AROUND THE BUILDING. It was insane. I hadn't waited both times I ordered so I was amazed to see how fast and how long the line got.

I ordered the toast, and my parents had the poached egg w/ sausage and granola with strawberries and yogurt. The quality of the coffee and food was superb. Just superb. The prices are reasonable and I would definitely go back any chance I have.
author: Kathryn B.

description:
I really like the coffee from here.  The differentiator for me from other blue bottle places is that this place serve a cold drip coffee called "Kyoto".  Kyoto carries such a kick that can power me through the rest of the afternoon.

There are many snacks available to complement your afternoon coffee. 

Did I mention this is a nice sit-down place as well?  The indoor seating consists many long tables and high stools and outdoor has a nice public square with chairs. 

The only downside is that there are always a line out the door.  I WANT MY COFFEE ASAP.
author: Steven M.

description: Outstanding service. Great coffee. They will give you a demonstration in siphoning if you enjoy that. Order anything - it's all good. The New Orleans iced is definitely worth a try though.
author: Sean T.

description:
My favorite of all locations due to the parking lot. I also just saw Alanis Morissette here last weekend. I think she had one hand in her pocket, and another one carrying a latte.

My favorites here are the New Orleans iced coffee, Kyoto iced coffee, or a standard cappuccino. Cannot go wrong with anything here. I just wish they had the same waffles that they serve at the Ferry building.
author: Andy L.

description:
Oh pretentious blue bottle...I just don't get it.  I wish you all the success, but I've found at every branch of your blossoming chain that the wait is EPICLY long.  I've been to a branch where there were 2 people ahead of me when I arrived with my friend.  I swear that the 4 of us total were there for over 15 minutes for the extensive ordering and making process.  I just didn't get it.

Then I offered to bring a group of girlfriends to get a cup of coffee before we had to leave our hotel, and the line was out the door...I recoiled my recommendation, but the girls saw something someone was eating and wanted it.  The line, just a little out the door had us standing and waiting 25 minutes.  I timed it.  We all received our food and drinks between 35 minutes and 40 minutes after we arrived.  I just don't get it!  I guess it is some kind of "experience" to wait that long for coffee?

And, I'm sorry, I'm not a coffee expert, but I have tried coffee all over the world.  Honestly, I couldn't tell your coffee apart from Starbucks!  Peets, the brand I usually get is Major Dickason's, I think is better!  Maybe because my office always provided that I got hooked, but whatever!

Again, wish them all the best, and you can work on your auto-biography in line!!
author: Lacey P.

description:
New Orleans Style Iced Coffee.
Pure chicory heaven!
author: Derek N.

description:
Love Blue Bottle Coffee!

Have been here a few times while traveling in SF. Great Coffee shop, great for moment to relax and enjoy some delicious latte in a cute little area sorta off the union square strip.

They do fresh chemx and extraction, which is awesome.

The Safron Snickdoodle cookie was pretty delicious!

Great vibe, Coffee, Hot Chocolate....Coming back for sure!
author: Steven H.

description: This place didn't have disgustingly bad coffee, but it had a lot of hype so I was disappointed to get a fairly mediocre tasting drip coffee. Especially waiting in line for so long with a million hipsters in the most awkwardly arranged spaces.
author: Danielle C.

description:
As good as it gets!! Amazing crack coffee! The New Orleans Iced Coffee is the best coffee I've had (yet). 
Can't really say much, just go try it, it will not disappoint!
author: Helen D.

description: This is heaven in a cup! It's so good that lines go out the door! It took us 20 minutes to get our coffee while we were visiting, and apparently this is considered a short wait.
author: Ying Ying Z.

description:
Super cool!  This cafe would be good even if it a. wasn't home to the first five light siphon bar in the US, b. wasn't somewhat hidden from the main drag of the city, c. didn't have to most slammin' double chocolate chip cookies ever.  EVER.  

This was my first experience with coffee produced on a siphon, and while I'm not usually drawn to Guatemalans, the cup that the siphon produced was nothing short of incredible.  A light mouthfeel, but intense syrupy flavors of chocolate and stone fruit made for a memorable tasting experience so much so that I have half a mind to learn to brew with one at home.  The cafe itself s what you can expect from Blue Bottle, a clean design, lots of brushed metal, etc.  Comfortable for sure.  It was fairly busy when we were in there, I'd like to catch it on a slower day so I can actually get a better eyeful of the siphon process.  Looking forward to a return visit.  Did i mention the cookies?
author: Adam B.

description:
Happiness is stepping out into the California sun with a New Orleans iced coffee from Blue Bottle in your hand. Cold-brewed and steeped overnight with chicory and a touch of sugar, then served on ice with a splash of milk, this Blue Bottle specialty is the thing to get. 

Though the java's obviously the draw here, the food is also delicious. My egg salad was the perfect lunch: creamy, seasoned well, slathered on crusty bread and served with pickled veggies. 

While here, I grabbed a few additional bags of beans to go, as they make for light and delicious-smelling gifts. Though I worried they might be wasted in my friends' regular-ol' coffeemakers, the staff assured me they'd brew up just fine. 

I'm sad I don't have a Blue Bottle in my neighborhood, but I'm looking forward to bringing some of its magic along with me when I head home.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I usually avoid Coffee Joints with cult followings as a rule of thumb but yesterday in a moment of weakness I found myself inexplicably drawn into  the shop sporting the Blue Bottle logo.
 
Not sure if it was the fact that it was 80 degrees outside (is that even possible in SF?) or if it was the elusive 5 minute window during the day where the line DOESN'T resemble Best Buy on Black Friday but there I was.

One sip of my New Orleans Iced Coffee and I suddenly sympathized with every Cheater who's ever scurried away on a forbidden tryst. I quietly finished my drink and ducked out before an incoming crowd of Hipsters could spot me and point an accusatory finger.

Eventually, I'll get caught and will have to deal with the repercussions of my mocha-induced misjudgments, but until then the Blue Bottle will hold me captive with her exquisite selection of bondages.
author: Kevin T.

description: When its not over crowded and I am in that decrepit waste land of a hood! It rocks! The baristas are killer, they are attentive and really try get you moving! The coffee kickass, their mochas kicks ass and the breakfast is "The Bomb"! I usually get the egg,sausage and corn bread thingy! Perfect portion and quite yummy, yummy, yum yum! It just when you walk out of there reality hits you! I guess that add to the flava of it all......?!
author: Miguelito C.

description:
Stumbled upon this lovely coffee shop while waiting in line for the Chairman Bao Truck at Mint Plaza. There is no wording, just a simple blue bottle. I can tell this place is pretty popular with the local folks that work around the area, like SF Chronicle and Square. There is almost always a line out the door and about half the people have paper cups for take out.

Interior reminds me of a high school science lab, especially chemistry! There are large siphoning cylinders for the Kyoto-style iced coffee as well as the drip coffee. I had a latte the first time, with lovely latte art handcrafted and tasty. And although I usually like to put sugar in my coffee, this one didn't need it at all! I also tried the New Orleans style iced coffee and it was so refreshing! The coffee is definitely strong and kept me going throughout the day :)
author: Karina C.

description: Yes, it's super expensive but it's totally worth it for this high end brew.
author: Nathan E.

description:
Again rounding up and giving a 4 star when my preference would have been to give a 3.5. Maybe it is a woman thing to need the 0.5 option.

Anyway, had an espresso shot and cappuccino here and they were both quite good. I would have like the cappuccino a little stronger with more espresso and that is my big gripe about this place, that the cappuccino wasn't strong enough. The foam quite nice but the milkier base not so.

My memory of a good cappuccino is that you are not aware of when the foam ends and the milkier part begins, the whole thing just feels like one smooth aerated perfection. This cappuccino was definitely not that.

Also, with the limited seating and the longish line to get the coffee, the final product didn't seem worth the fuss.

Parting remark, despite my rants the cappuccino and the expresso were pretty good. And given my limited success finding good espresso in the bay area this might become by go-to when in the city.
author: Anupama C.

description:
Okay! So seriously!! You guys really need to try Blue Bottle!!! Today, I went by for coffee and was in a slight hurry!!!! I looked at their menu and could not find a quick cup of joe for the life of me! So I ordered the Individual Drip Coffee which is...  yes, individually made at the time of your order!!!!! They pour hot water into a porcelain vessel that holds the filter and coffee and it drips down into your cup! Yeah, I had to wait but it was worth it!!!!!!

Damn, this stuff is AWESOME!!!!!!!

Deal is, this place is all about quality. They treat their coffee like fine wine. And if you walk in wanting their coffee, they assume you've heard how good the quality is, and thus they don't hurry the process by any means. So tough nookies, you're going to have to be patient. I've never seen the staff at a coffee shop so at ease and completely in tune with their craft. A cup of coffee is damn easy, but a quality cup of coffee is damn hard.
author: Al L.

description:
So I finally came back. I have to say I LOVE this place! I came at a less busier time (not during breakfast time) ... and it was equally clustered but definitely breathable  this time around. The baristas were very nice and gave us a taste of their famous siphon'd iced coffee. 

This place, when not busy, is very open and airy, and a great place to relax with a delicious cup of coffee that you will ever sip on ... in this region anyway. This location has slightly better parking and is a little easier to find than the Linden st kiosk location plus takes credit cards and has more stuff to buy! Recommended for anyy time of day!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Great coffee, great atmosphere, typical high end and serious coffeehouse.  

One negative is that they do not have artificial sweeteners, FYI.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Had another girl's day out with my mom and my sister in SF. HAD to come by this place again. STILL 5 stars. just wanted to update on what we got. 

I got a soy latte which was deliciiiouuus. This place just seems to do everything right. This time around, we came around brunch time, so they offered a different menu. 

I got the belgium waffle with strawberries. ohhh jeeez. it was so good. It was the perfect portion for me to finish every last bite. It also accompanied my coffee sooo well. (the portion may be small to those with larger appetites..) 

my sister & mom got the grilled cheese with house-made mustard...I wish I could buy that mustard and take it home. It was incredible.

Every single time i am in sf...i WILL make a stop here. It's one of my must-dos! (:
author: Priscilla O.

description: Best espresso drinks I found in SF.  Cool store but not as ornate as the other coffee houses.  They have some cool brewing techniques/science experiments with burners and test tube style apparatuses. That would be fun to try on another visit. As far as food, forget trying to go healthy...the waffle is amazing. The Popeye eggs look better than they taste though. I highly recommend this place.
author: George C.

description:
I love Blue Bottle!  This is the first Blue Bottle shop that I've been to, but I've had their coffee that's sold at other local shops.  I tried the kyoto iced coffee; it's a little bitter for my taste so I probably won't get it again but I'm giving five stars because I'm a big fan in general.

When I went there I tried to look for the long line everyone on yelp was talking about to help me look for it,  but there was no one there when I went around 11am, just a few people sitting in the shop.  So if you can wait a little while for your morning coffee, you won't have to wait in line.
author: Elle P.

description: Very tasty coffee, high quality, many locations, very popular.  For all you caffeine addicts, another spot to get your fix!
author: Chaya B.

description:
The coffee is perfectly acceptable and no one here has ever made me a bad cappuccino, but what prevents this establishment from being a solid five stars is the inhospitable staff, which I'm beginning to think must be a job requirement to work at a third wave coffee shop. The other downtown Blue Bottle location (inside MOMA) is just as bad. This isn't your quaint neighbourhood café where anyone will remember your order from visit to visit or, quite frankly, make any small talk whatsoever beyond "What would you like?" (if they even ask, usually making eye contact is sufficient). 

They serve savoury food here but I've never seen anyone order it. The baked goods are decent but the "Snickerdoodle" (loose definition) is to be avoided at all costs, unless you love marzipan, which, if you're a reasonable human being, you don't. 

Long lines between 2-4pm.
author: Kat F.

description:
I'm reviewing this location, not the coffee itself, which is the quality you would expect from Blue Bottle.

On a hidden corner in SOMA.  Plain, gray, metropolitan-feel with 15 minute lines in the morning.  Awkward set up inside makes you have to walk around or through the line.  Staff is professional and kind.  Clientele is tech/hipster.
author: Benjamin K.

description: My favorite of the blue bottle locations. The coffee is still really good, but there are a lot of other very good coffee shops and coffee roasters in sf now.
author: Meredith G.

description: For true coffee aficianado, this place is great. It's not a place for the quick cup; the Blue Bottlers exercise the patience necessary to create the perfect cup. Order a latte "for here" and enjoy the artistic talents of master baristas.
author: Ric R.

description:
I'd like to thank Yelp for steering me to this amazing little coffee joint.  I just wish it wouldn't have brought the other 30 people as well.  Yes, they have amazing coffee and food, but the line was long and slow moving, due to the small size and little seating.  

Once I did get my coffee, which was a caramel macchiato, it was quite delicious.  Nice and strong way to start my day.  They also have lots of strange coffee drinks that I have never heard of, using weird science lab equipment to make them.  I'd like to try one of those next time, but decided on something I know for my first time.  

The food was probably the best breakfast dish I had in SF this trip.  I had the poached eggs w/ Buttered Thick Cut Acme Toast, Prather Ranch Cured Ham, Gruyere Fonduta.  Wowie-wow-wow was it delicious!!!!  The toast was enough to make me want to go back for that alone.  Put everything together and it was ridiculously good.  I can't wait to go back my next time in SF....which I guarantee that I will.
author: Lacey M.

description: Best coffee on the west coast. Refreshing alternative to Starbucks. I highly recommend their latte.
author: Farokh S.

description: I've been reading the blue bottle coffee book so since i'm here in san fran visiting i wanted to visit the coffee shop. like the book said, the shop is on the side of this financial building and it's pretty easy to miss. the sign is just a small blue bottle. I got a latte and it was delicious. the store itself is small. they drip the coffee right there in front of you. i really enjoyed my latte and i would love to go back and try the coffee there too.
author: Xinyi T.

description: Great coffee and wonderful service. Line was out the door when we arrived but it moved quickly. Both the barista and the cashier greeted us with a smile and we loved that the cashier sent us off with a 'Rad' considering we are from Southern California.
author: Leigh M.

description:
Wow.  Have I ever been even more late to the party where everyone's already at the after after party and I show up with the box of taco bell.  

But yes, for some time now, my foolish ass thought this was further down like around 9th and market and wondered to myself why anyone would even go there.  But no, I'm wrong  Its been here by 5th and Mission all along!  Safe and absolutely awesome since its just a few minute walk from Union Square.  

And of course, the roasts change between some of the favorites like Three Africans or Bella, etc.  But the kicker is, this place serves up some serious breakfast.  People are actually sitting down eating a full on meal while enjoying some of that Blue goodness.  

Gotta do it up like that next time I come back.   Hate to say it, but it's hard not becoming a coffee snob in SF.
author: Vincent K.

description:
Here's a recap of my conversation with the cashier:

Me: um, do guys have a "secret menu"? [air quotes included]
Him: no, we do not have a "secret menu". [insert mocking air quote here]
Me: oh, okay.

Barista: wait, do you mean the gibraltar?
Me: YES!  I want one, no wait, two!

It's a beautiful shot of liquid goodness, jam packed full of caffeine and flavor.  

The line was insane, and the space was filled to capacity (and spills over to the outside).  Crazy!
author: Jenny L.

description: Blue Bottle is the best coffee I have ever tried - on any continent. This is coming from someone who lives part time in South America so you know it's legit. And this location is my favorite because the staff is always so friendly! The line can get long but moves along fast. The one at the ferry building is getting a little ehh in my opinion...at least the little to-go window. Nice to see Mint Plaza turn into kind of a cute little hub of hipster-ness.
author: Danielle R.

description: The New Orleans Iced coffee is one of the best in the world.  I crave it!
author: Miles C.

description: The coffee is good but not out of this world even though the prices are sky-high. Oh well ... at least I tried it. Was it worth the wait in the line winding outside? Not really! Yes, they have fancy apparatus but again, the coffee isn't that great.
author: N. D.

description:
Yeah, whatever. Just get it to go. This place feels so used and abused no longer young & fresh.
Good Fucking Coffee. 483+ Yeeps can't be wrong..
author: Patrick S.

description: I've only had the drip coffee here and it was pretty good, but based on the slow douchey service and price I probably wont be back.  20 min in line is just not worth a marginally better then average very small cup of coffee.  I have better things to do with my time then wait in line.  I also don't like the one size (small) fits all.  If they sold coffee in medium or large sized and had quicker service I might come back.
author: Brent P.

description:
I should preface this by saying that I'm no coffee nerd.

That being said, I did find the latte and mocha I had on consecutive days to be thoroughly enjoyable. Obviously, there is no comparison of a place like Blue Bottle to a massive chain like Starbucks. With the latte and mocha at Blue Bottle, you can still taste the beans and the roast. They are not overwhelmed with syrup or anything else. Indeed, I found the coffee drinks I had to have a really nice freshness to them--the coffee had red fruit qualities and tasted delicate.

Since this was also my breakfast spot the two mornings I came, I had the steel cut oats both days. I try to stay away from butter and cream, so I asked for extra jam with mine, and thought the bowl of oatmeal to be utterly addictive. Really high quality.

Before going, you should be forewarned to expect a line out the door. The Mint Plaza location is close to the Moscone Center, so there's probably a fair amount of business people here in addition to the hipster regulars. The vibe is nice, the coffee hit the spot and the breakfast food outstanding. If you have the patience to wait in a line similar to what you might find at the nearby Apple store on a product release day, then you can't go wrong with Blue Bottle.

P.S. I've gotta be a homer here and say I still prefer Stumptown's coffee to Blue Bottle's.
author: Ben S.

description: Some of the best coffee I've had.  Great beans, roasting, and brewing options.  They'll be sure to impress any coffee nerd.
author: No P.

description:
A Seattle gal wandering the streets of her not-home city looking for OUTSTANDING coffee can turn ugly. Especially if said girl is undeniably hooked on the bean, but won't drink a subpar roast. Snob. I know.  Three cheers for Yelp's iPhone app! Hip Hip..... (you know the rest).

Blue Bottle Coffee Co. was PACKED when I walked in. At first I thought a group of some kind was having a morning happy hour because the buzz and energy in the room was alive! But after a few minutes in line, and a couple of great conversations with the chatty strangers on either side of me, I came to the conclusion that Blue Bottle brings out the happy chat in a person - even pre-caffeine!  

The space is on the big side of small - you dig? - but laid out in a really awesome flow with lots of places to sit. High ceilings make it feel super airy. The small menu shocked me with the delish choices - and I was soooo craving steel cut oats so lucky me for wandering in! A tart jam, some brown sugar, and a wee bit of cream were all served on the side so I got to choose my own adventure bite by bite. Service was super friendly, and a sweet little busgirl scooted around and around and around the place like a super fast smurf cleaning up behind folks and smiling at anyone who made eye contact. They should make a breakfast quiche in her honor and call it QT Pie. 

Extra shout-out to SF yelpers who made the decision easy once I found Blue Bottle reviews on the iPhone. Great coffee. Great place. Y'all were right on!
author: emily r.

description:
Blue Bottle is my favorite place to get coffee when I am in San Francisco.  When I am staying in the city and I can walk here, that is a true treat! 

Their coffee is unsurpassed and their shortbread cookies are amazing.

At peak times, expect the lines to be long.  The secret is out.
author: Lee R.

description:
Nice place~ a little hard to find though hah
quite impressed by the latte and liked the atmosphere there:)
author: Xiaoxue Z.

description:
I love you blue bottle and I have wanted to tell you this for so long.  You taste really, really, really good (trying to keep it PC).  Japanese iced coffee, although expensive is a treat.  I also enjoy the New Orleans iced coffee with a hint of the creamer put in.  I think this is a great location, but I have also visited you in multiple locations in NY and SF.  Sometimes the wait at this location can be a little long, but not nearly as bad as you would find down on the water.

Please come to Seattle (my current home) and show us how coffee is suppose to be done.
author: Aaron H.

description: Great coffee, super slow service at the cashier counter, order messed up as an added bonus ...
author: Deep N.

description:
OK. Yes, the lines are crazy. But is it worth it? Yes it is. I would have given 5 stars, except the lines are too long and the lackadaisical attitude of the employees can be annoying. Is it OK for the cashier to sit and chat with a coworker (ignoring the customer)? No, probably not, but the coffee is soooo good! I can deal with these service-related annoyances. 

TIP: If the line ends at the door, the wait is within reason (10-15 min). If it's all the way to the corner, it's gotta be your day off, as you'll be there 20-30 min, waiting for a cup of coffee!
author: CaliGirl X.

description:
A line out the door, but is that really so bad when you're standing in the sunshine and the wind among awesome buildings and interesting people in the heart of SF? :) 

We had paid $4 million to put 15 minutes on our meter to try this place, so I was admittedly kind of disappointed when the barista politely refused to make either a macchiato or a con panna in a to go cup because, in his words, "it's too small and would stick to the sides". But I have some crazy respect for people who care about coffee, so I'm hoping to go back later and try those in their attractive ceramic cups, because the cappuccino they gave me was amazing! Milk-wise, it was more of a tiny latte, but the Clover milk was sweet and delicious, with lovely latte art, and the espresso, while not super bold, was balanced and tasty. And I'm very hyper now, so....mission accomplished!!

They've got a beautiful selection of siphon and Hario gear for sale, from kettles to a gold (plated? painted?) siphon set, to hand grinders and, of course, many types of beans. If you want to kick your addiction up a notch, this is definitely the place.
author: Christine M.

description:
Sorry but overrated for me. I am no uppity coffee elitist or anything just someone who requires some sort of value for the money or time you spend at a store, we waited 45 minutes in a line of about 15 people ahead of us to order two mochas which had no real sweetness (or even bitterness) to it, just kind of middling, which were not even hot. They were lukewarm.
45 minutes to waste and 10 bucks down the drain. Sorry guys. Not coming back here again but it was an experience to see what the san fran locals consider good. So we gave it a shot.
author: Brian C.

description:
Sure, a line is a line, but these guys haven't figured out how to handle their customer base yet.  They've got work to do.

Their food is top-notch, and I love dropping in for brunch on the weekends.

Siphons and special brews (nel-drip, etc.) are definitely worth the price.  When they try, their beans rival the best in SF and their brews can be great.  However, the Three Africans blend (their main coffee) is sub-par and I've yet to enjoy a cup out of the 5 or so I've had over the last couple of years.

Hit this place without a line and get a siphon brew with brunch... That's deserving of 4.5 stars.

Hit this place with a line and get their basic drip coffee... That's 1 star.

I'll give 'em 2 till they sort this out!
author: Rob W.

description:
I don't really know why I keep going here.  I like the poached eggs and Acme toast - very tasty and done to perfection.  However, there is nearly always a huge slow-moving line (I've stood in it for 20 min), and their coffee isn't so incredible that it's worth waiting in a line like that.  I normally drink an Espresso (sometimes a Macchiato), and I find their coffee has huge flavour (good), but bitter after-taste (not so good).  Also, there is no WiFi, which is only a problem when I arrive solo, which has actually been every time.

So, I guess I really come here when I'm in the nood to stand in line for a long time, for some OK coffee and no WiFi.  Hunh.
author: Dave S.

description:
Ok I used to love this place. 
But evidently they are physically unable to make a "dry" Cappuccino. "Sorry I can't foam the milk other than wet"...

Nice

My friend asked for a red eye and they said "well, we think that would compromise the flavor of the coffee, so I'm going to NOT do that, and serve your ish* separately."....

Seriously? who's working for who here?

If I were them I would write in big letters on the bottom of the menu: 
"no substitutions, special requests, or alterations will be made.
Go eff yourself
Go make yourself a damn coffee drink"

I thought to myself "damn! I thought I done walked into a burger king just now. Can't I have it my way?"

Flame on...
author: Christian V.

description: Now that I've quit coffee, I am working hard to find delight in things like tea and chai. Had a great pot of fresh mint tea at Blue Bottle just a few weeks ago - it made my day (admission: it was a grey rainy Monday so a pot of mint tea was actually capable of having such an impact on me). I also always seem to find a spot to sit in the cafe, regardless of how long the register line is - always a pleasant surprise!
author: Erin W.

description:
Yes it's true.   Their coffee really is that delicious. 
 It really is.

And it comes in small batches to buy and take home.  All freshly roasted and dated, so you know what you are getting.  I brought home the "Three Africans" blend and enjoyed it to the end.
author: Sandra K.

description: So worth every minute in line! I enjoyed a wheat free cookie and my friend had a molasses cookie that was delicious and even had a peppery essence to it. Neat place and good service! Love it when coffee is an art!
author: Heather F.

description:
Latte, Mocha, hot chocolate... Whatever you pick, it's a win. 

With beautiful aesthetic, exceptional coffee this spot will become your daily go to.

Lines can be long, but it's worth the wait.
author: P B.

description: This place is excessively trendy, but that being said....not bad. There was a line out the door, but it moved pretty fast and the employees were quite friendly. Tried the New Orleans style iced coffee and the Kyoto iced coffee. They make a pretty good New Orleans style, but I thought the Kyoto was awful. Way too bitter and just "blech". Had some pretty cool coffee gadgets for sale too, but the place was definitely packed so it was hard to look around, pretty much just tried to get in and out.
author: Cassandra F.

description: Delicious coffee, fun spot. Loses a star because of the long lines and high prices. I understand how expensive good beans are, I really do, but I think it's unnecessary to charge $4 for a plain cup of iced coffee. And by regular I mean tiiiiiiny.
author: Nicole H.

description: I needed a pick me up and I just got a popover from The Rotunda.  So what else on the 7x7 list can I scratch off?  Blue Bottle Coffee since it was nearby...kind of.  So the Gibraltar is not on the menu and you just have to order it.  The place itself is very quaint and located in the Mint Plaza in the back.  Just search for the #66 since the place isn't really labeled.  The Gibraltar is served in a shot-like glass.  It's pretty darn good but definitely a coffee drink and strong.  Not sweet at all, but they have really cute creamer and sugar containers at the desk.  The folks at the counter didn't seem very...friendly.  So good to stop by and try it.  Perhaps I should try something I like more like lattes or a hot cocoa or mocha.  Next time!
author: Carolen M.

description:
5 stars for the coffee preparation, quality, temperature, taste.  3.5 stars for the smugger so thick you can cut it with a knife.

Will I return?  ABSOLUTELY.

Do I frequently drive 1 hour each way to grab a cup from Blue Bottle?  YEP!

My wife had the soy hot chocolate with melted chocolate, yum!  I ordered the cappuccino, and the macchiato.  Man, this coffee never disappoints!  

No line today! Whoo hoo!
author: Todd A.

description:
Yummy!  I'm not a big coffee fan but during a team offsite, after lunch @ Chez Papa we treked on over to Blue Bottle coffee to see what the fuss was all about.  The line was out the door so I knew that they had to have some GOOD coffee in order to create this following.  I opted for the Iced coffee since it was a beautiful day outside and I wanted something to keep me cool. 

The coffee was amazingly smooth and delicious. I will definitely bring my husband here since he's a huge coffee fan.  Will definitely return.  I loved it.
author: Christine P.

description:
Love the coffee, hate the long lines, awkward seating and attitude.  Would only go there if I was forced to.

I went here once on a coffee break.  Okay, so I was buying myself a treat because it was a special occasion.  But the exceptionally rude service ruined my day and possibly week.  I was so upset afterwards that I walked back to the office in tears.  Yes, I'm a sensitive one and the blue bottle mint plaza cafe is a total scene, but hey, no coffee shop service should be that rude.

After I braved a 30+ min line, I asked for a decaf iced coffee, and basically got major attitude for asking for decaf.  The barista (after giving me a dirty look and saying something snarky to the other barista) explained they didn't do decaf iced coffee.  Okay fine, I went with a decaf iced latte instead.  Then I asked for a cookie.  I hesitatantly asked which one she recommended--the chocolate or the ginger.  Another eye roll--the barista explained that the chocolate one tastes like chocolate and the ginger one tastes like ginger.  Um Thanks, I can read.  After plopping my cookie onto a coffee filter (they don't do normal bags here), I got my decaf latte and headed out as quickly as possible.

The kicker, the cookie fell out of the coffee filter onto the floor.  Great packaging, guys, very functional.

I know that the cafe was busy and don't really care that they didn't have decaf, but why does the coffee need to be served with such a strong dose of attitude.  Siphon or no siphon, I'd much prefer a bitter overbrewed cup served with a smile, than the crap I got here.
author: Shila S.

description:
Love the dripped coffee, it is strong with full flavors! It definitely adds punch to my day. I had the syphon coffee as well, it is more for the look than the taste that attracted me to try it. 

Blue Bottle is the one an only cafe where I see line like a popular club in Mahattan.
author: Catherine Y.

description: Tasty place with lots of fancy laboratory equipments. It was really cool. The latte and grilled cheese were both awesome!
author: Lily W.

description:
So they have pretty decent coffee. Not the best, but certainly better than most. It's the line that sucks. And the fact that if there's something specific you want from their menu, there's a good chance they'll be sold out of it. Of course, you only find this out after you've been waiting in line for 20 minutes.

4 times this has happened to me. So basically I waited over an hour of my time waiting in that line on four separate visits, only to find out that what I wanted was sold out. Each time I should have just left and gone elsewhere, but instead felt obligated to order something, especially after waiting. I suggested to the staff that they should put up a sign stating whatever they sold out of so that people won't have to wait for nothing, as I have done multiple times.

I've decided to give up on Blue Bottle. But if for some reason I decide to go back, I will cut the queue and work my way inside to make sure they have what I want, while everyone in line gives me the stink eye. Nah... I think I'll just give up on Blue Bottle...
author: J K.

description: Awesome coffee!  But, you're probably not meant to stay around too long as they don't have wi-fi.
author: Eric O.

description:
i feel like i just walked into a fancy high school chemistry lab...i like it.

came in on a sunday for some alone coffee/brunch time.  easily got a seat by the window with my latte and frittata.  omg it was so fluffy with little chunks of potatoes (i've never met a potato i don't like), rosemary, sweet carmelized onions, and love.

i can't think of a better place to go for some lazy sunday solo time.
author: Sally T.

description:
The $5 Acme toast is a little like John Travolta tasting the $5 shake in Pulp Fiction. I don't know if it's worth $5, but it's good!

The $3 regular espresso good, but no better than other high end places; $9.50 for a shot of the fancy schmancy one was out of even my java junkie league. 

Iced Kyoto is the bomb--wonderful blend of sweetness & a little bitterness--a short date with a sweetheart.
author: John I.

description: Before I even landed in San Fran I knew I was coming to this place. I heard nothing but good things about Blue Bottle. This location is pretty far off the beaten path and took a little effort to find. It sits off the road and back around the corner of a building. When we walked in it wasn't that busy, so we were able to order our coffee immediately. I wanted something crazy so I went with the nil drip coffee and my wife got a latte. The nil drip coffee probably took about ten minutes to make. We pulled up a seat behind what looked like a chemistry set and watched the dude go to work. He slowly boiled the coffee up to temperature and then allowed the drip to slowly happen. When he gave me the coffee he described it like a wine..."Hints of blackberries..." I was skeptical but, he was right and that coffee was mustard. My wife's latte was also top notch. They do serve food here but by the time we got our coffee the line was out the door, so we went somewhere else. Suffice it to say, this place is unbeatable and we came here numerous times throughout our bit. Definitely give this place a go for some awesome coffee!
author: Justin K.

description: I tried a drip coffee and was little disappointed that it didn't come in a Cup/mug, as I stayed there. Also that coffee didn't taste very good for me. Maybe I should try the Espresso as a second chance.
author: Daniela S.

description:
Alright BB, you make some damn good coffee.  Duh.  You're popular, you have good looks, you're young but old enough to know your way around.  How about you open up another location or something?  Seriously.

The demand for your amazing coffee far exceeds your ability to provide, and this is a huge problem for people like me who don't exactly love waiting in line for 45 minutes for a damned cup of coffee and scone.  Why?  WHY????  The problem:  you're worth it.  Damn it, I love you, but you make our relationship so difficult.

Some of the best coffee I've ever had?  Yes.  Excellent baristas who take their time on every order?  Absolutely.  Tasty baked goods and a delightful brunch menu?  Check.  How about you give the people what they want, what they need, and hell, what they deserve, and spread the love.  It's not selling out, it's just being considerate.
author: Dan R.

description: The quiet BB that seems to be separate from the hustle and bustle of the rest of SF in the area. Also unlike the Ferry locale I can get my favorite Kyoto. The line will push all the way till closing on Sundays but once you get your cup you can sit outside in the plaza which is great when the sun shines through
author: Kim N.

description:
One of my favorite coffee spots in The City!

I love the space.  Tucked into a corner on Mint with minimal signage, this location feels like a special place that not everyone is in "the know" about (completely absurd, I know, but I'm enjoying my delusion).  The coffee-chemistry interior immediately connects with my inner-coffee junkie.  

The coffee is serious business.  If you've not cultivated your appreciation for these individually-brewed cups of caffeinated genius, you'll be annoyed by the long lines.  To those who value expertly-extracted flavor, you'll not be disappointed.  

So put a few extra quarters in the meter, walk to the corner at Mint Plaza, strike up a conversation with someone you don't know while waiting in line, order your coffee in a real cup, find a seat outside (weather-permitting), take a deep breath, and sip slowly.  

Life is good.  And to me, it seems to be a little better with a sip from the Blue Bottle.
author: Jeffery G.

description:
Line moves kind of slow, but coffee is so worth it.

The New Orleans ice coffee is amazing!! Ask for less ice so you get more coffee!! The Mocha was okay, too chocolate-y for me and not enough coffee taste.

It's also a little tight in here so take your coffee and go to Alamo Square! 

Also, I hate the location. It's in a back alley and there are homeless people scouring the area. Makes me feel REALLY unsafe. 

Amazing coffee though!!
author: Jenny A.

description:
I went in for brunch with three Colombians, and they swore it was the best coffee they've ever had!  And you can imagine how particular Colombians are about their coffee.

But the coffee is just part of it....the food is freaking amazing....or if I adopt the NCal slang....its hella amazing!

Let me put it this way....we were on vacation with only two mornings to spend in SF, and our first brunch at Blue Bottle was so good, we came back for brunch the second day.

Poached eggs on a "soup" of scallions and shitake mushrooms?  It sounded odd but rewarded my taste buds.  The food is perfectly executed.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Daniel B.

description: More hype than caffeine, it's ok but not worth waiting on line with the people that are to cool for Starbucks.
author: Kevin K.

description:
Everyone deserves to have a good coffee just once in their life.  If you want a good coffee... you get it here.  Likewise, if you want the brewing equipment that would take you forever to research to discover what the best is, they have it.  Chemx glassware, grinders... and oh yes... the coffee!  Oddly enough, I passed this place a dozen times and never went in because it didn't look like a coffee place that was interesting.  I heard about Blue Bottle in a coffee shop in London!  The owner being familiar with San Francisco claimed there are two places in San Francisco to get coffee: Blue Bottle and Four Barrel.  I haven't tried Four Barrel - but he was right about Blue Bottle.

I bought a bag o' beans - roasting date stamped - and it is the most tasty coffee I've ever brewed... I have a single cup chemx that I use at work.

I do have one complaint - I ordered an expresso and the chaser was tap water that had a chlorinated taste.  I wish they would have run it through a filter to get rid of the chlorinated taste... but they probably would (rightly) rather I not be so tight and buy a nice bottle of spring water to go with my excellent expresso.  5 stars and nothing less!
author: Steve S.

description: Blue Bottle has the best coffee, but I rarely go there since it *always* has a line. Tonight I stopped in on my home from the gym since it actually didn't seem to be too busy. I was the last person in line, and when I got up to the front, the lovely barista bought my coffee! "Yours is on me, since I'm so happy you're the last one," she said. It made my afternoon. Delicious coffee *and* baristas with awesome, friendly attitudes? Sold.
author: Hanna J.

description: Used to get this for free at work (not the full menu), but I got a latte here for the first time and it was delicious.
author: Thomas C.

description:
YUM! I'm not as big a fan of coffee as some of my friends, but this place is pretty awesome compared to what else is out there. 

I was in San Francisco for the weekend and I had had Starbucks, Peet's, coffee at a cafe in Japantown, and finally Blue Bottle. I think Blue Bottle takes the cake in terms of quality (Starbucks coffee always hurts my tummy afterwards). 

I had the cafe mocha at Blue Bottle, accompanied by a small plate of cookies/pastries. When my cafe mocha came out, it was almost too pretty to drink. Of course I took pictures of it. It was delicious and didn't need anything extra. The cookies/pastries were an excellent complement to the coffee. 

This location was a bit crowded (rainy, late sunday morning), we were lucky enough to find seats to sit and enjoy our drinks. Service was very attentive and friendly.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Blog Post - http://dabblewith.com/2013/05/15/top-shelf-cup-a-joe/

So I recently discovered Blue Bottle Coffee is not just your average cup of joe. Blue Bottle Coffee, is a native california micro-roaster that introduced Japanese-style siphon bar to San Francisco. They only carry three blends of coffee however each is hand roasted in their own roastery. James Freeman (founder) took the creation of coffee to a new level by controlling where the coffee is imported from as well as the equipment that is used to make the coffee. Freeman imported coffee and equipment from Japanese beverage giant UCC. UCC sold Freeman a $20,000 halogen-powered siphon machine that sits in the Mint Plaza café. Mr. Freeman is still tremendously involved with the brewing of the coffee and he meets with his staff each day in the company's production facility for their "cupping" ritual--a blind tasting of all the coffee roasted the previous day, as well as coffee made from beans they are considering buying.  Some things that set Blue Bottle Coffee apart is after roasting, coffee beans exhale carbon dioxide for several hours. Instead of keeping the Blue Bottle beans in bins, they are mixed in blends and bagged within four hours to harness carbon dioxide and keep oxygen (and oxidation) out of the bags. Blue Bottle never pre-blends their coffees, thus assuring the ideal roast profile for each bean.

blue_bottle_kyoto_dripperYou may also wonder why is there a coffee siphon sitting on the counter from Japan? Well Mr. Freeman has been influenced by his many trips to Japan, which has a long tradition of hand-brewing coffee with scrupulous care. He makes pilgrimages to a cafe near Shibuya Station in Tokyo called Chatei Hatou, which brews individual cups of coffee for $15 apiece. Mr. Freeman describes them as "life-changing perfection." He studied the Japanese manual coffee-making techniques and has switched to more Japanese equipment over the past five years. Moving more deeply into the culture, he has begun studying the Japanese language, toting his flashcards around and meeting with a tutor about twice a month.

Blue Bottle Coffee's Timeline: 

In 2001, James Freeman (burned out musician) Founded of Blue Bottle Coffee in a 186 square foot potting shed adjacent to Freeman's Oakland apartment.
Freeman would roast coffee beans in his shed, then load the beans and a drip coffee contraption into his Peugeot station wagon and drive to farmers' markets in Berkeley, Oakland, and eventually the Ferry Plaza in San Francisco. Quickly expanded to semi permanent carts and kiosks.
In 2008,  Freeman took an investment ($5 Million) from Kohlberg Ventures, a Silicon Valley-based VC firm that has backed several high-end food companies (ex:  Scharffen Berger chocolate).
Built a larger coffee roastery and commercial baking kitchen in Oakland. Caitlin Freeman headed the pastry program.
Opened three cafes in San Francisco: Mint Plaza, Ferry Building and San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. 
In 2009, Freeman expanded to New York City. Opening a roastery and Cafe in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. Used is traditional kiosk method and expanded High Line
Annual profits of Blue Bottle for 2011 were $15 to $20 million. With a growth rate of 70% annually. 
In 2012, Blue Bottle Coffee Inc. got a new President and CEO Bryan Meehan who headed the group of investors to purchased the controlling stake in Blue Bottle Coffee for $19.6 million.
Expanded to 10 locations between San Francisco and New York.
Now, James Freeman is the President and CEO of Blue Bottle Coffee Inc. while Bryan Meehan is now Executive Chairman.
History of Blue Bottle Coffee: 

In 1683, The Turkish army arrived in Vienna after having swept across much of europe.  The Viennese choose Franz George Kolshitsky as their emissary.  He passed through Turkish lines to get a message to the nearby Polish troops. The Polish Troops brought Vienna to victory and the Turks fled the city leaving everything behind. One of the items left behind was, strange bags of beans that were thought at the time to be camel feed. Kolshitsky recognized them as bags of coffee because he spent time in the Arab world. He then opened the first Central European coffee house (The Blue Bottle) and served the 'Turks' coffee.

Blue Bottle James RoastingWhen did it come to the Bay Area?

Mr. Freeman was a freelance musician who converted a potting shed into a coffee roastery. Using this six-pound batch roaster, he decided he would only sell  coffee less than 48 hours out of the roaster to his customers. He choose to only use the finest organic, and pesticide-free, shade-grown beans. Now he has build an loyal enthusiastic customer following and  Blue Bottle Coffee has grown to a small network of cafes, wholesale partners, an espresso cart, a coffee kiosk, and some vintage German coffee roasters.
author: Cameron M.

description: I really really really like their cafe lattes.  Just creamy smooth, just the right temperature.  And for some reason, adding sugar is not necessary.  I'm not a huge fan of their New Orleans iced coffee, just not my fancy.  It's too rich for me, for iced coffee I prefer Dunkin Donuts iced coffee, full of sugars and diluted with ice!  Other than that, for primo coffee, Blue Bottle is top choice.
author: Kevin W.

description: I've been on a quest for a great cup of coffee an stopped off at Blue Bottle. I ordered a house drip coffee and it's not worth it. 7eleven coffee and Starbucks tastes better. Philz is up there so far.
author: Johnny M.

description:
Excellent coffee and decent if limited brunch choices, but let's face it, you're not here for the food. As far as coffee drinks go, it's hard to top these guys. The Kyoto iced coffee is to die for, and their mocha was one of the best I've ever had.

Be ready to wait in line a bit on the weekends! It can get kind of busy. Star deducted for the long wait and reverberant acoustics, which can make it hard to hear the person you're trying to have an intimate conversation with. If they sound-proofed the ceiling and walls just a little bit, this would be an even more fantastic date spot.
author: Joseph C.

description: Sameer Test done for galeforce.
author: Ross G.

description: Great coffee. The poached eggs with toast were so so because the eggs were overcooked. Extremely limited seating and location is a bit off the beaten path. I would drop-in for coffee and skip breakfast next time.
author: Lynee L.

description:
Let me just say up front that I am a huge fan of Blue Bottle, and having had coffee from some of the best cafe's and roasters in the country (Coava, intelligentsia, Stumptown, Verve) I can say that they make some of the best espresso and espresso drinks I've ever had. Their coffee and Iced coffee is the best I've had, both the new orleans and the kyoto iced coffees are amazing. Blue Bottle has the only Halogen Siphon system in the country and barristas that know how to use it.

The Mint plaza location is the only location that does Kyoto style iced coffee, it is also the only location that does single origin siphon pots so I suggest going here if it is your first time to Blue Bottle.

Every location does espresso right, and if you are used to espresso from Starbucks, Petes etc... it is a completely different animal. The espresso at blue bottle is extremely clean tasting with no bitterness or burnt taste, you can actually enjoy this espresso without any milk or sugar added.

I also want to say you shouldn't hate on Blue Bottle because their lines are too long, there is nothing they can do about that and it takes time to do things right. I would suggest planning to wait if you go to the mint plaza or ferry building locations as they tend to get a lot more traffic than the other locations.
author: Jeff S.

description: Awesome coffee. You need to try it, if you're a serious coffee addict, like me. The staff was friendly and the biscuits and cookies we good.
author: Kevin I.

description: Someone from SF recommended this as the best coffee in San Francisco. He lied. Don't get me wrong, coffee is good. It's not the best in San Francisco, though. I went on a weekday in the morning at around 11-ish. The place was packed. Parking isnt toooo bad (in case you're driving) there is a parking structure nearby. Anyways, overall decent coffee, very good service, however. I'd go back.
author: Chela S.

description: Love heading here after a meal and getting the affogato! Big enough to share and perfect for your sweet tooth and coffee craving. Their iced New Orleans style coffee is great as well, but you be wired for a very long time.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Rest in peace Mr. Cunningham.

------------------------------------
Best Blue Bottle loc for people and fashions study.  I was sure I'd morphed into Bill Cunningham.

Disappointed in the highly touted Japanese coffee-making hardware, smaller and just not scary in real life.

Kyoto coffee also just not.
author: Mutant O.

description: Indisputably the best cup off coffee I've had in a long time, possibly ever.  This is coffee for people who know their coffee, are picky about it, and can appreciate a perfectly crafted cup.  The drip coffee and macchiato were both simple, balanced, and delicious.  By the eight hundred reviews and the line out the door every morning, I'm thinking I'm not the only one drinking the koolaid.
author: Alicia W.

description: I was visiting from out of town and have been looking forward to trying blue bottle (along with philz) for literally YEARS. Maybe I should have tried something else (ie. latte?) but I had the new orleans iced coffee with soy and it tasted very bland, watered down, and light. And that could just be me, because I like my coffee super strong. Within minutes the ice basically turned it to really diluted iced coffee and that's never an enjoyable experience. I do like the atmosphere a lot, though!
author: Cathy C.

description:
Economic Profiling.

My friend got back from Blue Bottle the other day, furious.  She had gone with a friend for coffee and some conversation, and everything was going well, until they tried to use the restroom.  

Her friend had to, and he went up to get the key, but came back.  She asked him what happened, and he said they wouldn't let him use the restroom, because they said he was Homeless!!  She, or course infuriated, went to get they key, upon one employee said, "Don't give it to her, she's going to give it to him."  She then proceeded to tell them that they were both paying customers.  

Could they not see them sitting there THE WHOLE TIME, having THEIR coffee??  Blue Bottle's apparently not aware of anything going on at their shop, either that or they're racist.  

Dear Blue Bottle, would you not let him in your bathroom Because He's Black??

When she told me, I was furious.  Their pretention has obviously crossed over even into the realm of legal wrong.  This is straight economic profiling.  


Boycott Blue Bottle.
author: Jon O.

description: Cool spot. Great coffee and tasty poached eggs. Would definitely come back next time I'm here in San Fran.
author: Zach C.

description: Guess I'm a bit too blue collar to appreciate the atmosphere here. When I couldn't figure out how to find sweetener for my coffee I refused to keep asking for other things like wifi. Must be just me, seems popular so I'm sure they don't need my patronage.  BTW, $3.00 for 8oz daily drip coffee is a bit too rich for my taste.  Coffee has some caffiene in it.
author: Don S.

description:
The drip coffee of the day was strong but really good.  I thought their americano was good, but I've had better.  I didn't have time to try their siphon again.

The peaches greek yogurt parfait was excellent.  I really liked how they used unsweetened yogurt and let the peaches and pecan granola add a bit of sweetness.

The eggs benedict was also outstanding.
author: Brent S.

description:
coffee: 4/5
service: 5/5

solid coffee and great baristas. Line is always out the door, even in the middle of the day. So this is never a quick coffee run. I haven't tried the pastries here, but I'll get them next time. This coffee shop is pretty small and has limited seating. There are actually many people who sit and do their work here, so you may be out of luck finding a seat with your friends.
author: Cecile S.

description: New Orleans Ice Coffee. 5 Stars. Get it.
author: Andy H.

description: Blue Bottle reminds me of Demitasse in Downtown LA - Kyoto style coffee machine and the he baristas are very knowledgable, friendly. It's tucked away in a tiny plaza on Mint St. Very cute little coffee shop! My BF loves going to cafes and yelp reviewers told us to come here so we stopped by to enjoy some good coffee ^-^ We ordered caffe mocha (my bf's fav!) and their popular New Orleans style iced coffee! Yummy! Next time we'll definitely try the Kyoto iced coffee! :)
author: Clara Y.

description:
Friends and I often have the Blue Bottle/Four Barrell debate and I am always hands down BB!

Love this spot in Mint Plaza- really cute and a nice place to have a conversation with friends.. haven't tried any food yet but don't really plan on it. The New Orleans iced coffee is great on a warm SF day.
author: Seema M.

description: I don't see what the hype was about. I got the New Orleans Iced Coffee with soy milk. Maybe the barista added too much milk because that's all I tasted. At least there was no line.
author: Helen D.

description: Some of the best coffee in the city, but 12 workers and one register with a line out and around the street, including one person watching another person fold napkins? Taking it down to 3 stars now for the cafe au lait poured better at Starbucks.
author: David A.

description:
What's a surprise to find such a nice cafe near the Powell Station !!

I was just there last weekend and I really liked Blue Bottle Coffee Co. I used to intern a block from this cafe on Mission St., but I never knew such a nice place exists there. 

I forgot the name of the breakfast menu I ordered, but it was delicious. I was on the way to do rock climbing and it gave me a lot of happy energy before climbing. People who work there were friendly and I liked the atmosphere. In addition, people coming to this place also had great energy. 

I totally recommend this place !!
author: Sayaha A.

description:
I was never a picky coffee drinker -- I was even satisfied with those K-Cup individual instant coffee servings they used to have.

In my first couple of months after moving up to the Bay Area, a friend of mine drove me around SF and one of the places happened to be here.

Wow. I thought good coffee was Starbucks or McDonald's new double-roast coffee... those didn't even compare to the flavor of the coffee I had here.

Needless to say, I've been a picky coffee drinker ever since. Their espresso-based drinks (lattes, mochas, iced coffees) are very very good. Their drip is great too, but I've since discovered Philz and I tend to favor their coffee more now. Either way, though, this place is worthy of the full 5 stars. 

By the way, have you noticed that this cafe, as "cute" as it is, kinda reminds you of a high school chemistry lab? Maybe it's the stools.. maybe it's the coffee siphons that remind you of chemistry equipment.. I don't know! 0_o?
author: Kazu O.

description: Delicious! Coffee that tastes like coffee. Nice batistas and staff, clean and tidy cafe. My favorite is the New Orleans!!!
author: Meriem B.

description:
The line is always out the door for a reason - this place is amazing. I come here for breakfast every so often. I am in love with the oatmeal with butter and brown sugar. You have to order it to understand. The yogurt with fruit compote is also amazing. You can only get those to-go, the other (delicious) breakfast dishes you must enjoy there.

The cappuccino is rad. People are pleasant and always smile. Love it!
author: Danielle G.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker but fell in love with New Orleans iced coffee that I had at The Ferry Building Blue Bottle Coffee Co. 

I was near Union Square so decided to get a blue bottle (since I'm not in the city often, when I'm in the city, and if I'm near a good coffee shop I always get a coffee! - always ice).

Wait: I waited 30+ mins like a lot of other yelpers.  It took them 2 mins to make my iced coffee as they had the coffee all pre-brewed.    

For whatever reason the taste of New Orleans iced coffee I had here was not as good as the ferry building.  If I remember correctly, Ferry Building Blue Bottle dripped my coffee at the time of my order and I think that maybe what may have made a difference.  (if that was not the case...well I don't know maybe I've been spoilt by Philz coffee lol)

I think I'll have to try New Orleans iced coffee at another blue bottle before I make up my mind as to whether or not I want to get blue bottle iced coffees again.  (Maybe their factory branch in east bay??)
author: Sujan H.

description:
First timer from out of town, tried the Kyoto iced coffee. As good as advertised, smooth, not bitter, extremely flavorful. Will return a few times more this trip, a convert to cold brew coffee.

Also tried the molasses cookie, perfect pairing with the iced coffee. 

Only down side was the long, slow lines. In the end, it was worth it.
author: Mike H.

description: Perfect cup of coffee, need a pick me up in the AM and this is the place to go. Its like a cup of smooth velvet and it is just delicious.
author: P C.

description: The New Orleans Iced coffee is the drink of choice here! I also had their poached eggs on acme toast which was also very good. It's a small place that isn't suitable for groups. I had a work meeting with 2 coworkers and found seating easily. It's def worth trying if you're in Union Square.
author: Kat P.

description: Delicious drip coffee and other caffeine boosting options.  This place is a coffee science house, so it is definitely worth the trip.  They brew a select batch everyday meaning you can go multiple times for a different tasting.  The food is very good also and Blue Bottle has many locations around the city.  This location in particular is near the Tenderloin district, so don't plan on enjoying your coffee walking around the area unless you head north only.
author: Daniel J.

description:
When I was in LA, I was in love with Intelligentsia, almost convinced that it was probably the best coffee around. But when I moved to SF, my friend insisted we go here for their coffee and she's completely changed my mind.

This place is absolutely adorable - baby blue and white setting, cute stools with long, modern-esque tables. It's the perfect place to sit, have a biscotti (or pastry of choice) with a cup of delicious coffee. I ordered the Cafe Mocha as it is my staple choice of coffee drinks. My friends got the iced coffee which I tried as well. The mocha was delicious! While the chocolate was rich, it didn't mask the taste of the coffee at all. You could still smell the aroma and taste their coffee.

I also ordered their coffee cake which was cook, but I preferred it made a little differently. They also serve brunch! YUM. And I loved it because the portions were not gigantic, just enough. I ordered the poached eggs, piquillo pepper and parmesan polenta, with prather ranch Italian sausage. Highly recommend it! I also got a bite of the waffle and the grilled cheese. Let's just say ... I'm coming back for the grilled cheese and another cup of coffee.

I'm in LOVE. :)
author: Angela K.

description: My macchiato and persimmon-topped granola were perfect. The espresso was made well. The persimmons were sliced thinly. The granola was spiced just right! More importantly, my meal left me feeling good too.
author: Elizabeth A.

description: Blue Bottle is pretty cool. They have a great shoppe with a bunch of cool laboratory-like contraptions that they brew their coffees in. I love the look of the place and the great logo. It is clean and sleek and has neat wood. It is like walking into a museum. It is the coolest.  Do I love paying $4 for an iced coffee served in a tiny paper cup? Not really. But because Blue Bottle has such a great look and such outstanding coffee, I am giving them four stars. Wish they would get the larger Greenware plastic cups (made from plants) and just serve larger iced drinks... Still a great place.
author: Ari R.

description: The most amazing coffee I've ever had.  Serving size is perfect.  Speedy service.  Grilled cheese is excellent with the mustard.  So amazing.
author: Melody J.

description: Tasty cafe latte, yummy New Orleans ice coffee. Cute space, limited outdoor seating. Long lines.
author: Sandy M.

description:
Came here on new years day, but it was closed. So my husband being the coffee aficionado, had to come back to try the legendary blue bottle. Line wasn't too bad but as the other yelpers warned no place to sit so we had to take it to go. 
WARNING: paper cups effect the taste of coffee. Paper will make coffee bitter after some time. 
Nonetheless the taste was great and Bella Donovan was splendid in all it's glory and hype. 
If you like coffee and you're in SF it's a must.
author: Mia S.

description:
Shorter lines than the Ferry Plaza option.
Takes credit unlike the kiosk.
They have food which I didn't order, but they have a $20,000 Halogen coffee maker that blew my mind.
