The Indian Jasmine Estate Coffee and the Chiapas both blow my mind with every single indulgent sip.

The barista's aren't douchebags like the ones I dealt with at Ritual, either - they are cheerful, pleasant, and keep everything together despite the crazy lines, jam packed restaurant, and heat!  Cheers!!
author: Michael U.

description:
Fantastic coffee! As if you had any doubt! I really don't need to reiterate this in yet another review about this place...

The line is usually pretty long, but if you've got 10-15 minutes to spare, it's worth it just to hang in line while chatting with a friend. The good thing is that so many people get their coffee to go, there are usually open seats when you're ready to sit down. I like the spartan interior of this shop. It's bare of all distractions but in a nice way. I also really like that they don't have a huge sign outside. It gives the place an unassuming look.

While the pastries look good, I would never order from their brunch menu - it's just not my style, all the local/organic/quirky combinations at pretty expensive prices for what you're getting.

The staff range from friendly to snobby. When my friend and I were there, she had to use the bathroom, so she went up to the bar and asked one of the baristas if there was a bathroom, to which she got a rude "No" and a turned back. My friend then came back to me and said that there was no bathroom. I told her there definitely was, as my other friend had used it on a previous occasion. Another barista had seen the entire thing and then called her over, waving the bathroom key, but I was just shocked that one of his colleagues had flat out told my friend there was no bathroom - even though we were paying customers!
author: Carolyn S.

description:
Blue Bottle gets it right! This is the only place I can order just a latte and it is so perfect it needs nothing else! The New Orleans iced coffee was also a perfect balance of creamy goodness and coffee bitterness... One cold night we tried the hot chocolate and it too was rich, smooth and delicious (if they added a dash of sea salt I'd throw in 'perfect' as well). 

We came across Blue Bottle on vacation.. and  found ourselves making excuses to take the walk (out of the way) either on our way out or back in for the day (sometimes both!).. The only negative thing I can say about this place is that a few of the barista's were in fact rude and seemed almost annoyed to take our order. Despite the cold staff, I will be sure to stop in Blue Bottle next time I am back in the city.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Ok, I love BB coffee. First tried it in Rock Center NYC in a nearly impossible to find midtown location. The Mint location was my second. Love, love, love the lattes and caps.

Had to knock a star off for the pretentious hipster element happening, at least on my visit. In particular, it culminated in the following: Me asking them to grind a bag of beans for me since I was on vacation and had a place with a french press. I got the speech. You know, beans are best when ground right before...blah, blah. Ok, true but I have no grinder at my rental, just the French Press. The guy then chides me for not bringing a hand grinder with me when I travel. He just got back from Spain and took a grinder you know. Seriously? I'm a pack light, carry it on my back traveler... the pack is on my back while we are discussing whether they will grind some beans for me but bean rules are bean rules and they refuse. I could tolerate the bean rules (I guess) but a lecture on travel hand bean grinders?????? That's a bridge too far.

But I digress. BB is still the bomb.
author: Mikey D.

description:
Wow Wow Wow even if this coffee wasn't like angel sweat from heaven go to the Mint location to see the awesome contraptions they use to brew coffee. 

"Perhaps the most compelling, is the five-light siphon bar, manufactured by the Lucky i. Cremas company of Japan - the first of its kind in the United States...Next is the Kyoto-style iced-coffee apparatus, which produces a delicate, refined, fragrant cold brewed coffee. Last but not least is the one-group San Marco lever machine. Clad in glorious rounded copper, it was our first machine. We think was built in the late 1970s."

Just make sweet love to this coffee already! You will have no regrets. I'm in full-blown stalker mode on Blue Bottle. We are forever friends. Oh god do they love me back?

We went to three different locations - too many times to count over a two week period - and they were all great.

Drinks I tried at various Blue Bottle locations:
Caffe Latte
Hot Chocolate - with TCHO chocolate
New Orleans style iced coffee
Single Origin Drip Coffee
Cappuccino

Stuff I brought home:
Granola
Honduras Yarasquin Farms (whole beans)

I give all those items 5 stars. The staff seemed quite knowledgeable and even the hipster vibe was so fitting it made my day.
author: Phoebe R.

description: Always on the look out for coffee when I travel. I came by Blue Bottle on the first morning and returned 3 more times in two days. Quick (pour over takes some time) service and very friendly. I was always there before the rush, so I don't know how crowded/long the line gets. The coffee was great (I can't remember the specific beans they were using): smooth with good berry taste and aroma. Price is reasonable for good coffee. The macchiato I ordered was well made too. There are small pastries and muffins available. I bought whole beans and they made terrific coffee at home.
author: Brian I.

description: The one of the infamous high quality coffee slingers in San Fran. The lattes are solid. Try the lemon buckle. Siphon coffee bar was closed. Bright space. Can't beat high quality caffeine.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Nice. Tried the latte. Above average at best. Very nice foam design. But if you are ever in LA/Pasadena, try intelligentsia.....way way better. But intelligentsia employees are jerks, blue bottle folks were very nice. Also tried the lemonade at blue bottle, nice but nothing special.
author: SonU V.

description:
My friend bought me a bag o' beans in exchange for a ride to the airport.

I had a head to head battle with the bag from Ritual Coffee Roasters. Still deciding which one is the winner... they were both very good.

Unfortunately, I'm not a big fan of fancy schmancy coffee drinks.. I like my coffee black... so I can't tell you about their other drinks. However, I definitely would like to come back and try their coffee made in their fancy coffee makers.

To be continued...
author: Victor C.

description:
2nd time to Blue Bottle Coffee and liked it fine.  This time got the Kyoto Iced Coffee ($3.5) and hubby got the Caffe Mocha - Michael Ricchiuti chocolate $4.5.

The Kyoto iced coffee strong, black coffee w/ some ice cubes in it.  I couldn't drink it until I added tons of cream & sugar into it.  

The Caffe Mocha w/ Michael Ricchiuti chocolates is good.  I enjoyed it.  Not heavy coffee flavor, pretty coffee art, and really good chocolate.

Credit cards taken.

Bathrooms are outside their coffee shop out this one door, need a key to open it.  Separate men & women available.  Women was clean when I used it.

Enter on Jessie St.

Hrs:
Mon-Fri 7:00 a.m.-7:00 p.m.
Sat 8:00 a.m.-8:00 p.m.
Sun 8:00 a.m.-4:00 p.m.
author: Ann L.

description: Serves the best coffee closest to my flat, too bad there's always a line! Would be a cool hangout spot, me and my Macbook, if only they offered wifi!
author: Kalong W.

description:
You would think a place with a $10,000+ espresso machine and a $20,000+ siphon coffee maker would brew up some kick ass coffee. Well, they surely did!! 

I blame it on my young age for my inexperience with good coffee, but I'm starting to really enjoy the good stuff now that I actually NEED coffee to wake up. Plus, I always like something warm to drink in the mornings while I walk around in SF to keep me toasty. I've been a coffee drinker since MIDDLE SCHOOL, but I never considered it real coffee. It was the usual Starbuck's drinks drenched in milk, sugar, caramel, and whipped cream. It wasn't until I was going to college full time and working full time that I started asking for double shots, but that had no effect on me whatsoever either.

Then, I was introduce to Blue Bottle Cafe...hidden behind an empty mint building on Mint St (go figure), I discovered a new realm of happiness. I even tried Siphon coffee for the first time and that got me wired! Of course, I had to ruin it by adding a teensy-weensy bit of cream and sugar (which, my brother's heart sunk after he saw me do that), but I'm just not used to drinking it straight on yet. Especially not siphon! I have a feeling it'll grow on me, but I'll have to make more visits out to BB. ;)

Oh, and they give you a bar of chocolae toffee to compliment your coffee. Who doesn't like toffee?
author: Michelle W.

description: It doesn't get any better. They consistently serve one of the best mochas available in SF, and the breakfast options are pretty epic as well. The staff are super friendly as well. You may need to wait 15 minutes or more in line, but it's totally worth it.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Ok so here is the deal, I really like their Coffee. Especially on a hot day I would definitely recommend getting their New Orleans Coffee.  One might ask, what is a New Orleans Coffee?  It is coarsely ground coffee infused with chopped chicory with a small amount of simple syrup. What can I say simply delicious.  But here is the kicker, I can not deal with the line. It is absolutely ridiculous.  Put another person on staff during peak hours.  I'm
Not even mad, I'm just saying.
author: George K.

description: The line here gets pretty long as with all Blue Bottle cafes.  The coffee is made better than the one at the Ferry Building.  The one in the Haight makes better coffee.
author: Byron L.

description:
One of the top 4 places to get coffee in the city. The New Orleans Iced Coffee is where it's at. Sure you can make the stuff yourself at home, but it's never really quite like how they make it at Blue Bottle. The service is fairly slow (in a good way) as there's usually a line out the door with the baristas paying good attention to each customers drink order. 

Best coffee in the city: 
1. Blue Bottle on mint, hands down
2. Four Barrel
3. Ritual
4. Dynamo 

The atmosphere inside is very contemporary and fits well within the rest of the restaurants in mint plaza (save for Latte Express which has one of the best Bánh mì sandwiches in all of downtown, even compared to saigon sandwich).The area is a little dicey being wedged in between 5 & 6th streets + Mission & Market (bums bums bums & bums), but there's usually a decent amount of the business casual class running around the area to make you feel at ease.
author: Ed D.

description: I'd like to meet one person who doesn't enjoy Blue Bottle Coffee.  I don't know what it is but it's one of the best coffee's I've ever had.  There are several locations in and around the bay area that serve Blue Bottle but Mint plaza is a pretty unique location.  Having an actual cafe where people can sit and enjoy their morning/afternoon/evening cups of coffee before they go about their days is a great treat.  Most locations only have walk up and walk away services.  Although Mint Plaza is in the middle of downtown you find yourself able to relax and get away from it all here.
author: Kevin J.

description: I see that  many folks really like this coffee.  I find the taste very different.  I would say that I really dislike the taste and much prefer other coffee houses.  On top of this there is always a line for this place.  Obviously other folks do like it.  For me though it costs more and does not taste nearly as good what I have had at other coffee shops.  I guess it is a matter of personal taste.
author: Robert G.

description:
The coffee here is really great and that's saying a lot for me because I can almost never tell the difference between different coffee's. it's a little expensive but they put a lot of work and preparation into each cup.

One drawback is the ridiculous line that forms and the ensuing wait. This place gets crazy busy!
author: Christopher C.

description: This place was fantastic. Cool vibe, great coffee presentation. While in town for the weekend, I had a New Orleans iced coffee that was one of the best I've ever had, as well as a latte and a waffle. Good food and good coffee.
author: Andrew V.

description: This place recommended by friends, the food is lovely, BUT I ordered what I described as a 'double shot with about a half an inch of milk' or what we call in oz a piccolo latte. I was served a large latte and told we only serve one size. It tasted ok, but it was just disappointing that I wasn't even offered a replacement.
author: Luke S.

description:
(See pics)

Came back and have tried their breakfasts a couple times. Belgian Waffles was thick and light taste. Popeye Eyes (eggs in the toast) had very crisp edges and the cooked egg was just perfect. Steel Oatmeal with brown sugar and butter was fairly heavy as they did put a lot of melted butter to help greased you up for a full day of work!

I always prefer coming here when it's not as crazy busy and crowded. The servers were less stressed and more talkative too.

When it comes to picking up the beans, I tend to go there first thing in the morning since the beans go very fast. If I remember correctly, they have deliveries on Mon, Tue, Thu and Fri.
author: T L.

description: Loved getting granola in a jar! The mocha and iced coffee were good. Next time I think I will use soy milk with the iced coffee.
author: Jessica M.

description:
RUDE RUDE.

I love coffee. We actually wanted to try Philz Coffee, but it was further away from our hotel and I resigned to try it sometime in LA. We live in San Diego. Also to note - my husband and I were highly recommended to try Blue Bottle during our visit up here - to try a specific drink and treat. We both ordered the New Orleans style iced coffee. This is how it went. Stacy is taking our order.

Us: "Two New Orleans style Iced Coffees. One with soy and the other with whole."
S: "Whole? Whole what?"
Us: "Ummm whole milk?" 
S: "Uhhhk"
Us: "Oh can we also do a Brandy cake?"
S: "Wow, we only carry that during the holidays... how long has it been since you've been here?"
Us: *through grinding teeth* "We're visiting... so this is actually our first time" (and last!)

I think I saw in here the words "rude hipsters" who serve the coffee at this particular location. Couldn't have said it better myself. Stacy did actually recommend a very good fruit muffin thing. However, rude service or not... the coffee wasn't anything to rave about, truly.
author: Michelle C.

description: My review here is purely on the service and atmosphere. My group and I arrived at Blue Bottle at 1:30pm on Friday after having brunch at Dotties. After hearing much about the "siphon" method we were excited to see this demonstrated live. However, we did not know that they stopped at 1:00pm for any siphon coffee and were disappointed. But the staff here were so friendly and accommodating! The owner told us to sit down and then proceeded to make our day! I'm all about customer service and I thought it was lovely that he was so chill about it.
author: Van N.

description: So trendy it doesn't even post it's name.  You have to trust you have arrived there, or be one of the cognoscenti who recognizes the blue bottle symbol, above the door.  The place reeks of preciousness, but the coffee is darn good.  The iced New Orleans is way good.  You will know you have arrived when you see the group of confused folks like you outside wondering if this is the place.
author: Guy K.

description:
Wow, I came in here with high expectations and they were met.
I wouldn't consider myself a coffee connoisseur, but the coffee here was a step above anything I've had before. The staff was friendly in answering various questions I had, and the ambience was nice too. It is tucked away around the corner in an alley off Mission, which helped its ambience as an getaway from the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Charles G.

description:
Oh MY - I love brunch at Blue Bottle....especially when it's just me and my guy. We love to come here early enough to beat the crowd and each order an entree from their brunch menu.  Today we had the frittata with bacon and the poached eggs on French lentil soup.  Both were fantastic.  These of course were accompanied by our mochas. 

This is definitely our breakfast happy place....you know that feeling you get when you get good food, service and walk out of the joint ready for anything....ya that happy feeling. It comes free with a meal at Blue Bottle.
author: Lea G.

description:
A cafe mocha is espresso, chocolate, and milk.
It's a simple drink, but when it's done right, each sip is heavenly.

With that said, I had my first espresso drink from Blue Bottle Coffee.
And it was AWESOME!
Whether it was the espresso, the chocolate, or the barrista, it's the best mocha I've ever had (so far).
Their espresso is an ideal compliment to chocolate because of its intense yet smooth bitter sweet flavor.  And by the way, a double shot comes standard.  Gotta love that.

I think the barrista tried to make a heart design in my mocha but it looked more like a skull and crossbones.
Thanks for trying.  I guess.
Normally I would take that as an omen (damn The Alchemist) but it'd take a lot more than that to deter me.
author: Dan B.

description:
Outstanding quality!   BEST Ham/cheese/poached egg sandwich EVER!
- Eggs poached perfectly
- Special Ham had great flavor
- Gruyere cheese was wonderful compliment
- Béchamel sauce was outstanding
- Thick cut toast done & toasted right!

A bit pricy for a ham sandwich, but it was well worth the splurge.

Coffee was delicious.  Viewed the special drip process.  It looked very cool (and expensive) but did not get to sample it.

NOTE -  our cab driver had a hard time finding the address.  We had to help with our GPS.  There is no signage (other than a hip-looking blue bottle high up on the corner of the building.)  But, the long line is the giveaway.  Not many seats.  But, they seemed to turnover quickly.

Would go back anytime!
author: Tony S.

description: I really like this place. I am impressed with everyone's coffee knowledge and their willingness to share it. I had the siphon coffee and enjoyed the tasting experience and watching the whole method and process.
author: Josh H.

description: Great quality coffee, just what I was looking for. I would also come back for their tuna sandwich, which seems to be a healthy alternative for a starving customer. Although I am rating it 4 stars because my coffee was not that hot as I would like it to be. I guess this is a characteristic of drip coffee. Overall, great service, good food, and great coffee. I will give it 5 stars next time if I get a super hot coffee.
author: John T.

description: My first 5-star review. So good I had to come back again an hour later for another. Worth waiting in line for. Super smooth cappuccinos...exactly what I was waiting for.
author: Donald D.

description:
Blue Bottle has good coffee. 
They treat espresso right. 
The service is not great, but hey, for me, the coffee makes up for this. 
The espresso here was really nice, smooth, full bodied, but light, kinda floraly, but not that citrusy tangy nonsense. 
I also got a cappuccino, which was lacking, it was very milky, it was kinda just a latte, I'm not a fan of that. 
My lovely assistant, Katie, got a mocha, she was a fan, it was pretty good, they used real chocolate which was evident toward the bottom of the cup. 
All in all, Blue Bottle is good, not the best, but good.
author: Truman S.

description:
Hands down, some of the best coffee in town.

Welcoming all coffee snobs, Blue Bottle takes pride in the art of preparing coffee.  The baristas know everything there is to know, from the roasting process, to the grind, to the extraction... they boast beautifully made coffee. 

It's all so yummy...  I don't think there's anyway to go wrong.

If you're one who prefers to dress up your coffee and doesn't *really* love the taste of coffee, at least come & get the mocha.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
My recommendation: New Orleans Iced Coffee

At $3.75 a pop for a small cup of iced coffee...Blue Bottle better be gold in a cup!  The 3rd wave coffee culture in SF is roaring and Blue Bottle is one of the first and strongest on the scene.

The beans are fresh and everything from the roast to the presentation are carefully and well executed.  I've tried straight espresso, cappuccino, and both of their iced coffees (New Orleans and Kyoto)...all amazing.

The only thing preventing Blue Bottle from hitting a 5 in my mind is VALUE!  This coffee shop is amazing for taste, customer service, and respect of the craft but $3.75 for an iced coffee (with far too much ice and not enough coffee) is really pushing it.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Supercilious scene, surprise. The coffee is exceptional. Thus far, I have had a macchiato from the bronze machine, a siphon pot, the kyoto iced coffee and the cassoulet...all excellent.  The Siphon pot comes with tiny, perfect sweets such as sea salt caramels.  The people who work here are interested in being here, they're pretty good at what they do. The space is urban-beauty...really, it's more beautiful than chic.  Take a look at that ceiling.  The preponderance of Rivers Cuomo clones is a little tedious.  

(yelp made me remove my youtube link to battles-tonto)
author: kimb s.

description:
The coffee IS good, and pretty,...but somehow never quite as hot as I'd like at Blue Bottle.  If I savor the flavor I end up with cool coffee.  Perhaps a latte is just the wrong thing to order.  Next time I'll try a drip or something else.

Also the coffee "fixin's" bar is in an odd spot in this location.  It'd be fine if there was not a line...but what are the odds of that?
author: Linda M.

description: Yes, I wait in line for a cup of joe.  It's worth it.  A simple latte which makes starbucks and the large chain coffee look like yesterdays dish.
author: garbanzo b.

description:
This used to be a place where I would treat myself - braving the lines, the prices, and the overly precious indifferent staff - to a delicious breakfast and coffee regularly.  Then, a new chef took over.  Most of the menu has devolved within a month to just short of bad.  For instance, the thick-cut acme toast has been replaced with "Firebrand thick-cut toast", which is basically an inflated piece of Zwieback milk toast, rough and tasteless, with a useless stain of butter in a circle in the center of the one piece of bread.  The toast used to come with a pot of butter, so you could actually spread some to the crusts.  Oh, and you got two pieces before.  But that's okay, because no thanks on two pieces of that dry cardboard.  Who would have thought you could mess up TOAST?  If you get it with the poached eggs, they basically melt the bread into a sort of polenta-y mush.  It only gets "better" from there.  The other delicious poached egg dishes are all gone, replaced by a breakfast sandwich with a weird, spongy egg center and some "fancy" greens to make it hipster.  I ordered the steel cut oats this morning, and had to give it back to the kitchen because it was honestly truly awful.  It was soupy and literally slimy, completely tasteless no matter how much sugar and jam I threw at it.  It used to be a crunchy, textured oatmeal.  I can't even believe they are calling it "steel cut oats".  It is more like a blended slug.

The coffee is still great, still love the New Orleans iced coffee and the lattes are perfect.  But I would seriously avoid wasting your money on the hype if you need to eat as well.  I do notice the lines are really going down (wonder why), so if you just need a cup that's a bonus for you!  You also don't have to watch all the people taking photos of their food, another plus.  I too would be embarrassed to post that I paid $5 for a breakfast that amounts to a yellow square on a plate.

Seriously a major shame.
author: Carolyn G.

description: New Orleans iced coffee was excellent.  It was creamy, but still had a strong coffee flavor.  Usually when I feel the coffee is creamy, the milk overpowers the coffee. I wish they would open a Blue Bottle down in the south bay.  Their baristas are amazing. I've tried the Blue Bottle coffee served at Fraiche Yogurt, but it's just not the same.
author: Jenny H.

description: Coffee was smooth and delicious! The location was a little hidden away but that just means less crowds, which is always nice is SFO.
author: Najah Q.

description:
I'm a recent convert to Blue Bottle, and now I'm afraid to admit I'm a bit of a Blue Bottle addict. (Admitting there's a problem is step one, right?) I was staying overnight in San Francisco on business and my hotel was a couple blocks away from Blue Bottle's shop in Mint Plaza. Sure, there was complimentary coffee at the hotel, but I couldn't resist the urge to get a cup of Blue Bottle's intoxicating coffee. 

So I braved the crowds and headed down to Mint Plaza. The wait wasn't too bad--compared to the wait times I'd been warned about at Blue Bottle's shops. That 18 minutes in line was so worth it once I took a sip of my cafe au lait. Mmmmm. What a perfect way to start the morning! One sip and the bustling downtown neighborhood melted away into my cup of coffee. The smooth drip was cradled by steamed milk in perfect harmony. Seriously, there's no better way to start the day than a good cup of coffee, right? (Except maybe with a cup of tiger blood, if you're Charlie Sheen and CRAZY! Sorry, I couldn't help the Charlie Sheen reference.)

I wanted to pick up some food--like one of the saffron biscotti--but I had to get over to Cole Valley for breakfast, so I resisted the urge. 

Sure, there's bound to be a wait at Blue Bottle's Mint Plaza, but I'll definitely be back next time I'm looking for a pick-me-up while downtown. Whether shopping, working or touristing, a cup of Blue Bottle will make the day much better.
author: Raul N.

description:
My oh my, oh my, oh my.  I am always in coffee heaven when I have their lattes.  Just so creamy and flavorful.  I always pair that with their outrageously delicious ginger cookie.  Yes, cookie....just one!!!!  At $3 a pop, it'll just be one thank you!  LOL.
The day I went, it was late in the afternoon and they ran out of their cookies :(

The line is always out the door.  But there's always seating indoors.  

This place is definitely a treat.  I haven't tried their other locations aside from the Oakland location but I wish there were more locations!!!
author: Glenda J.

description:
Overrated, too cool, and coffee that isn't hot enough or strong enough to really be considered coffee.  Did I say it's double the price of normal coffee?  

Nowhere to sit.  The staff behind the counter look as if they don't want to be there.  The other staff that serves what you order are amiable enough.

The crowd is horribly pretentious.  I guess that makes me pretentious too.
author: Tony U.

description:
I was told this place was the only cafe to get a drinkable coffee in San Fran - and they were right. The coffee is great (Aussies will love it - a proper latte at the right temperature!) BUT the service is slow slow slow slow. A 20 min line to get in the door and the staff were in no particular hurry to do much of anything. 

The food was also great quality (I had the corn bread / poached egg breakfast), but after you've waited 40 mins to eat from the time you first lined up, you find yourself really annoyed by the whole experience. 

The owner really needs to train the staff to keep up with the volume - quality can be done efficiently (and the owner must be haemorrhaging money from the customers that get sick of waiting). Its just not practical to wait this long - especially for the poor people that just wanted a takeaway coffee!

For takeaway, if it takes longer than 7 mins from the time the customer arrives, you're wasting people's time.
author: Scott D.

description:
The only comparable espressos & cappucinos to those in Italy.  I was very impressed, but be prepared for a modernesque ambiance and polished coffee shop rather than your laid back coffee spot.

The drinks are all reasonably priced . This is a good place to come to catch up with someone over some coffee, not that convenient for a to-go place as there was always a long line.
Looking forward to come here again if I'm in the area =)
author: Veronica S.

description: FAVORITE coffee in SF.  This lovely place has certainly ruined all other coffee for me.  Smooth, perfectly crafted and never bitter.  The cups are delicious and a work of art.  Try the caffe mocha and the New Orleans iced coffee!  Come on the weekend for spectacular brunch offerings like eggs in toast with whipped maple butter or poached eggs with Catalan style greens.  There is often a long line but it is worth the wait.
author: Laura E.

description:
Delicious. So. Delicious. 

A great quick break place to hit during work hours. I love me a good macchiato, and the chains just don't do them right. Blue Bottle's properly sized cup (small!) offers the quick kick-in-the-pants that you crave from espresso, and they make it look oh-so-pretty. 

+1 for caffeine rushes at work and gravity brewing. Delightful to watch. 

+ 1 also for the ambiance in the place. High ceilings, nice wood counters, and they don't have to go cups for their macchiatos, so you get a nice moment of slightly forced pause. I dig it.
author: Allison S.

description:
Being a true coffee lover, I have forced myself to get over the whole 'hipster vibe' of trendy coffee shops. This one is my favorite of the Blue Bottle shops. It is a little off the beaten path, but always seems to be hopping. The building is beautiful with lots of windows. 

I have never had a bad cup of coffee either. The baristas know what they're doing. I highly recommend the New Orleans ice coffee. So good!
author: Elise M.

description:
This was my second time going to the Blue Bottle after watching a feature on them on the Food Network. The first time I thought the coffee was pretty darn good, this time however it was a little more bitter. I had the New Orleans brew and my husband had the Kyoto coffee. Mine tasted as if it was sitting for a couple of days too long. 

On another note, the atmosphere is very stuck up, and the baristas seem like they really don't want to service you, and after standing in line for about 25 minutes out the door, I think that is rather rude. The patrons are also not in the mood to share "their" space with you, even though all they're doing is playing on their iPhones. 

I would probably go again as they don't have a decent cold brewed coffee locally, but I would suggest the baristas lighten up a bit.
author: Genna M.

description:
My hipster colleagues have been raving about Bluebottle for a couple of years now... and I finally made it over to this new-ish location for my inaugural visit today.

My assessment, hype notwithstanding? Legitimately solid.

I went for the $2.00 drip coffee. It was good. Very good. Probably not swoon-best-coffee-I've-ever-had good, but definitely better than Peet's ($1.65), Starbucks ($1.60) or any of the similarly priced coffee shops I can think of in the area... and therefore as worth the $2.00 as it could be.

The high windows, bright white walls and nifty coffee devices in there are cool too. I'd go to 5 stars if they were just a bit bigger and had real seating options... though I can't blame them for sticking to counters and keeping us riff raff from hanging around all day.
author: Geoff D.

description:
yummmmmy coffee, friendly staff. 
i have bought many bags of coffee there before but was having trouble deciding what to get, so one of the staff started describing to me in depth the flavors and aroma of the ones i had questions on.  

havnt tried the goodies there but love the new orleans ice with soy, drip coffee, and soy lattes! strong tasty coffee is the way to go!
author: Linda T.

description: When I came here I have espresso or macchiato because they are the best  in the Bay Area.
author: Mauro M.

description: Whoa!  Off the beaten path. Long lines and AMAZING drip brew and Lattes. Hope you find it and when you do, don't pass this gem up!
author: Chuk S.

description: 'Ahhhhhhhh' was my first comment after a sip of this delicious coffee. Coming from Wellington where the coffee is SO good, I really struggled I find a halfway decent coffee while I was in USA. Blue Bottle coffee came recommended by a friend so I gave it a go and was really pleased I did. A smooth coffee with milk that was steamed perfectly. The service was great and the price was reasonable given the amazing coffee you got. Definitely come here or to one of their other outfits if you are hanging out for a good brew!
author: Olivia C.

description: One of the best cappuccinos I've had, even though they ran out of almond milk. Pastries are great too, had the berry buckle. Fascinating to watch them make the drip coffee also.
author: Alessandro M.

description: Don't normally like milk in coffee, but their New Orleans Iced is excellent.
author: Chien-yu S.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee, you are the smart girl whose beauty is hidden behind a pair of geeky glasses and a Chuck Klosterman novel. Modest, smart and environmentally aware - once you meet her, other girls seem shallow and self-absorbed by comparison.

Being an avid Yelper, I kept hearing fellow Yelpers rave about Blue Bottle Coffee. So I decided to see what all the fuss was about. I strolled on over at lunchtime and was surprised to find that Blue Bottle had been right under my nose all this time, much like the nerdy girl that no one notices. I suppose because street signage isn't obvious, I passed it by several times without realizing the deliciously tasty coffee treasures that lay within. I decided to try the New Orleans iced coffee - partially because of the great reviews and partially because I haven't tasted anything "New Orleans-inspired" that I haven't liked.

My iced coffee was served in a nameless white paper cup with no lid, no straw. With coffee cups becoming somewhat of a fashion statement nowadays (i.e. Starbucks), I was expecting a trendy, self-promoting logo or something of the sort. How unpresumptous of you, Blue Bottle. 

They asked if I wanted my receipt, to which I said "no". I then realized how much paper the other coffee shops must waste by printing thousands of receipts that people throw away five seconds later. How smart of you to look out for the environment. I'm liking you more already :)

My iced coffee was a rich, mildly sweet piece of sunshine. It's stuff like this that makes me realize what coffee is supposed to taste like. I strolled down Market Street all the way back to my office in FiDi, enjoying it sip by sip. 

Blue Bottle, I just hope you don't sell out for the sake of popularity. We geeky girls need you on our team. You may not get as much attention as the popular girls with their Christian Louboutin shoes and their Marc Jacobs bags, but those who get to know you will inevitably become a fan. I did :)
author: Mariela D.

description: Shut the front door and hold the phone!  This is absolutely the smoothest, most incredible coffee you will EVER put in your mouth!  Not only do they have the best roast out there, but they use the best products to make the cappuccino so delectably smooth...I just drooled... Anyway, I live in San Diego and miss this place everyday...I love where I live, but I might just pack up and move for this coffee...or if you creators are out there listening [reading]...maybe you would like to open a franchise down here in the lovely SoCal region?!?  Please go enjoy the best coffee you will ever drink, spend the dollars, it is worth it!!  Cheers!
author: SARA S.

description:
I'm crazy about coffee. I love it in all of its various forms, and its about time I review blue bottle.  I'm going to focus on the beans and the brewed espresso I have had in the café.  

-=[The Beans]=-
I have tried various roasters in the city (ritual, graffeo, roastery, etc.) and have found none to be as consistently high quality as blue bottle. It is priced around 7 for a half pound depending on the blend, which is about the same as other high-end roasters.  Just finding out when most other beans were roasted can be an issue that is why I love that blue bottle prints it right on the bag and will not sell beans that are more than 48 hours old.  I enjoy the Hayes Valley roast most often.  

I brew most of my coffee as espresso as I have a low-volume commercial plumbed-in machine in my kitchen (i'm nuts). It gives me control of the brewing temp within 1 degree, so on a long shot I emailed them to see what temp to brew their beans at.  This is what they said: 

"Hi,
We usually set our machines to 200-203 depending on the day of roast and the weather.
The roman usually likes a lower temp but that is the only one that I would recommend at around 198-199."

They tune parameters of the espresso making process based on the weather. 

-=[Espresso]=-
I have only had espresso in the café, but I can say that it was tasty and prepared with such care as to elevate it to an art.  I like that it is served with a glass of water. 

The espresso itself had a thick dark reddish-brown crema, was prepared ristretto style (shorter/smaller/stronger shot) with a slight bit of speckling in the crema. 

It is presented in thick walled Italian made Nuova Point cups which are used for great espresso all over the world.   Coincidentally if you like the cups, Café Trieste in north beach sells them.

The café was busy with a mix of business people on lunch break and tourists.  Everyone was friendly and the service was prompt.  

My only complaint is that one time I was trying to go to the café I ran in to a rather confrontational crack head while trying to park. I can't blame blue bottle for that though.
author: Jeff F.

description:
When you charge $4-5 for a small latte/cappuccino, you need to know who your clientele is.  Once you have that figured out, you should stop hassling them at your restroom door! 

This place makes amazing coffees and the baristas are all fantastic.  I am giving it a 3 because of my restroom experience.  I met a friend here today for coffee. I came in, sat down, got a latte, used the restroom, typed a bunch of emails and realized they don't have free internet.  Since my friend wasn't due until 30 mins after, I went over to the Westfield mall, used their free internet and sent all my emails.

I came back into the store literally 15 mins later and wanted to use the restroom again.  I wanted to wash my face before my friend showed up. The security guard stops me and says to me "Are you sitting here." I reply  "Yes, I am siting here. I was here a few min ago and now I am back again". He says "This restroom is only for paying customers". I got really irritated by this comment of his.  He had allowed me to use the restroom barely 20 mins ago and had seen me buy my latte and sit down.
I kept calm and told him that my friend was coming now and we were gonna sit down and get something again. He didn't seem to be convinced but handed me the key nevertheless.  On my way out, I told him I understood he was doing his job but he could have been nicer to me.

Agreed this is San Francisco.  You have weirdos who can show up and bathe in your toilet sink.  But hey, look at me! I am your 20 something office-goer, neatly dressed, polished shoes, laptop, iPhone.  Plus, I was here 20 mins ago and you saw me buy a latte.  This business needs to do more to care about the people who can afford its coffees.
author: Prav S.

description: The Affogato is a must. Could be a bit crowded on a Sunday morning.
author: Agboh W.

description: Awesome place. Excellent coffee. Delicious food. And the staff is outstanding.
author: B D.

description:
I don't drink much coffee (in the words of Kenneth it makes me feel like "my heart is trying to hug my brain").  I don't subscribe to the NYT or SF Chronicle.  I don't subscribe to any "hip" magazines like 7x7 that tell me where I'm supposed to be.  All I knew was that my friend serves Blue Bottle coffee in his restaurant.

So....

On the way to lunch today as we were transitioning from the land of teenage mallrats to crack hotels, we walked by the new mint plaza.  Someone mentioned the supposed $20,000 coffee machine in Blue Bottle Cafe (someone more informed than me will have to confirm this).  Curious about anything so outrageously expensive that does something so simple, we knew had to come back and check it out for keep-you-awake-at-the-office-after-a-good-lunch coffee.

The coffee makers here is a science delight!  I could sit in here all day and watch them make it.  If chemistry was this cool when I was school I might actually be practicing my degree still.  The coffee makers look like a combination of high tech and hand made lab equipment.  I have no idea how they work (yeah, I didn't get that good grades in chemistry but can admit it has something to do with heat and vacuums) but they are fun to watch.  In my defense, we weren't the only ones in there taking pictures (you'll have to ask Angie R why she walks around with a real camera - not camera phone - in her purse).

I did not try the coffee myself but hubby reported good but super caffeinated.  I did try the chocolate pudding, served in a beaker of course(!) , and thought it was delish.

Decor is also nice.  Different than most other coffeehouses in going for the opposite effect of small and cozy.  Instead, tall ceilings, lots of windows and light.  Pale wood.  V euro I thought.

Not crowded at all during the week.

Bike Parking: v weak.  You can try the fence next to the building or the railings in Mint Plaza.
author: Jean K.

description:
My hand is still shaking from the Kyoto-style iced coffee...

Served straight up (don't you dare ask for cream or sugar - the baristas and I are judging you already for just thinking it) the Kyoto coffee is an experience.

Block off your morning, because you will go into the most incredible coffee-stupor you've ever been in.  The intense aromatics coming from the first waft will wake you up in an instant.  The taste is almost thick, fruity, alcoholic, and floral all at once.

It took Connie C. and I almost three hours to finish our coffees... we didn't know what we were getting into.  I have the blurry photos attempted after drinking it as proof.

OFF MENU: is the Gibraltar.  a perfect little mega-shot of rich and creamy goodness.  Served 'for here' only. Whisper it in line... you'll thank me later.
author: Alexa Z.

description:
This is the best coffee I've ever had.  However, it is so pure and strong, I think my heart is beginning to beg me to cut down on it.  Tried the Kyoto and the New Orleans.  No bitterness at all.  Smooth flavor.

And it keeps you awake for hours.  Great for long study nights.  Don't worry if you can't get it late at night.  One cup will keep you awake for at least 10 hours.
author: Maria S.

description:
It must've been the third morning of our honeymoon that I woke up morning feeling toxic from too many drinks at the hotel bar - and in need of coffee and greasy breakfast - but a goood greasy breakfast. While my husband was in the shower, I concocted a plan for the day, and we stumbled down the street in a hung over haze in search of breakfast at Blue Bottle's Mint Plaza shopfront. Little did we know that we were about to encounter a coffee dreamworld.

A $20,000 syphon brewing system, where water heated by a halogen lamp rises up through the grounds to make a perfectly smooth cup of coffee.  An iced coffee system that redefines slow brewing: water passes through the grounds one drip at a time over the course of eight hours. Eight hours!  Perfect pour-over coffee and espresso drinks made with care - and a limited but delicious breakfast menu besides.

And what a breakfast it was: a grilled ham and gruyere sandwich for me and a fabulous frittata with goat cheese, sweet corn, and red pepper puree for Shane. I coveted that frittata. I dream of that frittata. Fortunately he shared a few bites, and we shared two syphon pots of Amaro Gayo and Guatemalan Guya'b, enjoying the former much more than the latter. As we were sitting in the front window enjoying our breakfast, we spotted the owner of one of our favorite Ann Arbor coffee spots standing in line for his own breakfast. What are the chances?!

So great was our enjoyment of that greasy breakfast that we went back for more the next day, sharing the dreamy frittata and thick slabs of ACME toast, along with two beautiful cappuccinos - my husband's first!  His tastes in espresso drinks previously leaned in the vanilla latte direction, so this was a revelation, and the beginning of a beautiful obsession.

If you're in the Financial District and in need of breakfast, I can think of no reason to go elsewhere - unless you're easily deterred by lines or don't like good things.
author: Elizabeth E.

description: Went to check the contemporary coffee shop in the SOMA. Had a perfect latte macchiato, made by as the perfect epitome of a San Franciscan tattooed  hipster barista. It's like going  to Disneyland and hug the Mickey mascot. Recommend
author: Rodny L.

description:
Actually 2.5 stars but I will put down two instead of three because I am still annoyed. 

The coffee here is excellent. 4 stars. The customer server here is not excellent at all 1 star. My score is an average of the two most important things for me about the business, the product and how I am handled.

There is a fundamental flaw in BB Mint's service. This seems minor but it runs rough over a basic concept of customer service. 

I finally get to the counter after two employees spend 3 or so minutes doting over a bicycle delivery guy. When he walks away both employees also walk away from the counter. Annoying but non-critical. Then the employee working the register asks what I want. I order a half-pound of beans. Then the employee walks back to where I suppose they keep the beans, stops by another employee and talks for about 1 minute about a beverage the other employee just made. They were not working and talking or anything like that. It was like they were at a party. 

This seems petty but it points out what maybe a fundamental flaw in the BB customer service philosophy (if one exists) that the customer's time doesn't matter enough to finish whatever you are doing for the customer before you decide to socialize or whatever. 

You should consider not doing that.
author: Lamb Shanks S.

description: The coffee is great but customer service is bad, was going to order something off the menu but then they said the menu was wrong it wasn't peaches it was  plums, don't like plums. so I ordered something else but they gave me the wrong thing and they wouldn't fix it :(
author: Serena S.

description:
Love the space - large windows, seats along the window, bar and a communal table in the middle.  There's a fresh and bright feel to this place. 
Their latte was strong, velvety and yes, latte art just makes me happy.  The baristas are the hipsters kind (I guess that's the standard, isn't it?) and weren't the most friendly baristas I've encountered but whatever, I was there for the coffee.
author: Tanya N.

description: Great coffee shop.  They give you free water while you wait on line.  The coffee is strong and rich.  The only downside is the line can be long and sometimes you have to wait outside.  I highly recommend this place.
author: James P.

description: I am a HUGE HUGE HUGE fan of this Company and location. The location is a hidden jewel and the Coffee is DELICIOUS! Prob the best coffee I've ever had and coffee is my religion. Kyoto iced coffee=LOVE
author: Emily C.

description: Love the coffee .. love the place ..their waffles are a hit. its a small place but always always busy ..there is always a line for coffee.. and you have to sometimes wait for even getting a spot to sit after standing in line for about 30 mins. but I don't think it will stop me from visiting blue bottle everytime I visit SF :)
author: Waran V.

description:
I guess the coffee is good. I love the style of this place and how it is decorated. The long line of people says enough about the quality of the coffee. However, i honestly think that the staffs are a little too snobby. They acted like they're the shit, but seriously, better customer service would be appreciated. I basically stood there at the counter for like five minutes before this one woman decided that she would take my order. There were like thirty people in line. The staffs took time like there's no one in line. I mean why would you be organizing coffee bags when there are a huge line of people?

Beside, that the place was cool. I'm not really a coffee snob and I don't strive to find the best coffee shop in town. I, however, enjoy and prefer good customer service so i'll be chilling at other cafe.
author: Snook C.

description:
What a thrill to be alive on a bright Sunday afternoon of the early spring, almost implausibly privileged with simple indulgence:  reading Mallarme's anecdotes while sipping on a cup of Blue Bottle Coffee.  The fragrant aroma burns deep with enchantment.  The verve from the acidity glows.  And, the richness of the body lights up all senses.  Sweet beauty.  Harmony.  Perhaps, it is the incompetent beverage that we gulp down our throat everyday brings out the sophistication of this cup of Latte.  And, it only takes one sip of this Latte to remind me gratification; thanks to the Farmers, the Roasters, the Tasters, and the Baristas.  And, thanks to the sun, the soil, the wind, the altitude and the latitude.  The cup is slowly emptied, but the cheerfulness is pervasive.  A moment like this is a blessing.

A girl accidentally took my order.
The friendly staff made sure that I had my drink, promptly.
The winter white bean casolette makes the experience at this place even better.
The order took a while to come out 
so that quality could be ensured?
The cafe got crowded and loud.
But why restrain other people's enjoyment.  I had my fair share.
author: Vivian H.

description: Second time going to Blue Bottle to get some coffee and breakfast in the city. There was a line when we got there but from our first experience, we wanted to get coffee from there again. I ordered the mocha latte and the husband ordered a latte. I also ordered the Acme Toast French Toast and my husband ordered the Frittata. The presentation and food was so good. I love how they make creative designs in the coffee. I loved the breakfast! I would definitely make it to Blue Bottle the next time we hit up SF. I love their ambiance, style, and coffee.
author: Cheryl K.

description: Well, here's to the best latte you can get just about anywhere. After trying blue bottle and deciding it was THE BEST I now order the beans online so I can make my own blue bottle lattes at home. However, I can't make it as good as the folk at blue bottle so I always make a stop in here when I'm in SF.
author: Madeline S.

description: Get your fresh cup off coffee here. Worth the price of anything you order and definitely worth the wait. First time I came here I almost walked past: just look for the blue bottle sign on the corner of the building!
author: Lauren A.

description: Went here for brunch/breakfast on my trip to SF. Great coffee and great food. Very busy though, line was out the door, definitely worth it!
author: Arsalan H.

description: The pretention of Blue Bottle is cut by the hordes of tourists waiting in line.  Fortunately, the quality doesn't suffer.
author: David S.

description:
MMMM the one thing I cannot live without is coffee and when there is great coffee I am a very happy camper. I actually researched Blue Bottle for a project I was working on at school so I had heard great things about the place, so I knew I had to check it out when I was in SF. The first thing I did the minute we arrived in SF was head to Blue Bottle which happened to be near my hotel. The interior was very cool, high ceilings, simple but beautiful moldings and crisp decor. Of course the main focus was the coffee itself and the beautiful siphon machines. 

It's just fascinating to watch them use the siphons and watch the coffee magic begin. I had had siphon coffee in Japan when I lived there so I already knew how delightful it tasted, so I was excited to get some @ Blue Bottle. But I ended up getting the hand drip house coffee which was also great. My cousin got the cappuccino and the foam decor was quite lovely.

We got there just in time before the long line appeared. The servers there were perfectly nice, I just wish they had more delectable treats there to enjoy with the coffee. Like Tartine inside, oh my that would be heaven.
author: Helen P.

description:
I no longer live in San Francisco and I no longer drink Blue Bottle on a regular basis and it is one of life's greatest points of sadness. There is nothing bad to say about their coffee or their espresso or their anything. 

The espresso is like drinking pure silk and the pour-over coffee (the only way they do it) is something akin to traveling the world in a sip...THAT'S how full-bodied and complex it is.

I think of Blue Bottle every single day like I was married to it. It's ruined me for most other coffee. Sometimes drama is true, y'all.
author: Michael B.

description: Excellent coffee! Primo waffles and poached eggs! Go!
author: Zsa Zsa G.

description:
Great coffee.  Everyone knows about the individually dripped coffee, but they are so much more.  The latte is so tasty and delicious, it's almost more like a stout than a coffee.  

Though, we usually bring the beans home.  If you don't know which kind to buy just ask the desk or look on their website for which blends/beans do best with which mode of prep.  We like the Bella Donovan because it goes well with a kemex but if you use a french-press Three Africans is tough to beat (it benefits from a darker, richer prep than the usual drip).

This is the one blue bottle location with plenty of breakfast choices too, which aren't shabby either.  But be prepared to wait in line if you're around the morning coffee rush.
author: Zack S.

description:
I have to agree with some of the reviews that they don't have great service but the coffee is honestly good.

I've tried the dripped coffee, latte, mocha and waffles.  None of them has disappointed me so far. They have very limited seats so there is a line at the door most of the time.
author: D C.

description:
Full disclosure: if you're an affected, pretentious java aficionado who savors in the whole snooty & showy experience of all things coffee, then stop reading this review and head right on over to Blue Bottle--because it was made for pompous folks like you. 

For the other 95% of the caffeine-consuming world: the eternal wait, matchbox-sized space and non-existent customer service (despite the laughably all-in-black clad staff outnumbering the patrons 3-to-1) makes this place a huge, yawning bore. There are simply far too many other java establishments in SF too choose from than to deal with these faux hipsters with their French presses and attitudes.

Do I like a bit of pomp & panache on occasion (as well as a decent waffle)?...sure I do. But then I also like businesses that actually care less about putting on airs and much more about pleasing customers.
author: Steven B.

description: Prepared by baristas who know their stuff, this is classy coffee done right. Blue Bottle sets the bar for artisan coffee in the Bay Area and serves as an example for other competing coffee companies.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Disappointed regular!  I used to have my coffee here every day!  Now they've changed the order process to accommodate the crowd!  Well we were quite happy to wait, but now often there is no contact with anyone but the payment screen!  And twice my breakfast was cold, even the coffee!  Looking for another watering hole!
author: P S.

description:
I just finished a lovely breakfast with Rachel S., and we both had a wonderful time. 

We were there about 9am on a Thursday, so there wasn't a crowd. The staff was friendly, helpful, and quick about both bringing us our orders and answering questions. The space has a fairly industrial feel and the acoustics aren't great, so it's certainly not a lounging type of coffee shop; however, it was still a comfortable place to have breakfast. 

The poached eggs on toast were perfect, delicious, and attractive. (see photo) Even the butter that came on the side was sweet and tasty...not that I know anyone who would just eat butter straight! The fancy Siphon bar is only available from 10-5:30, so we were limited to the standard espresso bar fare. My mocha was tasty, but even more so it was beautiful: a thick layer of foam on top was finished with a fern design of cocoa powder. (Again, see photo) The coffee drinks are all made with organic whole milk (Clover-brand), which lends a slightly tangier-than-normal flavor that, while nice, took a bit of adjusting.

Prices were reasonable and entirely in-line with other coffee shops. The mocha was $4.50, the eggs/toast was $6. I would absolutely go back.

LOCATION WARNING: Finding this shop is a little tricky because it has no frontage on the main streets and no prominent signage sticking out from the exterior walls. Don't bother looking for "Mint Street" as it has no sign and isn't really a street, not even an alley; it's more of a parking lot. There are 2 approaches: 1) Walk down Mission Street between 5th and 6th. About halfway between, turn into the parking lot/alley (Mint, apparently) across from Mary Street. About two doors in will be the cafe, at the intersection with Jesse.  2) Walk down 6th Street from Market and turn left on Jesse. Half a block in will be Blue Bottle. Note that Jesse does NOT go through to 5th.
author: Bill B.

description:
I was delighted when my industry peer suggested meeting at the new BB.  I'd been thinking about it since I saw a write up in the Examiner with tantalizing photos (I just checked online http://www.examiner.com/a-1290383~At_Blue_Bottle__coffee_reaches_the_upper_limit.html, and those food photos aren't listed, but just go, you'll see what I mean).

The space is done up just right - I like how the wood-grain high tables compliment the beautiful coffees that are created with soulful care.  Service is also amiable.
author: Cathy K.

description: I have been a BIG FAN of Blue Bottle and always afraid to write about it because the Mint location is small, usually a line out the door and sometimes hard to find a seat. This is one of my two favorite coffee spots (the other is Cafe Trieste in North Beach)  when home in the City by the Bay! While they make some good lattes, I recommend getting a drip or one of their ice coffees.
author: Gordon H.

description: This place was AMAZING.  BEST. COFFEE. EVER.  Brought home some beans back to LA.  Can't wait till they open their Venice location next year.
author: Lisa U.

description:
best coffee so far in the states, i've been traveling round for 3 weeks now. 

i had a double shot macchiato. flavour was smooth yet bold with a subtle nutty undertone.

this place is easily up there with sydney coffee so game on san fran! very excited to see what else you have to offer.
author: Reuben S.

description: Nice bold coffee for a cold rainy day. Had the drip coffee and apple juice. Staff all really friendly and engaging.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I'll join the cattle call of people that sing the praise of this place... it's out of this world, no seriously the siphon coffee is really that good, like really... there's no bitterness to the coffee produced in the siphon, there are more complex notes and a smooth and even flavor from the start to the end of the scientific like serving vessel that it arrives in. 

Here's where the pain begins, the bloody lines are ridiculous! Come early and maybe if the gods smile upon you you'll get a seat. Don't come too hungry, the portions are small but quite good and they do run out of stuff so if you've had your heart fixated on a blue bottle breakfast you may be somewhat dissappointed if you didn't come early. Oh yeah, siphon coffee isn't an all day thing, so again, come early...
author: Len S.

description: Coffee is good here, but I wish the place is more down to earth and less pretentious. Snooooooty staff. That attitude doesn't make the coffee taste any better you know.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Their hot chocolate is like no other. 

The hot chocolate is dark and rich with a bitter taste, but the aftertaste is delectable making you yearn for more. 

This location is in some kind of back alley behind Union Square where you would expect a lot of people to be but the line was long (Not sure whether to attribute it to the slow working baristas or their delicious coffee). 


Verdict: 

With San Francisco's weather? Find me the nearest Blue Bottle!!
author: Heidi C.

description: New hipster trend alert: FRIENDLY baristas - awesome service two days in a row - and killer coffee to boot! Something great is going on here...
author: Dana L.

description: I was only able to go three or four times while in the area, and each time was jam-packed with people - but worth the wait. Very nice soy latte, and the waffles! Heck, I'd go for those alone.
author: Krysta G.

description:
Joy in a ceramic cup~

I absolutely love the coffee here. I've only had lattes and the New Orleans style iced coffee, so far. I want to try everything they have on the menu though. The cookies are pretty tasty too, very soft and not overly sweet. A great way to jumpstart the day.
author: Jenny M.

description: The international language of coffee still needs some translation. Having ordered a cortado in NYC to get my preferred ratio of double espresso shot that isn't drowned by too much milk, the lexicon in San Francisco is similar to that in Chicago and the drink is called a 'Gibraltar'. This is the name of the small glass the coffee is served in. There's a very long queue mid-morning at the Mint Plaza and there's a very good reason why - the coffee is smooth as and, ta da, perfect in every respect. Kudos guys. Just as well there's no wi-fi, otherwise I'd never leave.
author: Michelle D.

description:
Blue Bottle is pretty much the poster child for the Third Wave Coffee movement and is the standard by which all other Third Wave-ish roasters and cafes are judged by. I'm also a huge fan but the competition in the SF Bay Area is quite stiff and I like to think of Blue Bottle as being one (very important) component of the Third Wave Coffee movement along with other greats like Ritual, Barefoot, Four Barrel, Sightglass etc.

First let me tackle the technical details:

- Locally roasted, fresh coffee beans: 
 Check. Blue Bottle is one of the most well known local SF Bay Area roasters.
- Baristas with proper training on pulling espresso & steaming milk: 
 Check 
- High quality Milk: 
 Check. Clover Organic.
- Latte Art:
 Check

The quality of drinks produced by Blue Bottle is very high. I'm very impressed by how they maintain a very consistant drink quality throughout their multiple locations and many different Baristas. They must have a very rigorous Barista training program.
author: Fouzi H.

description:
I love blue bottle. We have it every day at work (for free!) but I never get tired of the best cup of coffee ever, and happily visit mint plaza on weekends. 

They put care and precision into making each amazing cup of coffee, and they are super nice and friendly. We were craving a bagel (and maybe a donut hole or 5...) after our drips and cookies (olive oil shortbread is so good, and ginger molasses is an 11 on the scale of gingery goodness!) and the friendly barista suggested a cute little place down the street.
author: L B.

description:
I'm not a big coffee drinker, but my latte was dang good. After walking down a small parking lot, we finally found Blue Bottle and I'm glad we did. It's such a cute place. 

We split the waffle & poached eggs. I'm kind of a snob about poached eggs and these were delicious. Perfectly runny yolk, yummy! Employees are super nice & friendly.
author: Jeannie T.

description: Small tucked away corner shop. Few pastries, few seats. Had an excellent cappuccino.
author: Brett N.

description: I like the coffee, but this location tends to have more "colorful" characters (read: homeless crack addicts).  I prefer the Hayes Valley or Ferry Building location, where I can get my Blue Bottle on without being harassed for change or being lectured on the perils of eternal damnation.
author: Erika C.

description:
Crowded as heck during weekend brunch, but the top-notch food and drinks, friendly service, and charming ambience make the experience a pleasant one. 

An acquaintance of mine kept gushing about the hot chocolate here, and it did not disappoint: smooth and creamy, without overwhelming sweetness or richness.

I also loved their brunch frittata: perfectly crisp bacon, mealy potatoes, and fluffy eggs with a toasty crust. 

This place has a great modern vibe: everything from the business card display to the sugar dispensers was sleek and interesting. I could spend hours watching their infrared siphon coffee pot or their fancy-schmancy Kyoto coffee contraption thingy. If only I could try their coffee! I'm unfortunately caffeine intolerant - I go loopy. But their food and non-coffee drinks are enough to keep me coming back.

Don't let the crowds deter you - the line moves fast, and your order comes out right away.
author: Jen L.

description:
The trouble with this place is the service.  They say that any place with a line in SF is worth the wait - just stand in line.  I usually agree that a line is an indicator of something amazing.  Here it just means REALLY SLOW SERVICE.

I had 15 minutes this morning, and the line that normally snakes out the door and around the corner was actually contained within the interior space.  Sweet!  Or not.  For the ten minutes I stood in line I saw them ring up 2 people. TWO.  In TEN minutes.  On a Sunday morning with 5 employees, wait 6.  Absolutely ridiculous.  I left, since there were still 4 people in front of me.  The coffee is worth a reasonable wait, but I can't justify standing in line for 20 minutes, getting bumped into constantly by the small space and the people pushing through the line to see the french presses and various coffee making vessels.  They have a great product, but their service and layout is a mess.
author: Kristel S.

description:
This has got to have the BEST coffee I've ever tasted in my entire life albeit the slow service & expensive coffee. However, the waiters may be a little "slow" just because they put so much work into every cup of coffee that they make. If you want coffee from here before work and you don't want to be late, just make sure you don't go during the rush hours of 9am and lunchtime 12pmish. 

My favorite drink there is the Mocha. They put REAL ganache in the drink and it has this smooth, rich chocolate flavor to the mocha. I've also tried New Orleans style ice-coffee and that's great too. 

Overall, I have to recommend this place to anyone who loves coffee and wants to taste the best thing ever.
author: Tran N.

description: There's a line for a reason...great coffee + latte art! The staff attitude is really fantastic. The only downside is that the place is such a hive of activity that I felt guilty lingering.
author: Nick L.

description:
As I waited in line here a few days ago I watched one of the baristas preparing a pourover coffee. I decided to order one, and the guy working the counter insisted the one that was already made was mine, and got extremely defensive about it. I ended up just taking that coffee, which wasn't quite as warm as I like. Tasted underextracted, and the beans seemed over-roasted or too finely ground. It wasn't full-bodied, but at the same time it was bitter. Not a great pour. I make a better cup at home. 

I also ordered an espresso. Points for it being served with sparkling water to act as a palette cleanser, but I was unimpressed - again, beans tasted over-roasted I think. 

I wouldn't come here again on account of the service and the coffee. Was it better than Starbucks or Peets? Sure, but the coffee did not back up the image that Blue Bottle portrays.
author: Mark E.

description: This place has great coffee, a great atmosphere, and some really cool brewing techniques. I ordered an Ethiopian coffee from the siphon bar and they brewed it using a Japanese siphon bar machine which was incredibly cool to watch.
author: Jene L.

description: If I wouldn't have put myself on such a budget on my vacation I would have had breakfast here every morning and gotten something more expensive. I only got a "cheap" black coffee. This place is a little more pricey to downright expensive depending on what you order. I would give this place 4 stars but one of the straight guys that work there gave myself and my buddies a free shot of there New Orleans style coffee. Plus the staff was incredibly friendly. I even was hit on by the guy that took my order. I would probably find this flattering if I myself swung that way, but as you can tell I don't. Nevermind that, it was San Francisco. This ole' South Carolinia boy's eyes where opened up quite a bit to all the craziness that is San Francisco, but Blue Bottle Coffee Company was probably one of the little bit of normal that one can find to unwind and enjoy a fresh cup of New Orleans Joe.
author: Marshall R.

description:
Had to try out that siphoned coffee. What a great place to just chill out with a friend or just do a bit of pleasurable reading while holding what looks like something from a chemistry set and sipping some of the best coffee ever. 

My cousin was the first to tell me about this place and I was like WHOA when I saw a video of the siphoned coffee being made. Never have I ever seen something like that. Looking like a scientist creating some insane concoction that could either give you eternal youth or just destroy the planet. 

The service was really amazing. Made sure we wanted everything just how we described and then carefully brewing our drinks. It seemed to take forever to make the coffee but just that alone was entertainment to us. 

We received out coffees in what looked like flask and then she poured some of it into a little beaker. Truly a mad scientist kind of drink huh? The lady also gave us a note that it's meant to be drank black and changes flavors slightly when temperatures differ. She was right. 

I had the Honduras which was amazing. Best coffee ever hands down. I rarely, if ever, drink straight black coffee, but this was just extraordinary. Smooth and packed with delicious aromas. If it wasn't so expensive, I'd get it regularly. 

This is my new favorite coffee joint but too bad it's so far away from my place. If you love coffee. you can't pass this place up. This is the only one that I know of that has the siphon bar. Pricey, but so worth it. Now to try their "regular" coffees.
author: robin w.

description: Good coffee? yes. Worth standing in a massive line for? eh....  They make a very good coffee, but not the kind of earth shattering, ground moving, sea parting coffee the java nazis make it out to be.  I visited their outpost down on the piers which may have influenced my experience.  Good coffee. I'd go back.  But I'm sure there are plenty of barristas in the area making a similarly good brew.
author: Kenneth E.

description:
Love the coffee here.  
I am also a fan of their interesting pastries.
We both got lattes and that ish was good.  It wasn't too strong/bitter and had just enough foam on top.  Delicious.

Also, the saffron snickerdoodle was great... as was the St. George Absinthe cookie, I think it was a shortbread?  

Overall: Yummy coffee, very intriguing pastries, and the line NEVER stopped going out the door... it must be crazy to work there.
author: Isabella O.

description: Working in the tenderloin had its ups and downs...being 2 blocks from blue bottle was a plus. Love their lattes!!
author: sandrita j.

description:
My first Blue Bottle experience was disappointing.  It reminded me of my first trip to a miniature golf course:

 i can't wait to go explore that house shaped like a shoe! then i'll go climb to the top of that 10 foot windmill and jump into the little lake!  IT WILL BE THE BEST AFTERNOON EVARRRR!!
Wait, I can't go inside the shoe?  What about the windmill?  And the lake??
This sucks. I want to go home.

Well, it wasn't THAT bad, but it was disappointing.  Everyone and their stepdaughter raves about BBC, how good the coffee is, how cool they are, that you'll never have a better coffee and they're worth the price.

Well, it was a good latte.  Not exceptional, just good.  But it required a 20 minute wait almost $5.  So... I guess I'll give it another shot.  Apparently i'm supposed to have their iced coffee because its incredible.  But I reserve judgment until that day.
author: Mari C.

description:
Finally, a Blue Bottle Coffee Co. location with decent enough space to sit down.  The space is a loft space with seating room for about 20.; that's about 19 more seats than most of their other locations.

The coffee is great.  I've always had great cups of coffee here and I love how they don't charge extra for soy.  This lactose-intolerance price discrimination will not stand, man.

This location is conveniently located to the SF Shopping Center and Union Square.
author: Marcin M.

description: You know, the quality has gone down significantly. I used to love this place but now every time I go here between their coffee beans to take home and their espresso coffee, I am not impressed. I don't put them in the same boat as Starbucks but they are not upping their game... Although every time I go, the line is out the door so it sounds like people are happy with what they are getting.
author: Lo F.

description: Delicious, and i mean DELICIOUS coffee here. I usually like my coffee extra sweetened, because I have a sweet tooth, however, I didn't mind the lack of sugar at Blue Bottle. The coffee was so smooth and the baristas are all extremely friendly. One of my favorite cafes in SF. :) I will be sure to check out their desserts in the future; been here twice and haven't tried their food yet, that's a first...
author: Selina S.

description:
I repent! My very well informed wife dragged me here on my last trip to SanFran . A veteran of twenty years as a musician touring Europe i have come to know that  every respectable corner shop boasts coffee that on a bad day is 10 times better than anything Starbucks serves. That being said: hot damn Blue Bottle serves good coffee. Get the waffle too! Buy beans etc, whatever they are doing works and is good. 
I hate to be told what is good and or hip but I have to give it up to my wife who reads and absorbs. 
Returned 3 times last week when doing a week gig in San Fran and the lines were still long and the wait still well worth it.
author: Karl L.

description: There was wayyy too many shops/cafes to chose from within the westfield food courst. I walked by the pastries and it was like love at first sight....there sweets are to die for. Portions were more than enough for 2-3 people, price was reasonable as well. There coffees are made fresh individually so no watered down aftertaste. Would def return for their llunch menu as well.
author: Zaynaf S.

description: It's fine. The puritans are going to roll in their graves but I prefer my starbucks coffee.
author: Partha S.

description: Blue Bottle Coffee elevates the coffee tasting to a higher level - satisfactory, pleasant and artistic.  No more words.  You have to taste by yourself.
author: H. L.

description: Great service, had my Kyoto replaced with New Orleans since it was not done brewing this morning. Coffee was very tasty in my opinion especially with a slice of sweet toast. Planning to come again hopefully the Kyoto will be ready next time with the same friendly staff as well.
author: Jimmy L.

description: By far, the best coffee I've had in San Francisco till now! No wonder this place is always crowded.
author: Srivatsan S.

description:
If I could just sleep under one of their tables, I'd be in heaven. Where to begin? 

"Blue Bottle coffee? What's that?" This is the stupid little question I asked upon my return to the City by the Bay. It turns out that Blue Bottle coffee is the nectar of the gods. Roasted by some little joint in O-town and brewed individually at locations throughout the BA. Yum x 10^23. This place has all of the specialized Blue Bottle paraphernalia to make iced drinks, drip drinks, etc etc. With limited parole from my tropical Florida prison, I couldn't waste time with the iced beverages.

On to food. At 0800, a magical thing happens here. Fresh baked bread appears, frittatas start frittataing; the breakfast service begins. I enjoyed their light-as-a-cloud, toasted-to-golden-perfection toast served with a fresh berry compote and butter. The poached eggs on toast (second breakfasts) were a work of art: perfect pearly pouches perched on puffy plateaus of p'toast. Inside, golden treasure. Absolutely divine.

I'll miss you, Blue Bottle Coffee Co. Think of me in Florida. Alone. Surrounded by that other coffee company.
author: Brian P.

description:
I spent a morning with a friend.

As I sipped on my rich and complex coffee, as we were deep into superficial conversation, I noticed that I had a smile on my face.  Time seemed to stop for a split second, the world seemed brilliantly imperfect, and life was wonderful.

Moments like that are rare.
author: Yeeman N.

description:
I'm a fan!  The place is on a small street in the middle of Hayes Valley, so it's a nice place to walk around and enjoy the sunshine after you've grabbed a soy latte.  I'm not a huge coffee drinker so usually as long as it's sweet and doesn't taste funky it's good to me... but I do enjoy their soy lattes.

The artwork of the foam on top is awesome.  It's so simple but that extra touch really gets me and puts a smile on my face.  It's worth checking out - especially on a Saturday morning.. followed by a short stroll and maybe brunch at Stacks. :)
author: Melody T.

description:
The real deal as far as coffee shops go.  
Great find on a recent visit to SF.  I was staying near the Powell St. BART station and was a little concerned about where I was going to get my coffee.  I had no idea how awesome this little coffee shop was.
I like their bio-degradable lids and have yet to try the siphoned coffee, but am looking forward to trying it sometime soon.
author: Virginia L.

description: Best place for New Orleans iced coffee in the area.
author: Erik M.

description:
Such a cool place to get a cup of "Joe". Never have I ever wanted to sit at a coffee shop to drink my coffee leisurely until today. Watching the coffee barista prep, brew, carefully prepare coffee was so interesting to watch.
Must try:
1)New Orleans Iced Coffee simply delicious
2)Grilled ham and cheese( will not disappoint)
3)Asparagus,walnut, cheese, salad

Lastly..Rosemary shortbread..Mmmmm

Parking can be fun, be prepared to drive around to find a spot.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
So. Chic. Right. Now.

Just grabbed an espresso at this Blue Bottle Location, and let me say, I felt oh sooooo chic.
