Now it might be that Im about to head to a fashion show, and wearing one ridiculously couture getup. Or then again, it could be the fabulously modern interior, limited and well-done menu, or the glitzy business clientelle. 

Want a quick cup in a chic environment? Blue Bottle it is.
author: Thom S.

description:
I visited Blue Bottle when I was in San Francisco earlier this month. It was highly recommended by several friends so there was no doubt that I had to make the trip.

The coffee was amazing - I had the New Orleans style iced coffee and it was divine. I would go over and over again just to try the different offerings they have there.

I went fairly early in the morning, so there was no line! A few people sititng inside but pretty quiet overall.

The gentleman who served me was very nice & helpful, despite my being groggy at having to get up early on vacation & not having downed any coffee yet ;)

My only comment is that I didn't see much in the way of food (I'm a big fan of breakfast to star the day). Not sure if I just missed it (the decor is very busy & eclectic, especially behind the counter) or if it just wasn't set up yet for the day. 

Strongly recommend a visit to Blue Bottle if you're in the area. They have other locations too!
author: Danelle W.

description: Got just the standard drip coffee.  Amazing. I am not much of a coffee person even considering I am a law student. However, it was clear the quality of the product. Only slight against them was the lack of sweetener other than suger and the line to order. Yet, the coffee was so balanced I found no need for splenda in the end.
author: Joseph D.

description:
The coffee they serve is extra fresh (beans less than 48 hours out of the roaster) and they are known for utilizing the siphon method of brewing which brews a very clean cup of coffee.

I order a drip coffee and Bella selects the New Orleans style iced coffee.  The color of Bella's drink is striking and it is served in a lean highball glass.  And it tastes even better than it looks.  I forgot to ask but I assume this is chicory coffee which is standard New Orleans coffee.  This style of brew takes me back to our UCC Café in Walnut, CA.  

This place truly is for the coffee purists.  Check your request of funky flavored coffee drinks, whipped cream and caramel sauce at the door my friends.
author: David E.

description: Some if the best coffee you will find anywhere. This location has drips that are done in what almost looks like a science experiment and takes some time giving you a truly refined flavor experience. They also have a small breakfast and lunch menu that is California style cuisine with a twist. If I don't have a long time, grabbing a simple drip or espresso drink works. New Orleans style iced coffee comes in handy on warm days. Highly recommended if you are a coffee snob like me.
author: Jared C.

description:
I L-O-V-E Coffee and I know this place was featured on the Food Network, so I had to try this place. This place has limited seating, so keep you eyes out for open seats or divide and conquer if you're with a group. 

There was a long line out the door and kind of around the corner, but the wait isn't too bad because the weather was nice. I got the macchiato and the BF got the iced Kyoto drip coffee, which was featured on Food Network.  I LOVED my macchiato, it had lots of flavor and it wasn't bitter.  

I tried a couple of sips of the Kyoto coffee (black - no cream no sugar) and I didn't like it because it was too strong for me (I drink really strong coffee too).  It had a really sweet after taste to the coffee and that's all I can say about it because I just didn't like it. 

This is my go to coffee place in San Fran, when I come back of course.
author: Karen C.

description:
I know this is supposed to be like the original 'cool' coffee place in town and I was excited to come here when I moved to SF since I'm a huge coffee person. 

I don't think it's better than the other top choices (Philz, Ritual, Four Barrel) and might be my least favorite of them all. Their coffee choices are generally very bold and they all have that sourness, I can't think of a better word, to them. It is interesting in their New Orleans on the first couple sips but it gets pretty old after seeing it as a common taste profile throughout all their drinks. Their coffee is often a little watery even though it's packed with flavor so I'm not sure how that's possible.

Food wise, everything looks delicious and I've had the poached eggs a couple of times which were very delicious on thick cuts of fresh bread. Kudos. A little expensive at $8-9 for toast with eggs but nice to try.
author: Sam H.

description:
Who knew, my first 5 star review would be a coffee place.

An amazing, educational, sophisticated and real coffee experience ever. Felt like I lost my virginity all over again...

All I can say to Blue Bottle Coffee is...nothing.  Bow down to the greatest coffee taste ever and this place is now my standard for excellent coffee.

And, the barista Trevor was highly informative and took great pleasure and detail into making each coffee order.  He always did a quality check by smelling the aroma of each drink.  Almost felt like wine tasting, but coffee tasting this time.  I was imbibed by my coffee and took mental notes in hopes to create a lasting memory of how wonderful this coffee tasted.

I will return to SF soon to visit you Blue Bottle Coffee~
author: Saki U.

description:
Amazing coffee!!!  And the food was good too!  We drink Blue Bottle Coffee regularly at home with our own espresso machine, and from other locations in the area, with this being my first foray into this Blue Bottle location.  While the lines were long, the communal tables were fun and we enjoyed meeting new people across the table.  

Coffee:  I ordered a decaf cappuccino - I know, I know, I'm told constantly that real coffee drinkers don't drink decaf - but I do.  And Blue Bottle rocked the decaf!  The milk was steamed to the point where the lactose turned into yummy sweetness and the coffee was perfect.  

Food:  I ordered the waffles and wow - I don't eat waffles often but when I do - I want them to be like this!  Thick and crunchy on the outside with creamy insides - they didn't need the mounds of butter and syrup I just had to add, but boy, did that add so much wonderful goodness.  

I'll definitely be back for more coffee and waffles next time I'm in the area - in the meantime, I'll continue to make my own coffee at home with Blue Bottle beans.
author: Amee C.

description:
As a fan of coffee. I set a pretty high stand for it. Blue bottle is certainly one of my favourite. I don't think I have to mention how great it is because other yelpers have already done it for me!

Staff in this store are very friendly and professional! 

I also love the ambiance at this place. I was there on a Wednesday morning reading newspaper and preparing something important for a meeting. It totally has the right atmosphere for me to do those things. 

Can't wait to visit again!! :)
author: Mel C.

description:
One of the reasons I love San Fran so much is the abundance of comfy and quality coffee shops. Blue Bottle Coffee Co is definitely one of the better coffee shops I've been at in my life. 

Every time I've been there has been a line and definitely a wait. But it is well worth it. I was blown away by the latte I had and have not been disappointed by anything I've tried. Great hot chocolate, fresh homemade whipped cream for their espresso con panna, delicious cookies and I am coming back for their awesome looking brunch menu.

It is a bit small and not a lot of free seating so I wouldn't recommend it for a large group. But so good. Come here.
author: Jane H.

description: Blue Bottle lattes are amazing.  Delicious stuff -- wish it was a tad bit hotter.  I also ordered the toast on their limited breakfast menu, and that was also tasty.  The service was a bit slow -- there tends to be a bit of the line, and you may be waiting in it for a little longer than you may like.  It's worth it, though, for that delicious coffee.
author: Mel G.

description: Got here at morning rush. Didn't have to wait too long though, it was shorter than the ferry building Blue Bottle line! I ordered the SG-120, which came in a beautiful Hario glass. It worked so well, and I would come again and order the same thing!
author: Steven M.

description:
When I pay $4.50 I want it to be: really good AND hot. It was not. I acually threw it out, I don't think I ever done that before. 
Also had 2 cookies; shortbread with rosemary was ok. saffron snickerdoodle not so good.

two stars only because service was good.
author: Jen N.

description:
I love Blue Bottle coffee, but this is pathetic.  Friday, I was in line over a half hour just waiting to order, and the line was less than 10 people long.  

Good things come to those who wait and all, but this coffee isn't good enough to wait ten times longer than any other cafe.  The baristas were so inefficient, distracted and redundant.  Hire a staff worthy of the product.
author: Quinn S.

description: Thank you to the superb quality, education, and service provided by the Blue Bottle Coffee Co staff and Baristas! The barista politely educated me about the coffee quality and recommended the best purchase for my tastes - an unadulterated cappuccino. The taste, temperature, volume, cup, and appearance were supreme! I also appreciated being treated with respect as a customer - not being "upsold" and most importantly receiving the finest cup of cappuccino I have ever had. Many people are somewhat indifferent to the taste of coffee. However, if you truly enjoy sipping the best, then Blue Bottle Coffee with great beans and equally important, skilled baristas, make this an unforgettable experience!
author: John R.

description: 4.5 stars.  Hype is high here.  For the most part it was great and lived up to it.  I think it  is difficult to decide if its the best espresso anywhere, as that is a silly claim with too many variables to judge from a single experience.  What I can say is that the various times I have had Blue Bottle, it has been pretty consistent, even with the growth and opening of new locations.  Their espresso roast is robust and on the darker side....how I like it.  It was pulled for the right amount and it was without bitterness.  Best anywhere? Probably not, but a darn good one I am happy to have anytime.
author: Porca M.

description:
The day I took my boyfriend and our friend Ish here, they were both impatient and wanted their coffee stat!  I'm sure they would have written a 2 star review for the wait.   But for me, I don't mind waiting 10 mins for a taste of fresh and potent coffee.   It's like drinking jet fuel!

Nowadays my boyfriend won't drink anything but Blue Bottle Coffee beans.   

This location is airy and spacious.   Initially I had thought it was a wine bar before I started living here in the city.    I had the toast here and it was nice and thick!   Love it.
author: Morgan L.

description:
I've been to a few locations that serve Blue Bottle Coffee, none of which have had a line as long as this location. It was Saturday, around 2pm, but good Lord! The only thing I could think of while standing in line was, "Is one brew at a time a good business model?" 

My friend ordered the siphon and I got a regular latte. The siphon coffee was actually really good (and strong!). It is probably one of the only coffees I've ever had that I actually thoroughly enjoy drinking black. However, I don't know if it is worth the price tag. I am by no means a coffee connoisseur though. I actually enjoy McDonalds coffee more than I do Starbucks, but according to some article in some newspaper, McDonalds has better quality beans than Starbucks - so hey, maybe I know what I'm talking about.

The latte was mediocre. In a nutshell, it's a neat thing to experience but I don't understand the hype. Blue Bottle is a bit overrated. Am I going to get a bunch of hate messages now? Eeeep. 

~Emily
author: Emily L.

description: Much has been written at BBC. What can I say, just love the coffee. A must stop when in the City
author: Abe K.

description:
So, my rating is for their awesome coffee and food. I'm sadly allergic to coffee (which I love the taste of), but I do sneak sips of my friends' mochas and New Orleans iced coffees, and Blue Bottle coffee is bangin'. I had a hot chocolate once, too, and it was bomb. I've also tried the gingerbread and biscotti, and seriously, also bomb. When I tried their ginger tea, I was a little overwhelmed with how strong it was, but if you like super intense spicy ginger - definitely try it. 

The menu is very simple and authentic, so don't go there if you need to have your fancy fraps or overly sweet drinks. 

However, I would give the service 2 stars. Don't get me wrong - I frankly could do without the perky barista shit that you get at mainstream places and like to get in, get out, and be done with a few pleasantries here and there. Blue Bottle just has a certain...attitude? Like, I love your food and I'm not mean, so don't be rude to me, please.  The lines are always long, so expect a wait if you go during peak times.
author: Andrea B.

description: These guys think a ristretto is the same as an expresso... I was expecting a bit more from people who sell coffee!
author: Nicolas P.

description: This is a Blue Bottle Coffee shop located in Mint Plaza between 5th and 6th St. I've sampled a good portion of their coffee menu: latte, cappuccino, drip coffee, New Orleans style iced coffee, Kyoto style iced coffee, siphon bar coffee, and affogato. My favorites are their single origin drip coffee and siphon bar coffee. Although Blue Bottle makes excellent espresso-based drinks, they're not the best I've ever had when compared to Sightglass Coffee or Four Barrel Coffee. However, I have to say the drip coffee here is extremely strong and full-bodied. You can instantly taste the superior quality beans used and afterwards I am noticeably energized from the caffeine jolt. One of these days I will finally buy some of their coffee beans for my French Press at home. I've tried both of their iced coffees (New Orleans and Kyoto), but I'm torn between which one I like better. To be honest, I probably just alternate randomly between the two depending on my mood. Either way, both are perfect for those occasional sunny 70+ degree days here in SF. Unless you're already in the general area or it's your first time here, I suggest trying the Mint Mojito Iced Coffee from Philz Coffee as a point of reference. There's also the halogen-powered siphon bar coffee! The machine apparently cost more than $20,000 to import from Japan. Sure at the end of the day, the concept is nothing new: siphon coffee, the difference being in how it's heated. But hey there's a reason the World Siphonist Championship originated from Japan right? The secret is in the stirring...watch the baristas use bamboo paddles to create the captivating whirlpool! Trust me, this unique brewing method really does produce a unique cup of coffee so try it at least once. I would describe it as a lighter, sweeter, more aromatic form of your normal brewed coffee, but with very complex flavors due to the level of extraction. Be careful since it's extremely hot! Each cup has different characteristics due to the different origins so just ask the baristas for advice. Also, each siphon coffee order is enough for at least two cups of coffee in case you wanted to share. Finally, there's the affogato: Humphry Slocombe ice cream with a shot of espresso. Wow this must be heaven! Just be aware there is no Wi-Fi here and seating is pretty limited (maybe 20-25 max?). All in all, there is always a line here, but seeing how legendary Blue Bottle is here in the Bay Area, any Blue Bottle location is a must visit!
author: Andy C.

description: The best mocha I have ever had! We were in town for business so I was a little nervous when I saw the line out the door....but once you taste the coffee, you see why! So good and totally worth the wait (which was not that long at all).
author: Sara P.

description: Worth The Visit! Coffee, Cappuccino & The Chocolate Chocolate-Chip Cookie Were Delicious. Service Was Great. The Shop Is Modern - Less Is More!
author: Sunshine Y.

description: I really really want to like it and I've given Blue Bottle a fair number of tries at a couple of different locations. I've bought a couple of different blends for home brewing but this coffee really doesn't do it for me. Perhaps I'm been over exposed to Peets and it has ruined my taste buds? I've tried a few of the other so called 3rd wave coffee's and prefer those or good old Peets. To me Blue Bottle is like expensive Maxwell House for hipsters.
author: David W.

description:
The best coffee I have had in quite a long time. Loved the coffee and loved the atmosphere. 
After seeing her make a cup of hot chocolate, I wanted one of those too...oh well...there's next time.
author: Lane A.

description: Great coffee beans to take home with you, the Latte tastes great and the ambiance is also really fancy. I also didn't mind the 20 minute wait outside with other patrons. Cool thing to see if visiting San Fran.
author: Shahram L.

description:
I'm drawn to this blue bottle location for their iced Kyoto coffee, a cold, slow drip process done overnight. The aroma and flavor is almost like drinking a fine wine where you pickup scents of chocolate, nuts, and of course, deep rich coffee.  The flavor is so smooth, intense, and unlike anything you've tried before, it's addicting.

I like to sit in front of the siphon bar and to watch the artistic brewing process while enjoying the coffee with something from their lunch menu, like the tasty leaf salad with a grain mustard dressing, or the Prather Ranch all beef hot dog with carmelized onions. For a coffee house/cafe the food is surprisingly good.

You also have to try a saffron snickerdoodle to go with your coffee... as smooth and tasty as the coffee. 

A definite must for anyone visiting SF and looking for the best cup of coffee in town.
author: David M.

description:
The Bella Donovan coffee is reason enough to stop by this cafe. The food is little hipster oriented but good. The locations are all interesting and add to the trendy atmosphere. But I would be a regular if I lived in town just based on the coffee.  If you aren't lucky enough to live nearby they do have a website and you can order whole beans that will be shipped to just about anywhere in two days time (roasted the day before shipment in most cases) and you can enjoy it at home.

A must when in SF!
author: Ryan J.

description: Their cappuccino is worth the 1/2 hour rate...it's like crack. But why the 1/2 our line ups?
author: Catalina C.

description:
Lattes are velvety smooth.
The espresso is sweet with a pleasant acidity.
Individual drip coffee very good balance of body and flavor and acidity. It makes you go... "ahh."
Now the Kyoto Ice Coffee is liquid speed. It's very strong, but the flavor is good enough that you can drink it black. It's so thick that it coats your tongue. My friends and I took a few sips and we were speed walking up and down union square. A day later my body crashed and took a couple days to recover. 
Blue bottle doesn't have a wide variety of drinks and flavors like some cafes, but the drinks they do have are of high quality.
I don't know if my body could handle the Kyoto again, but strangely i want it... I'm addicted after my first time...
author: Sharon K.

description:
I enjoyed this place, but I am docking a star mostly for the service and attitude.

My boyfriend and I came in at 7:30am starving and wanting breakfast. Unfortunately, they don't start serving breakfast until 8, which is kind of weird. So we got our drinks and at about 7:50 I got back in line to order food. At 7:55, it was my turn to order. The girl looked at me accusingly and asked where I got the menu (one of the baristas begrudgingly gave it to me earlier because I actually wanted to see what they offered). She then tersely informed me that my food would not be started until 8. Ok, ok. That's fine. You don't have to be a bitch about it. This was my first time there. I wasn't trying to break any of their "rules." I just wanted f'''ing breakfast. Never had to endure so much just to give someone my money.

That being said, our lattes were quite good. They definitely make quality drinks. The atmosphere is modern and cute as well. And, for a place that specializes in coffee, their food was surprisingly excellent. My by got the french toast and I got the regular toast (huge thick slabs) with butter and jam. Everything tasted wonderful.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Prices are a little high, but you get what you pay for.

You get:
-ultra, extra, fantastically talented baristas
-hip local
-fantastic coffee

Don't come expecting anything much more or less than what those three things entail.

I would just say you wanna wait for the hype to die down.  This weekend the joint was way too packed, line out the door.
author: Peter v.

description:
3.5 stars

Long story short:  Coffee ain't too bad.  Prices seemed decent.  Space is pretty cool.

Long story long:

I had a couple people tell me I had to check out Blue Bottle because the coffee was really good.  Now, I'm no coffee connoisseur, so I normally take their word for it.

This is located in Mint Plaza, which contrary to how my friend was making it sound, didn't have a lot.  I was expecting stores to be lining the entire plaza but that wasn't the case.  I dunno.  The space itself has that concrete, minimalist look to it.  Kinda cool actually.

I got a latte, the size about the equivalent of a "grande" at Starbucks.  I think it was like $3something, almost $4?  I can't really remember.  The cashier was really nice.  Everybody there seemed really nice and enjoyed working there.  That's always a plus to see happy and enthusiastic employees.  Nothing like starting your day than when you go somewhere and the person looks like they want to leave.

I left and took a sip.  Not bad.  Again, I'm no coffee connoisseur, so I can't compare.

Why is it so hard to write a "long" review of a coffee shop? meh
author: Austin S.

description: Out-the-door weekend line? No thanks. I prefer stopping in during their "off" hours. Friday evening was still a little too cozy for our liking, as we decided to order to-go. Their offerings are reminiscent of an Intelligentsia-style quality (for those fellow Chicagoans out there) but with a quirky hand drawn, mad-alchemist touch. I had a taste of the boy's cappuccino and it was like sipping on a strong, luscious, caffeinated cloud. My tea; however was a different story. I know, who in their right mind would order tea from a coffee place? Apparently this girl. For such a fine tea product, the water was waaaay too hot, causing my tea to taste bitter and gritty. No respect for the leaves, BB. Next time, I'll stick with their tried and true.
author: Jenny H.

description:
I hate coffee.. I can't stand it. But I had the New Orleans iced coffee here around a month ago- I'm addicted!
I'm here almost every other Sunday for brunch before work. Their waffles are huge! Extremely tasty and not too moist.

I could do without the crazy lines but I know my 20-30 minute wait (in line then for my drinks/food) is well worth the wait. 

Staff is attentive and it's always clean. I love the location. Props for outdoor seating!
author: Amanda S.

description:
Didn't get a chance to try restrooms or their food; came here to meet a stranger for a meeting. It was okay - their service is friendly and the seating isn't too shabby. They even have outside restrooms. 

A huge plus is that large area of outside seating... SF has some quaint alleys and backsides for getting your grub on, or meeting on, or whatever is up to you on.
author: Carl Z.

description: Cool place, but my coffee was cool too.  I really like my coffee hot.  Maybe I should have ordered a hot coffee.
author: Gjon C.

description:
Coffee... Caffeine... A daily necessity in my life. 

The lines are long, regardless of the Blue Bottle location you go to, but the coffee is always so fresh, how can you say no?  I don't frequent as much as I would like, since $2.50 for a cup of coffee daily could run a hole in my pocket book... and the time waiting for my coffee to be made individually could really add up... but if I could, I would, come every single day!  

The best part, each location has a different feel.  The one in the Ferry Building has somewhat of a touristy feel... but also the "avoiding work - so I'm going for an extended coffee break feel", the one out of a garage in Hayes Valley has a neighborhood feel... and this one in Mint Plaza is a mix between locals and tourists, and it is extra homey feeling with SEATS inside and food served on the weekends - if you're up early enough. 

Come early. Come often. Get CAFFEINATED!
author: Lisa L.

description:
love that i can walk out the front door with my beau and get good coffee.
hate that others know too and there can sometimes be a line
author: Fins L.

description: I am a little picky about the froth on my espresso drinks. The froth, as they say, is supposed to be micro-foam and velvety. That is exactly what I got each time I got coffee from there. You can see the barista spending extra time to make sure that the foam does not have big bubbles. There is usually a big line there, which sucks. They don't have wi-fi and any big seating place. So, not really ideal if you want to work from there or hang out with friends. But if you want to drink nice latte, this is the place.
author: Rohit J.

description:
Okay, I went back the next day at 7am (it was a ghost time - hipsters sleep late) and explained that their latte was basically a cup of hot milk with zero espresso flavor and they suggested I try a Gibraltar - not on the menu. It was quite good - although a bit tiny (equal parts espresso and milk).

Bottom line they are extremely nice - great customer service.... I still think the latte is disappointing... Maybe I'm tainted because every other spot has a latte with solid espresso flavor...
author: Jeff D.

description:
Finally, a gilbraltar (and now I know how to pronounce it)!! 

I mistakenly thought you can only order gibraltars at certain Blue Bottle locations (Ferry Plaza location excluded), so I stopped by this location prior to catching a show over at Golden Gate Theater.

This place can be a little hard to find. I was a little scared walking through the 'hoods of Market/6th before happily stumbling upon the shop tucked away in the Mint Plaza.

I love the atmophere. It's super clean and modern and I like the fact it doesn't try to be 'earthy' or too cozy with a lot of brown/tan colors. It was pretty packed for Thursday at 6pm. What followed was this:

Cashier: Hi, what can I get you?
Me: Hi! um..you guys have that off-menu drink that's very popular, right?
Cashier: Are you talking about the gibraltar?
Me: Yes! ... how do you pronounce it?
Cashier (very soft-toned): gi-bral-tar.
Me (barely heard him): Oh okay! I'll take two of them!
Cashier: Sure ::pause:: do you know what it is?
Me: ....kinda...

So he went on to explaning that it's a shot of espresso with steamed milk served in a shot glass, with a bit less milk than a cappuccino. Okay nice to know, but I'm not even gonna try to claim I know barista language, I just want the gibraltars!

And finally, they were ready and all I can say is that as I happily sipped my gilbratar, everything faded into warm, declicious gibraltar fuzzies and I was content the rest of the night!
author: Jing D.

description:
As a first timer to Blue Bottle, I asked for recommendations first.  I ordered the latte and enjoyed every drop.  With just the espresso and milk, it was sweet and just perfectly roasted beans, no need for sweetener.  I just went for the drink but would love to try their food as well.  I would also try their other coffee drinks.

I've tried Philz once and it was just that one time that makes me highly recommend Blue Bottle instead.
author: Allen C.

description:
I think it's overrated. My friend raved about their whatever style iced coffee. So I got excited and that day after lunch we went. He got his coffee instantly. 

Me? I waited at the front of the line for 10 mins while none of the staff acknowledged me, and one of their regular customers who was standing right behind me got served before me. Yes, cause they know what the guy is having, but when they make everything to order here, that just means I will have to wait longer and is rude! Meanwhile 2 baristas are just wiping the counter and chatting in the background and there is a line of 15 people out the door.

Don't get me wrong the coffee was good. But the lack of customer service for someone who wanted to love it, has put me off this experience all together. I'm going to stick with Philz.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I love San Francisco's coffee culture! I am from Australia and we are very passionate about all food and drinks.

Without a doubt, this place delivers on quality of coffee, but the reason why I wont give it 5 stars, or go there too regularly is because the service is just soooooo slow. It is insane! I get that it looks 'cool' to have a line all the way down the street, and that you want to put time into every cup, but really guys- you are a business and should be a bit more efficient.

I know a lot of  amazing coffee places that have a barista on shots, one on milk and someone separate on the cash register. If you could make your systems a bit more efficient I would be there every day! Now I only come when I know I have a spare hour to wait in line.
author: Lital K.

description:
I've heard so much about this cafe and always wanted to try it.  Being a huge coffee fanatic, I like to try and experience different cafes.  

My first time at Blue Bottle was last weekend, Sunday.  I ordered a soy latte and it was, by far, the best cup of coffee I've had in a long time.  It was smooth, creamy and incredibly tasteful. 

I'll definitely be coming back for more!
author: Raj D.

description:
I had heard so many good things about this coffee and this cafe...so I got myself going early on a Saturday (because I was sure the place would be packed by 10:00am) and headed downtown. 

The line was already long at 8:30 but I didn't mind.  I wait in long lines for things I like.  The staff wasn't that friendly but, whatever, I've gotten kind of used to uppity baristas in San Francisco.

I ordered a cappuccino and waited at a table, assuming it would be awhile since this place seems to be a "boutique" coffee place that prides itself on taking forever, kind of like Four Barrell.  I really don't mind waiting for my coffee because when I go to places like this, I am going for the experience, not to rush out the door.

Anyway, my name was called and I picked up the most delightful-looking cappuccino, with a tree designed into the carmel-colored foam on top -- a good sign.  Unfortuantely when I took a sip, the coffee I had looked forward to was weak, milky and bland.  I was so disappointed that I wanted to cry.  I don't know if the coffee is always like that, or maybe I'm just used to Philz and Peet's.  I won't be going back, because it's not worth the wait and the price for coffee that tastes like that.
author: Janie A.

description: You had my heart at cappuccino. I brought your beans with me back to Austin. I love you.
author: Tracy H.

description: I stop here almost every morning when i visit the city. Great Americanos and Cafe Mochas. The food is also good for a cafe and priced right. The people working here are very nice and always keep me updated on other good coffee shops. It's also very clean . But the wait sometimes can be a bummer. But parking sucks if you drive. I try to walk here from my hotel. I also buy the beans to take home. I would say a good med-full body coffee.
author: p v.

description: I had incredibly high expectations for this place, and they kind of let me down. There was kind of a long line since it was around lunch. I ordered a cold brew and and a double espresso. The drinks were fine, but the order seemed really rushed, and there wasn't the attention to detail you'd expect from a high end coffee shop. The whole experience left me feeling like I was just another customer in a line that they needed to get through. It's a shame. I really wanted to like this place.
author: Joe A.

description: I happened upon this place while at the farmers market and made my oh so tired son wait in a long line and boy was it worth it. So much so that I made my family do it again on our way out of town. This time I also ordered the oatmeal and like the guy ringing us up said - it is a game changer. I am a huge oatmeal fan so I may be a bit biased about it being a game changer but I would say it was the best oatmeal I have ever had. I will be back - and I will TRY to not make my entire trip be about Blue Bottle's coffee and oatmeal.
author: Jayme D.

description:
Likely one of the best coffee spots in the country.  Great coffee, nice atmosphere, interesting brewing methods.  Also, the food was really enjoyable too.  

However, the staff is a bit surly.  We initially tried to order the greek yogurt and fruit, alas they were all out due to the time it takes to macerate the fruit - no big deal and I totally hear you. 

So we switched up orders and asked if we could get the waffle with some fruit on top - we saw them cutting up peaches and strawberries and it looked excellent (for macerating for the yogurt the next day). There were at least 25 lbs of strawberries and 25 - 40 lbs of peaches - I mean amounts beyond belief, already cut-up.  The response was literally - "If I let you have peaches then I would have to let everyone have peaches, so I can't."  Really, really, you think everyone is going to ask for a few peach slices on their waffle because I am.  

As a result, the waffle was a bit of a bust, I mean a plain waffle with a bit of syrup and powdered sugar - some fruit on top would have really made it stand above average - but then everyone's waffle could be above average and that just doesn't make good sense, does it?  

All in all, I would go back - but the coffee and definitely the food at Abraco in NYC is still far superior.  Keep trying Blue Bottle and lose the attitude.
author: Andrew W.

description:
The best coffee I have ever had.

Amazing espresso, beautiful lattes, and the syphon coffee is an experience.

Very minimalist design, which I dig, and good service. The baristas definitely know what they are doing.

The food was a treat as well; the fritatta was cooked perfectly, had a great mix of the balsamic onions with the cheese, egg, potato, and bacon that really got me through our drive back down the 5. 

Definitely check this place out if you appreciate coffee, it's an experience. Will return.
author: Jon R.

description: Service is horrible. Long lines are common, but the efficiency of the staff was  head-scratchingly poor.
author: Chris M.

description: Great coffees. You can sit outside in the sun on an early morning. The capucinno is terrific. Well balanced with taste of fruit, chocolate not sour.
author: Pieter K.

description:
I've been longing to try Blue Bottle, since I've heard so much about it!  Alas, I had the chance to sip a cup of their latte and it surely did not disappoint!  Rich in flavor and oh so soothing to the soul!  Loved every sip of it! 

I LOVED the clean modern/industrial decor with the bar communal type tables.  The crowd is a mixed bag, but primarily the artsy types.

Not much personality on the staff part....kind of snobby barista/cashier person, but the coffee made up for it.  I opt for Intelligentsia baristas...much friendlier staff....sorry, Blue Bottle!!  

The location of this coffee shop is hidden in a little alleyway, towered by tall loft/office buildings and restaurants.  Parking was a beast with nothing but street parking, but how can you get away from that when you're in SF?  There was a parking lot charging $9, but drive around and you'll find parking!  Stand clear of the homeless lingering around at the end of the block.  I was afraid that they were going to come after me after I refused to give them change.  Be careful!  Aside from that mayhem, once you step into Blue Bottle, you escape to a different world!  

DEFINITELY coming back during my next visit to Blue Bottle.  DELICIOUS lattes and great vibe!!!
author: Emily A.

description:
I won't review the latte because I personally think that it would be insulting to describe something that does an excellent job at speaking for itself... Suffice it to say we go out of our way numerous times to get it.

That this is our favorite stop to pick up lattes in the mornings/midday - as it's SO much easier to find parking - they have that 15 minute spot that usually available, and a few available spots around the area.. Also, the service is always consistent.

My only complaint: Blue Bottle stopped serving those AMAZING Bayon Gruyere Brioches.. We did, however, find out where they came from - Firebrand Artisan Breads in Oakland. I guess that gives us an excuse to explore Oakland at some point....
author: Asha S.

description: We have been to Blue Bottle Cafe on many occasions to SF and have enjoyed each coffee experience.  We also took my daughter for her 21st birthday with a group of her friends that are coffee lovers and they were impressed.  I love how they make the coffee and are never rushed just to make sure it is the perfect cup.  The food is excellent and you can see the care that goes into each and every dish.
author: Randee S.

description:
Mint plaza area is great.  You step off of Mission or 6th and all of the sudden it's like you are in a different world of taste and sophistication.

I had only tried Blue Bottle at a farmer's market (Berkeley I think) and never at the retail shop.  The shop itself was pretty cool...very sterile and the staff was well kept in their black shirts.

The coffee au lait ($3.50) was good but just a little pricey.  The heart in my friends cappuccino was a nice touch.
author: J. S.

description:
After a lovely afternoon of browsing the SFMOMA during their 75th anniversary weekend, I was desperately craving for a warm mocha. I know Blue Bottle Coffee is served at the top floor of the MOMA but I really wanted to see the actual place so I walked the two blocks over to Mint Plaza. 

The line was out the door but the people didn't resemble the hostile "I need my coffee or I'm going to choke someone!" crowd that are usually found at coffee establishments. Here, it seemed that people actually relaxed with their drinks. They were there for conversations, the nice late afternoon break with friends, and just to slow down a bit. I ordered a mocha and three cookies: Recchiuti Double Chocolate, Lavender Pinenut Shortbread and a Snickerdoodle. Yup, I love my sweets! 

Now I can't remember the last time I drank a mocha from an actual cup. It was always in a to-go tumbler or paper cup. I guess I needed to slow down too and I'm so glad I did here. The cookies were extraordinary. They were soft and crunchy in all the right places and the different flavors were unique and satisfying. 

Of course, Blue Bottle delivered on their coffee. I'm not a strong coffee drinker and even a little embarrassed to admit I usually opt for those syrupy coffee concoctions. The Blue Bottle mocha is made with Recchiuti chocolate but is far from sweet. But it's so flavorful that I didn't miss the sugar at all. Even the aroma was like drinking in the actual work of art. Five perfect stars for the end of a perfect day.
author: Julia T.

description:
I've slung coffee for a good 10 years.  I worked the small cafes and the starbucks.  I can confidently say I know how I like my espresso, and I know when someone pulls a shoddy shot.  That being said, Blue Bottle has become my mainstay for espresso and espresso based libations.

I'm also a gearhead or technogeek, who loves the accoutrements of any given industry.  I guess I'm also a sucker for science labs and all those odd shaped flasks and bunsen burners... but I digress!

I usually order lattes as that's my drink of choice (soy these days as a lactose intolerant) and the soy lattes that are made from this esta-bliss-ment make me crazy with love (and caffeine fueled exuberance).  You can taste the flavors of the espresso and the color of the crema is gorgeous and luxurious.  This is a coffee drinkers coffee, and the line out the door proves it.  (yea, I'll stand there and be late for work that's my prerogative).
author: Moxie W.

description:
The Product: It's Blue Bottle coffee, which is a consistently wonderful brew. Remember that "Blue Bottle coffee" isn't a single blend - they do have a moderately sized selection of beans, so that what you drink at one Blue Bottle may not be the same type at another!

The Venue: A pretty small, but chic cafe quite literally in an alley just off of Market. The quickest way by foot is through "Mint Plaza" (zoom in on the Yelp-provided map), and I suppose if you wanted to, you could drive right through on Jessie St. but a security guard will most likely tell you not to park there and move along. The cafe itself is adorned with coffee siphons (I suggest YouTubing a video on how these work), Blue Bottle swag, an island table with chairs, and some window seating. Certainly not a study cafe, and probably not a good coffee-date spot, either (the entire cafe will hear your conversation). I think it's a great place to take your break and enjoy a delightful cup of coffee. Their expresso-based drinks are also very good and as you can see from the photos, aesthetically pleasing, too.

Overall: I am a fan of Blue Bottle, adorned alleys, and a nice place to just take a break. Drop in on your 15-minute break, bring the paper, converse with a random stranger, and enjoy the product of a company that has a genuine passion for what they do. More seating would be nice, but they do well with what they've got.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
#28 on 7x7's SF Big Eat: A Gibraltar.  It's not listed on the menu, which makes it tricky if you're curious what it is exactly. 

It's basically an espresso with a shot of milk...like a short latte, but not exactly a cappuccino since there's not much foam.  I particularly liked it because I wanted the effects of the caffeine but wasn't in the mood for too much liquid.  I've attempted to order a gibraltar at another coffee shop before and they told me they only serve it in a glass cup/mug, and not in a to-go cup.  Not sure if it's the same at BB. 

I'm a fan of this location because it's nice to grab a seat and kind people watch, but it does get quite busy.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I'm hooked on Starbucks only because I want that gold card with my name on it and the only place that brews Blue Bottle on the East Bay is 20 min away (without traffic) from where I live now. 

But seriously, Blue Bottle is arguably THE coffee place to go to when you're in the area (I highly recommend Catahoula if you're ever in Richmond/El Cerrito and Intellegentsia if you're in LA/Venice). You can't go wrong with a simple latte at Blue Bottle, but if you want something unique then go ahead and try the secret Gibraltar that is not on the menu. The coffee is smooth, fragrant, naturally sweet without any sweetners, which is how coffee is supposed to taste like, unlike the occasionally burnt and diluted brew they serve at mega chains. 

It's located a block away from the Westfield mall and the Powell Station. A cup of latte to-go would definitely be a great beverage in hand when you're shopping around in the windy SF!
author: Tiffany C.

description: I finally tried the Gibraltar so I could check it off on 7X7's The Big Eat SF list.  It was good, but it didn't have enough of a caffeine kick for me.  I still have to try other drinks on the menu, but for now, the New Orleans iced coffee is still my favorite!
author: Patra I.

description: If you're in the area and you have several hours to spare then this is a nice place to grab a coffee. The staff are clearly passionate about their beans, but a little less concerned about those who are there to drink them.
author: jenn s.

description:
what's up with the rude, snippy workers?? I thought this place was supposed to be cool? guess i was wrong.. 

and my drink was disgusting!  it was burnt, and when I asked for a new drink, the girl yelled at me and shoved my old drink back in my direction, spilling it on the floor and all over the counter.....  rude!
author: Pammy S.

description:
My partner and I live in 2 Mint Plaza with Blue Bottle being just steps from our front door....  3 Star rating for a very specific reason.  It has nothing to do with the service, nor the product....  but the WAIT!
I get that great coffee takes a little time and a very specific process BUT for gosh-sake PLEASE create an EXPRESS lane for those ordering the regular drip?!?  See a line out the door and going around the corner?  Start mass producing it....  10 mins for a cup of albeit very good "liquid crack" just isn't a good thing.  

But, it certainly wakes me up!  Thanks guys!
author: Kyle P.

description: Brilliant coffee, Kiwis and Aussies looking for a flat white fix will enjoy! Great space and atmosphere, only one star less given the 15 minute wait to order.
author: David C.

description: Proper Coffee.  Great and Happy Staff.  Quick flow through a relatively long line.  No fuss, just GREAT coffee! I expect to be a regular now that I live in the area.
author: Brian M.

description: This place is awesome!  They have some really good coffee at really good prices.  It's all organic too!
author: Joey Y.

description:
I've been drinking blue bottle coffee for 2 years at the Temescal farmers market. The line is usually manageable but, as of late, has become out of control. I've since boycotted blue bottle until today.

I walked 2 blocks out of my way to pick up a 1/2 lb. and, while I was there, a decaf (it was 3PM) americano since decaf drip is not available at this location. I watched no less than 10 people, who placed their orders after me, get their drinks before me. 

I waited over 10 minutes before I finally said something to the guy at the counter. He was very nice and explained that this particular barrista has his own style of pouring drinks. It just so happens that my drink, and me, got the shit end of the stick. 

I asked very politely to just give me my money back as I really had to go and, frankly, waiting over 10 minutes for an americano, no matter how good it is, is just ridiculous. He offered me a free cookie instead. I thanked him but told him I wasn't hungry and I really just wanted my coffee, or my money back so I could get back to work. Seriously. Instead he offered me a regular drip coffee which he would make for me personally but warned me it had caffeine in it. Thanks.

Five more minutes go by and I'm seriously considering just leaving and not getting my coffee, or my money back. At long last, the barrista produces my americano and apologizes for the delay. I take the coffee and bolt out the door, half running back to work. Somehow, the coffee doesn't taste as good as it would to have those 15 minutes back in my life.

To sum it up:

1. If you're going to take 15 minutes to make my drink just tell me and I won't order one. This is how you keep customers.

2. Put up a sign that says, "good coffee takes time", or some other hogwash. At least set the expectation.

3. If someone nicely asks for their money back because you can't produce coffee in a reasonable amount of time, give it to them, not a cookie, and hope that one day they'll come back again.

I'm done with blue bottle. The coffee is good but seriously I've had better. Anything off the shelf in Central America blows this crap away. Any freshly roasted coffee just about anywhere, really, tastes as good. 

The business model will work fine in SF and probably New York where people trip all over themselves to wait in line for whatever is hyped-up at the time but like all fads in big cities this too will fade. 

Fair well blue bottle, you have one less customer as of today.
author: Bryan M.

description: Try the siphon pot coffee. It was the cleanest, smoothest, tastiest cup of coffe I've ever had.
author: Samer N.

description: Between mediocre to good coffee - really LONG line - very very insightful baristas.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Blue Bottle is the best coffee in the city.  I cant believe sfers buy starbux when they have access to this wonderful coffee. 

I faithfully buy one half pound every week.  I've tried other beans but nothing  compares to Blue Bottle.  I make espresso, french press, and drip at home and it tastes as good as when Blue Bottle baristas  make em.  I love you Blue Bottle!
author: Hillary L.

description:
One word sums it up: AMAZING!

I ordered a latte for $3.5. It was delicious! My friend ordered an ice coffee...they told him it'd remind him of whisky. I had a sip, and yeah, it was strong/good!

You can tell that they really area about the way they make and present your coffee here. 

The place was packed the whole time i was there (Saturday afternoon).  Can't wait to go back
author: Tim Y.

description: Liege waffle!!! So buttery delicious WANT WANT WANT. Please bring it down to SoCal such a far drive just to enjoy some dough!
author: Manley M.

description: I was in town for a conference and Blue Bottle came to the rescue. I remember BB from a visit in NYC and decided that I had to the slight detour to check out the SF location.  As expected there was a line for the morning rush but as anyone who enjoys a great cup of coffee or latte knows it is well worth it.  I came back every morning to get my fill and one day decided to stay and enjoy a sit down breakfast of two eggs over thick toast.  So yum.  I know there are so many other places to get good coffee in SF but if you are ever in the area BB does not disappoint.
author: Dan C.

description: I thought this place would be all hype, but it's not. AWSOME coffee and fast service. I wish I lived closer for a daily dose.
author: Azin D.

description:
Best latte in the city hands down!

I always come in here wanting to try their drip coffee since I hear so many good things about it but every time I end up with a latte in my hand as I walk out. I don't understand how they make it so good compared to other cafes and the prices are relatively the same. Their food menu looks pretty damn good too but I haven't tried that yet either.

I want to give you 5 stars but I have to say efficient service is lacking. There's always a line and it doesn't seem like the baristas are moving very fast to clear it. But damn you for making the coffee so good I'm willing to sit in this horrendous line waiting and waiting and waiting.....
author: David C.

description: My morning spent here last Friday drinking Rusty's Hawaiian Nel drip followed by a Kyoto-style iced coffee was simply the finest caffeine experience of my life.  As if that wasn't sublime enough, the eggs benedict on Acme toast with Prather Ranch ham was a delicious breakfast and the cute blue-eyed brunette employee working on the other side of my counter seat was a great conversationalist as she worked and I wallowed in the afterglow of coffee nirvana.  Perfect.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I sincerely doubt that Blue Bottle needs *another* five-star review, so I'll keep this brief.

Best coffee I have ever had, period.  Employees were super nice.  Great space, quite a bit of seating for a coffee shop, and the food looked great too, although I'd just eaten when I arrived, so I only had a double chocolate cookie.  It was excellent, but not the best cookie I've ever had.  It's okay, though...this is Blue Bottle Coffee, not Blue Bottle Double Chocolate Cookies.

I had to have Blue Bottle every day that I was in San Francisco for a weekend trip, and after 3 days back in Chicago, I was missing it so desperately that I went to their website and strongly considered ordering a $19 pound of coffee.  I think I was mostly deterred by their very complicated (and illustrated) instructions for properly preparing their coffee.  I was afraid they'd cut me off forever if I poured it into my Mr. Coffee automatic drip.

So I am left dreaming of a return trip to San Francisco.  It's actually a recurring dream.  All of the cable cars and buses are broken and I have to climb a never-ending hill to get to Blue Bottle.  I'm sure it will be worth it if I ever make it...
author: Melanie H.

description:
I LIKE being a coffee snob. It means that (at least, it feels like) when I go to a place serving excellent, excellent espressos, I enjoy it even more.

I've heard a lot about Blue Bottle Cafe, and having already enjoyed their cappuccinos at their store in the Ferry Building, I was even more motivated to seek the cafe out. I had also just seen a picture of a meal that someone took, something involving poached eggs that looked mind-blowing.

First off, this place is TINY. People were waiting outside to order. Seats were hoarded and I evil-eyed a few people saving seats for people without ordering food or drinks yet. 
 
The food... I had egg in a hole, a thick slice of Acme Bakery bread with an egg cooked inside, along with maple butter. The maple butter was a bit odd, but the egg and toast combo was delicious.

My partner had the prociutto grilled cheese, and holy moly amazing. Paired with capers and stone ground mustard, it was one of the most amazing grilled cheeses I've ever had.

Paired with a cappuccino and a mocha, this meal was one of the best brunches I've had so far. Highly recommend Blue Bottle to anyone loving a good espresso drink paired with amazing, locally produced food.
author: Tracy O.

description:
Blue Bottle (the Mint location) is the science lab of coffee. Walking in, the first thing that catches your eye is the infrared siphon pot system from Japan that take you back to high school chemistry. There is a stark, clinical feel about the whole place: very serious about coffee.

We have been there numerous times and have found the staff surprisingly pleasant. SF is famous for "third wave coffee" AAA (arrogant, aloof, a--hole) baristas, so it is a pleasure to find some kindness (at Four Barrel, too). The first stop is at the order point of the espresso bar once you get to the head of the line. We ordered toast, a traditional cappuccino, a latte, and a siphon of a nice colombian estate.

The latte art was lovely, as expected, and the siphon very delicate. We shared it and truly enjoyed the subtle nuances. The toast was perfect: think, crunchy, with butter and intensely flavored berry preserves.

All in all, a great place with fine coffee, excellent service and simple foods done well. The only negative things are the sterile environment and the lack of a roaster.
author: Joe J.

description: The coffee is great and the atmosphere is cool too. It has a very casual vibe that lends itself to ordering an espresso and drinking it and being on your way shortly. Nice staff too.
author: Matt R.

description: Amazing coffee, espresso drinks and food.  It doesn't get better than this.  Blue Bottle has set a new standard for what coffee can be.
author: Alden F.

description:
such great coffee and such a great unique environment.  It's like coffee meets chemistry lab.  

Love this place!
author: Matt V.

description:
Quite an interesting contraption they have set up there. New Orleans iced coffee is sooooo bomb. 
Kyoto is great too but simply black on the rocks.
author: JL S.

description:
Sure the staff could be warmer and more inviting, but their breakfast is so GD good!

The poached eggs on acme toast with gruyere and ham is an unbelievably good breakfast, as is the poached eggs on greens with catalan style tomato sauce. They also make a proper cappuccino that tastes great.

Haven't tried the vac pot coffee, but what I have had was top notch.
author: Ernie B.

description:
I love this place. I love their coffee and espresso. I love their food offerings. I love the communal and bar style sitting area. I hate the wait and I hate the meters. Nuff said?

Okay, just a bit more. 

Blue Bottle is obviously one of Bay Area's pride-and-joy babies. We love it, we take good care of it, we praise it, celebrate it, and add it to anything we can i.e. Humphry Slocombe Blue Bottle Vietnamese Coffee flavor-flave!!! I have no one particular favorite style, but you can't go wrong with a suggestion from the staffers. And boy am I gracious locations are finally popping up more and more.  My only beef, is the waiting in the line and parking in this area - beyond that, this baby is good one. 

Just make sure you have PLENTY of time on your hands to wait, drink and savour. Bring enough quarters!!!

BayArea, you've done good!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Starbuck fans would never understand.  
Best espressos drinks that I have had ever!  I look forward to going to this place every-time I come to the city.  I have had the secret 'gilbrator' drink, mocha, and cappuccino.  All of them were made w great detail and I love the finishing artistic touch where the foam has some kind of a flower, plant, or heart design.   
It is definitely worth the wait.   There is ALWAYS a wait so make sure you set aside about 20 minutes to get your drink.
author: DN T.

description:
This small cafe, with it's minimalist decor (a few narrow tables and bar stools) and fancy japanese steam-punk coffee drippers, could get by very well with just serving some of the city's best coffee.

But, no.

The food!!  

The menu is not large, but it has variety, and It is some of the most delicious brunch food I've ever had.  I've found myself drooling over combinations that sound unlike my taste:  poached eggs over sauteed greens and tomato sauce? poached egg on vegetable soup? fritatta? egg sandwich?  all of it sounds like it could be mediocre, bizarre, or even unappetizing.  

But, no.  

Every meal I've had here has been i-n-c-r-e-d-i-b-l-e.  Best of all, you feel good and healthy at the end of it.

YUMMY!!!
author: Grasshopper R.

description:
Best coffee in the bay by far. Lines can be a bit long sometimes, but it is worth it. I love both Iced coffees personally. Make sure to go to an official Blue Bottle location, otherwise it definitely isn't as good.

Worth the money every time :)
author: Bryan R.

description: I am new to Yelp, but it's very fitting that this would be my first review! I love love Blue Bottle Coffee Co, its literally the best coffee that I have ever had. The Union square location is amazing, and the staff is extremely friendly! 5 stars!
author: Sheryl P.

description:
A temple for coffee devotees...  I enter the building reverently.  Patrons speak in hushed tones.  Sacred glass vessels are prominently on display.  Ahh the Mint street blue bottle mecca.  

I was introduced to Blue Bottle coffee by my brother who has the most tricked out home espresso machine and burr grinder of anyone I know.  I'm a mostly decaf drinker, and their Decaf Noir could be easily mistaken for regular - its so delicious, no one would know.  I had been to the Hayes Valley kiosk for my own fix, and was delighted by the little stand, and the freshly brewed, creamy chocolatey cappucino.  But had never been to the source...  It's a beautiful shop in a somewhat sketchy area with limited parking.  Worth a stop in.

The coffee is truly amazing.  When I ran out of beans, I went back to my Allegro organic-free-trade-french roast from whole foods, but who could go back to the over-roasted swill that used to be the height of espresso deliciousness?  Blue bottle definitely knows their roast.  I placed an order online, which i would recommend to anyone not within driving distance of SF.  It was fun reading the coffee descriptions.
author: Teresa S.

description: To get the full experience with their drip coffee, you have to drink it there. They dont sell it to go. With the limited space, it's really only practical if you go by yourself or with only one other.
author: Jon S.

description:
What happened to this place?  Clearly they have not been able to adapt to their tremendous popularity. 

So after waiting quite some time to place my order I waited another 10 minutes to actually receive it.  And what did I get  for an espresso con panna.... a spittle of espresso with 3 or 4 tablespoons of whipped cream.  Horrible! Naturally, I left with an awful taste in my mouth.  And it wasn't only due to the drink. 

Due to being underequipped, the service and quality now suffers. Boo!
author: Roger H.

description:
When you love something, you accept it for what it is.  

I love coffee.  It's the first thing I think of when I wake up in the morning.  I don't try to make it something it's not--an over-sugared, complicated menage of artificial flavors, foam, soy/non-fat, and double double-shots.  

Don't get me wrong, I'll take a stroll around the mall with a mocha frappuccino on a particularly hung-over Saturday morning.  But when it comes to my every day coffee, I like it simple (okay, maybe with some half&half)--and it doesn't get any simpler than Blue Bottle drip coffee.

Love at first taste.  You don't have to be afraid anymore--you can drink it black.  Without cream.  Without sugar.  And still without the acidic aftertaste or that bitterness that makes the corners of your mouth turn up ever so slightly.

There's no turning back now.
author: Brianna H.

description:
Did breakfast before a business meeting next door last week.  Happy to announce I had the best bowl of oatmeal ever.  

I am somewhat of an oatmeal junkie, Quaker Oats old-fashioned is my go-to choice at home but I try to sample the wares on the road.  Blue Bottle served a perfectly formed (firm) bowl of steel-cut oatmeal, alongside a small dish of coarse-grained brown sugar and another of creamy butter.  The sides were rich and colorful and blended in perfectly.  

I didn't fully appreciate, until now, how much upside there could be in the perfect bowl of oatmeal.  Steel cut in particular can be tricky and 99 out of 100 places makes it runny and tasteless.  This stuff is the connoisseur's oatmeal.

Good with a cafe au lait.
author: Glenn W.

description: I got a New Orleans style iced coffee. It was disgustingly strong. I left it outside by the garbage can after one sip. If you're a super-duper coffee aficionado snob then you'll probably like Blue Bottle but if you're just a chill working stiff like me who doesn't care if it's Starbucks or the little mom-and-pop coffee shop down the street then don't go here. Pretentious. Just a little bit.
author: Julie K.

description:
Yes, Blue Bottle is my favorite coffee in the city.  However,  I've been to many of their locations and this one is my least favorite.

*The male cashier seems physically unable to smile, even at a child who asked him a sweet question.  Instead he kept a deadpan face and didn't answer.  Further, he really takes his time and makes you feel like you're inconveniencing him when trying to order your drink. 

*The wait is ridiculous. The female barista is friendly, but everytime I've been here it's been a 15+ minute wait after waiting a good 10 minutes to order with only a small handful of people in front of me.

I suggest going to Linden.  Fastest, friendliest service.
author: Michelle M.

description: Amazing coffee, service, location.  Love the latte and the use of Three Trees Almond Milk just made it heavenly!  Don't think....just go!
author: K M.

description:
Five stars for the delicious coffee and the care that goes into Blue Bottle products and food. However, the service is slow and unorganized. I always get the impression that the help is stoned, or at the very least disinterested in their jobs. Maybe it's just cool to make people wait and wait and wait... 

Given that the coffee is hand crafted and doing business in San Francisco is an expensive venture, the price point is acceptable on the beans and java products. But $5 for toast? 

I will continue purchasing the coffee beans, but no thanks to the food or the long lines.
author: Jana S.

description:
Outstanding coffee.  Would have to say the latte i had there was probably the best I've ever had anywhere.   You could tell by the flavor that the roasted beans were fresh and the quality of the milk superb.   

The coffee siphon system they use is interesting as well.  You can see it in action here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHz-NIPTvf0

This particular Blue Bottle Coffee shop is in a good location near Moscone Center, so drop by if you're attending a Tech conference or Car show.  Its well worth the 5 minute walk.
author: Gil D.

description:
I had the worst machiatone of my life here. Talk about overextracted, bitter, and burnt tasting. It was so bad, I had to add 3 tbsp of sugar into it. (I normally add enough sugar to bring out the flavors in the espresso, but not enough to make it super sweet). And I could only manage to drink 1/3 of it. Blech.

The barista couldn't give me any flavor profiles of their beans either.... ? At least the space is nice. I'm wondering if it's worth it to give it another shot with a different barista.
author: Ta G.

description: I loved the coffee here. I consume a lot of coffee both low quality and high quality, both expensive and inexpensive. Blue Bottle is a great in between where you can get reasonably priced drinks and very expensive ones. I was able to sample the basic coffee (no frills) mocha and Kyoto Drip. The coffee was smooth, not bitter and enjoyable, the mocha great and topped off with a cute little swan design. I may enjoy the Kyoto better on a hot summer day but it was late December and raining so my judgment was skewed. It was however, very strong and bold in taste and have no major complaints. Bottom line, if your in SF definitely make this a place to check out
author: Frank B.

description:
After reading an article about the "Third Wave of Coffee" in GQ on my flight to the bay area, i was excited to give this place a shot on my short trip. 

Walking into this place was like walking into my high school chemistry class, has it been a little more "hip". They had bunson burners. Making coffee. Is this really the 3rd wave? Anyways me and my Dad ordered two coffees to go, which took like 5 minutes, to which i was thinking, oh, this is gonna be mind blowing coffee goodness, as anything that takes this long should lead to a religious experience. Upon receiving my coffee though, i must admit that i did not see the face of the Lord in my brew. Now don't get me wrong, it was really really good, of course better than Starbucks, but maybe only slightly better than Peet's. If this is the 3rd wave, id say it's choppy and head high at best. 

BUT, i did order the Bacon Brioche, and holy hell i don't know what wave we are on of Brioche but this thing was massively tasty. Congrats to whoever is making the pastries that Blue Bottle sells. I would come back just for that.
author: Sean O.

description:
I'm still trying to come to the realization that my standards are not the same as the standards of others. 

After all the hype, I was completely underwhelmed by the coffee here. I had just a drip coffee. It was unremarkable, with a slightly unpleasant aftertaste and film left in my mouth. I'd say it was fine and palatable. Certainly not worth the 5-block, rainy walk I took to get there.

The location is lovely, I went during lunch and there was no line. The employees are very pleasant. This is why they get 3 stars.

And I admit, I'm biased. I've had coffee that was so good, that it has brought me to tears. This coffee was not in California, I'll tell you that for free. I'll continue to order my beans from far far away, and make my coffee myself. Sorry, Blue Bottle.
author: Patricia E.

description:
Yum yum affogato with Humpry Slocombe Secret Breakfast ice cream is a beautiful breakfast.

Blue bottle does everything on their menu well.  Besides their famous coffee in a array of styles, they have Michale Recchiuti hot chocolate, excellent teas, delicious pastries, poached egg breakfasts, and lunch options.  

The location is very modern and relaxing, no matter how busy, the atmosphere stays relaxing.  My favorite 30 minute escape from work or shopping!
author: Annika L.

description:
Coffee as an artisanal experience is nothing new in San Francisco, but it's brought to a whole new level here.

Very good coffee - even my father, who's 'just a cup of brewed' kind of guy, enjoyed his drip coffee.   My latte was lovely, in part thanks to the milk.  I may never drink 2% again as a result.  

Only gripe here was that while the place does open at 8am on a Sunday, the brunch menu isn't available until 9am.  One example of the early bird *not* getting the worm, or in this case, the frittatta.
author: Jenn G.

description: Blue Bottle is one of the best coffees I've had in the US. The breakfast entrees are good, but not as great as their coffee. Nevertheless, if I want a good cup of coffee in San Francisco, this is the place I would go to.
author: FoodLover Z.

description: Weak latte, ask for double or triple recommended
author: Henry L.

description: My company is moving from the mission and I won't get to drink my daily single origin anymore. So I'm commemorating my lovely experiences at this cute little coffee shop with a review. Some mornings the line is out the door. I don't even notice the wreckage of litter and leering construction workers because I'm almost too excited for my cup of coffee. Usually, any sweetener or creamer or flavor shot you add overpowers the flavor of the coffee itself. But not this stuff. For the first time, I can drink my coffee with creamer and STILL taste the coffee. I must have been drinking some really cheap shit before. I think all that Starbucks I poisoned my taste buds with led me to believe your coffee had to taste like sugary milk. But no, not this time. I've grown up, I've graduated! I have seen the light and it is at the bottom of a blue bottle! When I first walked in, I was like what kind of frou frou ass coffee shop is this?? All hidden in the cut with no signage. Looking like a mad scientists lab with beakers and strange coffee machines everywhere. With its lofty high ceilings and employees who look like models for urban outfitters. But I got over that once the crack like caffeine settled into my body and I soon realized, this is my new favorite place to get my morning fix. If you genuinely like coffee, this is the place for you.
author: Ginger C.

description:
I have been visiting Blue Bottle on a regular basis for almost a year.  At other places, I have to dilute my drinks with cream and sugar to balance out the bitterness of the coffee, but at Blue Bottle, the brew is so fantastic that I will drink it black.  (Get the kyoto iced coffee!!!)  However, the coffee's not the reason why I'm writing this review-- it's the food!

Last week, I finally had enough time to sit down and actually eat lunch.  I'd always wanted to try Blue Bottle's food, but they don't make it to go, and there's hardly ever an open space to sit.  However, 2 people left as soon as my friend and I walked in, so we sniped those seats and decided to get a full lunch.  I ordered the gruyere grilled cheese on french country bread with whole grain mustard and prosciutto.  All of the ingredients were top notch and could put the food served at other surrounding cafes to shame!  I think the people across the table were laughing at me because I was enjoying the gooey gruyere cheese so much that I practically made eating it an erotic act!

If you have enough time in your lunch break for a slow meal, go to Blue Bottle!  And if you're lucky enough to grab a seat inside, don't be one of those people that lingers forever and prevents other people from having a chance to eat!
author: Christy L.

description: 4 stars for the really delicious coffee.  I would drink it everyday if I could.  1 star deduction for the douchey hipsters and their annoying conversations in line.  How on earth did these kids get so rich anyway?
author: J K.

description: hah! i entered the wrong building looking fir this place.  the atmosphere feels a bit strange for me because it looks so much like a chem lab.  i just dont feel relax.  however the barristas are awesome and friendly!  i ordere the cafe latte and it is smoother than any latte i had but im still not that impress.  ill still come back to try a few of their and will update this review
author: Elc C.

description:
Comparing different coffee products is largely an exercise in personal taste, but there's no denying Blue Bottle has raised the bar in what already was an impressive landscape of Bay Area roasters. If you haven't tried it, do. Everything works here, including the space, the people-watching, and the tasty $1 cookies.

If not for the "aroma" of the local derelicts outside, this would be a five-star experience.
author: Francisco G.

description:
The service is comically anarchic at Blue Bottle's Mint location; the quality is high in equal proportion to the evident disorder.

A line snakes about the cramped interior and out the door with hardly anyone except the overworked baristas to help expedite it.  Yet no quarter is given to impurity of technique or, it would seem, consumption of fine espresso -- no to-go cups for that shot!  

Bear the yoke of inefficiency, the endless waits, and be rewarded with perfectly made espresso drinks and exceedingly delicious drip coffee.

I'm sure with appropriate, high-dollar management consulting -- say, the guys who devised the autocratic System at Philz -- Blue Bottle could be remade into a paragon of efficiency.  No more 30 minute black-out period for siphon pot orders.  Utter clarity on when, exactly, those single-origin espressos are available.  A gibraltar that doesn't, annoyingly, cost $3.01 (seriously, is that intentional?).

And yet, I sense pervasive inefficiency is in the DNA of all great espresso joints and part of what makes going out for it fun.  For me, some things are worth the wait.
author: J W.

description:
Note to customers: for the love of tiny, seat yourself establishments... DO NOT go seat yourself while your friend stands in line for 20 minutes.  In that time another couple could have sat and ate and left and then it would be your turn, instead the people who've orderd are searching for somewhere to sit!  It's an interesting system if you just let it work, but those who sit before they've ordered are the ones messing it up!

I LOVE blue bottle, but only been to this location in Mint Plaza downtown.  I've only ever ordered my latte but was informed by a friend they had great and I had to check it out.
Thank god I did, it's fantastic!  I crave their soups, so hearty and flavorful and the bread... so far everything I've tried is fantastic.  There is usually a line and it doesn't move super fast but that is because they take their time with each latte, espresso, etc. and you taste the difference.  Once you've orderd the food comes out really fast.
author: Shelby C.

description:
Love this coffee and this coffee shop location. 

Tucked in a makeshift alley of shorts with a bunch of buildings that sort of make a quad is Blue Bottle Coffee. The space is airy and industrial. There is a tall communal table to sit at and lots of counter space lining the windows. 

On my first visit to Blue Bottle from Seattle, I tried their New Orleans Iced Coffee and a slice of their liquor rice bread. The coffee was very unique and the thick contents and sugar element helped my head ache. I do not think I would repeat this order more than a few times a year- the drink is very different but enjoyable. The bread was beyond dense and moist, and the yummy liquor and oils seeped through the bag. 

On my second visit, I made sure to work in a Sunday morning stroll to get a drip coffee. My wait in the line, which I entered when it was already out the door, was short, and I received my individually prepared drip within minutes. I also ordered a absinthe cookie for munching on. My drip was wonderfully full and flavorful. I added a little cream and sugar, and the boldness and quality of the beans and brewing shown through. The cookie was savory sweet and well baked. 

FYI's~ 
* They serve a few brunch items in addition to the baked goods that they have for sale 
* A few of the seats turn over quickly while others are occupied for hours- especially on the weekend 
* A line out the door does not equal a very long wait 
* There are chairs and tables available outside around the corner- they orange- use them- sometimes they get great sun 
* The 1/2 lb. bags make great souvenirs and smell so tempting
author: Natalie W.

description: Every time I visit SF and am in the Embarcadero area I ALWAYS make some time for a coffee break here. Lines are always long on the weekends, but the wait is worth it!  The New Orleans style iced coffee is delicious! Strong and aromatic with a rich flavor. Hands down my favorite! Tried their iced latte the last time I was there (they ran out of the New Orleans iced coffee and couldn't make an iced mocha b/c the chocolate they use is too thick) and that was good as well.
author: Joanna Q.

description: Loved my latte, complete with leaf design.  I was in SF visiting with friends, and they took me to this coffee shop.  Its located off the main street and I didnt even realize we were in front of the shop until i was told to get out of the car.  The line wasn't that long on a late saturday afternoon and we snagged a seat by the window to sit.  The people who work were very friendly.  They were even nice enough to explain how to make the design while it was being poured.  Next time i visit, this is somewhere I would go out of my way to come back to.
author: Kristin S.

description: Honestly the coffee is great, but the service is INCREDIBLY slow.  There are always several people standing around behind the counter, not sure why they aren't helping the line of customers that goes out the door.  I had two people in front of me today and it took 20 to get a latte.  Really too bad because they have great products, but I don't always have 20 minutes to spare on my way to work.
author: Kara B.

description: With so many 5-star ratings already, would mine really make a difference? Probably not.  The hype of blue bottle really does live up to it's expectations. There's a reason why the lines are long--people love it! I fell in love with it from the first sip of my latté.
author: J S.

description:
I'm normally much too lazy to write reviews of places but when I noticed Blue Bottle Cafe didn't have a Yelp review I knew I had to intervene! 

I'm not a coffee snob so I can't comment authoritatively on that (although I really like the mocha) but the food is really solid. It's not my favorite type of food but in terms of executing on the concept it doesn't get any better than this.
author: kavin s.

description:
I decided to try out this place after reading all the hype about their mochas and lattes.  I can't seem to get to the Hayes Valley locale, so I was glad to find this location too!!!  :)

Okay, I knocked off one star b/c the place is just too damn expensive for what I can easily slap together... and trust me, I'm definitely not much of a cook so that tells 'ya something.
