That said... OMG!!!  That is THE BEST MOCHA I've had to date!!!  :-P~~ I think it's the chocolate.  I'm more partial to the bittersweet chocolate than the milk chocolate.  (Milk chocolate tends to have WAAAAAY too much sugar in it.  Bittersweet doesn't have too much sugar, which is JUST FINE with me!!!)  And I would just LOVE to try to do one of those nice little designs they put in my mocha!!!  (The barista showed it to me once how they do it too!  It was KEWL!!!)

I saw this cream of potato soup that they were serving one day that look totally delish... and my sandwich was pretty decent too, considering.  (Okay, it's not as economically sounds as Lee's or the Banh Mi's but I'm reminded about how simple things can actually be very tasty!!!)

And... MUST GO FOR THE BRIOCHE!!!  (I'll write more when I have a chance to go there for brunch... unfortunately my schedule doesn't seem to allow me to go there during brunch.)

Definitely a place for the scene and to be seen place.  Lots of professionals hanging out there!  (And apparently the morning staff seems to think I'm hip enough.  They know now when I walk in to make a soy mocha for me!)  :-)

Keep on keepin' on, you guys at Blue Bottle... as long as you keep making my mocha the way you always have.  :-)
author: Joanna R.

description: What the heck is in this coffee that makes it so darn delicious??? It is the best coffee I've ever had...no joke! We got there and the line was long...I almost changed my mind about going to this place because I thought the wait was ridiculous for a cup of joe...I mean come on...it's coffee right?? Wrong! The wait is so worth it for this creamy perfectly blend of New Orleans Iced coffee. I've been to New Orleans and even Cafe Du Monde and other specialty coffee shops doesn't have coffee this good. They only make one size...so Starbuck goers, there is no Venti here. This is like the Mercedes of coffee....high end luxurious coffee that is oh so good! I'm a fan of this place and will most definitely go back every time I go to the city.
author: Leslie B.

description: If I had to choose one coffee shop in San Francisco, this would be it. Whether it's foggy and freezing and I'm in desperate need of a cappuccino, or the sun has broken through and it's the perfect time for a New Orleans iced coffee, the drinks from Blue Bottle are always perfect. Genuinely nice, unpretentious barristas, combined with a great location ensure that I spend far too much money here.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I am a coffee snob.

I am a trained barista with an affinity for good coffee.

Blue Bottle has this good coffee.

I just wish their employees weren't such hipster assholes.
author: Carlie D.

description: I'm not much of a coffee connoisseur but I have to admit Blue Bottle has one of the best cups of joe in the city. There is always seems to be a line to get into their quaint little coffee shop but the wait is well worth it. Much better than starbucks.
author: Kenson K.

description:
The quality of product = 5 stars

Best coffee in the city -- especially the New Orleans iced coffee, wow.  And the waffles -- "fahgettabouit", amazing.  Truly beautiful stuff.

The quality of service = 1 star -- 

Absolutely NO sense of urgency from the staff -- especially when the line is long.  So, so, so slow and yet the demand for the product so, so, so high!  The folks making the coffee move as fast as they can -- but the folks working the register are terrible.  If I owned this business, I would clean house and bring in folks interested in making some $$!

Overall, 3 stars given the quality of product.
author: J. SOMA S.

description: Excellent iced coffee- location is tucked away but is the best coffee we've found this close to Mosso.
author: Katie B.

description:
If i could wake up to one smell every morning, it would be coffee from Blue Bottle. 

The drip coffee is good if your looking for something simple. My favorite blend is the Giant Steps, because there is a hint of Dark Chocolate. Their coffee's are pretty strong, and not many drinks can get me wired like Blue Bottle's. On hot days, the New Orleans Iced Coffee is the way to go. 

For kids, you can even get the Hot Cocoa. Its very well done, with lots of chocolate flavor without it being super sweet.

The breakfast menu is good too!
author: Chris C.

description:
Blue Bottle, I know that you're hot shit and all. I really, genuinely do. (cue "We're not worthy!" a la Wayne's World, please).

But, sometimes I detect a hint of snob at this location.

The counter staff isn't the friendliest. What gives? I've ordered lattes, ice coffees & grub here and don't think they've ever cracked a smile.

Plus, whenever I ask for something to-go, the request seems to go right out the window.

I ordered some Acme Toast & Jam to go (which btw was out-of-this-world. Who knew toast could be that amazing??), but once they delivered it w/ utensils, plate & jam saucer, I gave em' a smile and a "I had asked for this to go". They then proceed to tell me that it's not available "to-go". Eh? I wish they told me that up-front, cuz I would've just skipped out on it rather than having to slather some jam on the 2 thick ass pieces, wrap em' in napkins and throw em' in the trunk of my scooter before dashing off to work. I don't know if they don't have boxes & little containers cuz it's their attempt at being "green", but if their Ferry Bldg location has em', then why not offer em' here too?

And the same thing happened today. I ordered an Affogato to-go not realizing that it was more of a desert than a drink. It was nicely presented w/ the server asking if I'd like him to "set" the Affogato for me w/ dishes in hand. Yipes. I really appreciated all the care that was put into the Affogato delivery, but I just wanted it to-go was all. When I asked, he gave me this look like I was nuts. Ahhh!

If the ppl at the counter just gave me a heads up about all these possible complications (especially since these were first-time orders for me), it'd make the servers less aggravated, waste less time & reduce confusion.

I'm a fan & all, but I've had better interactions at the Ferry Bldg.
author: Tiffany M.

description: Supposedly the coffee is great.  I don't really drink the stuff, so my review is about the food.  The potato leek soup was really good.  The toast with gruyere cheese was fantastic.  Also had the egg salad sandwich because I felt like the soup wasn't enough for lunch.  Also good.  But the two things for lunch cost about $13.  Too expensive.
author: Danny G.

description:
The closest thing to a 'real' coffee (read: Australian coffee) we have found since moving here. 

What we would call a flat white is their cappucino.  And it is pretty damned good: nice roast, served at the perfect temperature, not too much froth (what is with that over here?).

Only complaints: not serving cooked food before 9am on a Saturday! 
Also, just making one cup at a time, and incredibly slowly at that, seems a waste of (customers') time. There is a reason they invented 2 cup spouts for espresso machines!
author: S B.

description:
Mmmmm tasty coffee! If you even just a little bit of a coffee snob, you should definitely splurge for the expensive siphon coffee at least once. It's so smooth with no grit or little particles, it's like drinking coffee-water....just try it, you'll see :)

I never normally order food, but last weekend I tried the waffles and grilled cheese sandwich and they were delicious. 

Every time I come here it is lined up outside and around the corner. This coffee is worth the wait :)
author: M M.

description:
Just had one of the tastiest brunches ever at Blue Bottle Mint Plaza. Poached eggs over sauteed radicchio and kale with a sicilian tomato sauce and Spanish cheese. And of course, as always, the coffee was amazing. The space is very urban/industrial, and there is bar stool/communal table seating in addition to a few tables outside. It feels very airy and clean.

The downside is that the line is long and it moooovveees sloooowwwly. In my opinion, worth the wait. The staff is nice, if just a tad elitist. Definitely got a little judgmental stare when I asked for my coffee in a to-go cup even though I was eating there (I drink slow). 

Will happily returns though. Next time waffles?
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Pretty fancy - this location is nice and roomy. A great place to grab a cup of wonderful Blue Bottle and have a small snack.

I had the toast w/buter and jam today $5
The waffle looks good for $7.5

The line always looks longer than it takes - they are pretty efficient at getting your drinks to you and serving the ordered food. So don't be easily defeated.
author: Katherine B.

description:
Five stars for coffee is a given (see earlier Yelp). What's also good are the eats. I wasn't expecting anything special from my Diestel turkey sandwich on a sweet acme roll. Countless places in the city make them.

But I bet only a few top them with shaved celery.

And I'm pretty sure only Blue Bottle packs 'em to go in a coffee filter.
author: Jason B.

description: Gorgeous architectural space.  Beautifully-made latte.  Crazy kitchen gadgets to admire. But how can you be out of multiple breakfast options on your menu?  Loved my coffee, but left hungry.
author: Jill H.

description: I can thank my parents for giving me my first cup of coffee at 6 years old. Growing up in a house of coffee addicted parents set the bar high for me when it came to drinking great coffee as an adult. Starbucks? Pooey. Peets? Okay I admit I do enjoy their coffee on occasion, but Blue Bottle? Where?! What!? YES PLEASE!! They only offer one size but it's not the size that matters, it's how it's drank. And it's drank slowly, eyes closed savoring every sip, taking your brain and body to caffeine heaven. I dun' bout to pass out just thinking about it. Where my coffee at??
author: Jen Y.

description:
If you are serious about your coffee, well then, consider this your Mecca.  

The menu is very straight forward, none of that decaf double mocchachino nonsense here, just excellent beans expertly brewed.  The Embarcadero location staff was very friendly, none of the snobbery that you sometimes get in these specialty coffee places.
author: Jennifer G.

description:
If you ever want to feel like you're back in the Bayou, in a magical land with French influence that inspired characters like Ignatius J. Reilly, don't come here. 

But if you want an extremely tasty iced coffee named after the city of Cajuns and creole, this is your must-stop in San Francisco. I'd say one of the best iced coffees I've ever had... EVEN after my ice had melted (this is huge. it always tastes gross within 30 minutes). 

I want to come back again to try their drip coffee and espresso. And to hang out in the cute courtyard between the Old Mint and restaurants. And watch someone order the Kyoto Iced Coffee so I can get a tutorial on how that crazy glass machine works.

You haven't seen the last of me, BB.
author: Jared S.

description:
The coffee here is AMAZING and really delicious! 

I had a regular latte that had cute foam art. I was immediately converted. 

It was really cool to watch the siphon coffee being made. If I had more time, I would have sat around and just watched them make pots and pots of it. Instead, I had to flee somewhere else to pick up some muffins for friends. 

But next time, Blue Bottle, I will park myself by the bar and be endlessly fascinated with the siphon coffee and have some of your tasty offerings. I'll totally ignore the fashionable connoisseurs who will look down their noses at me because I'll be busy pressing my own nose against the glass to watch. :D  Now all I need to do is find some time.
author: Julia W.

description:
My boyfriend LOVES Blue Bottle. Worships it. So I'm here a lot. It's a great place to stop for coffee if you're going shopping down the street at the mall or union square. 

Beware: They run out of the ice coffee pretty early on nice days and they stop making the siphon coffee after 3pm.
author: Abbey S.

description:
This is my second time here and I again was not impressed.
I still have yet to go to the infamous 'Blue Bottle Garage' that is supposed to have the best in SF.  I had a macchiato, but it wasn't anything special. And my initial impression was that it was overly bitter.
The bitterness scale was: 2.5 out of 5
The flavor scale was: 3 out of 5. (being generous here).
author: Oren F.

description: Great coffee. Tried both the macchiato and Espresso. Friendly service, good atmosphere. Decent food. The pastries were not my fav but ok, the poached eggs for breakfast were quite nice. Will be back again.
author: J R.

description:
Breakfast Orgasm.

coffee - amazing without question.  Worth the wait, and the wait and the attention they pay to EVERY DRINK is what makes it so good.  If you have no appreciation for small touches of perfection, then this experience may be lost on you.

Yeah, it looks froo froo and the crowd (employees included) is of a certain cultural subset, but I felt welcome here.  I am not super "in" but the staff was super nice and answered my questions (what is a buckle?) and even remembered me when I came back the next morning.

The food - I would categorize as fine dining.  SO GOOD.  Everything in perfect proportion.  You get the waffle and wonder - will this be enough syrup?  IT IS.  They have thought about this.  You will finish your waffle with a clean plate and every bite having been perfectly syrupped.  The granola with fruit and yogurt - gasp - has perfect proportions of fruit to homemade granola to yogurt - every bite is simple perfection.

If you love details, this is the ultimate breakfast experience!

oh - and a buckle is a buttery, perfectly delicious, strussel-topped, topless muffin.  it was good.
author: Megan H.

description:
There is your standard cup of joe and then there is coffee!!! "Add french accent."  Yes they may both come from beans, and they both have caffeine in them, but they could not be more different.  True coffee not the americanized watered down burnt junk starbucks sells can be found at Blue Bottle.  Its not my top pick in california but it comes in as close second to my LA fave.  

I tried 3 cups "yes I love coffee and no caffeine does not affect me," a latte, a espresso, and a kyoto iced coffee.  Of the 3 my favorite was the rich bourbon flavor of the iced kyoto.  I will definitely be back.
author: Ben J.

description:
I've checked this place out...have never bought anything from them, but have checked out their glass pots and slow drip glass contraptions. Well, I am happy to say that I finally got a chance to try them today.

Came here with some friends of friends and tried their affogato drink/dessert (~$3), which I think they only offer once a week? I was told that it was a shot of espresso poured over ice cream. I was in the mood for dessert (since Town Hall's pot de creme dessert left me unsatisfied) and was just thinking it'd be coffee over vanilla ice cream, nothing too special but it had to be okay since the espresso was from Blue Bottle.

We were served with a chilled coffee mug with what looked like vanilla ice cream. Then the shot of espresso was poured over the ice cream and I just loved seeing the contrast of the dark, brown liquid dripping off the two scoops of white colored ice cream.

I took my spoon and dived in. BLISS. OMG. BLISS. The ice cream wasn't just vanilla, it was named something like "breakfast-style" ice cream or something like that. There were bits of corn flakes with the ice cream and a taste of bourbon. Then the espresso was...BLISS. I don't know if it was the bourbon or the espresso or a combo of both, but I was high. High off of coffee-laced bourbon and corn flaked vanilla ice cream. High off of watching the slow drip siphons and the employees making coffee from the smaller glass pots.

Thanks for the high, Blue Bottle. I will definitely be back!
author: Janel Y.

description: hidden away from the buzz from the market street and 6th avenue, this place is a hidden jewel for coffee lovers. The flower cappuccino was perfect. too bad most of the deserts were sold out.
author: Jen L.

description: Coffee is great but a little unimpressed with the bags of coffee sold here. I purchased two bags of the whole bean "three africans" blend. Took it home and was about to pour the beans into a container when... "February 10" on one of them and "February 17" on the other. They were purchased on the 23rd. Now, the latter date is not TOO bad.. older than it should be, but not terrible.. but FEB 10 !! that is OLD COFFEE ! it was stale.
author: Torrey B.

description:
I couldn't remember where I had heard the name "Blue Bottle Coffee Co." before, and then my S.O. reminded me: They were featured in the New York Times in 2008 because they have a $20,000 siphon bar imported from Japan: http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/dining/23coff.html?_r=1&emc=eta1

My, S.O., 3 other friends, and I had the pleasure of watching the brewing process which seemed like something you'd see in a science lab, not in a coffee shop. This visit, though, we decided to have a cappuccino instead. Their cappuccino gave other U.S. coffee shop cappuccinos a run for their money. Still not as good as a certain cappuccino I had while in Italy, but still pretty delicious. The cappuccino was less bitter than others -- more smooth and rich. It didn't need much flavoring for it to taste good, which is the true test of a good cappuccino.

We drooled over some of the food items that were being prepared in front of us: french toast, some sort of eggs in a basket (thick bread with a hole cut out and an egg cooked inside), etc.

The atmosphere was an ultra modern loft/warehouse and a hint of Victorian with extremely tall ceilings with carved crown moldings. We were lucky to find 5 seats directly in front of the siphon bar.

We're already thinking about our next visit so that we can sample the coffee from the siphon bar. At about $7 a cup, I hope it will be the best brewed coffee I've ever had.
author: Wendy K.

description: $21 for a large coffee and a frittata?  Seriously?!  We got two varieties of the siphon coffee and I didn't enjoy either one.  Maybe I just have an immature coffee palate?  The frittata was steaming hot and good quality, but it needed sauce of some sort (I thought, "give me salsa or ketchup or gravy or something!").  But the workers were all really nice.  We had a blast watching the siphon coffee process, but I will not go back.
author: Amanda J.

description: Oh god, the New Orleans Iced Coffee is out of this world. They mix the Kyoto-style iced coffee (the one that takes hours of cold drip extraction) and milk to make this amazingly smooth blend. I dream about this coffee on a daily basis.
author: Don W.

description: The siphon coffee was the best coffee I've ever had, and the latte we had while waiting for it was almost as sublime.  Good breakfast as well, cool space, interesting crowd, good staff.  Only possible complaints would be the line and the prices, but that's supply and demand for you.
author: Ira P.

description:
Most amazing latte I've ever had. Drink it straight, no sugar, it's delicious!

I'll never be able to drink Starbucks again!
author: Ian K.

description:
Blue Bottle, you treat me so well! I lost my coffee (yea, seriously), and you were so nice to replace it for me when I went in an hour later for a second cup. You didn't charge me, which definitely surprised me. Fantastic!

And I heart Chris a lot, but I still think Blue Bottle in SF tastes better than Blue Bottle in Brooklyn. The soy seems off there or maybe, it's the water.
author: Wendy L.

description: The line is usually a bit long but worth the wait if you are in the mood for an amazing espresso drink. In my opinion it is probably the smoothest espresso I have found in San Francisco. They always take their time to make sure the drinks are made properly...no matter how busy they get. Their mailing list is a pretty good deal as well if you like drip or french press at home.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Blah blah blah best coffee ever blah blah blah. 

I'm not a fan of coffee snobs (or ridiculous lines). I just don't really get it. Call me ordinary.

This is the epitome of the trendy, hipster, overpriced San Francisco establishment. BUT, if you put aside the overwhelming prices, it's good coffee (as far as I can tell), the baristas are often friendly or at least polite, and the venue itself is actually pretty darn sweet. Great for meeting up with your hipster friends or pretending to do hipster things on your iPhone. But seriously, it's an awesome space. I think that's what I like about it the most. And it definitely beats the Embarcadero location. (Though not the SF MOMA rooftop one.)
author: G. J.

description: I've been to SF for a week twice in a year's time.  The Blue Bottle is very good coffee in a hard to spot shop in SF. During my recent week in SF, I tried many of the shops around Moscone and I favored the Blue Bottle most when I was done.
author: Doug H.

description:
Fuck it, I'll give 5 stars.  

I really enjoy coming to this location because of the bright interior and the center bar.  It's quieter in the afternoon.  I can't imagine coming in the morning because I'm usually not even awake before eleven.

I only drink lattes but they make some damn good ones here, and at $3.50, they're a bit cheaper than Ritual's single origin latte.

The parfait is pretty good as well.  I've had it twice.  

I like that this is downtown and somewhat hidden from the general public ;)
author: Denis Y.

description: Delicious. The New Orleans coffee was really good, not too sweet. Perfect latte. Also had a poached egg breakfast with cornbread and sausage, amazing! My husband had the waffle with apple compote, also very tasty. I would highly recommend stopping here.
author: Leah T.

description: Having heard my friends rave about this place for so long, it didn't quite live up to my expectations, but it was close. While visiting I went to this location twice, once getting a latte and the other getting an espresso. The latte was balanced and buttery, and the espresso was truly stellar. It didn't need any cream to tone it down, which is just how I like it. I also liked how the location was a little hidden in an alley, but still had a nice outside atmosphere.
author: Jordan S.

description: Best coffee in the shopping precinct, and great brunch options in support. The space is nice, service friendly, sometimes a little slow, but worth the wait.
author: Jan M.

description: I am delighted by this spot. Every time I'm near the SOMA I make an effort to go here for a latte. I don't know what excites me more the coffee, japanese syphon, the newspapers hung on scrolls, or the large open windows.  Cute.
author: Hannah A.

description:
This review is not for this particular location, but rather for all Blue Bottle Coffee. I first tasted Blue Bottle Coffee (as plain hot drip coffee) in various coffee shops in Berkeley and thought that they all had a sour taste to them. The coffee was always weak and didn't taste like coffee, but more like apple juice, spoiled milk, or urine. Then I thought maybe I need to taste Blue Bottle Coffee at its source in San Francisco. Perhaps the folks at Berkeley just don't know how to brew Blue Bottle Coffee.

Well, I stopped by today and got a very small cup of New Orleans Iced Coffee for almost $4. It still tasted like apple juice piss. I do not understand what is the hype about this coffee.
author: Michael F.

description:
If only I can own my own siphon, I would. But for $20,000 a pop, I'd rather just settle and treat myself out. 

If ever in the City, make sure you stop in and get to sip amazing and great drip coffee. It's all that. 

Must try: Affogato.
author: Mika D.

description: I was really disappointed with a recent visit here.  I was last in SF in 2009 and spent lots of time in this cafe - and loved it.  It seems that a lot has changed in the last 3 years... The coffee is still good, but there is a level of pretentiousness and snobbery which takes away from the whole experience - there is none of that enthusiastic evangelizing about great coffee anymore - more of a patronizing "we know better than you" attitude which was horrid.
author: Kate S.

description:
Blue Bottle is for sure the very best coffee in San Francisco. Hands down, and I've been to all the locations in the area. I have to agree with the other Yelpers that this location has a bit of snobbery going on. I simply asked for a straw for my iced coffee. Instead I was given an apalled look as she said, "we don't have straws here." 

Let me rephrase that request, do you have a spoon that I may use to stir my iced coffee? "Spoons are on the counter." 

My advice at this location is to just sit down and look pretty, or take your coffee and run.
author: Kathy M.

description:
So they get two stars for coffee that is fancy.  And the obvious lack of 3 stars they COULD have had, if not for this particular incident.

I go in with my coworker Lexi.  We are stopping in for a bite to eat for her and a mocha for me.  She orders some of their mini potatoes - $5 for about 8 mini potatoes.  First charge of ridiculous.

She asks the guy nicely if they have ketchup.  The two guys behind the counter pretended they didn't hear her.  Finally she got their attention.

"We do, but not for those potatoes."  Second charge of ridiculous.

She asks him, well, do you have ketchup for something else?  Can you put it in another cup so I can get it separately?

The guy walks away.  Again.  Totally ignored.  Lexi goes after someone else behind the counter and asks for some ketchup.

The guy says, "We only have ketchup for our hot dogs."

Lexi kind of stares at him in shock.  Really?  

"The potatoes have been perfectly roasted, seasoned, and caramelized - ketchup on those potatoes?  Now THAT is an odd pairing."  

Then she retorts, "Well, I guess I'll just have to go to McDonald's."

To which, he shit himself and fainted.

PRETENTIOUS PIECES OF SHIT!
author: Kayla B.

description:
This place is so cool they don't even have a sign out front, excepting - upon close inspection - a small image of a blue bottle fixed on the corner of their building. The coffee is exquisite. I had a cappuccino this morning, so perfectly balanced and naturally sweet that I immediately dashed any thought of adding my usual sprinkle of raw sugar on top. I love coffee like this. Turns out they've got a small but very appealing brunch menu as well. We shared the Belgian Waffel (their gourmet spelling). It was simple,  well-prepared and hit the waffel spot. We waited in line about 10-15 minutes for our provisions, and at 10:30 on a Sunday morning, that's a breeze and well worth it. The line out the door was, in fact, the only way we spotted the place. 

For coffee lovers and connoisseurs, this is your place.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Pros:

- Quality Products (coffee, tea, pastry, etc)
- Educated Crew
- Decent Prices (3.5 for Latte, 1 dollar for Biscotti)
- Good Atmosphere (Not Loud) 
- Plenty of seats inside or out. 
- Internet Access 
- Quick turn-around time for drinks

Cons:

- Hard to Find Location (even when your right in front of it)
- Can get extremely busy
- The ordering line is always blocking the door, making it hard for people to come in/out.
- Small Serving Sizes (if you agree Quantity over Quality)
author: David C.

description:
Seven weeks ago I stood out front and waited,
got offered smack from a hooker, but still smiled elated.
Not many gals are dumb enough to kill time in the rain,
when there's a cozy warm spot inside calling their name.

But said cozy warm spot was thispacked, like most worthy places
and filled with too many "it's 5:30 on Friday" smug happy faces.
I tried to sit solo, but got scared and abandoned my drink -
Just grabbed my umbrella and ran outside to think.

Then a boy saw me outside, but had no time to talk,
So he posted a Craigslist Missed Connection - a site I just happen to stalk.
I answered his search for Blue Bottle's 'smiling brunette with umbrella' and he turned out to be a surprisingly sane and emotionally available fella'. 
So we kept seeing one another and the word "couple" had its appeal -
$3.00 for coffee AND a boyfriend, now that's a great deal!

Girls:  I mean it when I say Blue Bottle in the SoMa is prime "after work for singles" real estate.  

Boys: since I'm off the market,  I recommend you go here to find your own little 'internet darling/shallow attentionwhore' - tm SF Weekly.

Critical Assholes:  the coffee was hot and I liked it... useful enough for you?
author: Janney B.

description:
I don't drink coffee or tea, so it's weird I was even here.

My friend needed to buy coffee beans so we came here around 5pm on a Monday.  No such luck, they were all out of coffee beans.  

We had some catching up to do, so we didn't waste the trip.  We both ordered hot chocolates.  Now, I'm not a big fan of chocolate either, but this was some good hot chocolate.  Maybe only second to Citizen Cake.

I wasn't much a fan of their attitudes behind the counter, but it didn't really matter because I was just there to chit chat and drink a hot chocolate.  The barista did make a cute design in my drink which semi-made up for their lack of charisma.

I felt like a school teacher sitting on the stools, but the the overall atmosphere was relaxing and perfect for good conversation.

Loved it...may go back if I'm craving some hot chocolate.
author: Michelle V.

description:
SAME COFFEE --- DIFFERENT LOCATION

I finally found this location.  It is charming--off the main shopping drag, yet close enough to use one of the big parking garages, if need be.

My expectations were very high, as I've had Blue Bottle at 2 different locations, and I have been completely satisfied with both.  The long line out the door almost put  me off, but I perservered.  The line went so-so quick/slow.  I thought, just take a deep breath, and chill.  

So I did.

Splendid mocha.  I mean, really.  I got it in a not-paper cup, and it was the perfect temperature as I took my first sip.  I thought-heaven? Yesssss.  Thank you BB.  You've got me on the hook, I won't be ditching you anytime soon.  And really---what would I go to after this? Fivebucks is so 90's, it is now my last ditch choice if I *have* to buy coffee out.  I am loving Uncommon Ground beans, so I get that for home use, if I am not able to obtain BB beans at either Tacubayu or even driving in to the city.

The food options were lovely.  Just enough, not overwhelming and oh so yum.  I tried the Bacon Gruyere brioche, and it was just right along with my mocha.  I've had the sandwich twice before, the one with the celery and cheese? Can't recall the name, but it was perfection.

Now, if BB could only get a location in the W.C./Lafayette area, I'd never go anywhere else.  Peets=burnt coffee taste, Starbucks, well, we won't go there.
Love you BB!
author: Julia W.

description: I just don't understand the fascination people have with this place. I waited 30+ minutes in line just to get a drip coffee. I wanted to experience plain black coffee and determine if there really was something unique about their preparation of coffee as well as the coffee quality itself. I was disappointed. I am NOT a coffee snob but I know a good cup of joe when I taste it. This coffee was tart and had a cheap mouthfeel and aftertaste. I guess I'm not a fan so won't be going back.
author: Jonny G.

description:
I just had my first Blue Bottle experience, and I'd say it lives up to the hype.  I ordered a latte and it was smooth as silk.  Paired with the parfait it was the breakfast of champions.

I dig the location (just enough off the beaten path to feel special), the minimalist decor and the sunlight shining through the windows.  I feel like the vibe would inherently appeal to yuppies, but perhaps not so much to hipsters.

If you're coming in the morning, prepare for a line.  But you might run into a friend of yours further along who can order your drink for you!
author: Jonathan Z.

description: Blue Bottle is right below my office, and as great as that sounds this one is not so great.  :(  The staff is super unfriendly which is so not usual for a Blue Bottle.  It makes me sad that I have to walk all the way over to Starbucks by the mall to get a coffee because I dread going to the coffee right under my office.  Big bummer.
author: Christina M.

description: roast too light for my liking. BO overpowered the coffee aroma
author: Mark I.

description:
My wife swore she'd never come back to this BB months ago. I'm not so militant.  Thought I'd give this location another try.  Bad move- after a relaxing 30+ min wait th stupid snot behind the counter filled my Nola 1/2 full (o coffee) and would have filled the rest w milk if I hadn't asked her to stop from ruining the drink. She replied that they only had a little iced coffee left and now are completely out.  Well - tell me that before trying to pass me a cup full of milk and ice with NO COFFEE.  I am happy to order something else that will taste like coffee.  
Whatever happened to Blue Bottle taking pride in serving consistently good coffee?  I thought my wife was over reacting the last five times we stopped at this local.  Just for some context we are not some weird weekend warriors that don't have a history here.  We were daily regulars at the Hayes kiosk and now wonder....what happened??
author: Minotaur N.

description: Posh downtown site of the latest best coffee to grace San Francisco. Presentation of both the space, but especially the coffee, is artistic. Great private alley downtown feel, as you sit along the windows looking outwards or take a seat on a stool at the communal table down the the middle of the cafe. Plenty of hip pretense from staff and customers alike, but that's a reasonable price to pay for such great coffee.
author: Jake G.

description: Small hole in the wall place that's always packed with hipsters, I get my mocha or Kyoto iced coffee and bounce right out.
author: Katrina T.

description:
4 words --- michael recchiuti hot chocolate!!

if you like chocolate, you must try their hot chocolate!   it's soo good!  The taste is just perfect.  I am typically not a whipped cream kind of person, but it compliment the chocolate very well here!
author: Coco L.

description: This coffee is the best coffee in the world.  Go there.  Get the Kyoto Style Iced Coffee or an individual drip.  Every blend is the bomb.  These hipsters put their foot in it. The Mint location, in particular, is the bizznisss.
author: Julie B.

description: I am a huge fan of strong coffee and was very happy that I was able to try Blue Bottle's iced New Orleans Coffee when I was in SF yesterday.  The coffee was flavorful and definitely woke me up after eating a heavy lunch.  The prices are reasonable and similar to Starbuck's prices.  Funny thing is that they don't provide straws.  I hope a Blue Bottle opens up in Southern CA.
author: Tran T.

description: Expensive? Yes. Is it worth it? Definitely. Blue Bottle is one of the best coffee shops in the Bay Area, especially if you don't alter your drinks that much and want a great quality shot of espresso. I do wish this location was a little bigger and have a more "coffee shop" vibe but I'll take what I can get. Now, would I choose this place of Philz? I don't know. Both places have its pros and cons and it depends on my mood (and if I need caffeine at that moment) and where I am at. Would I got out of the way for this place? Probably not. Would I wait 30 minutes for an espresso? Probably not again. Like many places in SF, I would only go here if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Tam V.

description:
Here's the thing: I know this place is popular, I know it can get crowded. I also know that it's not the cheapest cup of joe. BUT since I know these things and know what to expect, I still love this place.

Their breakfast is delicious. From waffles to benedicts to oatmeal, it's always done beautifully. 

For first timers, I suggest ordering a siphon, even for just the "wow" factor. 

Tips: 
-Parking here is pretty hard if you're driving. I suggest using the MUNI instead. Or walking is awesome too.
-If paying with a credit card, there's no tip line. Try to bring some cash for tipping.
-They have their own bathrooms but require a key that you can request from the register.
-They sometimes have affogato (ice cream with espresso over it....and usually from humphry slocombe!!!) which you MUST try if you like ice cream!
author: Tyler D.

description:
I love and respect blue bottle coffee.  I am a regular 1 cup a day coffee drinker.  Last week my friend and I went to blue bottle cafe and suffered through a 30 minute line to place the order for the famed New orleans ice coffee and sg-20.  We would have ordered breakfast except I had ran out cash.  This is a cash only establishment!

We were both very disappointed with our coffee.  We both have ordered similar drinks at different blue bottle location and had been turned on to blue bottle because of those experiences.   We were in dismay at our cup of coffee.  We couldn't understand the long line and the glowing reviews for this location.  

The New Orlean ice coffee tasted  like a diluted Vietnamese drip coffee. The sg-20, the fraternal brother to the gilbraltar, was very different.   This was someone else's step brother. The gibraltar (Oakland location)  tasted rich, smooth and balanced....Mint plaza drink was watery.  It tasted like flat non-fat milk in coffee.  What's irritating, when told the drink did not taste right, the barista said the espresso at each blue store is different and will change the flavor of the drink.  I haven't even commented on the flavor yet....just the texture of the drink.  He didn't offer to make another drink. 

I wasn't going to bother writing this review initially written eight months ago...  At that time I was going to chalk this experience as my learning curve until i randomly had a conversation with a coffee connoisseur who happened to over hear my discussion about mint plaza blue bottle.  He said he never received a good drink at the mint plaza location.  He recommend going to Sightglass because there is less people and more consistently good drinks if I couldn't get to the Hayes blue bottle location. I am finally posting this review because I still remember how terrible that cup of coffee was and HOW LONG the anticipated wait for this cup, only to discover I needed another cup!!!!  

Time is valuable. There is nothing wrong waiting for what you want. This place doesn't promise a satiating cup of coffee. I haven't been back and no need to redeem this place.
author: Quynh P.

description:
After hearing all the hoopla about Blue Bottle I was excited to get in there and try it. It was a Friday morning around 11am and there were about 2 or 3 people ahead of us in line.... 15 minutes later we make it to the counter. How slow could they possibly be. There were 4 people behind the counter. I place my order and the woman wanders off... I am left standing there like a moron, holding my money in my hand waiting to  pay. There are 2 other staff stood there by the checkout not doing anything, see me holding the cash, and help the next customer. 

The girl comes back, takes my cash, then goes off to make my drip coffee. She bring the cup over  plops it down on the counter. So there I am staring at my cup off coffee. Remember, this is my first time there. I scan around the room looking for a station that has milk,cream etc. I don't see anything. I see 2 cartons of milk to the right of me on the counter, which the barrista appears to be using to make her drinks. I'm thinking, well maybe they are there for us to use too, however there is now a customer between me and my milk. I reach around (not in that way, pervert) and  grab the milk, add it to my coffee, and head out. Right now I feel like the crazy guy who stole the barrista's milk. As im leaving, I notice a tiny little place hidden right behind the door, behind the long line of people waiting that had developed. 

So, long story short, Blue Bottle, you get 1 star because your staff were slow, unorganized, unfriendly, unmotivated, and unhelpful. Maybe that's how you achieve a cult following, but not how you receive my repeat business. 

Oh... and the coffee wasn't that great either.
author: Mathew J.

description:
I LOVE BLUE BOTTLE SOOOO MUCH!

Blue Bottle is a great purveyor of the ristretto shot, two shortly pulled shots that are sweeter, more rich, and lower in caffeine content than their long pulled cousins. It goes best in a dollop of milk (cappuccino)!

I went to this Blue Bottle every morning during my last two trips to SF. I've had their entire breakfast menu, pretty much. The Belgian waffle, poached eggs with prosciutto, eggs in brioche, and the brioche w/ chevre and chives. EVERYTHING was/is amazing!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Blake D.

description:
drinks: delicious coffees and cappucinos.  and their pastries are delicious.  i always buy a bag of bella donovan whenever i'm in town

service: kind and knowledgeable...however, a tad slow.

final thoughts: i wish they had blue bottle in la!
author: Kara P.

description: Hole in the wall location but well worth the search. Best coffee in town. Only one size (small), no flavored shots, prices start around $5 (small)
author: Cee B.

description: Great atmosphere. Great service. Awesome java. Long line (10-15mins). No flavors for coffee. Really cool though!
author: Danny M.

description:
ugh... hate.  
no really, it's totally worth the long line to get a healthy dose of a shitty attitude.  every time.

I ordered a macchiato to go and was lectured on how it's no longer called that when it's put in a paper cup.  apparently it's 'against company policy' to make particular drinks to take away. 

lol.  get over yourselves and just give me my coffee.  you're not saving the world.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I didn't know this place even existed until a friend navigated me to its cryptic locale...

this place has that kind of too-cool-for-school San Francisco, I'm-too- awesome-to-actually-put-the-name-of-the-business-on-the-outside-of-the-building-so-people-know-I'm-a-cafe

but, despite the fact that its tucked away on a random side street in SOMA, and despite the fact that from far away it justs looks like another random abandoned building... this place has a devoted following with a line that is literally out the door... albeit a following that is composed mainly of hipsters who patronize the place out of a starbucks/peet's-anti-corporate-death-to-capitalism-we-dont-want-an-
american-apparel-in-the-mission based angst

the coffee was great...rich and flavorful... they definitely do a mean brew... and the ambience is pretty nice inside, a good place to have a
conversation

if I'm in the neighborhood, I'll be sure to make a return trip
author: Ryan K.

description: I work at the Chronicle and while I LOVE the coffee here, particularly the iced offerings, it is always a major time investment to come here. My coworkers and I will now only come here at weird times of day, when the line is less likely to be absurdly long. In the mornings we now drive to Sightglass, which while further away is just as good if not better, and ends up being less of a time suck than Blue Bottle. If you work close, love good coffee, and just can't commit to standing in line for 30 minutes I highly recommend Sightglass.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Do you think coffee is an art form? Can you taste the difference between Kenyan roast and Columbian blend? Do you spend several hundred dollars buying (and repairing) home espresso machines? If your answer is "Who doesn't?" then Blue Bottle might be your mecca. 

While the hot coffee is hard to beat, I always order the New Orleans style iced coffee. Slightly sweet, super creamy and strong enough to wake the dead...I do miss the stuff when I'm in NYC. I don't love that they only use paper cups so the iced coffee to go kind of loses it's appeal. 

The breakfast here is actually pretty amazing as well, especially the little $5 bacon brioches. Today I went a bit farther and ordered up the proscuitto and poached eggs plate. I'm still dreaming about that gooey hollandaise soaked sourdough...photo will be posted soon. 

5 Yummy Stars.
author: Jane K.

description: Finally had a chance to try this last week and I have to say I was impressed.  Be prepared to wait if you get the drip, but it is totally worth it.  The folks who work here are really nice and have a ton of patience.  Easy going and not too bad on the wallet.  The drip was not as acidic as I thought it might be.  They must do some prep work on the beans before hand.  I really enjoyed it.
author: Mot Y.

description:
FREAKIN' BOOYAH!!!  I've worked in coffee shops for about 8 years now and I consider myself pretty well versed in the art of espresso preparation.  I recently left my job at a serious artisan coffee shop, Caffe Medici, in Austin where they know what the hell they're doing.  They based a lot of their methods on standards of those such as Blue Bottle, Ritual, 9th St, Stumptown, and the like.  So, needless to say, I went in with high expectations.  And they were met...plus some!  

Aside from the fact that my espresso was amazing, I saw the barista pull my shots and then pour them out FIVE TIMES!  As a barista, I was very impressed that she was not willing to cut corners and serve me inadequate shots.  They were really sweet and thick up front with a really clean finish.  Bravo.  

My cappuccino was fantastic as well.  Perfect temperature.  Perfect milk.  Even great latte art.  And then, on top of that, I had a Belgian waffle and my wife had a big honking piece of toast with strawberry jam.  Perfect

Did I mention perfect?

Ritual (the competitor shop) was good but paled in comparison to Blue Bottle.  I'll be back every day of my visit.
author: Barrett R.

description: Oh my goodness! This was probably some of the BEST coffee I've ever had! I really don't know why I keep drinking Starbucks "coffee". Try the different siphon coffees... make it a tasting. It is delicious and a fun experience. The food was good, but the coffee is what makes Blue Bottle worth it. I must find places in LA that brew Blue Bottle coffee now.
author: Meagan T.

description: I drank the iced coffee the other day and I was literally bouncing off the floor and walls.  Thank god my fat is bouncy.  Don't add soy to your iced coffee.  Its nasty.  Whole milk or go home.
author: Fatty A.

description: I was visiting a friend in SF and he took me to this location (though we also went to the one in the Ferry Building).  It was SO chill and relaxing in here and definitely had a good coffee shop vibe for a Saturday morning.  I had a soy latte - my personal go-to - and it was one the best I've had.  Definitely strong, but good.  Seemed like it would be good place to get some work done.  The crowd itself was a little bit hipster - but I guess that's just to be expected.
author: Laura M.

description: standard.
author: Alvin D.

description: Very bad service. Disrespectful baristas. Expensive. Long line.
author: Thierry W.

description: They make a good cappuccino and latté, sure, but the drip coffee fad is horrible and BB shoulders much of the blame for making it so trendy. Sour, weak, often tepid coffee is *not* good, people. And it's even worse when you're paying over double was you used to for a cup of traditionally brewed coffee. Why must people fall all over themselves to follow a ridiculous trend that siphons money from their pockets, and the enjoyment from their coffee? And, baristas, do you enjoy slaving away over every single cup of coffee? How many steps can we add to this process? Come on, people!! End rant.
author: Em C.

description:
The clean minimalist interior and the baristas at this store are a delight, as is the Mint Tea which is made with fresh Mint leaves. I love the tea so much, that I bought  a Mint Plant to replicate it at home. Unfortunately, I am not a fan of Blue Bottle Coffee and this is a shame, because it's fun to roll out of bed on a weekend morning and stand in line at their "garage door" location in Hayes Valley with other sleepy San Franciscans for your first hit of the day.

I'm not sure if it's a matter of personal preference or if "the emperor has no clothes" I  I suspect that the coffee is either over-extracted or is flash roasted/ some other shorter roasting process and a licorice/chicory combination is added to disguise this fact. Not only was the licorice/chicory taste jarring to my taste buds in this combination, I got a seriously bad buzz from this coffee at all locations. I suspect that they cut corners in the roasting process despite the universal enthusiasm for their coffee in San Francisco. 

At the risk of sounding like a coffee "addict" a longer slower roast tends to give a nice steady buzz (the longer coffee is roasted, the lower the caffeine content so the darker and bolder the roast the less caffeine, indeed counter-intuitive) while a lighter or faster roasting process tends to give me that horrible jittery feeling as does coffee that is over-extracted. I feel strung out post-blue bottle coffee. While they have beautiful and creative store designs, there is too much good (and locally roasted) coffee in San Francisco to drink here. But, I will continue to drop into the SOMA Blue Bottle to enjoy the atmosphere and the Mint Tea.
author: Claire R.

description:
I came here only once and would love to go again.

While I might not be a coffee connoisseur, I can appreciate how the coffee is made.

Their equipment made me feel right back in Chemistry class and their stools were a nice touch.
author: Dhruv P.

description: This place is awesome. There was a line out the door and for good reason. The flavor of my cappuccino was immaculate. Really rich, hearty, almost caramel tasting crema, It was the kind of cappuccino where you'd take a sip, enjoy it, and the aftertaste was maybe even better. I've never had coffee this good in my life, except maybe Coava up in PDX.
author: Thomas R.

description: What can I say?! It's blue bottle! Wait can be long, but I love their coffee!  Clean... and simple... their drinks i.e. coffee and the lattes, and their foods such as the pastries are tasty. Saw their waffles and plan to try it in the future. Likewise their iced coffee is fantastic... the New Orleans ice coffee is tasty and I enjoy the atmosphere. Their machine is fantasic and I always visit this place when I meet my friends in the area.
author: Helicon K.

description:
I was grudgingly addicted to Blue Bottle for about a month. Then I got out of work early one nice day and decided I would stop in at my favorite coffee place and enjoy a cup on-site before sauntering off to other nice things. 

One of the women ahead of me got her drink to-go (after the usual wait) and she paused and said, "Excuse me, but this is barely warm."

"What?" the espresso making woman said, bloodlessly.

"It's just warm,"

Another woman, who was just one tick on the dial friendlier because the corners of her mouth looked capable of bending upwards on occasion, took the cup and felt it skeptically for five whole seconds before admitting, "It is warm. We'll make you another one."

So, I didn't think much about it, and I got my pretty latte in a thick brown cup, and I sat down by the window for a leisurely read as I had my coffee.

It was lukewarm.

Now, some may say it's cowardly not to want to complain about something you've paid for, and they would be right. But I was all set to be relaxed. I didn't want to talk to those unpleasant people, because I didn't want to harsh my nice time. So I drank my tepid latte and left. I had a good time for free at the Main Library, and nobody messed with me.

Strangely, I no longer wish to even buy their beans. There are plenty of other places that are happy to have customers.
author: Karen H.

description:
My boyfriend took me here when we were going around downtown.  He knows I love my cup of caffeinated joy so it was only a matter of time before we came here.

Is the coffee all its hyped up to be?  Why yes, yes it is.  I just had their drip coffee.  Really strong, really tasty.  So strong in fact I had a headache after a few long sips.  A few sips after that, the caffeine shakes.  A few sips after that I could have been prepared for a marathon.  I tried the Kyoto coffee which was a light, sweet refreshment compared to their abyss in a cup.

That being said there are a lot of things to be upset about for a cafe.  I have to list them because they bother me so much.
1) Perpetually long line. - Yes the coffee is that good to have a lot of demand, but must there be at least 10 people in the line all day?  We never seemed to move very far after a 15 minute wait.
2) Loitering? - All right I expect there to be at least one or two people that live in their seating area for any given cafe.  At this place no one seemed to leave their spot so that other guests can take a seat.
3) Long prep time. - Honestly, 7 minutes for a cup of coffee?  Nothing fancy here but it's a cup of coffee.  

I understand the hype, but unless I really do have an hour to kill waiting in line, waiting for my drink, and waiting for a seat to open up, I'm going to pass
author: Christine L.

description:
I battled rain, wind, & the cold yesterday to trek from a doctor's appt in Nob Hill down to Blue Bottle for their stellar lattes. And it was totally worth it. I had 2, in fact.

Also, since I was starving since fasting for my doctor's appt, I figured I may as well try their breakfast. I had poached eggs atop thick homemade toast, with melted gruyere and prosciutto, and it was fantastic! So yummy, I think I will return. :)
author: Sally M.

description:
Every time I try to come to this Blue Bottle, there's a line.

At least the wait got Janney a MC.  

I will try again and again until there's room to stand in there.
author: Lauren C.

description: Love everything about this place! Amazing cappucino, great ambiance just wish it had outdoor seating.
author: Jennie M.

description:
Blue bottle is one of the few great cafes in the city. Good espresso and coffee is surprisingly difficult to get in the city mostly due to the lack of attention to detail almost everywhere else.

Espresso quality here is exceptional, frothing technique is also exceptional. It had better be since it takes a REALLY LONG TIME to get your drink. The sheer level of attention to detail focused on any single drink here is amazing. Definitely not a good idea if you're in a hurry, but it is certainly worth the wait.

The food here is light, fresh and pretty tasty. A bit too green for my tastes, but good. The decor is quite airy and light filled.

Some downsides not worth losing even one star : No power outlets, no free wifi (?),  apparently no climate control (often too humid and stuffy), slow (exceptional) service, a bit uh snobby, and elitist.
author: george p.

description:
Went to try the siphon pot of coffee on a Sunday afternoon.  There was a huge line out the door, but it moved relatively quickly.  The cafe space is cool, and the coffee is amazing.  We tried a Brazilian blend (they have a daily menu of coffees offered brewed in the siphon pot).  It was entertaining to watch the siphon pot brewing (think sci-fi laboratory glassware with a Japanese modern, minimalist design).  

Ordering a pot for two was about $10, which can easily be split w/ four people (if you're okay with a double espresso-sized portion per person)...just enough for a gratifying taste.  Coffee was delicious.  It was extremely robust and flavorful.  Taste was very clean with minimal bitterness (which is supposedly due to the siphon brewing).  Drank the coffee black because it was so good...coffee with the sophistication of wine tasting.  Would definitely go back, especially to share the experience with any coffee-loving friends.
author: Matt S.

description:
Reluctantly, this is the best coffee I've ever had, espresso and drip coffee.

We came here yesterday to try the coffee in the siphon pot and the food. We ordered the Ethiopian coffee, and it was surprisingly delightful and didn't need any sugar or milk! The flavor was subtle, but good and had a natural sweetness and creamyness to it. No bitterness at all. Amazing. By far the best coffee I've ever had. I don't think I ever imagined that I would be drinking coffee without sugar or milk!

My boyfriend ordered the polenta with prosciutto, which came in a big bowl and was intense. Creamy, subtle, very filling, and great saltiness from the prosciutto. I ordered the creamy tomato soup with a puff pastry on top of it. Yummmmm. Creamy and came out piping hot. Very flavorful and went well with the pastry that would even out the intensity of the soup. It also went well with the polenta.

All in all, great coffee and food. Again, I still don't like the smugness, but I can't help but give it 5 stars for the excellent products they have.

Btw, our bill (siphon pot for two, polenta, and tomato soup) came out to be about $26. Yikes! Oh, we also got a second pot of the coffee for free because apparently they made another one for a customer who said they didn't order it. So they just gave us the extra pot.
author: Angela H.

description:
Best coffee in the city? I think not. Coffee was burnt and could not be drunk. Most expensive cup of coffee I've ever drunk. I came back a year after to try and change my opinion. It didn't.

Add +1 star for their espresso machine, which is really beautiful.
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
The Kyoto style iced coffee is like a caffeine IV.  It's so black - not so much bitter - just a very heavy black coffee.  If you like black coffee (and iced), this is it.

Personally, I did not *love* it, despite the fact that I do enjoy occasionally enjoy my coffee black.  Probably an excellent coffee choice for a bad hangover, but as someone who has never had a hangover, I can't say for sure.

I had a sip of my coworker's New Orleans style iced coffee and that was heavenly.  It was sweet, but at the same time, didn't cover the coffee taste.  A nice afternoon coffee choice for sure.

Baristas were nice and shop was clean.  Nice location, too, with plenty of outdoor seating in the adjoining plaza to enjoy on those rare days the sun comes out.

Will try to come back to this one more often, as it is the closest location to my work.  Would love to try their baked goods one of these days, too!
author: L Y.

description:
Chemistry coffee ... best way I can explain it.

Talented Barista staff, limited (but great) breakfast menu ... 

Best part is that it is tucked away off the beaten path, so for the most part it isn't too crowded.
author: N M.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is what my mind tells me coffee should taste like.  I have this image plastered in my mind, from excessive childhood TV watching, of Juan Valdez taking a sip of black coffee with a satisfied grin on his face.  My experience of drinking black coffee is similar to my experience of sipping warm whiskey.  As you go to drink you think this is going to be good, and as the liquid touches your taste buds they shrivel at the taste of the foul liquid making your face contort as you choke the mouthful down.  Blue Bottle Coffee makes me feel like I am a satisfied coffee drinker like Juan Valdez.  It makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside, and not semi revolted at the fact that I enjoy the stuff.  

This particular Blue Bottle location is ultra hip in a not so comfortable part of town.  Despite the sketchiness, I believe it to be worth the trot.  Although I have not tried their food, pastries, or snacks they look and smell divine.  Yet, I do have to say that the coffee is their main attraction.
author: Michele F.

description:
For quite some time now, I've been an avid fan of the soy hot chocolates (Michael Ricchiuti) simply because the Bay Area was NOT spawning exceptional coffee... I mean, compared to the history and devotion of the great Pacific Northwest. Sure there's your Peet's coffee and Mr. Espresso and other various shit... but I'm glad Blue Bottle Coffee Co. originated when it did. Motherfuckin' Chris (the best barista ever OMGOMG) stole my coffee virginity, not to mentioned he wooed me into fixed gears. He is an expert at post coitus espresso shots, texturing milk well/pouring latte art and making my soy lattes with tender, love, and care. I've seen all types of latte art from rosettas to hearts to weird squigglies, and Chris is the type of dude able to replicate all kinds of crazy shit. And on occasion, he'll whip me up an extra crispy, vanilla waffle. 

I owe Christopher this review for quite some time now... and this shitty review is a shout out to everyone at the Mint location. You all look so hot in your all-black get up. So classy. 

PS I'm sorry the ex-Creeps and other various moped/scooter riders make noise in that alleyway... but you all love the smell of 2-stroke. Deal with it.
author: Lea S.

description:
In a city full of amazing coffee Blue Bottle stands alone as the best, hands down, bar none, no question. Ritual is overrated, Epicenter is a close second and rising, and 4 Barrel is always disappointing, but BB is the most consistently great cup of coffee I've had anywhere. If you're a coffee connoisseur, or want to be, or just appreciate it now and again, you're doing yourself a disservice for not checking the place out. Go right now... I'll wait.

That said BB has it's downsides. The spaces are all limited, even Mint Plaza, are small and limited. Makes it tough to enjoy your coffee when 40 people are jammed around one table and some wall space. It's difficult to even feel comfortable to take along a book or a paper, and downright ludicrous to think of taking a laptop and getting any work done. Food selections are equally limited. Combined this makes Blue Bottle what I'd assume the owners wanted, a place to get coffee, maybe drink it, and leave, but leave me wanting. It's for these reasons that Blue Bottle is a rarity for me, but a nice one.

You can't go wrong with a regular capp or gibraltar, but if you've got the time and the desire go for the siphon at the Mint plaza location. Always good, sometimes amazing, once in awhile transcendent, this has been, on occasion, the best cup of brewed coffee I've ever had.
author: Scott R.

description:
Great cafe with the excellent Blue Bottle brand of coffee served.  Tasty snacks for brunch (sweet and savory) available for a steep price.  I do like the "siphon" coffee that is specially prepared, if only for the novelty effect.  It's fun to watch it being prepared on the side counter with bunsen burner type heat lamps.

I also like the location, almost as if secretly tucked away next to the ghetto, this cafe is in a trendy and newly gentrified area of downtown.

With hipsters galore, the line for this cafe can be pretty long.  That's the only real drawback.  It's way too popular.
author: R L.

description: Best coffee in town - especially the New Orleans. The biggest problem is the wait.It takes a century and a half if you try to get anything from the Blue Bottle operated coffee shops or kiosks. Magically, if you get Blue Bottle at any other establishment, it comes as fast as it should. My Theory, they only hire stoners - haha. Hey it's SF - there has to be a reason and this seems to be the only one I can think of. I mean, it is a coffee shop. Think about it! Starbucks anyone?
author: Ann K.

description: This coffee is okay. Had a Caffe Latte and I was not that impressed. The biggest reason they only get three stars. My drink was not hot. While you could blame me for not asking for extra hot, this was not even normal hot.  Still prefer Starbucks.
author: Stacey B.

description:
I am very picky about my morning cup of coffee.   I like it Black, Hot, and Dark in color. While in San Francisco my friends took me to Blue Bottle.   

There is nothing artifical about Blue Bottle.  The moment you open the front door, you can smell the coffee.  The organic beans are ground and brewed specifically for your cup.  With such attention to every cup of coffee, you will have to wait 5-10 minutes, yet this honest cup of coffee is well worth the wait and will allow you to start your day on the right foot.
author: Caroline Q.

description:
I came across Blue Bottle to escape the Starbucks desert that characterizes the hotel district just north of Market when I was at a conference here, and what a monumental relief it was to find this oasis.
Like a chemistry lab crossed with a modern dream. 

All sunlight and beekers on warmers with bubbling coffees of diverse origins.

The barista was friendly and superprofessional, heating and whisking and pouring our coffees as if she were preparing Japanese green tea. 
 
Blue Bottle has entered my list of Places I Must Go When Visiting the Bay.
author: Anita S.

description:
Blue Bottle is awesome.

Their mocha is delicious! It is made with Tcho chocolate and really taste like a hot chocolate with a kick.

The cappuccino is already good.
author: Jon R.

description:
I simply had no idea they served brunch here! Makes sense though -- their coffee's so strong, you'll need a little sustenance to keep your feet on the ground. After a few creamy sips of my latte, I dug into the salad with farm cheese, prosciutto and toast and the pear compote with greek yogurt. Yummm... excellent morning farm-fresh palate pleasers while watching the tattood baristas make some serious brews with a machine that looks like it's out of Wilie Wonka's chocolate factory. 

Warning: Once you go Blue Bottle, you never go back. Stay far away if you don't want to start mainlining it.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Every time I have friends come to San Francisco I take them to Blue Bottle first. I absolutely love the coffee and breakfast food (waffles, eggs on a raft, etc.). My favorite item on the menu is the New Orleans style iced coffee. 
Every details has been covered. The bathroom key is attached to a coffee making accessory. The milk and cream come from the same clever device. The best part is gawking at the giant Oji coffee machine and watching the meticulous process the barista must endure. 
Unfortunately the place can get crowded but it's worth it. Parking is troublesome too; I usually park in the lot on the other side of 5th or I just take the 27 bus.
Definitely worth checking out. Next time I'm there I have to remember to buy a t-shirt!
author: David K.

description:
After 25 years of existence and beginning with the year 2009 I have FINALLY welcomed coffee and caffeine into my life.

Took long enough right?

Blue Bottle... your Cafe Au Lait has shown me a world I've never known.

I owe you.
author: kate r.

description:
Dear Blue Bottle, 

Remember* when we first met, back when I was still a New Yorker and you epitomized all that I loved about the Bay Area? You were funky, honing your craft inside an old converted garage. You liked to go to farmers markets and all the cool little cafes. Sometimes, when I felt like it, I would invite you over to my house and you were kind to my little coffee pot. Your friends were witty, wore funky t-shirts and listened to cool music. 

I know that your community is a large one, but ever since you got that new job across from the SF Chronicle, I am not sure who you are. How come all your friends always wear the same black shirts every day? I mean I like black and all, and perhaps wear too much of it, but now I have a hard time telling your friends apart. Frankly they don't seem as happy as your pals at the markets or at the garage. 

And all those strangers coming in to have business meetings. Who are they? OK I get it; they all read the New York Times in which you were featured. Why must they all pose uncomfortably at those awkwardly tall tables? San Francisco is not New York and shouldn't try to be. And don't have your new friends attack me. This is a testament to how great it is in the bay. New York can't compete with its charms, its sunny nature. Leave the cold to the east coast.  Even my pal Grumpy* doesn't put on airs like this.  

Blue, what happened? I like your new toy but maybe your architect should have built a more well suited space for it. Or maybe you need to meet some artists who could add some character to the place. I feel like I am going to the doctor's office and he is too busy adjusting his lab coat to make my appointment. 

I visited you yesterday on my break from work, but I think you didn't spot me there. A gaggle of high heeled ladies were blocking your view. I had to rush in and rush out. I didn't feel comfortable. I'll see you at the farmers market on Sunday. You seem more like yourself there. 

No hard feelings. As I write this I am sipping a cup of your coffee, remembering the good old days when things were just lovely, simple and sweet. 

Faithfully Yours, 

Ole* Coffee Eyes

*http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=HNV4GQwjPZRkbSxtwicQ_g&q=blue+bottle

*http://www.yelp.com/biz/cafe-grumpy-new-york

*lazy way of saying old, not a reference to bullfighting.
author: Tina E.

description:
I have to agree that the cups are fricken small and the price is high at $3 for a small cup of capuccino...

BUT...

This is the BEST coffee EVER. Ok, maybe not ever, though it's pretty damn good. I don't know what they do or how they do it, each cup of caffeine is equally and heavenly good. When I'm standing in that God-forsaken line (yes, there is one) I can count on one important thing - the quality of my choice of caffeine is going to be excellent. 

This is the type of coffee that you sip, breathe in the aroma, look around to take in the surroundings, enjoy the moment, and relax with your cup of delicious coffee. I love it!!
author: Liz K.

description:
I'm pulling a star from my original review.  I might pull two now that I'm thinking about it...

Robusta is just gnarly. - My main bitch.  

The baristas and servers could use some congeniality pills BB Mint st. Frack those pretentious haters.
author: Robi P.

description:
Ok, I am not a Blue Bottle devotee. In fact, I can't stand their Hayes Valley original location, or at least the caffeinated pretense that pervades there. Even so, I had to admit that their coffee in and of itself was always at the peak of its flavor whenever I did have a cup (sometimes at a restaurant, or at a friend's place).

With this new location pretty near Union Square, there's a distinct friendliness that has been added (perhaps the staff gets there morning coffee before work!?). There's actually a chance to sit down here, not for hours but perhaps to enjoy your drink at a leisurely pace. While you sometimes see someone with a laptop here, those people tend to be lame and should be avoided. Somehow, Blue Bottle has succeeded in making the art of coffee drinking an activity, and not just a form of hot sustenance. 

Another nice aspect: they have food! And beer and wine! And come on now, let's here it for the Japanese siphon bar (http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/dining/23coff.html?_r=1&oref=slogin),  try roasting that bean, Peet's.
author: Nish N.

description:
I'm a huge Blue Bottle Coffee fan. I've waited in 20 minute lines at the Ferry Building, stood in the rain on Linden Alley and will go out of my way to dine somewhere that serves the magical caffeiney elixir. 

Needless to say I couldn't wait to check out the new Cafe in Mint Plaza. After one visit I can say the coffee is as tasty as ever but the space is lacking a bit. I understand that this place is packed at most hours and I imagine the lack of comfortable seating is a way to keep people from lingering. But honestly, isn't lingering what one wants to do over a great cup of coffee?

Service was quick and efficient and I won't hesitate to drop by when in the neighborhood but as much as it hurts me to say, I don't see myself making this Blue Bottle a destination spot. Hopefully the next Blue Bottle Cafe will have some couches, maybe a comfy chair or two...then it will truly be a destination worthy of the world class coffee.
author: phil h.

description: Don't have anything bad to say about this place. Just amazing coffee.
author: Anthony V.

description:
Okay, we get it, Blue Bottle Coffee is fantastic. That much pretty much goes without saying. BUT, these five stars are for the service. I went in there & bought four 1/2 lb bags of Giant Steps coffee @ the recommendation of one of the baristas. He was friendly, helpful, & 100% unpretentious, & that's been my experience at the flagship Blue Bottle location in Hayes Valley as well.

My four lucky friends in the Carolinas have been enjoying their beans & seem unnaturally productive of late. Hats off to strong coffee & the tremendously helpful staff at Blue Bottle on Mint St.
author: Pete J.

description:
Blue bottle coffee company is an amazing and eclectic mix of coffee ninjas and yumtastic food. The place is a bit small, and always packed, but well worth the wait. My two favorites are the mocha and the Waffles O' Doom (I think they just call them Waffles on the menu, but the "O' Doom" part is there, invisible). The prices are a bit high (last I checked, the Waffles O' Doom were $7.25), but for the quality and general atmosphere make it a fair deal. 

One interesting element that is really fun to watch is the cool siphon (light-based) coffee pots that they use to boil the water. It is very "mad scientist" looking and quite a lot of fun to watch (and take pictures of!) 

Many times I have been in there and ran into local celebs, such as the Editor of SF Chronicle, the Mayor, and others. The employees are also very nice and highly knowledgeable about coffee and coffee-related items (that's why I called them Coffee Ninjas in the opening). 

They are located right next to the old SF Mint building on 5th street and its really easy to get there via Bart (driving is a bit tricky and they have limited parking area, just like everywhere else in SF). I recommend making a day out of it: Start at Blue Bottle, zip over to MoMA-SF, a quick walk through the Meteron, and perhaps a play at ACT. Enjoy!
author: Anthony L.

description: I definitely prefer this location over the one in the Ferry Building. The line is shorter (but still takes at least 20m). The coffee comes out much hotter and has those lovely foam designs. You can watch the lab-like siphon coffee setup/making process to keep you entertained in line. Somewhat difficult to find and in a sketchy area, but worth the hunt.
author: Catherine N.

description:
Although I am not a coffee drinker, I am in love with Blue Bottle. 

Yes, it's hipsterish.

Yes, it's yuppie-ish.

Yes, it's hip-hopish.

Yes, it's also I-ride-a-road-bike-and-I-live-in-San-Francisco-so-I'm-coolish.

It's really everyone in one super cool place.

I'm not in love with the fact that the place is super small and the line is usually always outside the door and it takes forever to just place your order. I'm also not in love with it being so stuffy and warm in there. But the thick Acme French bread toast with butter and jam, the Belgian waffles with butter and syrup, and the Popeye toast that has eggs in the middle make up for the long ass wait and the stuffiness. Most of the workers are really nice also. And they usually sell my favorite Miette goodies too. 

So, whatever you are, just come here. Because it's totally you too.
author: Maureen B.

description:
VERY good, fresh coffee - - - brought to you by some strange siphoning process....poured for you at the table.

$11, service for two.

Deep, earthy flavor - - - while not quite strong coffee..... it goes down like silk, and has a stupendous aroma and lingering flavor.  I really love STRONG coffee - - and on that note, Blue Bottle did not deliver, but I have to say that every sip of this coffee makes up for what it lacks in strength in sheer taste and texture.  Now this is one GOOD cup of coffee.  
 
New location, with lots of friendly employees, hip people, and a community gathering type of feel..... 
 
I really liked Blue Bottle Cafe, and would come here again.  At approximately $5.50 pp for a cup of coffee, it's not cheap, and you barely pour out one large mug of coffee (though in their small mugs, you get nearly two cups) but the taste made it worthwhile.  

I didn't try their regular coffee on this day, but I've had it before at Mission Beach Cafe, and it's quite good - - though perhaps not comparable in the deep flavors that this Ethiopian coffee had.  The iced  coffees also looked really good.  (I would recommend you stick with the siphon process, though.)
 
Given how much I love coffee, I could probably live at this cafe, except the seating is just cold and hard... and not conducive to hanging out for hours, but I suppose that is the point - - drink and get out!
 
While my girlfriend and I did not have any --  they also seemed to serve up some food, including sandwiches, pastries, etc.  But then again, I am not one to go for food at a coffee joint, especially in San Francisco, where we have such great eatery options!
 
It's a cool hangout - - and one that I plan to frequent often... even if it does cost a pretty penny!  While it is a totally cool process and the coffee is really very good - - I don't know just yet whether this lives up to the hype.  Very good, albeit impressive, is not quite "excellent".
author: Grace K.

description:
Kyoto Style Iced Coffee .... oh my god.

I don't want to sound so smug, but this is what dreams are made of (in coffee).  It was so strong, yet so flavorful and ... GOOD.  Mind you though, I'm not exactly a coffee fanatic like everyone else here, but when I get the sense of tasting something this good, I can definitely understand.

Perhaps this place needs more seats, since it does get pretty crowded real easy.  Overall though, I'm hooked.
author: Ren L.

description:
I came for the $20,000 halogen-powered, imported siphon bar, I stayed for the...oh, wait, I didn't stay.

I read (http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/dining/23coff.html?ex=1201842000&en=1002925c4c14c0bd&ei=5070&emc=eta1), I ogled, and then I got out swiftly.

There was nothing about this sleek interior that encouraged me to linger and I'm sure I'm in the minority here but I like to sit in cafes that I like to sit in. Touches of warmth and color (blue would be a start, if an obvious one) were altogether absent and the staff are now outfitted in black button down shirts that obscure their personalities. Is this a (re)branding effort? I dislike it immensely. 

We were here on a Sunday afternoon and I can't imagine that a visit during every hour of every business day would require sipping coffee elbow to elbow with a bunch of strangers sitting in their high chairs 'round the communal table, raised voice conversations straining against the din, but I have no desire to experience this identity crisis again.

There is something of a park called Hayes Green, not far from the friendlier and less contrived Blue Bottle outpost on Linden Street and I always find an available seat there.
author: Michelle M.

description:
The coffee is fine; the hype, though, is a bit tiresome. Blue Bottle opened a cafe and it's attracted the attention of the New York Times. [The Chronicle, as usual, is right behind after being beaten by the Grey Lady on a story a story only blocks from their building.]

What I like best about Blue Bottle - beyond their ridiculously high priced [$18 a pound] coffee - is their no wifi policy.
