Nothing is more tiresome than walking in to any coffee shop in the city and finding multitudes of twenty-somethings tapping furious into their Mac laptops. Enough. Since when did a cafe become a place for anti-social, self absorbed, table-hogging behavior? 

Can't get through a cup of coffee without checking e-mail or updating your blog? Tough. I wish more cafes turned off the wifi and said 'no' the presumptuousness of instant electronic connectivity. Slow down, sip-don't -slurp and say 'hello' to your neighbor. The e-mail can wait.
author: John B.

description: I thought I was I coffee snob. Blue Bottle takes coffee snobbery to a whole new level.  If you are a coffee connoisseur, this is a must stop for you.  They brew coffee in the tubes and gizmos out of my 11th grade chem. class.  They place will definitely be on must hit list for my next San Francisco trip.
author: ira b.

description:
Blue Bottle always had the best coffee, and you'd have sworn they couldn't do any better . . . and then you try this crazy-wack-$20,000-hand-made-by-japanese-virgins-massaged-with-homemade-beer-made-out-of-pure-platinum siphon coffee machine coffee . . . jesus that's good coffee.  I mean really good.  Like - I never knew coffee could taste that good.  It's too much for one person, btw.  Share it with a friend or two and then bounce of the walls of Mint Alley for an hour.

I also love the poached eggs.
author: Joe C.

description:
I recently had Blue Bottle Coffee at a restaurant and had to try their coffee selection at this cafe.  Located near the old San Francisco mint, the area surrounding it has come a long way from the drab and dreary past.

What I love best about their coffee is the strength and full body flavor.  I have to say this is the only coffee that doesn't upset my tummy even with its strength.

On different times, I ordered the New Orleans coffee and the single espresso.  The New Orleans coffee is an iced coffee with a small amount of chicory and served with milk and sugar.  No need to worry about the chicory affecting the coffee flavor, as the coffee holds up on its own.  The single espresso packs quite a punch but is very, very good too.

Hands down, I have to say that this is the best coffee in San Francisco!
author: Janet H.

description:
Had the Kyoto style iced coffee recently because it was already late in the day and they stopped serving siphon pots. wah, I'll have to postpone that to next time.

The iced coffee was soooo good though. Very strong, but not bitter, super smooth, with light hints of caramel and spice. After a glass, I was totally wired for a couple hours. lol! o_O

I would have bought some whole beans for my automatic espresso machine at home, but I already have a ton of beans to go through. Definitely next time though!
author: Kenny J.

description:
I don't drink coffee, but my husband does, so Blue Bottle was on his "must visit" list for our weekend trip to San Francisco. We got there around 10am on a Sunday, and there were maybe one or two people ahead of us in line.  He ordered a siphon set with a belgian waffle. I ordered a cafe au lait (when in rome). As soon as we ordered we managed to score two window seats. 

The waffle and my au lait came out first - it takes a little bit longer to prepare the siphon coffee. I liked my coffee, I could tell that it was of a better quality even though I don't drink coffee often if at all. Actually, I haven't had coffee since I lived in NY within walking distance of Abraço, owned by a former blue bottle employee. If anyone would like a comparison, I prefer Abraço. His au lait is thicker, creamier and the cafe has a warmer, friendlier air, but now I'm getting off track. My husband confirmed that the cafe au lait was great. He drinks them everyday, so I'd trust him. The waffle, oh my god, it was amazing! Buttery deliciousness! 

When the siphon came out, the guy offered a few friendly tips: drink the first cup without any milk/sugar, be warned that it brings out flavors you wouldn't expect. My husband really enjoyed it. Its not something you drink everyday, but its definitely a great treat. We'll be back next time we visit SF!
author: Aryn F.

description:
I have to bump up the rating I gave Bluebottle, I've come here several times since my first visit and they've haven't run out of coffee which is a bonus. The coffee is definitely the best I've had downtown, it really gives you a jolt like no other coffee shop near by.

If you're willing to splurge try the mocha, it's fairly pricey at $4.50 but it really is the best mocha in SF (at least in my opinion). Still can't give it fives stars though, pretty pricey, takes a really long time to get any drink and the staff are consistently snooty. I think it's that the staff are trained to be coffee snobs so if you don't know have a PhD in coffee you're likely to get some attitude.
author: Bryan B.

description: Coffee and I have an extremely platonic relationship. I enjoy its aroma and appreciate its flavors, but never ever do I crave or desire it. But the mocha here is something I'd definitely tap. And multiple times too. I'd even possibly consider dating. But we'll see.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Come for the spectacle...just not on a weekend.

We were there on a weekday...and I can report that yes, 9 out of 10 visitors read about it in the New York Times. I asked.

The siphon-made coffee is good...very good. But at $10-$12 for the cup, you better not put any milk or sugar in it...that'll betray your low-brow roots. And embarrass your friends with their American Express Black cards.
author: Lindley E.

description: So I just tried the kyoto style iced coffee upon the barrista's suggestion and I'm in love. Amazing flavor and so refreshing! Only dissapointing thing is no wi-fi
author: Audrey B.

description:
Look up in the sky! It's a bird! It's a plane! It's...stephy s?

That's right folks, I am pretty much glued to the ceiling on a caffeine high after drinking a latte from this place 20 minutes ago. I've often wondered what speed or crack felt like and well, if this is it, call Intervention and book me, cuz I am done!

I am normally not a coffee drinker. It's a rare and very "blue" moon when I will agree to down some of this liquid fuel, but today it sounded good and after walking a chilly 4 or 5 blocks, I was definitely game and minus the severe shakes I am having right now, I enjoyed their offerings.

As for the place, well, it rang a little pretentious to me and $5 for a mocha and almost $4 for a latte, hmmm, seems a little pricey. Also they only have one size, so if you need more or less than their alloted portion, maybe go elsewhere. The looks of it is definitely minimalist which goes well with their small coffee menu, but honestly, it just felt like the kind of place that was super impressed with their own self-appointed cool factor. Maybe for the coffee obsessed this place would be worth a refill, but for this caffeine chicken, meh, I'll probably pass next time.
author: Stephy S.

description:
Perhaps some of the best drip coffee in the city. Everytime I come in I feel like I'm giving myself a special treat. 

However if you're a user of the Foursquare app for the iPhone beware of checking in too often. You may just unlock the douchebag badge. (I may or may not have experienced this.)
author: Aaron M.

description: Coffee is worth the wait. Double Chocolate cookie is worth the drive..... Decor is cool and they know coffee and are much less pretentious than 4 Barrel.
author: John R.

description:
Good lord, why do I even bother reviewing this place? Yum, yum...and more yum.. 

In case you haven't heard, this is on the top 100 places to visit for eating or drinking in your life. Well, at least in my book. Too bad it overlooks dilapidated run-down SF historical architecture but perhaps that will come to change in time...
author: Yelper A.

description: What the hell is a Starbucks? This place is changing the coffee industry. I come here from time to time for a latte and they have not let me down yet. The price is good and the coffee is on point. I love the quiet seating area and the crowd of people that Blue Bottle attracts .
author: Anthony C.

description:
I have a sordid love affair with coffee and if its bad so is my day. 

Blue Bottle has some great tasting coffee that never disappoints.


It's too bad that they think they are the best coffee place in the world and their service, attitude, and price reflect that. A good Latte doesn't have to cost almost 6 bucks and be served without so much as "have a nice day" or "Thanks for letting us anally rape you while your grandpa watches". I would have to literally break down in front of this place in order to patronize them again. For all you people who can afford it and love it that's great. But I'm not pulling down a six figure income and I cant afford to spend money just for the sake of spending it.
author: Brad B.

description:
She saw the pop eye toast cooking and thought she'd like to try it.  I figured, why the hell not, we could eat here, try out this amazing coffee, and take a half pound of espresso beans to go.  I decided to go for the "waffle set" -- a waffle and a pot of siphoned coffee.  Of course, I had to try the coffee.

The pop eye toast came first, two crunchy slices of brioche, each with a perfect circle cut through them, the hole replaced with a fried egg, served on a small square plate.  The presentation was fantastic.  But the actual dining experience wasn't; the plate was small, the toast was hard to cut through, and since it was carrying an egg in the middle, it wasn't exactly finger food.

In a way that pop eye toast represents what Blue Bottle Cafe felt like.  A little cramped, presented with flair, but not at all comfortable with being taken too seriously.

Of course the star of the show was the siphoned coffee.  As you watch it brewing, a miracle of physics as water in the pot bubbles, stirs, and ascends into the beaker filled with ground beans above it. The barista casually stirs the beans, churning a thick, earthy foam, and removes it from the heat, allowing the coffee to swirl back into the pot.  Inside, a hot, perfectly translucent brew.  And it tastes just like...black coffee.

I do have an espresso machine at home, have tried a variety of beans between Peet's Coffee and Whole Foods and occasionally pick up a canister of Illy's.  I also had a latte at Vivace Roasteria in Seattle, which I thought was amazing.  I also had the New Orleans iced coffee at the Blue Bottle Kiosk in Hayes Valley, which I also enjoyed.  I think I'm just starting to grasp the ins'n outs of coffee.  And but the coffee at the cafe just didn't cut it.

A lot of people looked like they were here just because it was the "cool" place to be.  Some of them even taking pictures it was so cool, like part of some live exhibit.  But the whole thing was just a little silly.  The food was pretty plain.  Didn't come with any preserves, no breakfast sausages, not even a garnish.  And the beans I brought home, a half pound of Retrofit Espresso, was alright, but I was less than amazed.

If you come to Blue Bottle Cafe, come here to watch the siphon show, but skip the brunch.  And if you're seriously looking for a cozy coffee shop to relax in, you may be better off looking elsewhere.
author: Tony L.

description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Blue Bottle Coffee.  So smooth! The New Orleans Iced is simply amazing. Since discovering Blue Bottle a few years ago, we order all of our coffee from Blue Bottle online and have it delivered to Nebraska.  There is just no way to describe it except "Simply the BEST!" You will not be disappointed, trust me!  It is just such high quality!  I use a coffee press and am amazed every morning how wonderful it tastes!!!!
author: Lisa I.

description:
There's a $25000 coffee brewing machine that looks like it was designed by HG Wells, and everyone in line bought filter-coffee.  Despite the atmosphere of spidery, hipster Morlocks and docile, Los Angelesian, "include a headshot with your resume," Eloi baristi, it is still Blue Bottle coffee and I just can't stay mad.

Since this is relevant and Yelp doesn't include it:  there's no official bike parking, and stable structures are sparse, so avoid the morning rush.

Update:
There's pretty generous bike parking now!
author: Jon B.

description:
I'm trying to get into Blue Bottle for the sake of my BF, who is hardcore about it and thinks it is the greatest thing since sliced bread (well, no...I guess he actually thinks it is the greatest thing since Ritual or Philz Coffee, which would make more sense). In any case, he goes through these coffee phases every six months or so, and Blue Bottle is in very high rotation right now! 

I've accompanied him about three times now, and I've had the new orleans style iced coffee, the kyoto style iced coffee, and the cafe au lait. Their coffee is damn strong! I swear it kept me up until 5 am one time, which was frustrating because I wanted to go to sleep...so plan accordingly, people...no afternoon coffee! I've also tried some of their food, which has always been on a sunday, so I don't know if they serve it the rest of the week, but the tomato soup souffle thingie and the the toast with jam is really good! Everything here is on the pricey side, but it is all very good quality.

Lastly, the environment of this place is definitely cool, with a sort of science lab feel to it (they have these crazy machines for brewing the coffee that seriously look like they are from a different time and place, you've gotta see it!) Overall, Blue Bottle is not an everyday type of coffee destination for me, but it is an "experience," and at least I know where I can go now to get super caffeinated for an all-nighter!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Blue Bottle isn't the pinnacle of coffee drinking for me because I like the coffee at Bernie's better. However, it is probably the strongest coffee I've ever drank outside of Tu Lan. I tried the siphon bar coffee once and I don't think I'll ever order it again simply because I don't think I can appreciate it enough to warrant the outlandish price. I still respect the owner for trying to take coffee drinking to the next level though.

On a couple of occasions they've run out of the New Orelans-style iced coffee -- the only thing they make that I greatly enjoy. It's understandable enough that they'd run out but pretty disappointing considering it's a bit of a hike to get there. The second time they ran out I asked if I could call ahead if it was a hot day to make sure they had some. Their response: "Actually, we don't have a phone". 

The self-flagellating seriousness with which Blue Bottle approaches coffee making and the absurdity with which they approach everything else will keep me from giving them five stars anytime soon.
author: Aaron V.

description:
So I really like the coffee at Blue Bottle. I like watching them brew the individual pots of coffee in the glass carafes. I love the new orleans iced coffee and I love going there when there isn't a line. This is the problem though... when is there not a line?

The line is huge and there is very little uncomfortable sitting. The coffee at bluebottle is 4 star coffee, but the ambiance is lacking significantly. No seating, no service, and a very unfriendly area (5th and Mission... ick) Also, no wifi. (You're in SOMA with so many computer upstart companies in the industrial part of the city... you should have wifi).

I have experienced much better coffee houses. Bluebottle may be inventive with their ways of serving and their roasting system, but I prefer my coffee houses to have a bit more class and a more welcoming atmosphere than that...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Blue Bottle expands!

I stopped by here last night after the gym.  Was impressed by the decor...and amazed at how many people were there.

Typical great, blue bottle coffee....but now serving basic eats and wine!

Lucky for me this is where I take my fire dancing class so I'll be a regular here!
author: Melanie N.

description: My latte was so beautifully made, I almost didn't even want to drink it. Great coffee!
author: Derrick W.

description:
The cappuccino was unbelievably good on my first visit. However, on my second visit I ordered a mocha and it was barely lukewarm. A total disappointment on a cloudy, windy day. 
[(5 + 0)/2] + benefit of the doubt(0.5) = 3 stars
author: Jen S.

description:
I love the coffee (both the drip and the lattes).   And I do also try and brew my own Blue Bottle at home (with decent results, but not nearly as good as here or at one of the kiosks).

But great roasted coffee - not over-roasted, but subtle enough that you can still get the flavors.

The only downside is that every Blue Bottle place is always crowded!
author: Lynn S.

description:
At one point in my life, I have always imagine that one day I will find something that will make me want to wake up every morning.  The one thing that will make me want to live, like a great job, my future children or a really really great vacation.  Unfortunately, I have not found that ONE thing, so i compensate with caffeine.  =)   

Blue bottle has helped with that on many Friday mornings and eventful afternoons, when I needed an extra pick me up.  I dont drink it every morning, since I cannot handle waiting in line every morning, so I only go on friday mornings when I feel like I deserve it after a whole week.  The coffee is always consistently good.  Smooth as can be, no tartness, no bitterness.  I... since I am addicted to caffeine, get two cups of coffee each time.  That will last me all morning and part of afternoon.  Dont try it if you cant handle caffeine well.
author: Janet S.

description:
I am way too classy to hang out on Sixth and Mission, and I am way too old to hang out at the Metreon, so . . . it's no surprise that it took me a long time to make the trip to Blue Bottle.  My friend loves this place.  She had been raving about Blue Bottle since June, and I couldn't wait to try it.  I finally did, on the last day of 2008.

It's a good thing we showed up around 10 am; we walked in and the cashier took our order right away.  15 minutes later, the place was literally overflowing with people waiting to pay good money for coffee made from the "finest organic, pesticide-free, shade-grown beans." I ordered a prosciutto and poached egg on toast and a cup of regular coffee.  My friend had french toast and a Cafe Au Lait.  Total bill for the two of us - $21.54.  Not bad at all.

We noticed two seats at the counter and sat down. These were actually the best seats in the house, because your only seating choices included a long, wide table in the middle, a long narrow counter along the wall or the counter by the cashier.  Our counter was separated from the "kitchen" by a thick pane of glass, which allowed us to enjoy the view.  

The view was very unique: it's hard to describe it, but if I had to, I'd say it was a cross between Jesse Duke's barn where he made his famous moonshine and a good, old-fashioned meth lab.  Water boiling in beakers on tiny burners, copper wires, siphoning . . .  We were sitting there wondering what the hell was going on. 

Then the coffee and the food came.  My coffee was extremely strong with a bold, unmistakable aroma.  If I hadn't had six cup of coffee the day before, I would have still been bouncing off the walls.  My breakfast was OK, but not spectacular.  The prosciutto seemed a little overcooked, although the poached egg was perfect.  It was an interesting take on Eggs Benedict: prosciutto and poached egg served on thick white toast.

I admit it, the coffee was 5 stars, the food was about 3.5, but the ambiance . . . maybe 2.  Overall, an "A-OK" experience.

What happened to the whole idea of coffee houses where you can sit down and relax?  If I wanted to sit on a bar stool and pretend not to notice people hovering over my seat hoping I'd leave, I'll go to some place inside the Oakland Airport.  If this place wants to be hip, they need to add some comfortable seating.  If not, just get rid of the seating area and serve your coffee to go.  Oh, and what's with the "one-size-fits-all" idea?  It's America, we need choices.  How about a big gulp size 44-oz coffee cup or a kids' size 6-oz coffee cup?

If I do come back here, I am skipping the food and taking my coffee to go!
author: Yan G.

description: Hallelujah! The coffee tastes like coffee and smells like coffee. If you are from the southern hemisphere and have caffeine withdrawals this is the place to go. It was quite busy when I was there but the wait was only 5 minutes, the food looked delicious too. I'll definitely be back
author: Wendy C.

description:
Coffee rating: it's excellent.  As for the drip, as usual, it's delicious (for the same grounds and drip, check out Velo Rouge around USF).  As for the fancy, whatchamacallit machine coffee: it's expensive.  At 11 bucks for a bowl (yes, it comes in an odd bowl with a handle) it may be a bit over priced -- but perhaps we're paying for the cost of the machine.  The taste of the fancy stuff is one word: weird.  It's like coffee but missing an acid tone.  While I thought it was endlessly drinkable, I'd prefer to just stick to the plain drip: and if you drink it here, it's delicious.  I imagine this fancy stuff would go over well with somebody just becoming acquainted to coffee.

The service was great.  The waitress/busser/whatever was amazingly friendly, full of tips, and like a hawk to clean up cups and dishes.  

The inside of this place is kind of dull -- I could tell they were trying to move from the traditional coffee shop "three person table" to the more space effective bar set up -- and it's alright, but this type of organization often leads to people milling about when it gets crowded.  This is precisely what happened when 6 O'Clock rolled around and 90% of the financial district streamed in for a taste of the Blue Bottle.

If you can, go in an off peak hour, and try the fancy stuff if you're usually a bit of a coffee wuss.  

Also: did not see any wireless -- but that might be because I was checking with my iPhone.
author: jack p.

description: Any fellow coffee aficionado, needs to do his / her pilgrimage here.  It is like Willy Wonka Land for coffee.
author: Björn Å.

description:
I'm a iced coffee lover and the Kyoto iced coffee here is off the hook. There are other ways to make this style of iced coffee, but they obviously chose a better method. They take a lot of care and interest in their coffee and its preparation, and it comes through in the flavor. The price can be a little steep, but it's worth an occasional trip.  

This location is a great place to stop for a moment to enjoy a cup of coffee, grab a bite to eat, and watch the siphon pots heat over the UCC loaned halogen lamps.
author: ryan c.

description:
WOOHOO! is right! 

I'm wired and Blue Bottle Coffee is to blame!

 Great coffee and beautiful atmosphere. The staff is really friendly and represents Blue Bottle very well. Um yeah.. and they're cute too. 

  A blessing and a curse, it is conveniently located a block away from my work. There is always a line, so its good to get there early, or at least before the "rush" hits..but I haven't figured that out yet, because there always seems to be a "rush". 

My fave is the latte', but I have sampled others. The Iced coffee rocks, but beware it makes one SO energized that one cup will make the rest of your day full of stuttering and speed walking EVERYWHERE.

 Goodness. I'm exhausted now.
author: First C.

description:
Elitist coffee! I understand that you get what you pay for, but jeez! How much money can you spend to calm your conscience?

Sure it's organic, sure it's shade grown, sure it's fair trade. But you needlessly spend cash on expensive coffee; but by the same token you won't give a homeless person change?

After your $20 cup of joe, maybe you can go and get into your super expensive 8 cylinder SUV and contribute your fair share of greenhouse gases. 

But who cares? You soul is saved because you bought that cup of coffee!

Get a grip!
author: Danny S.

description:
Shit.

No, Blue Bottle Cafe n'est pas la merde.  That was simply my reaction when I realized the character that it's positioned to have.

Fair enough.  The opening day crowd was a bellowing mass of ignorant hipster doofuses.  Expected!  The baristas were more Abercrombie servers than funky coffee people - I served up the softball question of why siphon brew can't be had to go, and got "It's corporate policy?" as an answer.  Corporate?  With a question mark?  Yeah, exactly.  I also don't want to buy a dessert with the Nipponese wunderbrew for $10+.. what's up with the scummy package upsells?

The usual coffee's good as expected but the pretentious factor is off the charts.  Blue Bottle Jr. and the happy beanslingers that live there are still my favorite, but I can't see going to the Cafe on purpose.  It adds nothing to the experience in the old Blue Bottle character that I had hoped to find in a second location.  I'd probably give this place two stars had it no connection to the garage-osk (and one yellow star if the coffee wasn't so well done).  Four stars if things work out after the crowds disperse.  Five red stars of justice for to-go siphon juice!

I'll try again in a few months.  Hopefully I'll get an Americano in under ten minutes at that point!  There's a lot of potential of where this place could go, and I'm hopeful that at least one or two of the employees are interested in talking coffee.  I want my boiled ham sandwich back on the line, not the boeuf Wellington on white linen in the front of the house.. ya dig?

To sum it all up: the cameras were getting in the way of waiting for my coffee.  That's pretty apropos of the whole experience.
author: K M.

description:
I was clearly not hip enough to be in this place.

Also, the coffee was exceedingly mediocre... and may have, in fact, been burnt.  When I asked if I could have an iced mocha, I was refused.  "Yeah, we have like, iced coffees and iced lattes, but we don't do iced mochas."

But they do make regular mochas... then can I please just have a regular mocha and a cup of ice?  The iced mocha was clearly too pedestrian for the baristas of Blue Bottle.

I'm sure there are better coffee shops in this city.  But if you want to be seen (and "scene"), then definitely go here.
author: b. R. c.

description:
I was so excited to learn that Blue Bottle was only a few blocks away from our hotel.  My first morning in SF, I had a latte from Blue Bottle, complete with latte art.  I LOVED MY LATTE.  Even my husband, who is not a coffee drinker, appreciated the tastiness of this drink.  Not too bitter, not too milky...just right.  My husband had the apple cider, which was not made by Blue Bottle, but it was also good.  The cinnamon brioche was tasty, but tiny.  The snickerdoodle cookie was not like any snickerdoodle I ever had, it was more of a vanilla-saffron (yes, saffron) cakey-butter cookie.  I liked it, but it's not a snickerdoodle.

My second morning in SF, I returned to Blue Bottle wanting to try the plain ol' drip coffee.  The coffee was a little more acidic than I prefer, but it still tasted good.  I also noticed that the coffee looked a little...hmm, oily (?), which may be attributable to the way they make the coffee.  This time, we had another snickerdoodle and the Gruyere-Bacon Brioche which I liked better than the cinnamon brioche.  Generous amount of bacon in this little nubbin of a brioche.

On my next visit to Blue Bottle, I will definitely have their latte again, and maybe try their much talked about mocha.  I would also like to try their hot breakfast /brunch items.  I didn't realize they served other food items until I saw oatmeal, poached eggs, toasts etc. coming out of the kitchen.  I thought it was a secret menu that only the locals knew about...until I saw the breakfast/brunch menu on the counter on my second visit.
author: CB R.

description: Great tasting lattes with beautiful coffee art. Also loved their brandy cake - moist and delish!
author: Irina N.

description: Great coffee.  Had the cafe au lait which came in an enormous cup/bowl.  Pleasant place to sit. Communal tables and long queue which moves at a decent pace.
author: Pig E.

description:
If the soup nazi, an art gallery and the owners of several speakeasies got together and decided to open up a coffee shop, Blue Bottle would be the result.

There is a respect for bean here, the making of each cup by hand - to order - and no non-sense: it is frowned upon to order any double-whip-non-fat-soy-vanilla..blah blah blah.

There is a reverence observed even by its patrons...everyone enjoying the coffee quietly, having what I assumed to be extremely intellectual conversation and pretty much minding their own beeswax.

The goods themselves are delectable, unadulterated and simply what coffee was supposed to be before D&D or Starbucks infiltrated the market and destroyed any authenticity. Okay, maybe that is a little harsh, but  try the coffee and experience this for yourself I am sure there will be very little to debate about.

I'll certainly be enjoying a cup whenever I am in town!
author: Leighann F.

description: Tasty espresso, interesting drip, and nice shortbreads. But it wasn't hot (4 times), so what's the point?
author: Arjun K.

description:
4 of my 5 last visits and always a line to the door; both weekday, weekend and various times of day. Ok, I don't mind a line, but once you order, there's the wait. I've been to this location at least a dozen times since opening and it's 10 minutes or more to get your drink. The last three times, I turned around and left. It's just coffee, not rocket science. 

I also have a problem with their food cut-off rule. Try to order some toast at 11:30am and you'll get "I'm sorry, the kitchen is closed." I look around - the toaster and bread are right there... but, no, they can't help out. It's not like I've ordered some elaborate breakfast. Some items, say toast, should be available all day. Come on!

Yes, the coffee is good, but it's not worth the delays and attitude. If you really want the "coffee nazi" experience, check out Ritual Roasters.
author: Philip M.

description:
Love the unmarked facade, the whiteness, the surfboard-esque table, the secret drink, the weird alchemy copper coffee distillation setup (Jodorowsky, anyone)?

I love secret coffee places. Being an out of towner in SF and being introduced to this place, and the "secret, not on the menu drink" made me feel special.

A little pricey like everything in SF.
author: Marianne G.

description: Love this coffee purveyor.  I splurge here, whole milk, no skim like I usually do, and it becomes a real treat.  Busy, but staff is always friendly.
author: So D.

description: I give only two stars because I was expecting more of a baked selection like they offer in NY. There are only cookies. What a mistake on their behalf considering you're waiting around for 10 minutes or longer for a cup of joe. They do offer a light continental breakfast but I'm a drink-eat-walk-the-dog kind of guy when it comes to a coffee shop.
author: Bob H.

description:
Have been going to BB for years in all the locations and like the coffee and have gotten used to the long wait just to order, anything - but - had I known it was going to be a progressive breakfast, I would have thought twice!

Went to the Mint location, alone, this morning around 9:30 AM for a latte and some breakfast. The line was short, only 4 to 6 people ahead of me so I went for it. The cashier spent a lot of time with the people ahead of me and my latte sat for 5 or 10 minutes until I could order a waffle. Then I had to stand and wait for an opening at a table since quite a few people were camped out chatting it up. Finally got a seat and then waited another 15 or 20 minutes for the food to arrive. By this time my latte was cold so I asked it it could be warmed up to match the warm food. Nope,  but I could order another and wait for that. 

Woulda been nice if the person taking my order had offered the extra hot option or even offered to deliver the latte with the food. I had no idea it would take this long to get the food out, especially since it wasn't an overly busy morning. There isn't an option for a refill or  a warm up on the coffee so would be nice if the management was a little more service oriented and made some recommendations when you are ordering since the clientele have no idea how slow the service might be. I was there for almost an hour, having my lukewarm/cold coffee then having my waffle with a glass of water! Nice!
author: Vince N.

description:
Hm...After hearing so many good things about this place, i was surprised at how pretentious everyone was. Maybe it's just the location. But we're talking in the "not so nice neighborhood" between 5th and 6th street just off of Mission.
So, I walk in one afternoon, and the first thing I thought was, "is this for real?" The baristas were very snooty, the people were sitting on their stools, talking about basically nothing, and the place itself just had a very cold feeling. I did order a mocha, which was okay, and I did buy a a pound of their coffee to take home (which honestly I found just average). I am giving 3 stars as I have had their coffee at the Farmer's Market and the staff is nicer there.
I do suggest either trying their other place or checking them out at the Farmer's Market. But don't waste your time going to this location.
author: Jan Z.

description:
"If you have to ask, you can't afford it..."  So I had to ask about the pricing for the Siphon pot coffee.  $9-11 depending on the beans.  

Those little pots remind me of my father making coffee in the morning when I was a kid.  He used to make my aunts bring the intricate pots over from Hong Kong for him whenever my mother used to break some part of them.  

So imagine my surprise when I see it is in front of every hipster next to their macs.  Dude, I knew my dad was cool.

I'm not a regular coffee drinker by any means but I do enjoy the occasional soy cappuccino.  Their New Orleans style iced coffee is really quite excellent; not too sweet with some chicory.  I can't wait for another hot day.

The cafe is definitely an upgrade from the garage space in Hayes Valley.  There is good seating and beautiful windows to gaze out of.  Due to the neighborhood, sometimes it is better to look at the window rather that out to the street. An alternative view: the molding on the ceiling is gorgeous.  

I live in the same building as a Starbucks but I'd gladly walk the three blocks towards disgusting 6th Street for their coffee when I'm in the mood.
author: Monica L.

description:
This is simply true excellence in an american coffee shop.  I have not had better shots anywhere in the US, staff is excellent, food is interesting and high quality, location is interesting, nice inside, etc.

Only downside is line length and speed it moves, but nothing is perfect.
author: Eric L.

description:
On advice of the Barrista I had a New Orleans iced coffee...soooo good! Not too sweet, hint of chicory, smooth smooth smooth. I gave a friend a sip, and she promptly ordered one at the next BB we encountered (at SFMOMA).

LOVE this place and their funky science lab-ish process!
author: Susan M.

description: I am very critical with how my mocha's taste because I have experience in the coffee world. When I first came to Blue Bottle Coffee Co I was very impressed and pleased. The only thing which I consider normal and a tad annoying for a high populated place, is the lonnng line. The barista's present their drinks very lovely and presentable. I have tried a few things from their menu. One of which I enjoyed was the Poached eggs with braised greens. Their Kyoto style iced coffee is def an eye opener, you will feel the jolt of the caffeine from this drink. This drink is def recommended for coffee lovers.
author: Grace V.

description:
4.5 Stars...

Two words: Secret Breakfast. Give em the side wink and say those words = tasty affogato confection. The melted ice cream and espresso soup was so thick, rich, and quality; a delectable treat. 

Yes, it can be a bit pricey, but when it comes to what Im lookin for in a coffee spot (unique, funky, vibrant) blue bottle is the perfect urban manifestation. So I'm over that. Give a lil love, get a lil love.
author: Nicole C.

description:
If you've never had Blue Bottle Coffee, then you haven't been living the good life. Their coffee is amazing! Chocolately, smooth, dark, rich. Yes, you'll have to wait at least 10 minutes for drip coffee or espresso drinks, but it's worth it. Otherwise, buy the beans at $7 - $7.50 for half a pound and make it at home. Love!

Read more on my blog: http://www.yummysf.com/blue-bottle-coffee/
author: Fanny S.

description:
This review is about the SERVICE.

I went to Soma Blue Bottle on a blustery March evening right before catching a movie at the Mezzanine and thought, what better way to warm up than with a nice cup of coffee. There was no line, I thought to myself, this is going to be easy-peasy.

So I walk in and order a decaf coffee. The tall-skinny fembot behind the counter mutters, NO DECAF. Wha?? Okay, maybe I'm asking for too much so I ask if they have herb tea. Fembot says NO. Green tea is my only choice. So I think about it for a minute, knowing I'm not really supposed to have caffeine (I'm extremely sensitive) but not wanting to walk out empty handed I agree to the green tea.

Fast forward 10 minutes. I'm still waiting for my tea. People who ordered a lot later than me are getting their fancy barista espresso drinks. I try to make eye contact with Fembot. She won't look in my direction. I feel like yelling. I contain myself. I walk up to the counter and look for my tea. I can't see it. Did she forget? No, I thought I saw her pouring the hot water and dropping the tea bag inside. But where is it? I start pacing nervously. I come back to the counter and lean on it. No one makes eye contact with me. I start fidgeting. FINALLY, a different barista hands me my green tea with a smile. I grab it and leave wondering what I did to deserve such horrible treatment.

I realize that I may have gotten this treatment because I didn't dump money into the tip jar at the time I placed my order. But STUPID FEMBOTS need to realize that people tip AFTER service NOT BEFORE. So if you didn't get a tip it's because no one should have to wait 12+ minutes for a stinking glass of green tea. You could have just given me the hot water and tea bag and I could have accomplished the task in 2 seconds. Easy-peasy.
author: L. L.

description:
Heads up, that siphon coffee they have siphons the cash out of your wallet quicker then you can say "Get your butt offa that stool can't you see my stuff I'm sitting there!".

My take on the beakerific brew - its good, better then the extremely bitter drip and espresso experienced at the Hayes location, but still more acidic then expected. The question is, is it really worth the high cost, and I can't rightly say it is considering the as good or better coffee I've had for much less (and the same goes for the lukewarm quiche). But you might not agree, it could send you into throes of mildly caffeinated ecstasy,  so I'd say go ahead and try it if you enjoy a good cuppa joe.   Watching the science experiment brewing is fun too.

Conclusion: a bean scene whose coffee costs a latte. 

3 1/2 stars nice new location considered.
author: GIR ..

description:
We stopped in here twice before leaving town - first time I ordered the NO style iced coffee (delish) and the second time I caved & ordered one of the self serve siphon pots.  It was neat to see the whole siphon pot process in person.  I know there are dozens of videos on YouTube, but the idea is to be able to DRINK the coffee, not just look at it.

It was worth it just for the experience - very good coffee, I grabbed a bag of 11ft ceiling for the road.

The interior is very pretty, with large windows, but the streets/alleys you need to walk down to get there leave a lot to be desired, but hey - it's not Blue Bottles fault, and I made it out alive.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
On my ever-expanding quest for good coffee in the Market Street area, I stopped by Blue Bottle this past Sunday morning to try their individually prepared drip coffee.  All I can say is 'Wow!' because that coffee was caffeinated to the nth degree.  It was a little too strong for me, but it did wake me up and keep me going for most of the day.  The coffee, though strong, was not bitter and did not leave that nasty coffee after-taste- instead, there was a very distinct after-taste of dark, unsweetened chocolate.

It was a little intimidating ordering coffee here just because the whole operation looks like a mad scientist's lab and everyone seems really serious about their coffee.  Someone is stirring a pot of dark brew in the corner (I think I heard that it was chicory), while there's a chemistry set of boiling water in another corner.  There are some nifty-looking individual glass containers of coffee that people are drinking from that I want to order if only I could figure out what they are.

In any case, this Blue Bottle Cafe offers Sunday brunch, so you could order items like Croque Madame, Acme toast with butter and jam, white bean cassoulet, and Belgian waffle with fruit compote.  Because of this, the line is pretty long on Sundays as everyone is trying to find a place to sit, dine, chat, enjoy their coffee and read the paper.   

I'd be back to try more of their other drinks, like the Cafe Mocha and the hot chocolate made from Recchiuti chocolate.  Be aware that they only offer organic half and half and sugar- you'll have to bring your own if you use artificial sweeteners.  The only other thing that I would add to their menu is some pastries because I was dying for a scone to go with the coffee.
author: Angela H.

description: Coffee was alright but not super impressed with what we ordered. VERY busy too be prepared to wait a while in line..
author: Lisa S.

description: I added this cafe as "to-do" in my Foursquare app. And was informed that it was nearby when I wandered around the SF downtown. Then paid a visited. Spent an amazing afternoon there. Awesome coffee to taste, nice in door environment to enjoy (though small..), and beautiful people to watch. Nice memories.
author: Yuancheng Y.

description:
You can drop the attitude, coffee shop cashier.  I, too, have tattoos and generally hate people, but unlike you, I treat them like crap only after they piss me off.  You sir, piss me off.  

You asked me if wanted to take my gingerbread to go.  When I said 'yes,'  you tell me in an annoyed and pissy tone that you dont have any to-go containers.  Why the hell did you ask me then?  

Is this all the grad school department has to offer these days?
author: brewgirl b.

description:
This is more of a coffee stop than a coffee shop. But it's my favorite that I've found here in SF so far.

I drink an Americano and theirs looks and tastes fantastic.  My americano here is consistently creamy, fruity and rich. It's a bit out of my way to get to their semi-hidden Mint street location but worth it.

Haven't sampled anything besides the espresso, but really that's all I need.
author: Alan F.

description: I've now had drips and lattes here and can definitely say this is some of the best coffee I've ever had. It takes a while but I enjoy the result and is worth the wait. I swore on my last visit that my hubby ordered a vanilla latte so I tried to get the same thing. They don't make flavored drinks I was told, but the soy milk was vanilla and it made an awesome latte.  And they were playing some Erykah Badu remixes while I was waiting in line, so I felt at home :)
author: Lesly S.

description:
So I finally got a chance to try the cafe. Wow, I love what James has done =)

Ordered a macchiato and tried the siphon. Macchiato was great as usual. I usually get them at the kiosk on Linden or at the Ferry Building so nothing new. Clean, well done. I'd been looking forward to the siphon ever since they opened up, and it didn't disappoint. And barista was right - it really sweetened up as it started to cool down. It tasted . . . alive. Best way I could describe it.

This is how coffee should be.
author: Mike W.

description:
For those of you who "just want a cup of coffee", you can go to any place that serves coffee since you probably won't be able to tell what good coffee is. This is not to poke fun, but some real advice. Blue Bottle charges more than average for "just a cup", why pay more if you can't tell the difference?

The siphon bar coffee is very good, however sometimes it is hit or miss. The coffee tends to come out with a slightly greater than average burnt note, but it isn't unpleasant. I have had some of the best tasting coffee from the bar, and I have also had some pretty good, but expensive coffee. I would say it is a mix between drip or pour over clean-ness, with a little more body and depth of flavor.

Their espresso drinks are consistently great. Their espresso and milk have been consistently excellent, and that is all I care about in this review. If a cafe has done its espresso and milk correctly, that cafe is better than 99.9% of all cafes out there.

I believe there are only four places in San Francisco that do so: Blue Bottle, Four Barrel, Ritual, and Haus, and three of those are in the Mission. Keep in mind, that they do not serve espresso or macchaitos to go, as well they shouldn't.

Their breakfast is very good, but also very expensive. If you are at all conscious about staying on a budget, you should not eat the food here. I usually get the toast with jam and butter ($4), which comes with two huge pieces of fresh toast, fresh jam and whipped butter. It is the best toast I have ever had, and I certainly paid for it. Breakfast and the siphon bar start at 8am.

Some people have complained about the speed of service. You must be used to the vacuum thermoses at Starbucks and Peets and every other cafe, not ground-to-order and dripped/siphoned-to-order coffee. If you got espresso, you would have noticed that they ground, leveled, and tamped their portafilters pretty quickly. They are clearly highly skilled and experienced baristas. The reason Starbucks can churn out the espresso is because their employees press a button and out comes the espresso. I think some Peets use Swift grinders, which tamp for them. I have no problem with the service, it's friendly and very fast for what you get.

I don't visit for the atmosphere or location, I visit because it's the only place downtown that does coffee right.
author: Kelly M.

description:
There are better/cheaper/faster coffee shops all over San Francisco. 

Their coffee is certainly freshly roasted and some of their blends are quite nice (though they only carry a few). And their brewing methods -- practically the whole point of going there -- are up to par, when they're functioning properly. It's all show though. Is a fancy vacuum pot really THAT much better than manual-drip-style (how they do their drip coffee)? I don't know for sure, but I don't think so. 

And if you're on a budget, don't even think about it.
author: Chris L.

description:
My love-hate relationship with Blue Bottle (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blue-bottle-coffee-co-oakland#hrid:7V5TJiYNy9QdKBgZ7M_cKA) continues at the new Mint Plaza location.  The coffee absolutely blows my mind, but equally mind-blowing is the long wait to actually get the coffee.  I nearly gnawed my hand off waiting in line on Saturday morning, and it wasn't even crowded at the time.  They really need to figure out a way to serve their addicted customers faster...

BTW, Blue Bottle, your new space is oh-so-sleek and cool.  Please please please don't let your newfound celebrityhood get to your head and affect the quality of your coffee!  It happened to my first true love (Peets)--I just can't bear to see it happen again.
author: Sharyn F.

description:
Probably the best coffee I've ever had. 
Fun place to take any coffee lover. Incredible coffee apparatus behind the counter. Atmosphere is clean and efficient. 
Employees are polite, but it seems like they take absolutely no joy in their work and they aren't very friendly. This is probably why the place has a reputation for being 'snooty'. It's not a bad attitude - they just don't seem to care. It's how I imagine workers at a coffee shop were in Russia back in the days of communism.
You can't be in a hurry. Getting a simple cup of coffee will take 15-20 mins - and that's if there's no line (and there always is). But the wait (if you have time to spare) is worth it.
author: Michael B.

description: seems like kind of a local secret, and very popular! it was packed on saturday morning and we had to park a couple blocks down. had a latte and it was amazing!
author: Spenser D.

description:
OVERRATED. They got my order wrong TWICE. YEa the coffee was smooth and nice but whatever, I asked for it to go, they made it to stay. Then they insisted on throwing that away to make it right. I ordered soy and got cow juice, yuk. sorry, pay attention.  
I had a great experience at the HAyes Valley location. monchichi barista and all, cute.
author: Ed R.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is amazingly delicious and I love it. That said, the Blue Bottle Cafe is my least favorite place to get it. The space is clean and modern and blue-green inside, with narrow bars and barstools to perch upon, if there are any available. The place is jam-packed with other coffee lovers, and the open spaces are so narrow that you must turn sideways while waiting for your coffee for the slim servers to scoot by you (also sideways)... so narrow and crowded that on my most recent visit there I felt the breath of the man behind me in line hot on my neck (and we weren't together, as in lovers, nor were we trying to be). The acoustics are such that it's very loud and voices are amplified in there.


I am willing and happy to wait in line for Blue Bottle coffee, and I do, but I'd much rather do it at the Ferry Plaza Farmers' Market on a Saturday morning (my first choice), or at their Linden St. location. Piccino is also a good place to get BB coffee beans! I go to the Mint cafe location only if I'm desperate for their coffee beans.

I really do want to try the food, because I read that the chef here used to be the chef at Medicine Eatstation, but I will have to figure out when their "off" times are.
author: Dani Y.

description: Amazing New Orleans style ice coffee--my favorite. Place is also in a hard to find area, which is cool and unique.
author: Niki A.

description: My cap today was flat & watery.  I needed a strong and delicious pick me up, and Blue Bottle did not deliver.  Over the years. I've found that this has been my experience with Blue Bottle's espresso drinks (cappucinos, mochas, & lattes) - lacking in flavor.  But I was hesitant to share my less than positive review amidst the praise...that is until many tries at several BB locations, including at Mission Beach Cafe.  Perhaps I should opt for straight espresso or drip coffee in the future.  Also, am I missing something?  Are espresso drinks supposed to be served lukewarm nowadays?  Stars for its tasty sweets including homemade biscottis.
author: Amihan C.

description: They actually care. Went during a busy hour with lines going out the door. By the time I got to the front it was obvious I've never been there before and the employee helped me pick out a coffee to drink. I also wanted to take a 1/2 lb bag home to try and he took the time to ask me what kind of machine or method I use to brew and recommended a type of bean based on that. Even with a big line behind me the guy took the time to help me out and I never felt rushed. I plan on going back soon when I run out of coffee.
author: Anthony H.

description:
mmmm

after a crappy 1/2 day at work, i boarded the muni, got off powell, and found myself getting a cafe mocha at this place and just a whiff of it made my day so much better.

maybe it was the friendly staff at the counter. After he took my order he asked me, "how are you doing?" and he meant it. i was thinking to myself, do i have shit on my face or something? but it was probably the crappy day i was having that was showing. 

while staring at the $20,000 thingamajig, i heard them call my name. actually, i smelled the coffee and chocolate before. 

i don't know what to say. this place reeks of hip hip coffee chi chi place, but its worth the $5 coffee. but i must say this coffee really made my day better. thanks bbc!

thumbs up: decor  that makes you concentrate on the coffee goodness.
thumbs down: walking down the pee smelly alley... nasty.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Super cute, but $3.50 for an iced coffee that would be a small size even at starbucks is beyond redonkulous.  It was absolutely fantastic tasting, but absolutely fantastic / $3.50 creates steeply decreasing returns on bang per buck.
author: Tasha D.

description:
This is a cool place even if you don't like coffee. The technique they use is really fun to watch. 

I got an Americano, at first I was disappointed about the size but it was really yummy. Very smooth and rich. I would like to go back and try some other things.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Fabulous cappuchino - one of the best I've had outside of Italy. It was a bit crowded but we got a seat by the window. Very courteous service, and prompt - considering the crowd.

Returned this morning and someone who seemed like the manager said "I remember you from yesterday - non-fat cappuchinos, right?" We chatted about his coffees and what we drink at home (Stumptown). Had toast and jam to go with our drinks - great Acme bread and yummy jam. Plan to return tomorrow.
author: Stanley T.

description:
Truth be told, I didn't have the fancy coffee from the $20,000 machine.  On the bright side, they only have to sell 2000 cups of coffee to pay for it.  You do the math.

The price of coffee here is a little outrageous.  I ordered a cafe au lait for $3.50!  I know my coffee -- I even love my coffee.  But really, this was cafe au lait.  In a small coffee mug.

On the flip side, they have a few bits of breakfast food (polenta, toast and jam, Acme toast with melted butter and poached eggs), which was quite good.  The eggs were delicious.  But not as good as Cafe Fanny's.

Minimalist look = IKEA.
Bewildered look = staff.
Bonus = plenty of newspapers to read.
author: Rachel S.

description:
There are several reasons to like this place.

The coffee is really good.  The iced coffee is best I've had, and the siphoned coffee is great.

The hipsters that hang around here are funny to laugh at, the best of which are the new parents who are still trying to be hip while carrying a baby in a backpack.  Sorry, but "BabyBjorn" isn't as hip as you think.

It's great listening to people be overly-pretentious here, like the hipster ahead of me in line that asked "what's on the siphon today?" which in addition to being technically incorrect is also really funny.  It is fun to watch the coffee being made, though.

There are a few reasons not to like this place.

The coffee is expensive.   $10 for a "pot" of siphoned coffee for two people.

It takes a long time to get the coffee, around 20 minutes when  there's a crowd.  Service is also a little spotty due to the crowds.

They also don't sell pre-ground coffee, since those of us who don't own burr grinders are philistines.  I loved the coffee-dude who rolled his eyes when someone asked for Equal.  Sadly, Equal's non-organicness means that it is banned from here.  Screw you if you're diabetic and want sweet coffee, apparently...

Finally, the hours suck, which seems odd for a coffee shop.
author: Bill C.

description:
Clean and modern interior
Good Siphon Coffee & poached eggs on toast
Staff was nice and efficient

In town for a quick visit and brought friend in tow.  Had a positive experience and nice service.  First time at this location and the cashier kindly explained the different blends available.  

If you love good coffee and have time to sit and enjoy it,  this place is for you.
author: M M.

description: I'm not a huge coffee drinker - I have the occasional iced coffee to pick me up during the week. But there is just something about Blue Bottle's New Orlean's Iced Coffee that keeps me coming back for more. It has such a smooth and unique flavor. I hit it up daily when I'm in SF. They need to bring one to LA asap.
author: Adam D.

description:
As I walked out of Blue Bottle with my Cafe Mocha (which is delicious, almost worth the $5 I paid even) I was thinking percentages...

90%: The percentage of the patrons that clearly travelled from far off nabes to be seen at the hip new coffee house opening.

50%: Possibility that I stepped in rat poo on my way in and out of the cafe.

And I officially declare that Mint Plaza is now 15% more relevant to the downtown dwellers such as myself, up from 5%. Those awesome orange chairs are that 5% in case you were wondering.

Actually I suppose a place like this should only be judged by its coffee, which is excellent. It appears to have free wifi too so that's a big plus for me.. The place was pretty well packed as far as coffee houses go so I decided to get my beverage to go. 

I am digging the minimalist utilitarian vibe this place has got. It deftly avoided any cliches you'd come to expect from a coffee shop as well. I've never been to a Blue Bottle cafe so I don't know if that's just their branding or what, but it certainly defies conventions in terms of its interior design.

After I got my coffee, I strolled on next door to Providence Savings and Loan and bought me a gold plated necklace.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
I would have loved to see their halogen brewing technology...but apparently it has operation hours.
It's good coffee, not the best. I enjoyed the design of my foamed milk on my mocha. I guess that's worth $6?
author: Keika L.

description:
They got rid of the rude fembot and hired someone friendly to take your order and their coffee is devine. 

I've taken a couple out-of-towners and the presentation and quality are wonderful in addition to fairly traded and organic coffee.

Get the Ice coffee.
author: Cristian M.

description: New Orleans Iced Coffee. Really good stuff.
author: E A.

description:
Rating: 3.5 stars

This review is only for the toast and the tea.  Sorry not a coffee drinker, but the person I came here with is a coffee expert and swears that this is the best coffee in SF.  However, the tea is wonderful here! If you dine in, they serve the tea in a teapot and it seems like it's homemade.  I had the herbal tea and it had fresh lemon and cinnamon sticks in it. Yum!  We also had the toast w/jam & butter.  The bread is from ACME bread.  Super delish!  Fresh and toasted perfectly!

It's a bit pricey to come here every day, but if you feel like spoiling yourself one morning, come here! I'd come back for tea and toast. =)
author: Michelle H.

description: discrete and corner location..mint plaza alley location...wonderfully crafted new orleans iced coffee...shy under $four...sweetness blended with cinnamon...milky smoothness...refreshing coffee flavors wake-me-up...
author: Hen A.

description: Blue bottle coffee remains my favorite. This location had a long line, but the coffee was still as tasty as one hopes.
author: Unkl- T.

description:
My friends and I came here on a Sunday afternoon after wedding dress shopping all morning and we were exhausted. The location of this Blue Bottle is so random. I had no idea it was there this whole time. The line was out of the door and around the corner, so you know this coffee has a good reputation.

The line moved fairly quickly for how long it was. I ordered their latte since they don't give their espressos to-go. The latte seemed a bit foamy for my taste. My friends ordered a mocha and iced coffee, both enjoyed their drinks more than mine. Next time I am going to sit there and sip an espresso! I'm sure it will be worth taking the time. 

I saw other customers ordering sandwiches & breakfast and they looked delicious. They have waffles! Getting those next time. 

There are a few other Blue Bottle Coffee Co. around the bay area also.
author: Chris C.

description:
We visited the cafe on a rainy night and recognized it by its steamy windows and hipster client silhouettes 

It's a beautiful, urban chic space toasty warm from a capacity crowd, constant foot traffic and steamed drinks, with friendly counter staff /attentive table service, and a buzz of animated voices.

When you drink the coffee you realize where the buzz is coming from. I departed from my latte ways and ordered an individual drip coffee ($2) which was so strong that it blew my socks off and made my hair stand on end. It was good and anyone who enjoys a rich, dark blend would love it - though a more mellow latte is more my speed for next time.

My pregnant friend ordered a beautiful decaf cappuccino and we shared a small but delicious dark chocolate Valrhona pudding ($4.50). 

My only quibble was that it was served in a narrow beaker which made getting at the deliciousness difficult - a more shallow bowl next time please, Coffee Gods?

The place was packed at 6, we waited ~10 minutes for seats to open up, but the crowd thinned at 6:45. And though they closed at 7 they graciously took care of their clientele well past closing.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Sharand N.

description:
Coffee there is great, the food is good too, though there's not much of it.  For me, good coffee at a coffee shop gets 5 stars, so I'll use this review to tell a funny story.

Me and my friend were sitting at Blue Bottle fantasizing about stealing their coffee beans.  At first, we were joking about puncturing the bags on the wall cartoon style, and storing the falling beans in our pockets.

Then, one of the employees walks by with 4 five-pound bags of espresso roast.  He drops one of the bags, but it doesn't sound like it breaks.  I say to my friend, "Man, I wish that bag had broken, I'd bust out my bean vacuum and suck those beans up!"

We're leaving, and as we walk out, I realize the bag *has* broken, there are beans spilling out., the hole in the bag is face down, so it's hard to tell what the damage is.  I look at the employee and say, "Can I have this bag?" He says, "You want it!?" 

I pick up the bag carefully, and probably 4/5 of the beans are still in the bag, and never touched the ground.  He says, "All right, take it, get out of here"  (in a fun way:)  

4 lbs. of Blue Bottle Espresso roast for free!
author: Stephen L.

description:
My friends and I love Blue Bottle.  It's no surprise we went to the grand opening of this hip little cafe downtown. 

Well, the coffee wasn't as good as the kiosk, but I'll give them some time to work out the kinks.  The espresso in my mocha was super bitter.  It also lacked the money shot-- the mouthful of recchiuti chocolate at the bottom of the cup.  I left craving a "real" Blue Bottle mocha.  Sigh.

The crowd today looked very New York-- it was quite an odd scene.  I felt like I was in the middle of Soho or something.  Super pretentious, but we probably contributed to that.

I'll be back to try some of the single origin siphoned coffees-- made in a super pretentious $20,000 machine.  I've gotta see what the fuss is about with these coffees and these ridiculous machines.

I'd go back if I were at the Westfield, but I am not normally in the area.  For now, I'll stick with the Linden location, where the more experienced barristas work the machines.
author: Poker B.

description: This SoMa location is right across from my office, and I could not be happier about it!  I love this place. The coffee is unbeatable, with a lot of amazing options to try.  I love both iced coffees, especially the Nola style for a special treat.  Their coffee cake is also delicious.  Awesome atmosphere as well, such a fan!
author: Bridget B.

description:
I LOVE LOVE Blue Bottle!
check out Arno Holschuh from Blue Bottle on Chow, talking about coffee:
http://www.chow.com/stories/10625

whenever i come into town i walk down to Blue Bottle. i always seem to get the same guy helping me and he is the sweetest. i ordered, the Gibraltar, #28 off of 7x7's '100 Things You Must Try Before You Die' list. 

http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

and yes, you really must try the Gibraltar before you die. but don't even think about getting it to go. it only comes in a glass, so sit your butt down and savor it to the last drop. something you try before you die shouldn't be gotten to go anyway. 
i enjoyed sitting at the bar and gazing at the chemistry set of coffee concoctions so meticulously displayed before me. i also had a front row seat to the chef working his poor butt off. i kind of felt guilty sitting there lazily with my specialty espresso drink. but he did an amazing job of getting the food out to the packed enclave.

the only reason i give Blue Bottle 4 stars is due to the long lines. but whatcha gonna do?
author: Brooke W.

description:
Driving from the Sunset District towards downtown.   (30minutes)

Paying seven dollars for parking at the Union Square garage.

Walking from the Union Square garage to Blue Bottle Coffee while listening to the sneaker pimps. (10minutes)

Having the employees hook me up with a free Cappuccino, PRICELESS..

Worth the drive.
author: Walter C.

description:
Now for being a coffee connoisseur & a non-stop addiction to it: I would have to give this an all star rating. Never will you walk out of here feeling blue....except for when your drink is gone...

So I heard they fixed up the Jesse Alley...very clean and modern looking now! Upon walking there, I could already smell the lovely aroma & directed my way in...

So a friend recommended the New Orleans Iced Coffee, unfortunately I made it too late (1pm ish), because they were completely out! Whomp whomp...so I opted for the Kyoto Iced coffee. Simply spectacular...dark, rich, & aromatic: just to my liking. This bad boy doesn't come with milk, so I added just a tad bit of half&half. I will be returning for the New Orleans drink! I am still sniffling at my drink's aroma & savoring the roasted flavor. YUM! And trust me, each cup is brewed fresh as you order, and the Kyoto coffee: through a VERY expensive high tech coffee machine from Japan, it seriously looks like your 12th grade chemistry class set up...glass & all! Not your normal coffee brewing process! 

The cafe is cute and moderately sized. Very clean & white color set up. Modern looking, and I like the architecture. Oh, and they also serve wine & little snacks. Service was great. The gentleman working there was nice, and took the time to explain the different coffees. And, it didn't take long for them to brew up my coffee. 

Simply fantastic experience! Once again I have found a new source to feed my coffee withdrawals. And have discovered my people have invented something pretty nifty....

I hope this cup magically refills itself...
author: Catherine O.

description:
As I approached the Pandora's box that is Blue Bottle Coffee, I wish I was listening to the angel on my shoulder speaking against it.  Now I am destined to suffer from severe DT's and night sweats, or take many extra trips across the Bay Bridge to get my fix.

Not only an architecturally brilliant space; dotted with exotic orchids and full of natural light, cheerful servers and fine SOMA people-watching, but one sip and I was hopelessly...hooked.
author: Madame X.

description:
I'm usually a "cream-in-my-coffee" person, but the coffee at blue bottle is so delicious that I enjoy it in its unadulterated form.  Maybe it's the beans they use, or the fact that they roast their own coffee nearby, or the trippy chem-lab setup that they use to brew it, but something makes it scrum-diddly-umptious!

Also if you are blessed with having your own espresso machine at home like I am, you should pick up a bag of their whole bean Roman Espresso.  It's divine.
author: Dave C.

description:
Yes yes yes yes yes yes.

Thank you Aaron, coffee is on me next time.

Whatever we ordered from there (Kyoto style iced I think) at 4pm today has kept me up so far; its 11:44pm and i'm writing the document thats due tomorrow on a seemingly full tank.

Seriously, and its not the residual caffeine high talking, it was THE BEST iced coffee I've ever had.  I look forward to having many more of these.
author: Todd F.

description:
On 5/19/2008, I received the following msg from Lily:

"Since we're both coffee snobs...we have to go and try this.  Got lunch plans today?

http://www.yelp.com/biz/bluebottle-coffee-co-san-francisco-3"

Oh hell yeah!  I replied.  So we went on the adventure to find this place where they housed the expensive ass machine that supposedly makes great coffee.

I walked in.  Hey, I've seen those little pot thing before, they were called... umm.. vacuum coffee maker!  I had coffee made from those before in Hong Kong!  

Anyhow, Lily and I were eyeballing the iced coffee selection... hmmm...  Kyoto or New Orleans?  Kyoto or New Orleans? hMMm KYOTO OR NEW ORLEANS!  dood... what's the difference....  We were looking at each other, confused....

$hit, just ask them!  OK... the barista told us, the New Orleans comes with cream and sugar? and the Kyoto was made from THE machine where they cold-brewed that for hours.  

And then, he said the magic words: i can give you guys a little of both to try.

OH HELL YEAH!

The Kyoto was black, no cream and sugar....  I asked the stupidest question:  Can i put cream in it?  I'm totally a Half & Half girl....  Well, guess what, the answer was yes....

The New Orleans came with cream and sugar.  

Now the taste test.  New Orleans... YUMMY.  Kyoto, OMG, strong as hell.  Lily and I looked at each other and said.. I think imma go with the New Orleans....  But lemme sip the Kyoto with cream one more time.  hMmm... I think I'm getting used to this....

HmMmm  The Kyoto is tasting better and better after each sip....

Sip on the New Orleans again... Dude, I can't taste the coffee anymore from the New Orleans... The Kyoto's strong ass coffee totally outshined the NO, and later on, the NO tastes like water....

The end of the story?  Lily and I both walked out with the Kyoto in our hands, spacing out, happily and overly caffeinated, shake-walking our way back to the office....
author: Gigi T.

description:
I wasn't impressed with the coffee at Blue Bottle Caf; consequently I'm becoming more convinced that Starbucks coffee is the best around.  I know many of you will disagree with me, and I'm starting to question whether my opinion is due to lack of palate maturity to distinguish high quality coffees or a personal bias resulting from frequenting Starbucks nearly every day for the past 6 years.

Anyway, I had read many good reviews about Blue Bottle and people have told me how great their coffee is.  We came downtown on Saturday to try Sultan Indian Buffet and watch the Final Four games.  We had some time between lunch and the basketball games, so we decided to check out Blue Bottle caf.  I was impressed with the location, a trendy little joint on Mint Street just south of Market.  The caf was very clean and well lit; a nice spot to converse with some buddies over some coffee, getting ready to get your day started.  

The one negative is that I didn't feel the price was justified by the coffee.   I paid 9 dollars for a drip, an espresso, and a caf au lait.  I'm not cheap, however if I pay premium price, I expect a premium experience.  The ambiance, crowd, and feel are all there, however the taste lacks.  The coffee didn't stand out to me and was disappointing.  I had my drip black so I could really taste the coffee, but there was nothing outstanding about it.  Tasted like a plain cup of coffee I could have bought anywhere else.  I'll probably go to Blue Bottle again; most likely the next time I'm downtown just trying to kill time... However I'll continue to favor Starbucks for my morning routine.
author: Timothy C.

description: Great coffee spot always packed with people , they have great brunch menu as well i would deff come back if i visit SF !!! Highly suggest stopping by !!
author: Dong K.

description: STELLAR coffee with over-worked staff in a too-small location. The lines were terribly long but the coffee: worth the wait.
author: Melanie F.

description:
Can't really say enough about this ultra high-end coffee shop hidden in the heart of the most tourist/suburbanite infected areas of The City. They opened one week and the next week were featured in a New York Times article, nuff said.

I've got a major coffee habit and after seeing the reverence that scads of Yelpers drop the Blue Bottle name with in reviews for the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market I was borderline ecstatic to hear they were opening their first cafe around the corner from my apartment.

They're tucked away around a corner in Mint Plaza and one of the best features of this hard-to-see location is that the clientele have a decidedly more City feel then most of the tourist traps that populate the surrounding vicinity. It seems to be a roughly equal mix of yuppies and hipsters, but good vibes all around.

So far I've had the opportunity to sample the following offerings::

Siphon Coffee: This is the main event. The magic machine imported from Japan, and AFAIK, the only one of its kind here in the States. The coffee it brews is rich, sublime, and obscenely priced. Bring at least one other friend to share the experience (and more importantly the bill) since depending on your bean selection a small pot costs $10-$13.

Espresso: Rich flavor, dark thick crema, yummy.

Cappuccino: Dense foam and steamed milk expertly layered (sweet designs!) on top of aforementioned espresso. Ridiculously smooth.

Kyoto Iced Coffee: Brewed extremely slowly overnight in the tall lab equipment next to the siphon machine. Has a strong whiskey taste, which was explained (by the barista) as a by-product of the extremely long extraction times. I'm not a whiskey fan, so not for me.

Various Food: They do not serve your typical coffee-shop fare here i.e. a shelf of pastries. Rather the small kitchen produces a small menu more inline with the "New American" style restaurants you'll find in The City. They use really high quality ingredients and the portions are sized to satisfy without stuffing you.
author: Joseph R.

description:
I will update this review should I have a better experience.  I had coffee here, oh, about 4 different times in the last several months.  It's true, the coffee is delicious, but the staff can be hit and miss.  On a cold weekend day, I stopped by for a hot chocolate.  It was served barely warm.  Because it was so busy, I thought about just drinking it.  Then, my friend was also served with hot chocolate as cold as mine.  No matter what price you charge or how busy it is, quality control should be in place.  

When I brought my hot chocolate back after two sips, the employee who made the hot chocolate threw it out grunting how he had to make it all over again.  His tone, volume, agitated behaviour said it loud and clear - retribution for complaining.  The worst part of it was that the replaced hot chocolates, both of them, were even colder.

Next time I'm in that neighborhood, I may or may not go back.  You know how it is.  Even if the coffee is good, you just don't want to perpetuate the cycle.  Bad service should be addressed here.   I see I'm not the only one who had a bad experience with the service.   Too bad.
author: Mina C.

description: Awesome place to have coffee and hang out. Sat up to the window counter and looked out the big windows. The New Orleans iced coffee was delicious and the mocha was too. The mocha was topped with beautiful foam art. Great place.
author: Tanner W.

description: Blue bottle coffee is the only coffee I can drink without any sugar! I've been to three different locations & they are all great. Great tasting & smelling coffee makes everything great :)
author: Sunny K.

description:
One thing is for sure. If you're into great coffee, this is your place. Pass up Starbucks for this. If I was rating coffee alone, I would have given this place 5 stars. The reason I deducted a star is because it's on a less than desirable street and when I visited (On President's Day at 11am) there was a line snaking through the entire place. The wait wasn't that bad, but it's awkward standing 12in from someone trying to enjoy their coffee, then 20 minutes later being that person. Keep in mind, I am not a regular at this joint, so my experience may be a rare one.

All in all, I love their intensity and dedication to a good brew. Keep on keepin' on.
author: Lucas R.

description: good stuff overall. The coffee is good, the setup is kind of nice and simple. A large wooden table in the center of the room is a lot of this place's atmosphere. There is a bar table that extends around the outer perimeter and then there is the tiny coffee bar on the far inner corner. It's lined with all the globes and interesting photos of the process. It's kind of pricey but overall good stuff. I like the standard drip for the good flavor and on a hot day the Kyoto iced coffee is the way to go. If you have a sweet tooth go with the New Orleans Iced or the hot cocoa The cocoa is more of a chocolate flavor and less of milk and cream like other places would serve.
author: Greg G.

description: After a few visits, the occasional lines and slow service are worth it.  The espresso was among the best I've ever had, and thank God they understand what a ristretto is (and that's why it is good).  For the people who want a vanilla raspberry mocha whip grande whatchamacall it, please go away.  Please leave the genuine places like this for the rest of us.  They know how to pull a shot of espresso.  They know what coffee is supposed to be.
author: Albert H.

description: The New Orleans Ice Coffee was okay. Not great, and too sweet for me. My bf's mocha was not great at all. I guess I'll have to come back and try some hot coffee from here, but as of now I'd rather go to Philz.
author: Melissa H.

description: There is always a line, and I hate lines, but when I need caffeine and I care what it tastes like,  I wait.  I saw some tasty looking brunch items that I need to go back and try out.
author: Seong P.

description:
I have had a soy mocha three times here. They are delicious, but way overpriced. I worked at an organic vegetarian/vegan coffee shop for two years in college, and I must say I am very impressed with their codes and ethic on the bean tip, and the science they have this down to. But the amount of caffeine in one cup is ridiculous. I am sure all of you hard core caffeine freaks are giving me the finger right now, but I would like a cup of coffee or soy mocha with the right balance of all ingredients. Meaning, I don't want to be wired until tomorrow morning. I would like to taste the flavor of the espresso beans and the chocolate and milk. It tasted like a huge cup of espresso and I was jacked for the entire day, only to come down with a huge headache at ten at night. 

I LOVE that they know what there doing. I just wish that there coffee came with a warning label. I guess if your a regular, you know that already. Maybe a little help for the people that aren't.
author: monika l.
