description: Yay!  Another Blue Bottle Coffee Co. and this one is even closer to my office!!  This one doesn't smell as lovely as some of them but the coffee is still tremendous.  I love ordering an espresso and getting a little tiny cup of sparkling water with it.  Excellence!
author: Ivan L.

description:
Not as good as the Linden Alley version.

Somehow, the lines move slower ( Guys, less chatting maybe? I'm
being an ass, but seriously. Buying beans is a 20 second transaction 
that takes 2-15 minutes because you're talking to each other or the 
customers. Please, keep being friendly, but get a cashier whose 
job it is to queue up orders and sell things. ).

Also far more likely to be out of whole beans than Linden. Sigh.

The fact that it's next to crackhead central is not a plus, but I don't 
really mind all that much.

On the upside:
 - The space is great.
 - The servers are friendly. Too friendly. 
 - Good coffee (drinks&beans).
 - A fine place to read a paper and have a coffee.
 - Interesting coffees (syphon and slow-drip). Good stuff.


If I want to get coffee or beans, off to Linden Alley I go. If I want to get
coffee, wait for 5-20 minutes, be told that they are out of beans, then
sit down and read while waiting for my coffee I go here. Nice place to
hang out, if you're in no hurry.
author: Max R.

description: One of my favorite cafes ever... I love coffee and this is the only place that serves the BEST COFFEE in the most unique way. Their Japanese style of coffee making is an experience everyone should have. Siphon anyone? Their breakfast is also great....
author: Ria M.

description: Really, really high quality coffee and great breakfast foods.  You can get Blue Bottle at almost any reputable place, but this is it.
author: Keith K.

description:
Don't get me wrong, this place is great.  It is a small little upscale cafe tucked away between the old mint and the SF Chronicle building.  The New Orleans coffee is phenomenal and strong (my eyeballs are still shaking from it) and the fruit compote with Greek yogurt is tasty (though it could use a little something sweet in it)  In fact, it is the perfect place for a first date, or an impromptu afternoon meeting, if you are lucky enough to find a seat.  

The only issue I have with this place is that for two New Orleans coffees and two bowls of fruit with yogurt added up to a whopping $26 bucks!  Now, I know San Francisco is not a cheap city, but this was a little ridiculous.  The waffles and poached eggs looked amazing, not to mention the cinnamon brioche but something is up if I have to break a $50!
author: Adam E.

description: LOVE. Worth the wait (15minutes) outside. Clean and simple interior. Fresh and pure ingredients.  Limited menu selections, but less is definitely more. Boyfriend had the Belgian Waffle and I had poached eggs on thick cut acme toast (heavenly!). We also shared a Soy latte and a kick-ass single espresso shot.
author: Tran L.

description: A F F O G A T O ! ! !  first time ever and I was sooo surprised. It was so good. Best coffee I've had ever. Next best is coffee from my house that I grind and brew. Will be back for more soon. Best enjoyed with friends.
author: Bernie T.

description: This is one of the best coffee places in SFO. The breakfast is very good as well. We had toasts with jam and the poached eggs and both were very good.
author: Alaap T.

description: The quality of this coffee shop is more than hype of coffee snobs, this is really quality coffee, the best I have ever had. In part the coffee is really good but the skill the baristas have in making the coffee is impressive. The food is also top quality. If lived in San Francisco, I would go out of my way to be a regular.
author: Bryan G.

description: One of the best coffee house out there.. love the Gibraltar..
author: Alex P.

description:
Literally just got back from grabbing some coffee at this place - SO GOOD! I don't know what they do or how they do it but the coffee you get from this place is simply out of this world. Not to mention it';s all relationship coffee, so you know growers are being treated fairly.

My only beef with this place the menu for food. From reading some of the other reviews here, i got the impression it had a a good if limited menu - They had 3 items on the entire menu! I ended up going across the street for a salad and then coming back for the coffee. 

Still - this place rocks my world!
author: Adam W.

description:
met up with a friend of mine on a monday morning around 8:45-9:00, and it wasn't very crowded - nice surprise. Looked at the breafast menu, and though fancy, wasn't enticing. I came for the coffee, I got the coffee (about 10 minutes later), and it was a good as the ones I get at the Berkeley farmer's market. 

Good place to come to finish reading for class, browse the newspaper, but I wouldn't use this as a lounging place.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I was mesmerized by their coffee siphon contraption. Who knew a place could make the act of making coffee go from the mundane to the intriguing!

Went there for the first time on Saturday with a friend who had been there before. I ordered a cappuccino with french toast, and she ordered a cappuccino with a belgian waffle.

When we got there Saturday morning, there was a line out the door, but it seemed to move fairly quickly. I was a little overwhelmed by the choices at first, and it was hard to come to a decision by the time it was my turn.

Luckily, we got a seat by the huge coffee contraption, next to the coffee siphons. After a few minutes, our cappuccinos arrived. The coffee was absolutely fantastic! All I could think of while drinking it was: "why aren't I drinking this coffee all the time?"

Our food arrived shortly thereafter, and I was really blown away by the presentation. The presentation was really simple, but it looked like a lot of care went into it. 

Both the belgian waffle and french toast were amazing. They both didn't taste like anything you could ever get at a breakfast diner. The slices of toast were really thick, and the waffle was sweet and moist.

I will definitely be returning!
author: Adam S.

description: I dont remember the last time I had such an amazing piece of toasted bread! I know this is supposed to be about coffee but had to share this as well. I asked for the round 'coffee holder/cup thing drip' and I dont usually have my coffee dark but this was pretty good. Not bitter or heavy, just perfect. They have a daily 'drip' I guess and that morning I had one from central america. The poached egg and cooked kale was ok. Would definitelly recommend.
author: K C.

description: Blue bottle coffee is one of my favorites, but I've only had their regular drip coffees or expressos. This location has the Kyoto, cold-drip brewing system which I had to try at least one time, even though I don't like iced coffees too much -- the drink gets watered down if you don't finish it fast enough, and I like to slowly sip mine.  Still it was definitely the best iced-coffee I've tasted, and I would order it again on a hot day. On the weekend I went, there was a super long line out the front door and it took about 20 minutes to get a drink.
author: Jermaine R.

description:
Disclaimer:  Granted, I'm not a coffee drinker!

Ya gotta love what it IS good for though - touristy, hipster scene, quiet and cute location.

3 stars for the food and wait.  I had a belgian waffle (from the 7x7 list).  


***NEWS FLASH***:  Blue Bottle sells a different waffle type at the Ferry Building than at 66 Mint.  Ferry Building is only $3 and totally yummy and denser and caramelized like.  The one at 66 Mint is just ok.  You can see the pics for the yummy waffle on my other review.

Don't go to 66 Mint for the 7x7 EATS list.  I know it lists the 66 Mint address, but looking at the reviews, it looks like they got the address wrong.  http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2011-100-things-try-san-francisco-you-die  **********

5 stars for the chill people that hang out at this location and also for the customer service.  They screwed up on my one order twice, but definitely made up for it with their customer service. I held myself back from their baked goods on the counter, but I'll be going back to this happy place!  It's also right around the corner from an open plaza (near Chez papa) and had lots of open orange chairs to lounge in a quiet tucked away escape only 1 street away from the bustle of Union Square.
author: Cathy U.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE!! 
New Orleans coffee is the best on either a hot or cold day.  I remembered the first time i drank this and it just got me wired like no other coffee(and  i'm use to having about 5- 6 shots in my venti caramel macchiato from starbucks.)  Unfortunately I can't see myself paying $4.50 for a cup of coffee everyday, but if i i could afford it i would be on it all day everyday.  I haven't had a chance to eat there yet because of their outrageous prices, but from what i've seen the breakfast looks appetizing.
author: Cedric F.

description: I've heard the coffee here is to die for, but I'm not a huge coffee drinker. They were out of lemonade so I had to settle for water. It was pretty good...but I was quite thirsty. It's a decent place to sit and chat for a bit though. I highly recommend it. Next time I visit, I'll make sure to order an actual beverage like a tea or something. It's a wee bit on the pricey side though.
author: Amy J.

description:
OK, I am NOT a coffee aficionado.  I do enjoy a nice concentrated macchiato, and when here I almost always go for the Gibraltar, which although a little milky for me comes close to a perfect blend of eyeopener and finesse.  Especially the presentation in a shot glass.

Where I *really* love this place is in the brunch/snack/lunch menu.  I've had the grilled cheese (to die for) and a mushroom-gravy concoction in cream-puff pastry shells.  Yum.  Saturday morning?  Yep.  Go.  Only unfortunate thing: It's often full.
author: Carlton S.

description:
Blue Bottle had me enjoy coffee again. I haven't seriously enjoyed coffee in literally, years. I do enjoy the taste of coffee but its been a while since I've tasted a brew this good. I had the cappuccino and although the espresso was strong, it went down smooth. You can taste the richness of the beans and the care that went into brewing that cup of coffee that you appreciate every sip that you take. 
Had a taste of the friend's cafe latte and it was weak-sauce compared to the cappuccino. If you're gonna go for it here, go for the strong stuff, you'll be pleased you did.

While waiting for the brews, I did notice that they had plate dishes but couldn't find their place or price anywhere on the menu. But they sure did look yummy. 

Unless you were looking for this place, you'd walk right pass it. So, keep an eye out and follow the smell of that delicious coffee scent.
author: Danvin R.

description: Coffee is amazingly delicious, they make each cup individually and have different styles and brewing techniques.  I only dock a star because the food seemed overpriced.  The cheapest snack was a small muffin for $5.  Grab one next door at the doughnut shop for a buck, but get the Joe here.
author: Wyatt D.

description: Get the New Orleans iced coffee and a little ginger bread cake.  You don't need anything else in life.  It's perfection.
author: Lauren K.

description: I so much love a taste of blue bottel that fresh dripped black goodness that sways like a small pond in my cup.  You cannot beat the quality of these beans and their roasting process, you taste the care and love they put into every bag.  If only our government employees could put half the effort into their work, we would live in Utopia! Delicious goodness in a cup.
author: Tom M.

description: Enlighten me on how this is the best coffee? First of all customer service here is horrible, workers had that "artsy fartsy hipster" attitude. AND the drinks...me and my boyfriend have experienced better. My boyfriend ordered a latte and I ordered an espresso vino. Presentation on both these drinks were amazing but it lacked in taste. So in hope to redeem ourselves we ordered a mocha, again pretty in presentation, but not the best we've had. For us it wasn't worth the time or the money.
author: Marilou F.

description: There's always a huge queue, and for good reason! The coffee here is, so far, the best I've had anywhere. The barista is very sweet, and the New Orleans Iced Coffee (with soy) was delicious!
author: Chris P.

description: The Kyoto iced coffee will knock you on your ass, but you'll enjoy the fall. Powerful to the pint of being hard to get down, but delicious.
author: Paul B.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker but came here on a Saturday afternoon and the place was PACKED.  What the hell is in that coffee?  Crack?

My man friend ordered me some waffles and there was crack in the waffles too.
author: Nezza F.

description: The latte at Blue Bottle is amazing. Honestly the flavor and texture is fluffy wonderfulness. Best ever. In the morning get the toast and jam. It is truly special. The mint street location is extra romantic as it is tucked away off the street like a sweet secret...
author: Kory J.

description:
Forget reading Purpose Driven Life, just drink BBCC's cafe latte & you'llknow why you were put on Earth.  It's that mind-blowing freakin amazing.  

It's so smooth & full of flavor.  I can't believe it took me so long to finally try this place out.  Peets, Starbucks & Coffee  Bean & Tea Leaf can't even compare to the happiness that a BBCC cup provides.
author: Sheryl S.

description: baristas at Blue Bottle are very helpful and friendly, which is nice because most independent coffee joint baristas tend to act like they know better and we don't worth their time.  The coffee is great, I had a drip and latte and they are equally nice. Wanna try their kyoto next time I'm there!
author: Vicky R.

description:
Clean and modern interior,Good Siphon Coffee & poached eggs on toast
Staff was nice.  I prefer coming here when it's not as crazy busy and crowded.
author: christy l.

description:
Alright. The infatuation of Blue Bottle is beginning to wear off. I've been here a few times over the past month.

Blue Bottle looks cool, it's chic. The coffee is good. The equipment looks cool and always gives you something to talk about.

But Blue Bottle needs to get its act together. The lines are always out the door. Their equipment always seems to be broken. Every time I come back, I leave more frustrated.

For a coffee shop that seemed to be taking off, it looks like Blue Bottle is smashing into the chain-link fence at the end of the runway.
author: Kelly S.

description: Amazing coffee.  The seating arrangement is a bit odd, but I can live with it.  There's also usually a line, but they take credit cards which is nice.
author: Nancy C.

description:
we go here every Thursday! our four-five some posse even has an official acronym - BBT (blue bottle thu!).. yes, its that important. at least one of us makes it every Thursday. Its a ritual, and we plan to keep it till the end of time. and oh, the coffee is worth it!

I love coffee.. i mean love. i have worked over the years to get over the addiction and I think i have (i used to drink 4 large coffees before everyday!) but i can't let go of my weekly indulgence on BBT (and Philz)...

I get the Quad Nonfat Latte (i mean i guess going quad doesn't really make my case for getting over my coffee addiction, oh well). 

Other drinks that i have tried - Macchiato (its an espresso shot), New Orleans Iced Coffee, Macau Iced Coffee (love this one and more bang for your buck) and the Chai Tea (really good but maybe a bit too sweet)

U need to have a day dedicated to Blue Bottle! Also, the duo who serves our coffee here when we go there every Thursday are super great and friendly (they did take a while to warm up to us though, but i think they love us now!)..:)
author: Sapna E.

description:
Let me be clear, I am not a coffee drinker. Thankfully when I do drink coffee, I have so many great options here San Francisco that coffee is a treat and not a routine for me.
Blue Bottle coffee is by far and wide the best brew you can find in the United states. Usually I am a cappuccino guy who mixes in a fist full of sugar, but at Blue Bottle a drip straight up is all I need. I highly recommend you and a friend split a pot of the cipher drip. This method only exists in two places in the world, Tokyo and San Francisco. You will be surprised how amazing coffee can taste. Also at this location the Belgian waffles are insanely good. Thanks to the staff that is always so helpful and willing to educate me on the many nuances in making coffee. These people know coffee like Napa knows wine.
author: Alejandro M.

description: Ah Blue Bottle. Your coffee is so delicious, but your actual retail locations leave something to be desired. Yes, these are the same delicious beans that you can find at coffee shops around the city. Yes, this particular Blue Bottle has some of the best mochas I've ever had. But I can't quite give it five stars when I can walk a few blocks in the other direction and get the same coffee with a quarter the wait and save 23¢ to boot. Ah, the curse of popularity.
author: James B.

description:
I had to register to review this place.

Sure, I'm not normally a coffee drinker but having been here twice I can pretty safely say their drinks are inconsistent at best. On both occasions, I've gotten extremely bitter/burnt coffee drinks. The first was a latte, and the second a mocha. The shittiness of both was confirmed by my coffee-obsessed boyfriend (who has no problems at all with the tasty beans he grinds from this place at home). Hell, my mocha didn't even taste like a mocha -- just a weird cappuccino. 

I bumped up a star for the novelty of the brewing systems and the availability of cute (but overpriced) vittles.
author: Jess F.

description:
Totally snobby!  Don't waste your time unless you (1) Research the menu in advance so that you know exactly what to order.  (2) Bring cash. (3) Have time to lounge.  This is not a great place to go if you're in a rush.

Bottom line: Great idea - bad execution.
author: B. L.

description:
Having been exposed to mass produced large-scale corporate coffees pretty much all my life, it was a surprise and a major wake up call when I came here. 

Everything is micro-roasted, fresh, and organic. I've tried the Louisiana Iced Coffee and the Kyoto style Iced coffee. 

The Louisiana is superb. There's a small hint of sweetness to it, but the smooth taste of coffee dominates. I drank it black, no creme, no sugar. It had this rich, almost chocolate-velvety texture and with each sip just got better and better. It was really aromatic, but never delivered that strong bitter taste that most other coffees give you. 

The Kyoto was a kick in the face. It is STRONG. I had it in the afternoon around 3pm and was still alive, tweaking, and kicking around past midnight. The taste is more condensed, almost like extra dark chocolate. Again, I drank it black, and this was a huge difference from the Louisiana. The aroma, wonderfully pleasing. 

This place has truly changed my perception and experience with coffee. Next time: the Siphon pot!
author: Derrick L.

description:
Blue Bottle Coffee is a favorite and well known among the people in SF. It's arguably one of the best coffees I've ever had... If you've ever tried their coffees then you'd know what I mean. They're known for their drip coffee which is individually dripped right when you place your order. Try their cappucinos as well - bold, aromatic and pretty darn amazing!

There are only a few actual Blue Bottle locations interspersed all over SF, so finding one is like finding a pot of gold at the end of a rainbow. Of course there are coffee shops all over the place that serve up blue bottle but you'll want to find the actual cafes where the baristas are well versed on each roast.
author: Janet T.

description: Great cup of coffee...Excellent lattes. Took home "Three Africans" beans two blends of Ugandan and two different Ethiopian blends--complex and yummy. Wish the store would have longer hours....tasty anise cookies too
author: Ericha F.

description: I first discovered blue bottle wondering the streets of the Jack London Square area of Oakland. I was enticed by the mural of a blue bottle on the outside of the cafe. Little did I know I was about have the best coffee I've ever tasted. I started with the cappuccinos and eventually moved on to my standard americanos. Not only is the espresso amazing, but I also love the atmosphere of the location in Oakland. Now that I'm no longer in the area, I walk blocks to the Ferry Building for my fix. Although, I still prefer the Oakland cafe...the coffee always makes my day. Every chance I get, I tell my friends they need to try Blue Bottle.
author: iheartpie s.

description:
I've been curious for a while about where the elusive Mint Plaza is located. Somehow, we stumbled upon it yesterday and decided to walk around and check it out. 

The plaza itself definitely screams gentrification and I couldn't really figure out if the empty buildings are residential or event space, but my curiosity was dulled the second I spotted the Blue Bottle Coffee shop in the far corner of the plaza. 

Being the hot chocolate fiend that I am, I quickly scanned the coffee menu until I found what I wanted. I was pleasantly surprised to find that they serve hot chocolate - and they use local favorite Recchiuti Chocolate. 

My hot chocolate looked like a work of art with a beautiful *micro foam* heart on top. 

The drink tasted as good as it looked. Not too sweet, perfectly chocolaty and rich enough, but not so much that I fell into a hot chocolate coma after finishing. 

It was just the pick-me-up that I was looking for on a weekend afternoon.
author: Lee H.

description: My bf had the cappuccino and I had the latte and both were very good. The espresso was pulled perfectly and very smooth. This is now my favorite coffee shop in SFO.
author: Norma H.

description: By far the best macchiato I've experienced yet thus far.  This place makes you stand in line for what seems like hours, in reality eight minutes, making every impatiently anticipated drop of coffee so much better.  Worth every minute.  Don't take my word for it, the line out the front door and around the corner should make it implacable.
author: Joel S.

description: I've heard all the hype, and finally found myself at Blue Bottle in the Ferry Building. Stood in a long line, paid a bunch, and was completely underwhelmed with my mocha.
author: Chuck A.

description: Great gazpacho! While known for their coffee, BB totally nails lunch, too.
author: Shannon W.

description: Crappy expensive drip coffee. I mean it. The coffee is weak and sour tasting. It tasted like BAD decaf to me. If you want amazing drip coffee in SF, go to Philz. Blue Bottle charges $3 for a TINY cup of shitty drip coffee. AND I waited in a 20 minute line outside in the cold for this stuff!!
author: Julie S.

description: I can always depend on an excellent espresso here or a latte'.  Service is always great and coffee is always strong and smooth.
author: April M.

description: The only reason I do not give them a 5 is because they do not live up to their own hype. This place has been built up to me over the years as a coffee mecca. True, it is outstanding, and the way their store and business is set up is really top quality. Their baristas are really professional, but it all feels a little too overwhelming and based on image rather than the final product. Its "hip" and "the best" and they know it. I was not a fan of their espresso blend and though the milk texture was phenomenal on my cap. Hard to sit, hard to get to, but I will definitely be making stops there in the coming years.
author: James O.

description:
The soy latte here is bar none, the best I ever had. As an American, I do wish there was an option for a Starbucks gallon size.

These guys are very serious about coffee. The service is excellent and cheerful. People aren't working here for money. They work here because they love coffee.
author: Matt W.

description: After flying in from San Diego, we were desperately looking for a coffee buzz.  Blue Bottle has three locations, but this one was closest to our hotel.  The surrounding area is somewhat sketchy but once you approach blue bottle the area is more upscale somehow.  We came mid afternoon so it was hard to find a seat, but we found a seat before our latte was brewed.  It was creamy, and the latte art was beautiful.  I dont usually eat baked goods at coffee houses because they tend to not be home made.  However we were starving so we ordered the olive oil shortbread, and it was one of the best cookies i have had in a long time.  The crowd at at Blue Bottle is definitely young and artistic but it is definitely one of the top places in SF to get a great latte.
author: Amy D.

description:
I actually think it goes without saying, because this is already a San Francisco must-see, but this place is totally an "A+++ would do business with again" type of spot.
The aesthetic of the space is antiqued modern with a hint of Japanese style. The staff is super friendly and attentive, like you'd expect from a sit down restaurant.
And then there's the coffee. Our group tried a pretty good cross section of things: an affogato for the sweet tooth, a drip coffee 'cuz you gotta, and a Kyoto style iced coffee because we nevereverdid before. My highest highlight was the Kyoto coffee for the bourbon-y taste, but the affogato is something everyone should try at least once in this life.
Now, I'm back home in Brooklyn, and I'm super excited to check out the Great Steps beans I brought back!
author: Kevin M.

description: Okayyy so this was basically my own fault..... After boyfriend saw the Kyoto iced coffee on TV, he insisted that we go try it. So on a trip to the city for shopping, we went. It's like a block away from Nordies, which makes it perfect and I was dying for a cappuccino. We were looking for it and all of a sudden I see the blue bottle on the wall, (there is NO other way to find this place honestly) and was like, THERE! And he was like, where?! And I pointed. And we laughed. Anyway..... we go inside and I was curious what the New Orleans Iced Coffee was. Basically its the super strong Kyoto Iced Coffee with sugar and milk. Yeah, that sounds good.... but also sounds like a lot of calories I can't have so I decided to be daring.... and I got the Kyoto.... the girl looked at me like, I know you can't handle this. and she was right. Boyfriend LOVED it. Says its the best coffee he has ever had, wants it everyday, blah blah blah. I on the other hand, after adding about 5 splendas (which I had to go find somewhere else because they did not seem to have that or milk/creamer out anywhere) and a little nonfat milk, it was still SO STRONG. Was the flavor good? Well, yeah of course..... but omg there was no way I could drink an entire cup of this stuff! I need to go back and try a nonfat cappuccino :)
author: Michelle S.

description: Seriously the best coffee I have ever had! I have been coming here since I was introduced to Blue Bottle by a friend and since then I have never been let down! No matter what size the line is, it's worth it. I still haven't been there for actual food but I'm sure that it's delicious! Now at random coffee shops I catch myself saying "Eh, it's not as good as Blue Bottle."
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
I love the coffee and the service here. But the location itself could be better. The place is also small and hence often you may not find any space inside to stay longer. 

The lack of a big name board makes this place "hidden".
author: Guru T.

description: Officially one of my fave coffee places to visit while in the city! The drip coffee is amazing and watching them make the coffee is also pretty cool. Great way to start my day although be prepared to wait in long lines... especially at the Ferry Bldg location :)
author: Steph N.

description:
Yes, this place is totally hyped, but I have to say that I think it's worth it. Even though my friends and I came during the busy Sunday brunch time, the staff was gracious under the pressure of serving a totally packed house.

The coffee itself is rather incredible. While you do have to be patient if you want a Siphon (from the uber expensive machine that lights up like a chemistry set), you'll savor the rich taste even more when your order is ready.

Food was awesome as well, healthy ingredients as part of traditional brunch fare with a slight twist. For example, the poached eggs on toast with maple butter was delightful. The charming sous chef was great about checking in with us and talking a little bit about the dishes.

Definitely be prepared to wait in line if you go on a weekend (much like you would at Tartine), but you'll be satisfied.
author: Tony P.

description:
Great high ceilings with stark white walls. Minimal decor. Hipster east coast feel.
Expensive coffee, but well worth it for the smoothness factor.
Baristas diligently preparing the coffee with japanese made machines (a sight to see in itself). 
The barista carefully unwraps a piece of caramel, takes it out, and neatly folds the wrapper back up, with the caramel atop to accompany your choice of coffee. (nice touch)
There were a couple of sandwiches on the menu. One with ham, one with cheese. I opted for none, because one ingredient was missing from each of them. I'm still waiting to see what the chef will bring to the restaurant in the months to come.

To be continued.....
author: Heidi L.

description:
Love the smoothness of the cappuccino.  Went great with my popeye toast..super buttery, flaky, and the egg inside the toast was perfect!!  My friend and I went on a rainy day, so it was pretty crowded inside.  But from the looks of the rest of the reviews for this location, it seems pretty crowded on any day regardless of the weather!

The staff was friendly and helpful, and even gave me tips on which bag of coffee beans to buy for my espresso machine and which bag of beans to buy for a regular coffee machine to make my own coffee at home.  

I will definitely be back to try the rest of the breakfast items and more coffee next time I'm in SF!
author: Astra W.

description:
3 words & 3 words only: Holy coffee heaven!

:)
author: Maricel B.

description:
Blue Bottle in the Mint Plaza is very hidden, but hip and urban, just like the Plaza itself.  Conveniently located next to the Shopping Centre, it's a great thing that it's not exposed to the world like the rest of the shopping district.  I can just picture thousands and thousands of tired shoppers desperate for a cup of coffee to jolt them back to life flocking here with irritable impatience. 

This is not, Starbucks.  The baristas here are not trained to work as fast as they can.  They don't bang out lattes after lattes like an assembly line.  Here, you must wait.  Whether it's just a cup of drip coffee or a magic-show-like siphon drink, everything takes time.  None of the customers seem to mind the wait either.  Everyone dresses hip, and acts patient.  

Despite the small size, there are seats for those that want to enjoy a coffee inside.  There is something very Murakami-esque about doing everything in a slow but orderly pace.  You get to enjoy the quality of a good coffee sip by sip, and read a newspaper provided by the cafe in the corner.  

The high ceiling and minimalist decor reminds me of this cafe in Barcelona, very clean, very calm, and everyone is in such a relaxed pace that you forget your breakfast took 2 hours.
author: Candice B.

description:
Cool interior, top coffee, cute baked goods and munches - definitely 4 stars
Slow service, odd location, some flies on the windows - 2 stars

Hence 3 stars overall.

I actually liked the Linden kiosk better, esp super efficient and knowledgeable baristas.
author: Angie Y.

description: We had a latte and a cappuccino and they were amazing which was no surprise. Five stars on that department.  The disappointing part was that we got there at 1:30 PM hoping to get something to eat, and were told that all the cooks were on break and we couldn't order any food for an hour. So as a cafe with a supposed food menu where you can't actually get any food, I have to give it 0 stars. But, if you go for the coffee, you will love it. Just don't show up hungry.
author: cecilia g.

description:
After many visits to the satellite operations at the Ferry Plaza and Hayes Valley, I decided it was time to check out the actual cafe.  

It was okay.  Fancy insides with all the brewing equipment and cute little French country style counter sitting, but that was it.  meh.

The other places are much more convienent and the counters were fairly dirty from sloshed coffee and creamer.  I went late in the afternoon (3p), but still hoped to nab some form of food treat to have with my coffee.  Only thing available was the gingerbread cake...  

It was good, just not worth hunting it down in the touristy streets of Market Street.  I will stick with my friendly neighborhood stands.
author: Becky T.

description:
When making plans for eating and drinking in San Francisco, I stumbled upon an article about Blue Bottle Coffee Company.  It's a local company of "artisanal microroasters" of organic coffee and espresso from countries like Costa Rica, Ethiopia and Mexico.  

Fast forward to the morning after my arrival in San Francisco.  I was standing in the kitchen of my friends' apartment waiting for the coffee to perk, relishing the wonderful aromas wafting through the air.  The wheels in my brain started to turn and I was prompted to ask if my friend had heard of Blue Bottle, but I interrupted myself to exclaim, "This coffee is freaking delicious!"

"Honey, that's Blue Bottle," she hollered from the other room.  Needless to say, I am now a huge fan.  I've had a few delicious cups of their coffee since arriving, but today I visited the café on Mint Street and enjoyed the best cappuccino I have had since living in France.

A few side notes:
1 Restaurateur extraordinaire, Danny Meyer, apparently fell in love with Blue Bottle on a recent trip to San Francisco and will now serve the coffee exclusively at Gramercy Tavern in New York City. 
2 I recently discovered the beauty of replacing organic cow's milk for soymilk in my coffee, which imparts a sweet, nutty taste and froths as well or better than "real" milk.
author: T. L.

description:
I love Blue Bottle Coffee, especially from the blue bottle coffee shops.  I've had their mocha, their cappuccino, their Kyoto, their Latte, their drip, their vacuum coffee (or whatever that one is where they light a fire under the water in a glass bowl) and I love it all.  I still remember my first cappuccino over a year ago.

Recently, my bf and I moved, and we brought one of the movers coffee, and we didn't tell him from where.  A few minutes later, I hear "wow, this is really good coffee".
author: Lexi B.

description: It was a little tricky to find, but my cappuccino was excellent.  Ginger molasses cookie with fresh ground cardamom, black pepper, and cocoa was out of this world.  Nice pick me up for afternoon studying.
author: Julie A.

description:
I was downtown attending a conference at the Moscone. Instead of eating stale bagels and weak coffee for a complimentary breakfast at the conference I met up with friends here for breakfast.

This place get's a solid 3 stars for the breakfast: I had thick toast with whipped butter and jam, my friend ate the poached eggs on thick toast. The prices were reasonable too.

This place prides itself on it's gourmet coffee, but we were all boring and stuck with the 'classics': cappuccino, latte, etc. In hindsight that was stupid of us, as we could have got that at Starbucks. Don't get me wrong though - the coffee was very good and poured well. They an extra half-star for that.

Also, sit and stare fixated at the strange coffee brewing contraption that look like it came from a 1950's science fiction film (my money is on Forbidden Planet).

I'll update when I've tried the gourmet (expensive) coffee, but for now 3.5 stars.
author: Chris K.

description: Kyoto iced coffee. Best iced coffee, ever ever. Their coffee is strong and flavorful, with no bitterness. The line at this location is pretty ridiculous, but all the baristas will quickly serve to please when you finally get to the freaking bar. They're very quick, efficient, and friendly, even while looking like they all jumped straight out of an American Apparel catalog.
author: Rachel F.

description: I'm a purist when it comes to coffee.  I only drink it black, no cream, no sugar.  After hearing much hype about blue bottle coffee, I had to try this syphon coffee.  It tasted super clean and smooth, but I didn't love the coffee. My friend described it as "sour." A large syphon coffee ($12-14) yields 2 small cups of coffee, which I thought was way too expensive.  If you love lattes though, paying $4 is totally worth it here -  I never get lattes, but it was so smooth and delicious.  Totally willing to make exceptions at Blue Bottle Coffee. I don't know about this syphon coffee though... Interesting technique, for sure.
author: Jen K.

description: Absolutely delicious siphon.  Reserved baristas.  Weird building.
author: Hallie T.

description:
As a huge fan of the Hayes Valley shop, I came in to try their new siphon coffee. For $11, I figured it had to be the best ever. It was very cool to watch, but when it came to sipping time, I think they do it much better by hand for $3. I didn't try the food because there wasn't much of a selection and it didn't look too appetizing.

I'm going back in my neighborhood where they do it homespun and deelicious.
author: Ted F.

description: The line was quite long, but I'm glad we waited. The hot chocolate was one of the best I've tried. It was rich, chocolate decadence without being too sweet. My husband ordered the pricey siphon bar coffee, which was delicate and delicious. The siphon bar brewing, complete with flames, made for quite a show as they made his pot to order.
author: Alicia P.

description: We found Blue Bottle on Yelp while visiting San Francisco. While it can be challenging to find the first time, and the line was long,  the coffee and atmosphere were definately worth the effort. The staff was helpful and friendly.
author: bert s.

description: Too many hipsters!?  Not worth the wait in line.  Peets is better!
author: Scotty 7.

description: Love to either have their New Orleans Iced coffee which a tiny bit sweet and super smooooothe or their Kyoto Iced coffee dark, bold ass yummy tasting coffee before they close around 7pm and wait in line for a show 20 feet across the street at Mezzanine.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
best americano i've ever had.  would've given 5 stars but portion was too small.

best take on eggs benedict ever.  a must.

coolest coffee equip on earth.
author: Michelle Q.

description:
Really delicious espresso. The flavors are well balanced and the roast is delicious - not bitter at all. They know how to make a thick foam and they even put a fancy design in the top. This is real quality espresso and it's some of the best I've had, unlike Crapé on the Corner (café on the corner) where unwashed rude hipsters serve stale espresso, over-pulled shots and loose dry foam. Sound familiar? Sound like every other lame cafe you've ever been to in San Francisco? Well not the Blue Bottle.

Blue Bottle employees are clean, well dressed, and they know a thing or two about how to pull a good shot.

One star off for the slowness and the fact that "they don't do single shots".
author: Brianna W.

description: I love coffee and was told to check out Blue Bottle on Mint St. while vacationing in San Fran.  Cool place, cool vibe & friendly people.  Went twice, and both times were pretty crowded with a line out the door.  I loved their Kyoto style Iced Coffee.  I wish we had a Blue Bottle Coffee Co. back home in Hawaii.
author: Michael B.

description:
I researched a few coffee places to visit each morning I was in town to see my brother.  I read some reviews on Yelp for each, and I was led to Blue Bottle because the organization brews each cup individually, which I always can appreciate.

I visited the Mint Street location.  The environment is nice; not the preferred shabby chic so many coffee houses prefer (see Philz review), but more downtown loft with high ceilings, plenty of tall windows, communal tables.

The coffee was good, not great.  A couple of points which make a difference for me and my experience.
- The business does not offer any sugar alternatives.  No Splenda, no Equal, no nothing.  Not everyone wants sugar.  Talk about lack of coffee diversity.  I might have seen sugar syrup; I wasn't sure because nothing was labeled, which leads me into complaint number 2
- Nothing was labeled.  They only had one milk bottle.  Well, which is it?  Milk?  Cream?  Half and half?  Soy?  Fat free?  Not really sure.  Why can't they have more alternatives, and label all of them.  Do they believe everyone partakes in the same beverage to mix in their coffee?
- Should I really wait 8 minutes for drip coffee?  I appreciate that it can take time, but that's slightly ridiculous for a cup of decent, but not superior, quality.  On a positive, the barista was friendly and she apologized for the wait.
- Why only one size?  Is there a rational reason for it?  If so, I'd like to know.
- Only one blend?  I assume that was the case because the barista didn't even ask me for a choice of bean.  Very disappointing because at least the other two I visited this weekend (Ritual and Philz) offered numerous coffee bean choices.
- Finally, like the other three, it was overpriced at $2.53 though I'm sure they're trying to pay rent in such a nice building.

I wouldn't come back here unless I was in the neighborhood and craving a cup of coffee  (and yet my cravings would need to withstand the painstakingly slow process of receiving said cup of coffee).
author: Brendan Jude L.

description:
The coffee is very high quality here.  The beans are freshly roasted and every cup of coffee is brewed by the cup.  The coffee shop is located in an old historic building.  The space is very small, but has a contemporary loft feel.  There is a big common table as well as bar counter seating.    

I absolutely love coffee and I like them strong.  All my life, I've never had a cup of coffee that's too strong in a cafe except for Blue Bottle.  I like the freshly roasted taste and the intense flavor, but I do have to add extra milk / half and half to "tone it down" a bit.  

I wanted to buy some beans here and make the coffee at home to tone it down a bit as I think the coffee bean quality is excellent here.  However, they don't sell beans ground (yes, whole beans is fresher, but I am willing to make that trade off in the morning as I don't want to grind coffee at 7 AM).  Oh well, for now, it's back to Peet's & Barefoot Cafe for beans.

You can also get Blue Bottle coffee in Hayes Valley (to go only) and at the Ferry Building on Tuesday at their stand in the Farmer Market.

Coffee - 5 stars
Atmosphere (this locale) - 4.5 to 5 stars
author: Paul K.

description: From the drip (which I'm very picky about) to the lattes, it's very well prepared and absolutely worth the trip. There's the usual line that extends out the door but it's worth it for the coffee.
author: Shauna S.

description:
damn good drip coffee. 

I must say, it's probably the best strong coffee i've tasted in San Francisco.
author: Eric Y.

description: Okay the coffee is good and everything but I'm not sure I understand why all the hype over this place. Is it better than Starbucks? Sure, but so is Peets and few other places. I guess you have to love your coffee to be able to think Blue Bottle is off the charts.
author: Leanne S.

description:
Awesome latte - not too milky, no sugar required, and came with a pretty fern on the foam. Thought it was interesting that they don't offer any flavors for their lattes (unlike Starbucks, which I dig for their cinnamon dolce and pumpkin spice lattes). Yet, the Blue Bottle latte was so good, it hit the spot right away. 
Yuppie crowd. Cool, minimalistic decor - metal bar stools give it a bit of an industrial look, and at the same time, ensure that you don't get too comfortable there. A bit difficult to spot if you haven't been there already....we had to ask a Security guard on Mint Plaza for directions to the place.
author: Shweta V.

description: I love blue bottle coffee because of the taste and the way they make it. I go to starbucks because its convenient and fast but when I have the time, I like to get great coffee and enjoy it. So Blue bottles one of the few places that I always get if I'm in a neighborhood that has it. Awesome coffee! I usually get the Cafe Au Lait or Latte but can't wait to try the other types. They have such a unique way of pouring coffee so it's a must see!
author: Tiffany L.

description: This particular location is my favorite. The siphon bar is cool and provides a crisp cup of coffee. The food is really delicious as well.
author: Steve S.

description:
I'm really more of a tea guy, myself.

That being said, the siphon coffee here was pretty good.  It was somehow milder than would be expected from what I suspect was a heavily steeped brew.  The sea salt caramel it was paired with was a well chosen, tasty offset.  It's a cool idea, and I appreciate the attention to quality associated with an operation like this.

On balance, it's hard to fault them for having a line out the door, and I was warned my drink would take 20 minutes to prepare - but it actually took about 35 minutes.  Also the decor here is not so endearing.  Sort of sleek and modern but lacking much comfort or warmth (the emotional kind; the temperature was actually too warm).
author: Oliver N.

description:
Pretty great coffee, but that's what you deserve for the price.

Modern interior, unassuming exterior (maybe they'll get a sign soon!). I like that the location is not right in the hustle and bustle, I hope it stays that way. Designed with just food and drink in mind: you don't go here with a laptop to work (no outlets: I'm sure a conscious decision), you get some coffee (perhaps some food), sit down, and enjoy it, briefly.

I'll go again, but that's because I don't know my other coffee options and don't know if I can find coffee as good nearby (any suggestions?).
author: Brian S.

description:
I wanted to believe more in Blue Bottle. I'd heard amazing things about their coffee, and I was excited to take my morning off and enjoy a good latte. After finding their location (only marked by a picture of a blue bottle), I established my place in a line that went out of the door. Normally long lines mean caffeinated goodness. 
To my dismay their breakfast menu was taken away by the time I made it to the front of the line. After making up my mind on an over priced pastry (that wasn't all that good) and an equally pricey latte, I found an uncomfortable seat and people watched. 
The over crowded seating area was a mix of suits and hipsters who hadn't grown into their heels. The seats were uncomfortable, and I wasn't too impressed with the layout of the baristas' work space or the seating area. 
My latte was lackluster... pretty but not warm nor strong enough. 

For all the people buzzing about Blue Bottle, I'd have to say I'd rather take my $10 elsewhere and get a full breakfast and a hot latte.
author: Leya C.

description:
Went on an incredibly rainy day in the mid afternoon so I managed to avoid a big crowd. I'm aware it's a 'spensive cup, so that wasn't a big shock, and I'll pay for quality.  Since I don't drink coffee much (unless in the presence of Blue Bottle, Ritual, or Philz) I figured I'd check the place out since it's only a few blocks from work. 

Ogled the NY Times-famous brewer and chatted with the friendly barista for a second, but ordered a latte that was so smooth it coulda been made by Perry Cuomo. About 1/2 hour later, I was so wired I was excited about the reports I was getting written for my database at work. (In an arts environment, that means I was REALLY excited). I spent a few hours buzzing about before the caffeine iron grip left me, but it was still worth the yummyness I experienced.

I'd love to see some more little snacks to enjoy with your beverage, and perhaps a better idea of what they are actually serving to nibble on, but all in all, it was as satisfying as I expected.
author: Emily L.

description:
Happened to be in that part of town today with the little one and husband. I was kind of excited since I hadn't been to this Blue Bottle, it was afternoon and time for a cup of coffee.

I get that there is this weird gentrification situation. 5th and Mission, kind of not a cool intersection. Lots of traffic, lots of lost tourists, elements of a little crazy and a couple of some down and out folks. Walk up a half block to Mint and its clean (okay, cleaner) and hipsters in orange chairs by Chez Papa. Lo and behold... Blue Bottle on the horizon.

No line. Nice. Order a couple of coffee drinks, a couple of cookies from Miette and wait. Not too much of a wait. Coffee, as expect was delightful. Not sure if I appreciated the "looks" from a couple of people there because we had a kid (she's a good kid). Hey, we were cool and young and hip once. 

While I love the coffee... I hate being in that part of town. I hate worrying about my little one touching something that she shouldn't while walking down the street. The traffic is terrible and the parking is ridiculous. Maybe, just maybe I'd come back if I'm around.
author: J B.

description:
Amazing, quality coffee with excellent, friendly service.

Since each drip coffee is individually prepared, don't go here if you are in a rush. Plus, there's always a line. But all for good reason. Its divine. 

A little too expensive for me to go to often, but the bacon brioche and a drip coffee is a great special treat to start a hard work day.
author: Dani S.

description: My family and I spent the day in the bay and had to stop by Blue Bottle Coffee. We ordered the cappuccinos and they were excellent. I wanted to go outside the box and order the Kyoto, boy it was super strong. It left an after taste and had me jittery the rest of the day. This place is super packed and always busy but it's worth the wait. Definitely will be back again.
author: Mr.rose J.

description:
i am one of these bizarre people who doesn't really like coffee, but will bend at the will of all things cold, sweet, and milky . . . mm ice cream. 
BUT i digress.

maybe it's just me, but this coffee makes me CRAZY. after i indulge in my 4 dollar (overpriced like whoa) iced coffee, i usually experience an exciting roller coaster of gratifying productivity and horrifying crankiness for a few hours. possibly worth it?

additionally, the attitude in here cracks me up. everyone is taking this coffee SO SERIOUSLY, like it is saving lives or reinventing coffee itself. well, i guess a $12 cup of coffee is a new invention?
author: shaine h.

description:
Awesome cappuccino. What struck me more was the number of hipsters hanging out in the industrial deco space. Everything that came into the eyes were photographic. I didn't think that the cappuccino was expensive - $3 for the European style cup, not bad. I shared Siphon coffee ($10) with my brother, and which gave me the plenty of caffeine to give me the jolt as I was finishing up the last drop. Oh, the siphon plate comes with delicious toffee square, which I'm pretty sure is made in their kitchen as well.  

Pretty people + delicious coffee. Not a bad combination.
author: Mio S.

description: Found this place as best coffee in SF, so we had to go.  Second day on our vacation and man, this is the best coffee Ive had since Italy.  Place was easy enough to find even though it is kind of hidden. Found a parking spot right in front.  Really wanted to sit down and try the siphoned coffee but no table space, this place was jam packed.  That, I guess, was the only draw back.  It took us 40 minutes to wait in line, place our order and get our coffees.  I ordered the individually prepared cup of coffee and Amanda had a soy latte.  I dont like the taste of soy milk, but this was latte was really amazing.  My cup of coffee was also amazing.  So much that I tried to make it last as long as possible.  Since then Ive been looking for a better than Starbucks experience.  I hear Intelligentsia in Pasadena is pretty good. Wish me luck.
author: Tony A.

description: Its a little off the beaten path as is typical of these types of coffee shops but well worth going to.  It's pretty much the same as any other blue bottle anywhere around the country, so expect absolutely excellent coffee (brewed to order!), lattes and interesting bakery items for prices that aren't too far off of Starbucks, but is SO much better
author: Andrew B.

description:
I hate to compare places because I believe in judging places by their own merit, but I suppose we all learn to understand things via comparison. Right? 

The only reason I found out about Blue Bottle was by reading yelp reviews for Barefoot Coffee Roasters in Santa Clara (http://www.yelp.com/biz/barefoot-coffee-roasters-santa-clara), so it's fair that I should compare.

I went to check out the Linden Street version first, just cuz I was in that area when it occurred to me. I wrote a review of it (summary: I speculated I didn't like it as much cuz it was a kiosk). So when I took my transplanted friend on his first SF outing in five million years, I decided to show him the famous SF cafe Blue Bottle even though I'd never been there. (I also took him to XOX truffles hahaa... I think I had ulterior motives here).

So this is where I finally share my impressions of the cafe, aka the beginning of the review?
.
.
.
wait for it....
.
.
.
Eh. It sure is stylish with it's concrete floors, gray everything, and steam punk siphon bar coffee thingie (hehehe STEAM punk. GET IT?!?! heh). But it might be the least cozy cafe I've ever been to. I think they're missing the point.
And the coffee is good. Sure it is. I would still not say it's better than Barefoot.

I would still like to try the siphon thingie-ma-bob, though.
author: Sasha W.

description:
Blue Bottle coffee beans (and the way they brew your beverage) makes for a superb coffee.  The store has glassware contraptions brewing beverages that makes for good eye candy... they even sell some interesting glassware so you can take the experience home (am I remembering that correctly, or was someone telling me that they had a set they got on craigslist?)

Hanging out on the plaza and sipping your coffee lends to a pleasant urban experience as you watch a shopping cart go by, some elderly dude practicing Tai Chi, and the every busy sky-scrape construction works walking to and fro.

Why 4 starts and not 5?  Well, I give the Blue Bottle cart at Berkeley's Farmer's Market 5 starts for sure.  This shop only gets 4 stars and here is why:
    One day a neighbor parent and I took our kids to the city on BART for excitement.  We hit Blue Bottle, walked around Union Square, and then BART'd home (amazing what passes for excitement in the 2 year old realm).  Anyhow, the patrons (the place was packed) looked at us and our kids like we were FREAKS from the East Bay.  You see, San Francisco SOMA area isn't really breeder territory.  Sipping their latte's, they sized our tots up as mere macchiato's on the scale of things. Tuh!

Recommendation: 
 Great coffee,
  don't go when it is totally packed,
  unless you are into meat markets.
A couple of people with bio-clocks a ringing in crowd did eye our kids -- so much so, I was worried they'd snatch one and raise her in their loft!
author: Rudy R.

description: Yay compostable cups but not for iced coffee. Deliciously snobby expensive coffee which I love. The tomato gardiniera is just a fancy word for ketchup. But yummy ketchup.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I don't know what they do that makes it so good, but holy crap.   This coffee is amazing.
author: Austin W.

description: Super great coffee and granola with apple compote. Toast is decent, poached eggs are quite good. One of my favorite coffee shops anywhere.
author: Stomping S.

description: Dee-lish poached eggs with white bean stew - love the big grilled slabs of Acme bread. I'm not a coffee drinker (gasp!) but this coffee is so good - not bitter at all, with layers upon layers of flavors. A bit on the pricey side (breakfast and coffee for two about $40 including a waffle to split) but worth it for the people-watching alone. Service could have been a bit more attentive for this much pomp.  Family-style seating, and limited to boot.
author: Emily C.

description:
Service really sucks. Too bad I still love their awesome coffee and make it a point to walk extra few blocks and get my cup of coffee before doing anything else in SF...maybe I should try a different location.

1 star for rude and inattentive service at the register (personal experience recently has been bad....maybe they're courteous only to regulars) . 

--------

Long lines (which is a good sign actually). But I've asked many times now for their siphon coffee..some reason or other never got to try it. :( Standard reply they're not making it right now? When do you make it then? "It depends!!" 

Ambiance is very modern and inviting (more active vs loungy). They have only a small store sign in front , wasn't easy to recognize the shop first time but now I know.
author: A K.

description: Finally got to try this place when  we went up north to visit the in laws. hehehe this was the best part of the trip =). i love coffee and i love blue bottle. i like it better than intelligentsia.
author: Suzie H.

description: Crowded on Saturday afternoon, but hell, I love the coffee. I am not a coffee affection ado, but I love Blue Bottle.
author: Marck N.

description:
No lie they make a good cup of coffee, but can we move things along any faster?

OMG, so all the people, ''in the know'' have found this spot and now the line is out the door.  Great, i love to support local business, but enough to get an ear full when I get back to the office.

Keep this in mind when you go, this is not going to be a quick trip.  It is never short of 10-15 mins waiting in line and getting your drinks.  Pls hire more people as when the line is 8-10 deep, you need more people making drinks.
author: Nicole F.

description: Love blue bottle espresso and mocha.
author: Nhung P.

description: I've been a barista for almost two years now, and rather then get sick of coffee, I love it more and more every day. I've tried many things on the menu at Blue Bottle, and they are the best out there. There's more to latte art than just aesthetics. In order to make that art, they have to make the perfect microfoam that feels like silk in your mouth, and the espresso has to have the perfect crema broken up when they pour the milk. It's a science, and Blue Bottle has it down. I could really dork out here, but I will spare you. I know coffee. They are the best in town.
author: Merrilee T.

description: I've been hearing lots about Blue Bottle Coffee, so when I found myself at Union Square, I quickly found the nearest Blue Bottle kiosk. I tried the New Orleans style iced coffee. For once, I didn't even need to add sugar! The coffee was smooth, flavorful, and not too bitter, just the way I like it. There were no lines and the cafe, which is tastefully furnished, was not too busy. I can see why this place is popular! I'll definitely be back to try some of their other drinks. The only downside is that at $3.83, I'm not sure if I'll be frequenting this place very much. While I concur that their coffee is good, it might not be worth the extra cash I'm shelling out. On a side note, some free wi-fi would make coming here more attractive!
author: Josh W.

description:
Atmosphere: Coffee-bar-ish. Packed and crowded during typical coffee fiending hours.

Service: Friendly and Funny. Mocked Jenny L., whom I laughed at.

Drinks: Gibraltar. Definitely hit the spot after a lazy afternoon. Coffee is also one of the best I've had.

Overall: Always a must get when I see one of their locations or know that I am nearby.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
I finally made it here after hearing, like, FOREVER about how great Blue Bottle coffee is. After all, I have been a coffee-anista since my early teens. I know good coffee. I have had coffee in Italy, Spain, Germany, France. In London, New York and Seattle. You get the picture. I am not a novice in this field.

So, the first time I went here I noticed the long lines, dirth of seating and stand-offish service, but no matter. The coffee was smooth, and gave a long lasting, deeply pleasureable caffeine high.

So, the following week i went 7 blocks out of my way to have another cup. I needed to work on a paper for school and figured I would combine coffee with a little word processing. I arrived and lo! it wasn't that busy. Then i noticed they seemed to have no outlets to plug in my Mac. Yeah, I'm a student, the battery is shot, i can't afford a new one right now.

I then make a cardinal mistake. I ask the short, unsmiling hipster barista, (yeah you, with the dark hair, looking like you're in Interpol or something), 'do you have any outlets in here?' He musters all his venom and snidely responds, "yes, we have THAT one" and points to an outlet 20 feet in the air by the ceiling. I say, 'that's not very helpful.' He responds, very pointedly, 'we're about the COFFEE in here.' I am dumbfounded and enraged, which I imagine was his intention. So I can't be there for the coffee AND want to use my laptop?

Well done. You just lost your boss a customer and earned this review, you supercilious little sh*t.

So, you are about the COFFEE, but not about being a CAFE, not about serving the needs of your CUSTOMERS and not about CUSTOMER SERVICE?

Oh, and $4 for a latte? I'll go to Philz next time. Coffee's good there, too.
author: Alison S.

description:
6 of us were on an espresso crawl in San Francisco...

Apple-store like ambiance thanks not only to the starkness, but the extremely well lit coffee making features which are clearly expensive and designed to impress you, distract you from the slowness, and make you think everything must be perfect here.

We got single origin espressos, regular espressos, cappuccino, and latte. The single origin espressos are usually pulled on a hand pull machine, but they explained that wasn't available today. Oh well. Then after ordering a couple of other drinks I ordered a 2nd single origin espresso and the same person started to explain the same thing. Didn't you just tell me that and I said OK?

We ogled the well lit glass coffee making items just like everyone else. It is a nice distraction while you wait. And wait. And wait.

While we waited we watched the FIVE people seemingly on staff at 4pm on a week day. Really? Five? Two people were on staff at Ritual and they took less time to take our order and serve us our drinks than these guys took just taking our order and we were down to 5 drinks by this time. One person took orders. Two people were on the espresso machine. One was washing dishes. The other walked back and forth a lot and we never figured out what she was doing. She had her jacket on so we thought at first she wasn't on shift, but she kept being behind the bar and kept walking back and forth, so who knows.

Finally, they called out my name. Two of the five drinks were made. They were a latte and a cappuccino and they were gorgeous. The cappuccino had not even 1/8th an inch of foam on top. There was no gradation of coffee/milk/foam as I would expect. It looked great, but wasn't what I expected.

Then we waited and waited and waited. Slowly the 3 espressos came out. This time the same guy called out "single origin espresso" even though I was standing right there and had just picked up drinks from the same order sheet so he knew my name. Every time he would call out a drink someone else would start to stand up to get the drink so I had to stay and hover to get what were clearly still my drinks from my order. I even asked the barista to sure and so the other people would know I wasn't taking their drinks. If you know my name and you can see that a ton of people are waiting and starting to grab the same drink, you call out the person's name if you know it.

All the while, there are two people at the espresso machine. What on earth is the second person doing? Cleaning? I can't quite tell. But she isn't pulling shots and while the guy pulling my shots is fantastic to look at and he has a great voice, he is the slowest barista we've seen today.

Anyway, once we all FINALLY got our drinks they were excellent. The single origin espresso was fantastic. Truly. Wow. Did I say wow? Wow. Totally worth $3 for an espresso.

The standard espresso was surprisingly similar to our usual haunt in the East Bay, Zocalo Coffeehouse.

I would have rated this a 5 star based solely on the drinks this time around, but the shockingly slow service and the fact that the drinks were only so-so last time I was here brings it down to a 4 star. I might have even gone down to a 3 star, but the single origin espresso was just so good I can't do it.
author: Mitch H.

description: The coffee here is killer along with the few food items you can order.  The staff is also friendly and efficient even though there's always a line out the door.  Don't worry if you can't find a seat inside the cafe - go find a chair in Mint Plaza and enjoy the great weather!
author: Vicente G.

description: For some reason the MINT PLAZA location is my favorite place for sipping a Blue Bottle Mocha...T.H.E. single M.O.S.T. amazing mocha latte you will ever sip.  Ever.
author: Lisa D.

description:
The coffee definitely gets five stars. After being irritated with the staff, nonchalant and too busy discussing whatever hipsters discuss (e.g., music, local art, uhh, music), the coffee was calming and almost worth the disregard the staff offered us. Definitely the best coffee I've had in San Francisco, to date. 

Hard to find and near a shady little alley (Jessie). Close to the 80. The friend I came with got me excited about the siphon/vacuum coffee thing but they curtly explained they only do it around four PM (but that they hadn't done it that day?). 

In short, not a fun experience but the coffee was great. : )
author: Sweet T.

description:
I went to two places looking for this giant apparatus for dripping coffee, and both times I struck out.  Where is this darn thing? I think the Food Network misled me.

Regardless, it's not here.  We popped in for some bagged beans to take home to my boss, and of course, if you know me in "real life", to refuel on the mid-afternoon caffeine jumpstart #1.  The bags of beans are all-kinds of expensive for half the size you'd get at a mainstream coffee shop, and they don't have a very large variety.  However, the coffee is tasty and always fresh, so I forgive the lack of options.

The plan drip coffee is also really expensive.  $2.30 for a small/medium cup?  A bit rich for my blood, but I do really appreciate a nice cuppa joe.

Like the other Blue Bottle I visited, this place has a weird setup that screams "inefficient".  The like queues out the door, but there's a bit space on the other side of the coffee bar...and a GIANT table for family-style seating while you munch on your lunch.  The flow of traffic is awkward, cumbersome, and unintuitive, especially for a shop that brews each cup separately...I appreciate the personal attention and freshness, but the traffic flow should support the business model.
author: Heather G.

description: The is place is a bit overrated and pretentious. The waffle was not bad, but my bf thought it was a bit hard.
author: Leah C.

description:
I had a cup of latte last week.  And WOW that was my best latte so far!  It's even nicer and better than Intelligentsia  in Chicago.  I mean Intelligentsia is very good but this one is just better : )

The decoration is pretty cool....small but that's okay.  People are here for coffee and they can go sit somewhere else.  I wish they open more locations with same standards.  That would be great!
author: Jay A.

description: Although the coffee is great, this location needs to better appreciate their loyal customers.  There were 25 people in line while only 2 folks were preparing coffee.  The other employees were not rushing or hustling at all.  A simple "we'll be right with everyone", eye contact plus a smile would go a long way.  The impression is that we somehow don't need to go back to basics on customer service.  Thanks for listening.
author: Jeff R.

description: I don't drink coffee but my gf does.  We came here and waited patiently for 40 minutes.  What a waste of time right?  Well, my gf said it was worth it.  So 5 star.
author: Roger W.

description:
CLEARLY the highlight of my SF trip.  I'm a super coffee snob, and this place is as good as it gets.  It's pretty obvious that the people in that city care about coffee too.....because the line can get long.  It's MORE than worth it.

I went there twice on my last trip.  The espressos get two snaps in a circle!  What almost blew my pants off was the Poached Eggs w/ Buttered Thick Cut Acme Toast, Prather Ranch Cured Ham, and Gruyere Fonduta.  I could *not* believe how tastey this was!  Not something I could (or should) eat every day.......but what an incredible treat!

The next time I'm in San Fran, I'll definitely be stopping by! In the mean time, I'll also be filling my needs with mail order beans!
author: Chris M.

description:
When I first moved to the bay area I was disappointed with its lack of quality coffee houses. But when I stumbled on Blue Bottle in an alley one day, and it's been love ever since.

The staff here are always friendly, the coffee quality is always superb, and the food is incredibly tasty. I'd recommend trying the siphon coffee once just for the experience, although I think the flavor is a little overrated.
author: Laura C.

description: There needs to be a Blue Bottle Coffee in every major city. I highly recommend the new orleans iced coffee if you are an iced coffee connoisseur.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Stumbled in here randomly & was super excited because I've always wanted to try their beans.

Good tasting, but cold cappuccino.

Crazy hot chocolate.  More for the cocoa crowd than the chocolate crowd (it's not really sweet).

I didn't know what all the contraptions were for until I read these reviews!  You'd think that being *in* the place would be more informative.  But no, this place is the epitome of "bougie" - I felt more comfortable drinking my cap in the rain.

Their beans and kiosk may be great (still don't know) but the cafe needs some soul.
author: David R.

description:
Kinda hard to find this place.. I walked from Powell BART station to Union Square, to the SF mall, to SOMA thinking it was "somewhere around Union Square" only to confirm by calling a friend to check on the exact location on Yelp, haha.. Anyway, the place is really small with little seating, but the coffee is so smooth. And there's no pastries either. I did get to see the $20,000 coffee machine though, wow so awesome.

3 hours later and I'm wired as we speak! :o
author: Fotos C.

description:
Update Wednesday, 26. March 2008:
Rating goes + one-star as I am now a regular for the black Kyoto-style [cold brew] iced coffee. Many days it's like coffee liqueur, a rich caramel character without bitterness. Caffeination supreme. Very visible bicycle racks just across little Mint St.

-----

Found Blue Bottle this lovely Sunday morning, just as the rain showers sputtered out. Very surprised to see it PACKED for BRUNCH. Yes real food. Contrary to other reviews, BBC isn't just coffee. Maybe the food is just a Sunday Brunch thing?

All the menu items looked delicious, but I wanted a place to chill out for a quiet coffee & reading time; BBC is definitely not on that vibe today. Ordered an espresso anyway, to sample the java. They delivered a short double with beautiful dark crema. Honestly, to dark & smokey for my taste... I like a lighter, fruitier bean/roast.

The siphon coffee looks interesting. Will definitely return for further exploration.
author: Mars H.

description:
The coffee was really good, and it's very entertaining just to watch them brew it.

I loved the space itself, high ceilings and open family-style tables, lots of light from the many windows.  I did think it was funny though, that 6th/Mission is right around the corner with bums and all, yet this place is packed with hipsters.

Almost everyone who worked there was really helpful and informative, but the dude at the register seemed to be pissed that we had such a large party on one order (work outing).  

The toast with egg imbedded is interesting, but I really thought the toast was a little too big and too flakey.
author: Aimee B.

description:
We had just driven back over the bridge, somewhat sleepy from wine tasting over at a place in Sausalito, and unanimously, we all agreed -- We need some coffee!

My friend had heard about Blue Bottle from her sister who visited the Hayes Valley location.  Since we were heading downtown, we decided to head over there.

Located in what seemed like a hidden spot just left of the hustle and bustle of the San Francisco Shopping Center sits BlueBottle Coffee Co.  We thought we were lost until we noticed a small sign with a picture of a blue bottle.

Upon closer examination, this place is packed!  The line was almost out the door when we got there, and it did go out the door by the time we were in the middle of the line.  When inside, we couldn't help but notice what looked like scientists/chemist bottles at the far end of the store, which actually were used to drip coffee.  The menu was small and simple and had just the usual coffee drinks -  cappuchino, mocha, latte, macchiato, etc.

I ordered their individual drip coffee.  I appreciate good coffee (bad coffee is such a shame, seriously) and they have GREAT coffee!  The atmosphere and ambience was pretty cool too!  I felt like a hipster, like -- I was hanging with the cool art crowd!

Next time I'm around downtown, I am definitely not going to settle for anything less.  I'm making my way over here for some, finally, good coffee!
author: Crys L.

description:
Sure, I'll give 'em five.
Yesterday I went to the Bluebottle for the first time, since a friend of mine told me it would be a good place to kill some time. I wouldn't say it was killed at all, but given an expansion. The coffee was perfect. I mean it. Perfect. The siphon wasn't in commission while I was there, so I got a simple cup of drip coffee. 
I've had Starbucks coffee once in my entire life, and the physical effect was enough to make me never go back. Jittery, sweaty, antsy, icky. The coffee at Bluebottle was like having tea with extra caffeine. None of the coffee effects, except the rush. 
I had a few teeny cookies too, and they were hella tasty. 
Buttery and crumby and small enough to try one of each. 
AND...
everyone working there was beautiful. And smiling. Which is nice.
(by the way, I just noticed a picture of my housemate working there...learn something new everyday, I guess.)
author: Sera L.

description:
Good coffee, comparable to the coffee from Barefoot Cafe. 

Nothing like a good soy latte on a cold rainy day with your friends.  

This place is very modern and chic.  Not the dark brown classy singer song writer coffee house feel...  but I like that feel.  But this place is still really good, love the coffee.
author: Seung O.

description: This is no rock concert.  And i say that because of the line. When patrons are waiting in a line that runs outside and around the corner of Jessie St. I'd consider this the most anticipated Cup o' Joe one could ever imagine. So make the most of your order. Get the espresso, French press, or the esoteric drippings of the imported Japanese siphon bar. Or try one of each. For something sweet, the melon cup with cottage cheese is tasty. Conversely the poached eggs on toasted brioche is an impeccable savory must order. Good things come to those who wait. Blue Bottle will not disappoint.
author: Alex H.

description: Best coffee and latte in San Francisco - and possibly in the continental US for that matter! I like coming here to do a little reading or people watching  - all while sipping on a delicious soy latte :)
author: Amanda C.

description: Perhaps the best latte anywhere, try the single source espresso for a truly sublime experience, and brunch on the weekends is a treat too.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Open airy lovely space on a quiet side street. Had the New Orleans iced coffee which is strong and lightly sweetened. If you are looking for something akin to Starbucks or Dunkin' Donuts iced coffee, this is not it. Will go for a hot drip or latte next time.
author: Rhea G.

description:
Three cheers for Blue Bottle's first cafe! I'd been delaying my first trip to BB since their other locations lack a place to sit. Today was their grand opening and that, no doubt combined with the mention in the NY Times, left the place super packed. However the staff was very friendly and courteous, and the coffee was excellent!

The cafe serves a number of traditional espresso and coffee drinks, and then the fancy single-origin beans made in the siphon bar (http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/23/dining/23coff.html), paired with some form of sweet for around $10. Fairly expensive yes, but you get your own pot with enough coffee for two, plus milk and sugar on the side, served at your seat.
author: Will A.

description:
Stopped by for a light nibble and something to drink before heading to a pilates session yesterday. It was one of those hot weekends in San Francisco (a rarity) and I'd heard this place had great coffee. Unfortunately, I didn't have any as me on caffeine and pilates isnt' a good combo. I did try the poached eggs on acme bread, which was really tasty. For $1 more, I got some of their sweet jam to go on the bread. Not a lot of jam for $1 mind you, but enough to satisfy my sweet tooth. 

The staff was nice...my only complaint is that it was TOO DARN HOT in the place. One wall of windows wouldn't open, and the staff said they'd be fixed next week. Luckily, I snagged a stool near one of the open windows on the other side of the room. I'm going back to try the coffee, which I did this morning...wow! Smooth, strong and delicious, just like a date I had last week.
author: David G.

description:
My americano rocked -- so good I can't help but give this place 5 stars.  The guy at the register was also helpful and actually gave a rip about customer service.  They had inadvertently given someone the wrong coffee, but the customer hadn't even noticed, and the staff was genuinely concerned about it.  
Plus, I was thinking about buying some coffee but they only had one bag left.  After asking me how I prepared my coffee (french press, thank you very much for the oh-so slightly knowing smile of snobbish rapport) the guy recommended I wait till the next day for more appropriate beans.
