If the coffee hadn't been amazing I might have given it 4 stars for itty-bitty little bar stools - great for svelte urbanites, but a bit small for the average adult - and the somewhat dodgy neighborhood.  Mint Square itself is gentrification on steroids, but the rest of the area has yet to follow.
author: Tullia F.

description:
Okay, a review of Blue Bottle has to start with the coffee.  Honestly though, it's been covered.  There's even a Chronic article about it.  Just for the sake of saying it though, the coffee is amazing.  Period.  There are lots of great coffee shops in the city, they all have their own reason for being awesome, Blue Bottle is awesome because it has amazing single serving drip.

I'm going back on Thursday for the Siphon coffee, I just didn't want to try to drink a pot for two all by myself.  I probably would have reached low earth orbit.

Okay, so the food - which is (-1 star).  The food was amazing, tasty and delicious, but it just wasn't enough for lunch.  I was expecting to get Lunch, really I had a snack and was hungry for the rest of the day.  So, I think the place is great.  I expect to try their breakfast stuff eventually, and I'm going to try the Siphon coffee on Thursday.  Cross your fingers, maybe I'll give them that 5th star.
author: Jonah H.

description:
My friend, who was once in his no coffee phase and is now in his no meat phase, insisted we come to Blue Bottle for their coffee.  Since it was unseasonably hot in SF, we all ordered the New Orleans style iced coffee.  I must say, I was prepared not to be taken in by the hype, but I truly and deeply enjoyed it!

I also liked the atmosphere, with the long communal table and stools, which invites conversation and no camping (like the lazy lounge chairs in other coffee shops).  I noticed many people would come and go, not for wi-fi, interviews, or air conditioning, but really just for the great coffee and the science behind it.  I hope to come back soon, so I can give their regular drip coffee (hot) a try!
author: EurJean C.

description:
I was hoping to have a tasty breakfast, but when I walked in, Blue Bottle was packed to the point of being uncomfortable. I ordered a latte to go and a bag of Giant Steps coffee to take home with me. The siphon bar looked really neat, but I didn't have a chance to sit and sip. 
However, as I walked around the downtown area during a gorgeous San Francisco morning, sipping the best latte I've ever had, I think I may have accidentally stumbled upon nirvana.
author: Heather S.

description: I just love Blue Bottle coffee.  There are better coffee at other places but this place is pretty damn good.  I usually get the mocha.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Tried the New Orleans Iced coffee.
It was good. 
Cold brew coffee, milk, & sweetener of some kind.
In my opinion, there are better sweet coffee drinks in la.
author: pineapple l.

description: I really wish we had one of these in Austin. It is located inside the old Mint building and the architecture is cool and the space is minimal.  The coffee was great and you can tell the baristas put a lot of effort into brewing it just right - even down to the coffee art in the latte - something you never get here.  The acme sourdough bread was great as well.  So good we came back for breakfast again the next day.
author: Helen T.

description: What can I say.  While they made one cup at a time as the orders came in, I watched people leave the line after they had already been waiting for 20 minutes.  I waited the full 40 minutes for my single batch drip coffee.  The coffee was good.  Not nearly good enough to justify the wait or price.  If I could be assured of spending no more than 10-15 minutes to acquire my cup of coffee, I would definitely go back.  That won't happen because the service model (or lack there of) is broken at Blue Bottle.  Every other person orders a drip coffee: why not start a few in advance?  The result will be exactly the same, minus waiting forever to order, and then another 10 minutes for your actual order to be served.  Also, how is it every time I go to Blue Bottle, I feel like I am inconveniencing the person behind the counter?  Still, the coffee is good, so they probably deserve a bit more than 1 star.  Yelp, any chance you will start allowing  fractional stars?
author: Jeff C.

description: Espresso done right. Period. Single origins on the old-skool Naples-Style hand pull machine. Sweet. I go whenever I'm in the city.
author: C. J.

description: Beautiful coffee, naturally, but what I didn't expect was the perfection that was two poached eggs over thick-cut acme sourdough.  A smidge pricey, some might say, but they were, without doubt, the best I've ever had.  Cheers to my new morning routine!
author: Allison B.

description: Blue Bottle has the best coffee in San Francisco - Absolutely love their cappuccino. This location in SOMA is in an alleyway off from the main street not easy to find, but once you see the long line to get in, you know you are in the right spot. This location has a counter with seating area and newspapers which it makes this a more enjoyable experience.
author: Gigi W.

description:
I had read multiple reviews about this spot and really wanted to check it out. It is located past the bustle of the San Francisco Shopping Center, a block through some sketchiness, and behind the Old U.S. Mint. It's like a breath of upscale hipster in the middle of seediness - just what I love about SF!

I stood in the line out the door and contemplated my coffee selection. Nearly $4 for a cup of iced coffee? Really!? I asked the guy what he recommended. Although I would have liked to see the barista use the glass apparatus to make my overpriced cup of coffee, I instead went with the New Orleans Style Iced Coffee - one sip and I decided it was totally worth it. The coffee was delicious. Flavorful, unique, sweet, but not cloying - I could taste every chicory note. Fabulous, if expensive.

This spot is perfect for meeting up with a friend or just grabbing a coffee to go. Why would you ever go to Starbucks?
author: Carolyn S.

description: Quite possibly the best coffee in town. Seriously it doesn't get much better than this, Philz and Peets just wish they had what Blue Bottle brings to coffee. The drip coffee is like something out of a dream, with fancy chemistry style drip coffee makers, you can definitely taste the love put into each and every cup. I'm happy after leaving Blue Bottle, even though they have long lines and many times no where to sit, and even once they ran out of soy milk, I've still yet to be unsatisfied.
author: nathan r.

description: The food is pretty good - but not 5 stars (maybe not 4).  BUT it is the best coffee in the city AND specifically Kyoto style is unique and incredible.
author: Victor B.

description:
Amazing coffee. Our new bean of choice for the apartment.

Love the Kyoto iced coffee, and the Japanese evaporating machine is a delight to watch.
author: Ryan M.

description: I liked the coffee here. I tried the Yemen and the Yirgacheffee. The Yemen was alright, but the Yirgacheffee made one of the best cups of coffee I've had in a while. The staff here was helpful in giving recommendations for what was good to try. They were also really patient with answering a ton of questions that my serious coffee drinker friends had about the preparation of the coffee.
author: Kristen R.

description:
A little hidden jewel on Jesse Street. I really only thought the 20k machine was in Hayes Valley.

I didn't have funding to splurge on a $9 coffee pot, but luckily we got to peep the process of brewing. It's really quite interesting and I am intrigued  to try it when I get a chance. 

My first visit had me contemplate between Kyoto and New Orleans. I opted for NO and it was very good. Quite robust and almost reminiscent of Vietnamese Style Iced Coffee...God knows what Chickory is?!  But yes.. the flavor soothed my senses and was not watery or too sweet to the taste.  My pal ordered a Latte and had an adorable little Heart Foam thing goin' on.

So yes. Next time... the special pot!!
author: Alyson C.

description:
The coffee was great - not life changing, but very good.  The staff was super friendly and took the time to explain the different coffees and brewing processes.  I had the New Orleans style iced coffee, which was perfect.  Not too sweet and just the right depth of flavor.  The only downside was when the server looked at me like I had two heads when I asked her for a straw.  Apparently straws are too declasse for Blue Bottle.  But I thoroughly enjoyed the coffee and the overall experience.  

I purchased a pound of beans to take home with me to try out in our french press.  Based on the cafe I had high expectations.  Sadly, I wasn't impressed.  I actually prefer the beans I buy at Starbucks or *gasp* Costco.
author: Erin W.

description:
Stopped by last Saturday after hearing about the 20$K Japanese Siphon Bar Coffee Machine everywhere online. Neat little spot with a long line but well worth the wait. It was pretty hot that day so I decided to order a New Orleans Iced Coffee. Great flavors. I usually dose my coffee with extra sugar but I decided against it since I wanted to savor the amazing flavors. Best iced coffee I have ever had. 

I would love to give this a 5 star but the melt-y coffee cups resulted in a mess all over my white dress shirt and dripping everywhere in the shops. 

Definitely a place to stop by if you're in the SF area. Now I have to find a place as good in NYC.
author: Anne W.

description: Definitely lived up to the hype! The coffee was phenomenal and the atmosphere was chill. The simple design made it easy to relax. The only complaint is the line takes a while.
author: Chris D.

description:
this blue bottle coffee cafe is tucked away 2 blocks away from the hustle and bustle of union square and the cable car turnaround.  it's kind of in a hidden spot at 66 mint.

luckily we beat the line when we got there.  the drip coffee and cafe au lait is always a great choice.  my favorite blend so far is the "big steps" which has a slight chocolate-y flavor to the roast.

if you're early enough, you can try their brunch menu which sells out pretty early.  this is the only location with seating (which is limited) and  the line is not has ridiculous has the ferry building location.
author: Carli F.

description:
My best friend said Blue Bottle is the best coffee she's ever had. While I was skeptical at first because I am the type of person that drinks coffee around three times a day, I was not disappointed - it may have even been the most top notch cup of Joe of my life. 

Amongst three friends, we split a cappuccino, a New Orleans iced coffee (with milk and sweetener), and a Kyoto iced coffee (darker and "more robust," as the easy-on-the-eyes barista so aptly phrased it). The cappuccino was to die for, the New Orleans was the perfect amount of bitter (no need for additional sweetener or cream or regret because of too much), and the Kyoto displayed the majesty of the sour, bitter tones present within the coffee. Some yelpers have complained about the coffee not piping hot enough, but really, it's a blessing - you WANT to drink this elixir right away, and my cappuccino was the perfect 
temperature. 

Blue Bottle is a must visit, period. The ambiance is nice, but really who cares? It's quite possibly what my best friend alleges it always will be - the best coffee in the city.
author: Luke L.

description: i would have loved to write a review for this BB location. whenever  i visit San Francisco i make a point to visit BB coffee and enjoy their variety of great espressos. however, i was very disappointed to stand in line all the way out side the store and wait for a prolonged period of time for it to move... the only time it has moved was when people left the line in front of me. this happened again later in the day after i walked  all the way to the store later in the afternoon. Ladies  and gentlemen at Blue Bottle. making a great cup of coffee is one part of the equation for a good business. please take your heads out of your asses and move those lines. i will be honest with you that i am  and routing for other independents to compete with you... they will get my business.
author: Alon O.

description:
The Blue Bottle, San Francisco California

Blue Bottle, San Francisco Coffee Shop Reviews: For Great Food & Amazing Coffee

The Blue Bottle handles coffee the way gourmet restaurants handle wine. If you want your cup taken seriously then this is the place to go. The options are wide, varied and affordable. This makes it a great place to frequent regularly. Although the place is known for its astounding coffee, Blue Bottle boasts a menu filled with simple flavor combinations that provide a gastronomic adventure to all.

The menu is extremely important to every coffee shop review because it says a lot about the type and range of services the establishment can offer. The breakfast, dinner and lunch menu changes throughout the year depending on what fresh produce or catch is locally abundant or available. It's a great way to learn about the area's local market. The ingredients are fresh and organically produced to guarantee safety from chemicals.

The interior design is crisp and simple and provides a sense of space and airiness. The lighting is strategically placed to cast a warm glow over the premises for a cozy and intimate feeling. Ambiance is considered for coffee shop reviews because it dictates how the customer feels as they walk inside the restaurant. The Blue Bottle projects an image of sophistication and elegance without being stiff or fussy.

You can opt for full table service or you can just get something to go. Either way, the staff will always be polite and helpful. Staff service can make or break a coffee shop review because everyone wants to be treated well. Customers who have experienced rude service are unlikely to come back even if the food and drinks are exceptionally good. A place's reputation and following depends on the quality of service almost as much as the quality of food being served.

Coffee is the heart and soul of Blue Bottle and it is what has given them much acclaim in numerous coffee shop reviews. Blue Bottle serves what is arguably the best coffee in the world. Some clarify that they serve the best coffee outside of Europe but almost every critic agrees that the coffee is astounding. Many coffee lovers deal with overpriced, over caramelized drinks that are more sugar than coffee. Blue Bottle respects the taste and subtle nuances of real coffee and complements the flavors with their own serving style. The beans they use are roasted locally or on site for maximum flavor and freshness. Connoisseurs will delight in exotic and regional choices of bean that reflect their origin and offer different flavor bouquets.

Combine great coffee with amazingly tasty pastries and you get the perfect hangout spot for people who want a brief respite from the business of their lives. This makes it ideal for a quick get-together, brunch with friends or a place to rest after a hectic bout of shopping. The combination of food choices, drink options, ambiance, cleanliness and service makes Blue Bottle the subject of resoundingly positive coffee shop reviews. Each aspect has been given special care and attention to ensure only the best for each customer.

 Augustus Smith. Worlds Finest Coffees.
 For additional reviews see.

http://www.worldsfinestcoffees.com/
author: Augustus S.

description: Try the slow-brewed Kyoto iced coffee. Very good, very strong.
author: Randy M.

description:
Hmmm.  I'm conflicted about this.   No one needs to sell me on Blue Bottle's coffee.  I could fall from my bike into a puddle of sewage on the way to their Hayes St. kiosk - but I'd soldier on - and by the time I took my last sip of Gibraltar I'd be thinking about how the sight of brown slime drying on my battered organic jeans is beautiful, as is everything in this fair city.

Therefore, it kinda hurts me to say that I think the cafe is missing something.  Nice windows, plenty of light, but sterile-feeling.  Plus stonefaced staff and pricey food.  

I met my sis there yesterday morning before she barted out of town, and we walked in just before 8.  No line!  Window seats aplenty!  But service was lukewarm to indifferent, and we each paid $9 for our coffees plus little breakfast buns that appeared to be the only food items on offer.  

Coffee was pristine as usual, and the brioche buns still-warm and buttery, but just as we started sipping and I told my sister that I thought they had an actual breakfast menu, a copy of the food list was plunked next to the register.  I'd have liked to know when ordering that steel-cut oats and eggs and toast were also options.  

Maybe they're aiming for a different downtown crowd with this buttoned down, more-formal package, but for now I prefer to stand in a dripping alley and shout out my order.
author: Erin K.

description: The coffee is great. The best in SF. But the staff have to get over themselves, stop posing, pick up the pace and make some coffee. I know it takes longer to make a good coffee. But sometimes it is ridiculous in there.
author: Greg B.

description: I thought Peets was strong but this coffee takes the cake! Made the vein in my forehead pop out. Liquid crack baby!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
It's the first day they are open and all, so I might revise this later, but right now all I can say is that I hope that this spot isn't a sign of where things are heading for the whole company. I love, love, love the coffee, so it really pains me to have to hate this new cafe. Yes, the space is beautiful, but in a supermodel kind of way - tall, icy and unapproachable. The place is seriously lacking in warmth - from the glass separating the masses from the coffee-making chemistry set to the matching uniforms that have turned the cool funky staff into some sort of barista-bots.  You will find me washing away the pretension over at the kiosk Hayes Valley.....

Update: Since everyone is bitching about the no wireless I just want to say that I for one appreciate when a cafe just says no to people camped out for hours on their laptops. Get a grip people - you can be without the internet for five freakin minutes and actually take the time to pay attention to what you are consuming or maybe - horror of horrors - interact with the people sitting around you at the communal table.
author: Claire B.

description:
Tried their super-expensive siphon coffee this past weekend. I was really hoping that I wouldn't like it that much, since it costs $10-12 a pop, and seems generally kinda snooty to specially import a crazy $20,000 machine. 

Unfortunately, the fancy-schmancy siphon coffee was delicious. And since the portion serves two people nicely, the $10-12 price tag is not quite as bad. Still pretty ridiculous, but sort of justifiable if I try really hard. 

Also, I really like the simple food that they serve. Blue bottle knows that if you take fresh bread, toast it and slather a crapload of butter on it, it's gonna be delicious. Who am I to argue? I left carbo-loaded and highly caffeinated, both of which had me buzzing a bit. Granted, the total cost per person was about $17, but you're gonna shell out at least $10 for a greasy-ass pile of eggs at any other place, so I wasn't really too peeved about it. 

I would give 5 stars for the food & coffee, but ended up giving just 4 because the prices really are high, and it's pretty crowded on the weekends to the point where I feel like I have to hurry up so that other people can get a chance to sit.
author: Julie J.

description:
This place is great!  I live nearby, and I'm so happy to have a place for delicious brunch.  And since it is off the beaten track, not too many touristy looking people.  

Coffee - I've had the siphon coffee and french press coffee.  Both are excellent.  The siphon coffee is extremely rich and flavorful.  I prefer ordering the darkest roast, as the coffee has more body.  While some might balk at the price ($10-$13, depending on the roast), one is essentially getting the equivalent of 4 espressos (don't get this if you want to sleep anytime soon!).  Additionally, the siphon coffee comes with some toffee or caramel, which enhances the flavors of the coffee.

Food - DELICIOUS.  I've eaten here for brunch twice.  Both times I've ordered the Artichoke Shepard's Pie.  Huge chunks of artichokes and caper berries in a tomato base, topped with potato puree.  Last time, I split with my sister, so I could have part of her Belgian waffle.  She said it was the best Belgian waffle she's ever had.  Its served with maple syrup and butter.  The consistency is light, crunch on the outside and moist on the inside.  My husband has had the Popeye Eggs (toast with a hole cutout and an egg inside) and the Croque Madame.  Again, both delicious.  

The minus one star is for their seating.  It can get crowded and some people tend to linger, so if you are with a couple friends, getting seats at the long table in the middle can be difficult.
author: Jory R.

description:
Do you cringe every time you take a sip of your coffee, but yet you still drink it every day? Blue Bottle is your solution!

I never knew that coffee could taste so good. I'm not sure if it's just weak coffee or if it just tastes amazing, but I'll give them the benefit of the doubt.

I ordered a Cafe Au Lait made w/ soy, which was probably the best coffee I've ever had. They make the mochas with recutti chocolate and they are delicious, but not too sweet.

They also have a brunch menu, which looks really good and seems very reasonable.

I would much rather walk all the way there than wait in line at the stand at the ferry building farmer's market.

The space is cute, the coffee machines look really cool & the crowd seemed classy & hip.

I am in love with Blue Bottle...it's going to be my new weekend coffee spot!
author: Elaine S.

description:
Best Soy Latte I have ever had.  The drip is amazing too!

This is another reason that San Francisco rules!  It is the best coffee city in the U.S.  Yes, even better than Seattle!  The rest of the U.S. sucks when it comes to coffee.  I can't believe they rave about Dunkin Donuts coffee back East.  That crap back East is like hot water with a coffee bean thrown in for flavor.  I usually go to the kiosk in Hayes Valley.  Worth the wait.
author: Roy J.

description:
So, as you have prob read you need to try the siphon coffee here.  how is it?  delicious.  very very good coffee, though a higher price indeed.  
the decor is great here.  high ceilings, not too much busy work around the walls.  cute little table and window bench to sit at.  
the french toast looked amazing, though we found it a bit dry and not fluffy.  I would not recommend it. 
the first time i went i found some of the staff sort of unhappy.  does it take so much effort to smile?  however the next time i went i had a great conversation with the cashier/barrista and my faith was restored. :)
author: Andrew r.

description: Had slow-dripped ice coffee new orleans style and japanese style and it was like drinking a milk chocolate espresso and a dark chocolate espresso.  The polenta waffles looked amazing and inspired me to change my recipe a bit (had just made some this morning and they just needed something new in them!)  The service was deliberately slow but I appreciated that when it was my turn they were all ears.  I could sense a little frustration from the line but they have a complex way of preparing drinks that just takes a little longer.
author: Norman P.

description: The siphoned coffee at Blue Bottle is divine!  And the mocha is not overly sweet but more rich and chocolate-y, which I love!.  It's also wonderful that all the espresso drinks are made with organic milk which in general makes a tastier latte or mocha.  But what made me want to give this place more than 5 stars was the rosemary pine nut shortbread.  IT WAS LIKE A PIECE OF HEAVEN!  The perfect blend of sweet and savory in every bite!  The rosemary and pine nut harmoniously blended together with the sweetness and butter of shortbread finished off with a little sea salt left my taste buds singing the Hallelujah Chorus!
author: Ingrid L.

description: Perfection. Truly perfection. It doesn't matter which location, you are lucky enough to visit, you are in for a treat. Trust me. Coffee is my business and I know what I am talking about.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Wow, so walking up to Blue Bottle and seeing a line wrapped around the corner both angered and excited me. My friend was visiting from Hong Kong so I was forced to stand in line and wait. Boy am I glad that I did!

Our toast and grilled cheese was delicious. I will say it is a little pricey for grilled cheese at $10, but made with gourmet ingredients so it was worth it! A friend of ours got the yogurt parfait, he was not too pleased. You may want to skip that if you go to Blue Bottle. Coffee was perfect, as expected. 

My next visit to Blue Bottle will be to get the Gibraltar. Keep you all posted!
author: Matt K.

description: A round of applause for the coffee guys! I had a Soy Mocha and am sticking with it for life. Lines are long, deal with it. Place is small, that's why there's, To GO.
author: Belinda M.

description:
Great coffee, but the long line and wait is ridiculous! 
The service is comical. A ton of people, but I'm still left waiting an insane amount of time. I sent an email to the management directly a long time ago and she actually disagreed with my assessment..... Um, OK.  Apparently I'm making this up!
I really wished things had improved a bit at the Mint location, but unfortunately no.
Great coffee, but if you need to be anywhere - like, i don't know, work? you may have to skip BB and go on the weekend when you can wait 20 mins for a cup of coffee.
author: Kerry F.

description: I have to agree with the customer service issue at this location... after ordering four Gibraltars for my friends, the guy taking my order gave me a seriously heavy eye roll.  Five stars for the coffee though!  Definitely enjoyed the BB on top of the SFMOMA!!!  Even with a line out the door, these cheerful girls kept the smiles on and the coffee coming!
author: Lauren H.

description:
I love this place.  It's a great location, seems like an old bank building perhaps, with tons of natural light, and cool interior design.  But of course the real reason is the coffee!  The lattees are top notch.  The baristas take time and make each cup of coffee a real work of art.  The staff is friendly, and the overall vibe of the place is great.  For a similar price to Starbucks, you really owe it to yourself to try it.  

I have friends that will drive all the way from Cupertino, because they crave the Blue Bottle!
author: Mark K.

description:
Why to go to Starbucks instead of Blue Bottle:  Unless you are way lost Starbucks is only one or two doors away.  From anywhere. 
Why to go to Blue Bottle:  adventure!  something to stimulate creativity!  
Even if you just about need an appointment and a second mortgage to have your cuppa concocted in an effervescent glass bubble by a specially- and highly-trained barista , you must go to Blue Bottle at least once.  The service is cordial and the food tasty and well-presented.  Hard place to find, but I guess that helps its je ne sais quoi.
author: Diana R.

description: I'm less accepting of the long lines at this Blue Bottle since there seems to be so many other great places to get coffee -- even Blue Bottle coffee -- in Soma. Still, if you're near this intersection, and need your fix, they'll be happy to serve you up a Gibraltar.
author: Lion G.

description: Love this place!  The location is very bright and clean, you can sit at the bar and watching the people walk by on the street.  The coffee is top-notch...they individually brew each cup of coffee!  Breakfast is also delicious. I highly recommend the french toast bread pudding!  Food service is a bit slow, so grab a newspaper and relax (don't order food if you are in a hurry).
author: M M.

description: OMG the New Orleans Iced Coffee is so delicious!  Went in to grab coffee after lunch w/ some co-workers (they had been there before, I hadn't) I was entrigued by their menu.  Kyoto coffee, New Orleans Iced Coffee, it all sounds so great! I'll be back to try the Kyoto coffee for sure, the cashier mentioned there were was a chocolatey aroma to it and I love chocolate!  It was also fun to watch the way the coffee was brewed while waiting. They were fast and friendly here, come try their awesome coffee!
author: Tracy N.

description:
I went here so I could brag to my East Coast friends who read the NY Times article. To be honest, I really didn't expect the coffee to live up to the hype. But it was pretty darn tasty. And I got it to go, so I imagine it would be even better if I had stayed. If you're in the neighborhood, check it out. 

I gave it only 4 start, though, because it's hard to find an in an alley, in a bad area, in the back of a building that's being renovated. Sketchy. Also, it's really far from my office. Why didn't they pick a spot closer to the Financial District or a neighborhood where people actually live???
author: Jamon B.

description:
Since I have a Yelp list about where to get great coffee, I guess it's about time I write a Blue Bottle review.

I love their coffee, and I've mainly been a patron of the Temescal Farmer's Market, and the Ferry Plaza on occasion.  When I heard the cafe was opening, I almost DIED.  Then when I saw the mad scientist siphon machine pics on Flickr...I died again.

So my first time, I obviously had to get the siphon coffee.  $10-12 seemed like a little much, even for this coffee snob...but it's the kind of thing you have to at least try once.   I went with the Costa Rican Micro Mill selection for that day.  Smooth and flavorful, rich but not as in-your-face as the traditional pour-over drip method that is popular at the markets.  It was exciting to watch the brewing process and to drink from the suspended globe on your table, but I'll save it for when I bring out of town friends here.

Next time I went with my tried-and-true macchiato.  Business was a little slower and they had a trainee make mine.  Probably the worst macchiato I've had from Blue Bottle, but still light years beyond what they try and pass off (if they even know what you're talking about) at most other places.

All in all, the cafe is a fun stop when you're downtown, but it's not the kind of place you can lounge all afternoon.  I'll bring friends and out-of-towners here for the novelty, or stop by for a high-quality fix or to pick up some beans when I'm in the neighborhood.  But I'll be sticking with the laid back farmer's market when I really want the Blue Bottle experience.
author: katie e.

description:
I am no coffee snob, but blue bottle does claim the prize for the best cup o coffee I have had in my coffee drinking career. I have been a patron of the Hayes Valley garage spot location forever! I don't care if none of them know me or my name. I have seen staff come and go, so yeah, I have been going there forever! I just recently strolled by and walked in and drank in the space with my eyes. Pretty place, pretty smells, pretty coffee maker that looks like it is something out of a steam punk anime movie. And it might as well be. I have only heard of the magical coffee experience that the 20k dollar coffee brewer from japan makes..

Whatever coffeemaker! Just give me the best god damn soy latte in all of San Francisco, and make sure you put those pretty designs in the foam that make me feel oh so special!
author: danny e.

description:
One of the only places in SF to get a decent tasting coffee. Don't get me started on the number of burnt, too strong, or too weak coffees in this country. argh! not sure why most places find it so hard, but this place nails it.
Go during off peak times and you wont have any probs with the queues.
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
I came here because I was told it was the best coffee in the city.

What I was not told is that having one serving of their single origin Brazilian espresso, with such a warm and fatty taste, would forever curse me to wander the world in search of the ultimate experience in coffee, unable to hide the crushing disappointment on my face every time an acclaimed shop fails to live up to the Blue Bottle.

Is it chic?  Hardly.  Come here if you love coffee. (if you love cheezy overpriced furniture instead, by all means keep visiting CB2)
author: Andrew D.

description:
Yes, it looks very cool. Yes, the siphon project is neat. Yes, the cold drip machine is mesmerizing.   Yes, they know how to use an espresso machine.   

However, when your beans are burned to begin with, there is very little that you can do to fix the problem.  Stop roasting so dark!  Take a single origin and press it, if your coffee tastes like ash - you probably burned it.  Go to Rituals they do a good job roasting.
author: David D.

description:
I would give five if not for the small space and bench that sits in the middle of the room.  I thought it was bigger, but it's not bad.  Very busy when I went for like the whole duration.  Lucky my wife and I got a seat to enjoy our lattes.  The crap is great! The flavor.  The art.  If you don't like the strong flavor of coffee (think it's bitter) go to Starbizzle, they got your syrup.

Saw the cool siphons, but not in action.  Looks very modern and very clean.  Impressive.  I only heard of this place after asking a friend about an organic coffee shop.  She said she goes to the one in Hayes Valley, but I decided to try this spot.  I didn't notice any organic "Hey, we do organic".  So, maybe it is and maybe it's not?

If you're in the area and ant to try this place, please do!  It's cool.  Just prepare yourself for a line (doesn't move too slow) and for sitting outside if you have to. :)
author: Alcides G.

description:
The espresso here is phenomenal. I think they use filtered water because the espresso is smoooooth. It's the perfect dessert and pick-me-up. Coffee beans smell really good. I smell in my bag. 

Great packaging design and some knick-knacks for gifts.

Tip from the guy who rung my order up: Gramercy Tavern in NYC serves it.
author: A H.

description: The coffee is the best in the city but they don't offer wifi, probably to keep the customer flow going through but that's not what one would expect from today's cool coffee house.  I'd also note, the coffee while excellent, seems a lot like Hawaii's Kona coffee.
author: Leif M.

description: Wasn't the best macchiato i've ever had, but the grilled cheese was FANTASTIC. One of the best grilled cheese sandwiches i've had. Loved the mustard sauce that comes with it. Would come back solely for the grilled cheese!
author: Kristine N.

description: Stopped by the SOMA location to pick up some coffee.... Place was extremely busy. The staff was moving at a snails pace.. I purchased 2 -1/2 pounds of coffee. I asked for them to grind it but I was told it was their policy was that they don't do it.No problem I have a great grinder. I made the coffee this morning and it was ok.... I like a strong coffee like Pete's French roast and it was not strong....
author: Robert O.

description: Best coffee in town.  Don't come here though if you are in a hurry.  There is usually a line out the door, but if you have few minutes (or 20) it's worth the wait.  The baristas are very efficient without sacrificing quality and will take orders a few up the line to get it moving.  Even though there isn't tons of seating inside, there are tables right outside and in the Mint Plaza.  I haven't tried the food yet but it looks delicious.
author: Janey F.

description: I swear I walked by this place a few times before I even noticed it was there - usually in the evenings so the smell of coffee wasn't present like it was the morning I went!  My oh my let  me just say after having a cup of just their drip coffee my life has been changed!  I love a good, strong cup of coffee and this was better than I ever expected.  The aromas are first to hit your nostrils, then the warm rich texture  rolls down your tongue followed by the taste!! Started off slow but ended with quite a punch - to the taste buds!  The staff was nice and got the long line of people in and out quite quickly.  The clientele left some to be desired - it still amazes me how entitled some people are but that's a whole different story and I didn't go to Blue Bottle to make friends or meet people who actually have manners - GASP! - I went for a damn good cup of coffee and by golly that's what I got!  Now to just keep hoping and praying Blue Bottle decides to open up a location (or two or ten) in Colorado - We do love our coffee here and I honestly think Starbucks would have some real competition if they did!  Keep up the good work BBCC!  You're tops in my book!!!
author: Nicole M.

description: Welcome to Gattaca. Ok, ok.. maybe that's a little much. But holy hell did they manage to come up with an aesthetic that is devoid of warmth. That is some serious coffee let me tell you. Ok, well, I actually only had an iced "New Orleans Style Coffee" (I think) - it was tasty.. but more than anything I really just wanted to see them use those giant steampunk looking coffee contraptions. You might duck in for a cup just to check those things out.
author: Jon L.

description:
hands down, the absolute BEST americano in the city. i love to go to both the hayes valley and soma locations with my favorite mug for a cup of that perfectly balanced, almost chocolately goodness as often as i possibly can.

and the soma location is especially wonderful because i can pair my perfect cup of coffee with a fluffy waffle or a bowl of oatmeal on occassion. :)

highly, highly, highly recommended.
author: bex m.

description:
The Blue Bottle experience is as close to perfection as you will find as far as the coffee experience is concerned. The only other places I've been to on the west coast with comparable excellence would be Vivace in Seattle and Groundworks in L.A.  Everything about Blue Bottle is tuned to an amazing aesthetic experience: the lighting, the space, the sexy employees, and, most importantly, the coffee itself. Blue Bottle sets itself apart with diversions from the standard Italian pulled shot espresso - although such are available - to variations including Kyoto style, siphon pot, and New Orleans style. Don't settle for less when this place is within reach. 

Oh, and the food is great, although a little overpriced.
author: AJH H.

description: The coffee here is great! The flavors are rich and you can taste the coffee not all the extras. The latte was ok, not strong enough for my liking unless i add an extra shot. The macchiato was good. The coffee here takes longer to get because they use a unique system to serve the coffee. I like the coffee here because its smooth and rich in flavor. it also has a cleaner coffee taste than other coffee shops.  The place is small and at the other end of the Ferry Building, so i didn't know it was there for a long time, but after trying it today, i will be back.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I was finding it difficult to find a good cup of coffee in SFO until I found the Blue Bottle. Once I discovered it, I was back everyday during my stay in SFO. I tried lattes, espressos, macchiatos, New Orleans Ice coffee and some siphon cups. The various blends are nice to sample. I was never disappointed with the coffee.
So why the 4star rating? Well, to be honest, because 3 was too low.
Seriously there are a few things that make this less than a fantastic coffee experience
(1) the baristas are not very knowledgeable. Whether you want to have a discussion about brewing coffee or about the blends (they have as much knowledge as the 50 word descriptions on the labels), you are in the wrong place. Now for the Starbucks crowd, you will not notice a difference. On the other hand, if you've been to Intelligencia or Stumptown or even Coffeehouse NW, there is a significant difference in the people making your coffee
(2) Along with Starbuck's style baristas, this particular BB is designed like a Starbucks - for not lingering about with your coffee. It is more comfortable than the stand-up coffee bars of Brazil, but if you want to sit and enjoy your brew and friends - this is not your spot. Needless to say, if you are an urban nomad looking for an oasis with good coffee, comfy sitting and WiFi, this is not it.
(3) Call me old fashion, but my preference is not to drink out of paper cups. If you go to great lengths to craft a good brew, why drink it out a paper flavoring cup?! Paper seems to be the default serving mode, so don't forget to ask if you do not want it this way.
But at the end of the day, if you are going to stand in line for coffee in SFO, better here than Starbucks!
And if it is summer, be sure to try the New Orleans Iced Coffee!
Enjoy
author: ken a.

description:
i'm a huge fan of this location of blue bottle.  the only draw back is that the line can be crazy long, even at random times like a late lunch hour or other middle of the day times.  my office is currently only a block away and I love having blue bottle nearby.  

they make excellent espresso drinks and the New Orleans (GO SAINTS!) iced coffee is also delicious.

the science fair-like set up for the siphon pots looks cool and is fun to watch.  the employees are super sweet, but can seem aloof at times.  great ambiance and a fun place to sit and sip your cafe when you can stop to enjoy the quality.  if you're in a rush or don't care about the quality of your coffee, starbucks or the donut shop on the other side of mint plaza might better serve your needs.
author: Annalea I.

description: For "true" coffee drinkers - I believe you have to drink this stuff black to really appreciate it. Line may look long, but it moves at a decent pace--don't worry, you'll get your cup soon enough. Probably won't get a seat though--this place is packed!
author: Joyce L.

description: They go through all the effort to roast the beans just right, brew it in a vacuum pot over an imported Japanese burner, timing it to exactitude and then serve it in this ridiculous single wall glass cup that gets to hot to hold against your lip. Whoever is buying their glasswear needs to find another job. Everything else about the place is great.
author: Jon D.

description: I cannot express myself well enough when it comes to describing my love for the Kyoto and New Orleans iced coffees; suffice to say I am addicted and do not wish a cure haha.  Though the coffee is more or less on the pricey side, it is well worth the cost...HIGH FIVE BLUE BOTTLE!
author: Jay B.

description: This is my favorite coffee place.  I love all of their coffee and varieties of it.  The thing you must try here is the siphon coffee.  It is really interesting and fun to try.  The coffee made in the siphon tastes totally different from the coffee made in the drip.  It's pretty expensive, but if you like coffee it's a must.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Blue Bottle cafe' is absolutely fantastic.  Great selection of coffees and unique preparation methods.  I've been there five times already.

Nothing but five stars all the way.  Kyoto style iced coffe, single origin espressos, a few tasty treats, and wonderful Siphon brewed cofee (truly worth the premium price.)
author: Luke G.

description:
great coffee, just like the Linden St. location and Ferry building carts....
the space is really nice too....
staff seemed nice, though i didn't actually speak to anyone....
author: Antonio G.

description:
OK, this place is gimmicky. The $20k vacpot brews an impressive cup of coffee, but not an $11+ pot of coffee.

That said, the coffee here is excellent.
author: R E.

description:
There are not as many places to get great coffee in San Francisco as people seem to think.  I usually make my own coffee at home because spending 3.50 on a terrible coffee just doesn't do it for me.    

This is as good as it gets in San Francisco or almost anywhere in the world.  The location is great; just off the beaten path but accesible.  The look is clean but with some soul still.  The food menu is short and not fancy but everything that they choose to do is perfect everytime that I have been in.  And although it draws a hip crowd I always feel comfortable instead of like an outsider that is priveledged to have gotten a coffee. The service is pretty good even if the line is a bit long because they have a food runner too. Oh yeah, and the capp is the best on more days than not. And that is saying a lot.
author: Robert A.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is about...  Thought the coffee was just OK.

Had the siphon coffee.  It tasted like very weak coffee.  The flavours were there but subtle. It seems more of a novelty thing.
author: Selc S.

description:
I love this place. The staff is courteous and knowledgeable and genuinely cares about the cup they produce.
My recommendation is a macchiato with a shot of single orgin pulled off of the La San Marco. Mmmmmm. Yum.

 If you want quick coffee, go to starbucks. If you want good coffee, that's prepared by people who care about what they're doing, come to blue bottle. Definitely worth the wait.
author: Austin R.

description:
I visited BBC on my vacation to SF. Read the glowing reviews and wanted to try it. There were a couple of people in line, so the wait was not that bad. The barrista is crafting a drink, so I don't mind that that it's not moving at lighting speed. Though, this would be a killer if the line were long and I was waiting to go to work...She answered my questions about the blend. 

The counter person...could barely stay awake and was pretty glum. I'm sorry you are young and having to work your way up in this world. It's hard.

I had a double short Americano---honestly, not that great. 
I do like a strong blend, along the lines of of french roast., but I found the drink to be a weird combo of bitter and wood chip flavor with very little to savor. Mexican beans? I don't know.

I do give them points for fresh coffee. 

I was curious and wanted to try more...
The Bella Donavan--blah...Like Maxwell house only with an attitude.
The Giant Steps blend is pretty good. But really Peets French or Cafe Darte Gourmet Drip has a richer, less acidic flavor for less money.
author: Gem J.

description:
Had espresso here this afternoon--double-shot, ristretto; $2 before tax ($2.19 after).

The siphons make for a neat thing to set your eyes on while you're waiting, although it may only interesting if you're new. It can get busy, and even when it isn't the place isn't set up as one at which you can spend all day--although there's nothing wrong with that. (If you want to go hog a table, go to a Starbucks.)
author: J. L.

description: This is by far the best coffee in the bay area- great aroma and taste. Recently I've been ordering the drip coffee in-store and it's wonderful because they change their beans occasionally so you can try the different coffee beans they offer (Giant Step, Bella Donavan, etc). So far, I'd have to say the Bella Donovan is my favorite- the aroma of the beans is unforgettable and it goes well with half and half. Remember to buy some beans while you are there to brew wonderful coffee at home or if you forget just order it online. They make it so convenient for their customers. I also love that their website provides info/video on how to drip coffee at home (they sell the porcelain dripper for about $22 or $24 but I am perfectly happy with my Melitta dripper for only $2.99). Thanks Blue Bottle for spoiling me with great coffee that I can enjoy anytime of the day.
author: Taiga M.

description:
Meh. Honestly , I'm glad they are located so close to Montgomery station because I can get decent coffee that's local--but it's not that incredible. With the dirth of locally roasted coffee in the Bay Area, I'm surprised so many people are on the Blue Bottle wagon....

Don't get me wrong- it's not BAD, it's just not all the hype either. If there were other locally roasted choices located this close to a "downtown" BART, I'd probably choose one of them over Blue Bottle...
author: Persephone J.

description: New Orleans ice coffee is amazing and the latte's are top-notch.  Annoying though that they don't have any sweetener and the lines can be a killer.
author: Ali B.

description: I've been meaning to try this place for a while.  The inside is very cute, though I suppose it looks more like a mad scientist's laboratory than a coffee house upon first glance.  I thought the line was unnecessarily slow.  It took forever to get our drinks and I really wasn't a fan of the holier than thou attitude I got from the baristas.  Tried the Gibraltar.  It was a bit strong for my tastes, but it was enjoyable.  I really liked their parmesan and fennel brioche.   Overall, it was pretty good, but I don't know if I get all the hype yet.  I might have to go back and try their New Orleans Style iced coffee or their breakfast selection.  Still prefer Philz.
author: Alea G.

description: They make a good cup of coffee, but for some reason only at this location.  All the other smaller sites I have been to do not execute it as well as this specific location.  Love the space too, but more importantly the coffee is good.
author: Joseph F.

description: This picky palate never knew a coffee could have such a wonderful profile and be so texturally creamy! Cheers to the best coffee in the city!
author: Bootylicious J.

description: Hands down the best Mocha I've ever had, its expensive at $4.50 for a tall but I keep going back intending to try new things but always get sucked into the Mocha, probably the place I'll miss most out of everything in San Francisco.
author: Abhinav S.

description:
so, i'm a local regular at the mint plaza blue bottle location. yes, the coffee is really excellent. but, in a city with many options for excellent coffee, i think there has to be something more to a coffee shop in sf beyond great coffee. this is especially true when one often has to contend with a line of (mostly) tourists at the mint plaza.

i really enjoy the space itself. it's airy and receives amazing light through huge windows. it can get loud, but i personally really enjoy the space. the bathrooms are generally kept clean. there is always an amazing fresh floral arrangement on the counter. they have added additional security staff to maintain some sanity surrounding the store (which has a large homeless, mentally ill population nearby). the coffee is well reviewed elsewhere, and it stands up to its reputation.

lately, however, i find myself coming back less often. somehow, this location has recently lost some of its specialness. it's not exactly one thing but there has been a series of recent changes that have somewhat genericized the store, especially taken in context of the high caliber sf coffee scene.

first, the iconic kyoto iced coffee was reduced from the standard iced coffee size to a much smaller pour mostly because supposedly they couldn't make enough to keep up with demand. still, it was a disappointing move. then, a change in their house made pastry selection removed some of the most unique offerings, including my absolute favorite: a fennel-parmesean shortbread that was just amazing--a perfect combination of sweet and savory that couldn't be found anywhere else. i used to crave this shortbread, and i would visit especially to get the shortbread (and then coffee). the store used to bring in the new york times--it's gone now. the store recently remodeled its counter space. not only does it look shoddily done in areas (gaps in joints along the counters and wall space), but the under-counter coat hooks are now gone (the message seems, don't get too comfortable and stay too long). the store had recently been using an unhomogenized organic milk from strauss dairy. it was special and delicious with tiny pieces of cream in the cold milk--it made the new orleans ice coffee even more special. (now, the new orleans can be bought in cartons, just like starbucks sells its prebottled stuff, so you don't even have to bother yourself to come into the store.) i'm sure some of these changes increased profits because not a lot of people read the new york times or bought the parmesean shortbread or even knew there were coat hooks under the counters. but, i think sometimes you have to invest in the details and special things to make yourself matter to those who care the most.

anyway, some of this might seem nit-picky, but in a city that takes its coffee houses seriously, this location, in my opinion, has less specialness left to justify a visit from an sf local with many (now superior) options for great coffee and a better experience.
author: D J.

description:
Possible titles for my review of Blue Bottle Coffee:

"Now I understand why people criticize Starbucks"

or "It makes Peet's taste like Starbucks"

Whatever it is, it's enough to make me want to move in next door.  My only critique is that they could offer low-fat milk but whatever still delicious...
author: Will C.

description: There's always a line at Blue Bottle, which is a good sign. I've had several drinks there. The macchiato is very good. But, the real show is the watching your coffee being brewed at the Siphon Bar.
author: Larry C.

description: Without a doubt Blue Bottle Coffee Co. serves the best coffee in town.  I love their location in the Mint Building in downtown San Francisco. The staff there is professional, courteous and friendly, their clientele mostly hip and the cafe itself is bright, airy and resembles one of those chic minimalist Swedish cafes in Stockholm. This is a place for discerning coffee lovers. You should check out their cafe latte that comes with a spectacular latte art on top.
author: Tamer I.

description:
omg. i miss this place.

i stopped by here every day when i was at a conference. 

its full flavored but still light. 

i wish we had japanese style coffee here in sd.
author: Diane I.

description: One of the things I miss most about SF is Blue Bottle Coffee - particularly the newish cafe on Mint St. Do I like waiting forever for it? No. Hence the 4 stars not 5. But - the siphon coffee is AMAZING - and I love that they give you a little sweet. The drip coffee and barista drinks are all awesome as well. This is a coffee event. When I am back in SF I never ever miss it! So, there you go, slow, but stupendous!
author: Lorelei A.

description: Awesome coffee. Best location. Typically too crowded but I guess that's what happens when a place is good... The New Orleans coffee has some kind of chemical in it (crystal meth, perhaps?) that makes you feel giddy and loopy for about an hour afterward. Extra points for all the Jules Verne coffee-making equipment. Food is tasty too. (Now if they could get their act together in the Ferry Bldg, I would be a total convert. What's the deal with the luke warm lattes over there? Do I need to ask for it to be "hot"?)
author: Jason Y.

description: 5 stars for the drip coffee, which is dark, strong, and smooth, yet manages to have a really subtle earthy aftertaste. -1 star for the sense of annoyance I feel at waiting in a long line where I end up listening to the conversation of yuppies who are way too pretentious about their coffee.
author: Daniel C.

description: They say that good things come to those who wait.  With Blue Bottle coffee, this is definitely true.  The baristas are maddeningly slow sometimes, but the result of the wait is always soooo worth it.  Blue Bottle coffee is like liquid crack.  I don't know how they do it, but this coffee is the type of thing you'd consider selling yourself on a corner in the TL for.  Ever since my first cup of the New Orleans style iced coffee, I've been hooked.  It's so good it will make you look beyond the line that seems to always take 10+ minutes (even if there's only 2 people ahead of you) and the price tag that indicates your beverage must be made from coffee beans grown in diamond mines and harvested and roasted by Peruvian virgins.  Just flawless, orgasmic coffee.
author: Chelsea D.

description: So we've been going to Philz coffee quite a bit and of course Starbucks for the sheer convenience but since my girlfriend's cousin raved about Blue Bottle we decided to go and try it again. So we roll up to the place and there is huge line out of the door. We place our order and we order the individually dripped coffee. I get my coffee and it's a little hotter than luke warm. It's good coffee. Definitely better than a Starbucks or something like that but I gotta say Philz is much better. It's ok. The food items are "gourmet" so they're unnecessarily expensive. All in all I much prefer Philz but it's pretty good coffee.
author: Hyung L.

description: I was so so happy to find Blue Bottle after the first day of (burned) Starbucks coffee at a conference I was attending. The New Orleans iced coffee was great, and the cafe au lait was also wonderful. The barista even made pretty designs in every customer's drink - they don't skimp on any of the details here! Both times I dropped in there were lines, but the staff moved fairly quickly and I didn't have to wait too long - but honestly, I would have waited longer. The food also looked amazing, but I (sadly) didn't get a chance to sample it.
author: Jessica V.

description: Well, if you are a tourist staying in Union Square like us (visiting from LA), going down 6th to get there isn't so recommended as apparently this is the hood (pure Tenderloin) and we swear we saw some questionable exchanges of money and handshakes. Eventually we made it though and I like how it feels like a secret hole in the wall - except for the long line. Having never had siphon coffee we tried it and it was fun to sit at the bar and watch the brewing but the coffee itself wasn't so different from any other good freshly ground and brewed pot. Fun place though if you take your coffee seriously as they have quite a few kinds.
author: erica u.

description: Ok, if you need the super high octane hyper drive coffee to get you thru the day, this is the place. The Kyoto Iced coffee is superb. The experience of watching the siphon brewed coffee is akin to dinner theatre. Blue Bottle, can you please open in the peninsula and the south bay? Please show these insipid disciples of weak coffe that is starbucks what true coffe should taste like. I feel sorry for the millions that support (the zionist supporting Walmart of coffee) starbucks.
author: Malfeo C.

description: I usually don't drink coffee but I was in dire need of a recharge after a long day at work. So I used my handy Yelp app on the IPhone and lucky me, the closest coffee shop was Blue Bottle Coffee. Seeing how there was a line out the door for this place, it made me certain there was a good reason for the better than average reviews. Looking inside, it did seem a bit snobbish especially since the menu was a bit more complex than your friendly neighborhood Starbucks. I ordered the cafe mocha to-go since I didn't feel brave enough to get a Kyoto coffee or whatnot. My drink was probably the best coffee beverage I've ever had. There was almost no bitter taste to it and had a wonderful aroma that made me wish my house smelled like that every morning. From now on when I'm in the city, Blue Bottle Coffee will definitely be my first stop.
author: Chris T.

description: Second time at the one at the Roof Top Garden at SF MOMA.  Had a regular coffee the first time.  It was OK.  Today I tried a Mocha which was luke warm and he overcharged me.  The price list said $4.75 but he charge me $5.20 so rather than argue at the time, I just left no tip.  Cannot recommend this to anyone.  It is OK but I have had better.
author: Irving W.

description: I went back yesterday and ordered a cappuccino with soy (sacrilege! ;) ) but it was damn tasty! Also, the staff was pretty nice and hot. 'Nuff said.
author: Melissa G.

description:
Coffee is great as always, if the review was just coffee it would be five starts, however they are still working out the kinks for the food. I am going to have to give them another shot in a couple of weeks. The menu states they serve breakfast starting at 9 am however they didn't start until after 10 am today we were tired of waiting so we went somewhere else to eat. 

The design is definitely interesting. The coffee set up is more like a chemistry experiment.
author: Phill and Molly O.

description: The coffee I ordered was a bit on the strong bitter side (individual drip for 2.5), and the line was out the door (waited for about 10 min). I really want to love this coffee, so I'll give it several more tries! Great modern/industrial interior space.
author: Chihee K.

description: This place makes you feel great about spending 3 dollars on a cup of coffee. The latte is so delicious and the ambiance is perfect. It is a perfect cup of coffee. The breakfast is also delicious and slightly overpriced but again...they make you feel great about spending money there in their cute outfits and clear coffee machines and perfect lines.
author: Lindsay C.

description: I'm a cappuccino fanatic and I have to admit that it's seriously difficult to find a place that makes them just right.  Blue Bottle is definitely a gem. The coffee is never too strong or too weak and their foam is unbeatable, the texture is so smooth, so satisfying.  It's like drinking a cloud.
author: Angela A.

description: I'm totally not afraid to stand in line for a good cup of coffee. And neither should you be.
author: CM P.

description: Long line goes by relatively quick! Found a hair in my drink but they quickly and gladly replaced it. They're really friendly and the design on the moca is amazing! Cute!
author: Eva J.

description: I've been to the Blue Bottle in Hayes Valley (5 stars), but this was my first time at the Mint Street location.  I will start by saying that I have been in the coffee business for many years, as a roaster, barista and cafe manager/owner going back 20 years and covering California, Oregon and Washington, so I know coffee better than most.  And I want to be clear that Blue Bottle has excellent coffee, no question.  When I went to this location, it was a Sunday afternoon and there were no lines, so I was helped immediately.  No attitude, but no overt friendliness either.  The cappuccino itself would get 5 stars, but I also tried the Kyoto iced coffee and found the flavor unpleasant - very acidic, and not in a good way.  It was also stale, but there is no getting around that; coffee grounds will begin to stale within minutes of grinding the beans, and this style of iced coffee allows the grounds to sit out for many hours, so it will never taste fresh.  Not very pleasant.  I drank about a quarter of it and gave the rest away. And the siphon bar was closed for some reason at 3:30 in the afternoon - too bad, I really wanted to try it.  So for all of those factors, I would give this Blue Bottle a total 4 star rating.  But the neighborhood dropped the score two stars.  It is the most vile, filthy place in the City, and I was born in San Francisco.  In the short walk back to my car, I passed two men pissing on the street, multiple piles of human excrement, at least a half dozen meth heads and the foulest of odors.  I will NEVER go back to that location, and I am stunned that anyone would ever go there more than once.  Yes, the coffee is great, but that is not enough to overcome the location.
author: LeftCoast R.

description: Love the coffee here--it really is delicious. I make sure to come here everytime I'm in San Francisco. I usually get a large latte and a brioche, as well as a pound of coffee to go. This location is my favorite due to the nice courtyard as the interior is almost always packed.
author: Tom C.

description: Virtually perfect.  The espresso had a fantastic thick, creamy mouthfeel.  It was fairly complex, yet perfectly balanced--no harsh roastiness or acidity.  The drip coffee was excellent too.  I think they use the same beans as I tried at their Linden Street outpost.  Not sure what they are, but they yield an elegant blueberry-cream flavor that reminds me of the Ethiopian Sidamo coffee at LA Mill in Los Angeles.  Also superb was the rosemary pine-nut shortbread--bursts of sea salt and pine nut flavor and texture amidst a rosemary-butter backdrop.  Mmmm.
author: Anonymous P.

description:
the hype is a fib...

the gf and i happened to be walking nearby so we popped in.  to my disappointment, we both thought the drip coffee and latte tasted pretty weak.  

we are by no means coffee snobs, but its pretty bad when my gf thinks a coffee drink is weak.  i like black coffee, and i like it slap me in the face a little and catch me off-guard.  this place suited neither of us.

i had high hopes when i saw they brewed each drip coffee fresh with that meth lab equipment (i dont care what it's called, okay! it obviously didnt make the coffee any better).

the fact that they make each cup fresh is great, but i really just need it to have a stronger taste, and pump some caffeine through.  it almost seems faux-coffee-affectionado, since the taste isnt really strong enough for someone to so elegantly theorize about.

i'm sure the barista's wont miss my service, the place is not very personable, and it feels a little sterile inside.
author: eric f.

description: The best coffee in the city!  New Orleans iced coffee is fantastic - lots of flavor, not too sweet.
author: Yevgenia F.

description:
This is fantastic coffee. period. Yes, it is overpriced... but once in a while on a Sunday afternoon - you deserve a top of the line overpriced coffee.  you do! Put on your shades, dint wash your hair, bring your pug with a funny sweater, and go stand in line with the rest of the yupsters.

Really though, I do like the coffee.  The new Orleans ice coffee is YUMMY on a summer day but it will set you back like $3.50.  Miguel is the most awesome barrista!
author: Alona E.

description: good, but not great. they're serious about their craft, which is admirable, but i don't think their product warrants the high price and elitist customer service. **update: i gave this place a second chance and i had a much better experience. instead of a cold four dollar latte, i tried the new orleans iced coffee. it was really tasty. if i get the chance to go back, i am going to do a full on chemistry experiment or whatever they do with the beakers.
author: Jacy C.

description: Ok...not that they need anymore praise since clearly everyone knows how amazing they are. (Their line s always out the door). Have you tried their food yet? It is so good. I recently have been ordering food with my coffee in the morning and it is delicious. Their butter pecan granola with milk is so tasty. I have been craving it every morning since I last had it. Their poached eggs with braised greens are also pretty bomb. Their acme toast is also amazing. It almost looks like fake cartoon toast because it is so large. It is soft and is paired with a yummy jam. Perfect for a morning snack. In the afternoon they also sometimes have popcorn with lime and lots of pepper. It sounds strange, but it is really the perfect salty snack. Very cajun inspired I suppose, just make sure to check your teeth for left over pepper after!
author: Kristy H.

description: Apparently this place has one of the most expensive coffee machines in America (the most expensive?) and it certainly shows.  For all the New Yorkers out there, it reminds me of a much more upscale Caf Grumpy - they have a similar way of organizing their coffees (by region) and it seems the menu rotates quite a bit.  I enjoyed the science lab feel of the place - pots of coffee are served in these Bunsen burner cum beaker contraptions and the dcor is that sort of severe, industrial-sterile.  That's not a bad thing, necessarily.  I enjoyed my latte that I took to go, but it didn't knock my socks off the way many a blend from Grumpy has.  Still it's a great place to get a great cup of coffee.
author: Sam P.

description: i love it, love it, love it. Best coffee I've ever had. Sure it takes 10-15 minutes to get your cup of coffee, but it's so worth the wait! Be prepared to stand in line for a few minutes and like i mentioned, wait for your coffee after you order. Nice, comfortable, clean coffee bar. I can't wait to go back. Don't forget to take some home with you. yummmm
author: Bianca V.

description:
wow, rich and bold coffee.

the new orleans iced coffee is like liquid dark chocolate!  8)
author: Ethan L.

description: Tried this coffee while visiting SF, and I have to say it is pretty amazing.  It was recommended by friends and it turned out this gem was hidden in Mint Plaza directly across from the hotel where we were staying.  Took home a bag of their Yirgacheffe Gelana Abaya and its incredible.  Has a nose and flavor of blueberries!  I will order more if I can find it online.
author: Andy B.

description:
great coffee!
fast service!
chic minimalist decor!
clean bathrooms!
love the new orleans iced coffee!

wish they took amex but they took my visa.
author: Myron J.

description:
blue bottle is one of my biggest discoveries since they were opened a couple years ago. Since then i go there 3-4 times a week for lunch. Their coffees are consistently good (only one time the barista made a mess on my latte)
...i am sure you can find some better coffee beans. But their milk / foam that they pour out from that magic (extraordinary expensive) expresso machine is unbeatable.
the only wish i have to B.b. has more varieties for week day lunch.. PLSSSSS i have been eating egg sandwich/ hot dog/ soup & salad & tuna melt sandwich like dorm food. I am not sure how much longer i can hang in there. weekends are better off but there will be 20 more people in front of you... i know your coffees are awesome but i really want to eat a real lunch meal with my colleagues too~ (as it is never enough for them with a big appetite). but in general, a great cafe.
author: Anne N.

description: While their Mint location is about as polar opposite as one could get in terms of ambiance, the modern, european feel of the Mint cafe definitely works.  The 17ft ceiling is different from their hayes valley blend they serve at the kiosk, a true crema-bomb with good flavor.  Every time I have visited the baristas have been friendly, helpful, and serve up some awesome coffee.  Their roman and retrofit espresso blends are an interesting change of pace from their other espresso blends, and are pretty easy to work with.
author: Andrew C.

description: We visited San Francisco on vacation this summer, and we had breakfast at Blue Bottle three times in a few days.  The coffee and the food were very decently priced for the quality.  Between three of us trying breakfast dishes while we were there, we tried granola with soy milk, compote, French toast, eggs benedict, and poached eggs.  They were all a hit!  We also had various coffee drinks, which were the main reason we kept going back.  Dishes with bread in them have gigantic, soft slices of deliciousness...  I hope we can go again!!
author: Michelle M.

description:
very cool that i now have a blue bottle by work and one by my house, and can get their coffee at Mission Beach cafe by my house too!  i often go to the one on Linden in Hayes Valley since i can belly on up to the coffee bar w/ pooch in tow and then hit the Octavia green, but i really love this downtown location, housed in a cool old building, on one of my favorite alleys in town (i "heart" the mezzanine!), the place is clean and simple, the afternoon sun hits this corner and makes it an enjoyable spot for a late day coffee date.   sorry yogi, you can't come in. 

we came here last thurs @ 5pm (before the 4th of July weekend) and actually got a place to sit, although the place was pretty much at capacity once we did.  there was no line when we ordered, but soon after a rush of late workers must have come in needing a caffeine boost.  cute and nice barristas, although the one we ordered from last time seems a little "head in clouds" - we ordered 3 coffees and he gave us 2, it had been awhile and i hadn't gotten mine yet, so i went up asking him where the 2nd iced one was and he said "oh i thought when you came over and said something it was just to confirm that the coffee was iced".  huh?  

anyhoo, i'd like to go back there and try some of their food some day...but i'd definitely want to go there on off times - i can't stand lines, not even for blue bottle.
author: Suzanne A.

description: I am totally addicted to this place!!  The espresso is the best I've ever had.  The barristas are all very skilled.  Lines can be long, but worth the wait.
author: Kelly H.

description:
one sunday, they were serving tomato soup and cheesy cornbread. well i didnt want the soup, i just wanted cheesy cornbread, but they said no. i get my coffee and sit down with my friends, when i look over to see the most adorable child ever eating said cornbread with his father, no soup in sight!! when i start bitching to my friends in my best inside voice, the father casually leans over to say "well, they have to give me what i want because i'm the owner." so i shut my face and die of embarrassment.

about twenty minutes later as my friends and i are finishing our coffee,  i turn to notice that they are now selling JUST the cornbread! before i can say a word, the owner looks at me and apologizes!! not only does he apologize, but he offers to buy me my own cornbread!!!

i was pretty stunned. that is probably the best customer service experience i've ever witnessed!

anyways, the coffee is of course brilliant. the food on weekends is pretty delicious for not having a full kitchen.
author: Jaei P.

description: Oh puhleez.  I have a high tolerance for fancy and pretentious, but this was ridiculous.  Coffee took 10 min. to come out and while smooth, tasted like a cup of Colombian coffee.  My freshly ground Peets at home tastes better.  My friend's double espresso also took 10 minutes to come out.  Dude, it's just a cup of coffee, ok?
author: Sam C.

description:
I really hate the attitude they have. Don't get me wrong, I love Blue Bottle coffee. Except that I can't get my hands on any. 

I made a special trip out of my way to go there this morning, and rolled in about 7:15 AM. When I tried to order, they told me they don't serve breakfast until 9 AM. Um, guys, if I came back at 9, I'd be fired from my job. Promptly. 

Ok, dining in is out. Weak with hunger at this point, I tried to just grab my usual bag of beans and go. Oh wait, no coffee either. None. Of any variety. They're out. At 7:15 AM. 

So---why are they even open? Maybe they're making so much money they don't need the approximately 20 bucks I was going to spend. That must be why there was ONE customer in there besides me. 

I just don't get it. Starbucks coffee may taste like crap, but at least they are willing to do business with you at the posted time. 

Minus one star for the food. Minus one star for the coffee. Minus one star for sucking at running a business.
author: Katherine O.

description: Holy moly, is that coffee or methamphetamine? Tasted so good, I immediately ran out to find some copper wire to steal. Then my teeth fell out and my hair got all wiry and I drove to LA and back without sleeping. What I'm saying is: "I Lost Me to Blue Bottle Coffee."
author: Chris R.

description: I discovered the Mint St location this past weekend and it was one of those times when I truly felt blessed that I reside in San Francisco.  It's quaint, it's hidden away, it's for me.  My only complaints are 1) it gets a tidbit cold when they leave the door open, 2) it's not conducive to studying since they don't have individual seating.  Hey, if I can't have my cake and eat it too, I'll bring an extra sweater next time.
author: Lily T.

description: For those that drink espresso thinking it delivers the most potent caffeine dosage has obviously not enjoyed a cup of Blue Bottle's drip coffee. This coffee house is serious about its brew. Their coffee is full bodied, smooth and delicious. I will gladly endure hours of caffeine jitters for a cup of their amazing coffee. What a treat!
author: Kevan M.

description: At Blue Bottle you don't have to wait in line to buy beans at Mint Plaza thank you   BE
author: BE L.

description: Yum! I just tried their individual-prepared drip coffee from that fancy machine. Delicious! My new favorite cup of coffee in San Francisco! Sort of like taking the subtle flavors of Ritual's cups, but giving it a full body with kick (rather than the weak brew they make). The "cool" people on macs don't bother me.
author: boo d.

description:
It was found online, through the New York Times. "A $20,000 coffee maker?! Please." Turned out to be Blue Bottle. Turned out it was opening that very day. Turned out that the very next day, I would convince my friend to drive up to San Francisco (160 miles, roundtrip, due to our going to school in Santa Cruz) to get just a cup of coffee.

Wasn't just a cup. I went and stuttered at the price, hesitantly handing over a dollar bill. The barista looked at me. I looked at him. "This is only a dollar." I nodded. I looked at her and handed the $10 over, cursing myself. We'd already gotten this far, though, and I certainly was not going to wimp out, even though it meant $11 less to buy food later. It was raining pretty hard that day, so when we walked in, everyone was enjoying hot coffee along with a lot of food. I was cold. I was wet. I was tired. I got my coffee.

Jesus. To this day, I don't know where it knocked my socks off to, cause I'm missing socks now. It was love at first sip. So I sipped again, and again, and again, till that whole damned $11 beaker was gone. Then the beaker was gone too. The barista cleared it. Huh. good service. 

Five stars for Blue bottle. Five stars for the coffee. 50 stars for the iced coffees- New Orleans of Kyoto- I'm happy to hand over $3.50. Five stars for their food- I've only had toast but everything else looks good. Five stars for presentation, five stars for its uniqueness. Four stars for its hidden location, but hell, that's a good and bad thing. 

If the two Blue Bottle Coffees were a pair akin to knives, this would be the big bad 10" chef's knife compared to the paring knife of the Hayes Valley kiosk; it's not better simply because it's bigger, but one or the other is better in the sense that it would be more apt for certain..tasks, per se. The kiosk is a small, quirky place, and it charters to more of the go-getters- the people who live their lives waiting in line only to jet off with a paper cup in hand, newspaper in the other, most likely getting to the MUNI stop just as the bus is pulling away. The cafe, however, is larger, but more languid. Here, people will come and sit for thirty minutes. The customers, for the most part, stick around. Many will enjoy a piece of toast (their toast is otherwordly, with the jam, WOW) or just some steel-cut oats with their New York Times. The ambiance is relaxed, and so is everyone else. These people will walk out, thumbs hitched in their pockets, reading the Arts section, and hell, the bus just left. Only a few more minutes till the next.
author: Shelby C.

description: An excellent latte for my taste has to meet certain criteria.  The lattes I had at this location were good, but they are not the best I have had.
