I like that whole organic milk is the default milk for lattes and I don't have to specified it like other places.  I have been at this location a few times and I have waited from 15-20 minutes just to get my order.  It seems that when I visit this place, there are a lot of tourists asking the barista a bunch of questions, which makes the line move slow.
author: Angelica S.

description: What a gorgeous and stylish cafe. The coffee is the most tasteful I've had (and I only drink decaf) and their snacks are a delicious mix of sweet and savory. Blue Bottle is like its own planet. And it's a wonderful experience. I like to get a cup at other places that sell it too but the true Blue Bottle experience I get only here. This may include sitting on the plaza or the stairs opposite when the sun is out.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Beautiful flavor in the coffee, great environment, albeit a little clustery inside. Definitely has the feel of a regular spot.
author: Paul D.

description: Yummy latte! The only thing that sucks is the long lines.
author: ALICE L.

description: Hey, I love your cappucino's and tokyo iced coffee, but does it really take THAT long to make an 8 ounce cup of goodness? The long wait is as consistent as the libations are good, but PLEASE some of us have to get somewhere.
author: M E.

description: I love coffee, they have a beautiful (manual) espresso machine, and a siphon bar. One of the best coffee shops ever.
author: Kerry F.

description: Absolutely great coffee and espresso! Service was not too great however the coffee is unmatched in this city. Philz coffee is next closest but they don't have espresso.
author: Ramzy H.

description:
I agree with the previous comments about this place being overrated. The slow service is integral to the ambiance - you have to wait to merit the staff's attention.   Unless you are a regular, you are a nobody.
The New Orleans Iced Coffee is overhyped;   the ice-to-coffee ratio was too high.   The sunlit space is this location's strongest feature, with the lovely view of the back of the old US Mint building across the plaza.   For my next cup of outstanding coffee, I'll stick to Rogers or Philz.
author: Anne J.

description:
four stars for a good cappuccino. so four stars despite the following:
 - siphon bar? it's like a fancy watered down french press that doesn't taste as good. yes, the flavor changes from sip to sip, but it just becomes increasingly acidic.
 - took FOREVER to get my slice of cake. one slice. not that busy. FOOOORRREEEVEEERRRR. to their credit, they're not even a month old at this location.
 - they have wireless. the SSID is even "Blue Bottle Cafe" so you know they have wireless, but they won't give you the network key. why tease? why?

despite that, the baristas in black are very knowledgeable and helpful. a few might be a tad pretentious, but they know what they're doing so that's understandable.
author: Trogdor B.

description: It's a great experience... I went opening day to show support and felt so happy to see such an inspired turn out.  My regular visit will always be the Kiosk in Linden Alley and the Market on Saturday but I'm looking forward to special trips to the Blue Bottle Cafe as a way to spread the love around.  I even sent the Times article to my mom and sister in Wisconsin, who are huge Blue Bottle fans, and they can't wait for their next trip to San Francisco for the Blue Bottle Cafe experience. Go James!
author: Joy C.

description:
an awesome coffee shop.  just enough off the beaten path to not be completely packed and allow you to chat over a coffee... or study.  

the food is on the expensive side, but VERY tasty.  i wouldn't bother getting a pot brewed again (even though the pot itself is pretty cute, and it's fun to know that it was made with a halogen bulb).  get a cup for $2 - you'll get just about the same amount of coffee for... 1/6... the price.

the staff are very nice and fun to talk to about their coffee and unique brewing style.
author: tamsen d.

description: Honestly, I think it is really difficult to review coffee, but this coffee is completely deserving of its 5 star review.  I ordered a latte and tried the plain black coffee and they were just fantastic, bold and full of flavor.  I left Blue Bottle craving more.  And they have a great atmosphere to meet up with some friends and just chat over coffee.  Add a homemade treat, and this place is a great afternoon spot on a cold or hot day!
author: Cara D.

description:
omg, the mochas here are insanely rich, even if you get it w/ nonfat milk!!  they are made w/ richeuti chocolate, and it's yummy.  too bad i wasn't able to enjoy it slowly b/c i had to either throw half of it away or down it b/c the passport agency wouldn't let me bring it thru.  :(

this place is cute.  be patient tho, b/c the drinks take a while to make.
author: Helen T.

description:
I dont know why that people are just so crazy about this place.
THIS place is nothing special. 
I think this whole thing is just a HYPE. MEDIA HYPE OR WHATEVER FEVER people are having now.  WELL, this hype kind of thing is going to slow down eventually.
Everything that we think and are experiencing are now controlled by the MEDIA, the NEWSPAPERS, the NEWS on TV, ONLINE NEWS SUCH AS yahoo.com etc etc.

This coffee just tastes like any other coffee.....it all depends  on how you make it. How much sugar you put...etc etc. 
The cashier, and the coffee makers at this shop are rude and look like they dont want to work....... . 

I can make a better coffee than this coffee shop!!!! I dont even need to use a good brand coffee!!!!..... 

SORRYYYYY I DONT WANT TO SPEND MY MONEY!!!!. EVEN 1 CENT.....I AM NOT GOING TO BUY COFFEE AT THIS PLACE!!!
author: Hand T.

description: Not much of a line, service was friendly. The soy latte was really nicely done. New Orleans coffee was good. Great cinamon rolls. The only downside for the business traveler is that they don't take Amex.
author: The O.

description: I finally found and checked out the Mint St. location for Blue Bottle.  Same great quality beans, same attention to detail, same yummy latte, same hipster-ish baristas.  The difference?  The insanely long line and delicious looking food offerings.  I was in a hurry and was mighty annoyed, but now you've been warned.  Go when you have some time on your hands.  I'll have to try breakfast one leisurely weekend morning.  Given their commitment to quality, I'm positive that it'll be fab.
author: Tamiko J.

description: Good coffee. Service is a little bit slow but the coffee was excellent
author: Cisdevry C.

description: Perhaps the best coffee purveyor in the city. I'm happy with this convenient location of the cafe. A small selection of food is served with the same quality inspiration as their coffee. A great stop for affordable gourmet lunch. My fave is the Ortiz bonito tuna roll sandwich. Ortiz is one of the best Spanish tuna producers.
author: Alex B.

description: Awesome hand pulled espresso by a friendly staff atop the SFMOMA.
author: Mike T.

description:
One of my favorite coffee spots! This place serves up some serious coffee, folks... and the New Orleans Iced Coffee is ridiculously delicious. The location is great, too... tucked away from the craziness of Westfield/Market St.

Also, if you're located in the South Bay/Peninsula and don't want to make the trek up to the city, you can always get your BB fix at Fraiche in Palo Alto.
author: Patrick C.

description: I've grabbed coffee from this place three times in the past week and a half.  The individually prepared drip coffee ($2.17 incl. tax for the equivalent of a "tall" coffee at Starbucks) is very good, and as another reviewer has mentioned, super caffeinated.  I'm glad they opened this location near work.  I've only been here around 8:30am on various weekday mornings, and I've not had to wait very long for my coffee.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: This is a classic "Soup Nazi" situation.  The coffee is fantastic- definitely some of the best in the city.  HOWEVER, the customer service sucks- I mean really sucks.  I already show enough respect by ordering straight off the menu, their New Orleans Iced Coffee is fantastic however their extremely condescending attitudes are not.  Every time I am in there they are always playing very somber kill yourself music (which is just fine), but in my opinion it comes down to the product and the way the customer receives it and this place needs a lot of help with their people skills.  I would not talk smack on anything else because that is all a matter of preference.  Coffee is great but the service is terrible- every day it is like making a deal with the devil.
author: J F.

description: Blue Bottle's affogato is sinful!  A combo of premium espresso and Humphrey Slocombe's 'secret breakfast' ice cream is a treat worth waiting in the 15 minute line.  This place is like Starbuck's on steroids!!!!
author: D. E.

description:
stop f.....g whining, people!!! if you want a couch go to bloody starbucks or some dirty coffeehouse on haight...ouch, the stools are a bit too hard for my sensitively pampered butt.. jez, what's up with you???? oh, they missplaced your order, you poor thing.... 
and, if you think the coffee being served at bbc was $20 you need serious math lessons....
anyway, totally 5 stars well deserved. coffee and food is excellent. service is great (if sometimes not so, well, it's a new place).
the interior is awesome and i love the stools!
and the coffeemaking contraption? superb!!!
and seriously, the prices are pretty moderate (a caraffe for 9-10bucks is good for 2-3 cups; the poached eggs $6).
author: bmwcafe c.

description: the best cup of coffee i have ever had, hands down. the place gets a bit crowded but if you can get past the lines and the activity, you're in for a treat. take a taste before you add sugar or cream... you'll be surprised to find a really good non-bitter cup of awesome. :-)
author: AJ B.

description:
When in SF for a conference a co-worker from out of town asked where to go to get coffee.  I pointed him towards starbucks.  He specified he wanted "good" coffee.  I gave him directions to Blue Bottle.  (Apparently you need to specify you want "good" stuff when asking me - who knew)

I love the Kyoto style iced coffee.  I only drink black coffee and the Kyoto iced is by far my favorite.
author: Ali F.

description: Well I can see this place is going to rock!  The space is quite cool and service top notch.  And in the end it's all about the coffee and this stuff?  It's the best in town. Had to run to work so just coffee and no time to sample the food items, but that's going to be a must tomorrow...polenta mit speck und Gruyere, now THAT's a cruel mistress ;-) (--Wine too!!) Tight.  New haunt!
author: Mark N.

description: The ultimate for espresso drinks (along with Ritual).  Not a place to work, but great for hanging out, if you can get a seat. ;-)
author: Ari M.

description: Still the best cappucino in the world, HOWEVER, the vibe/design in this new place is kinda weird.  first off, there is NO ventilation.  granted we were there this past sunday morning during the heat wave, but it was so hot inside that most people were heading for the only 2 windows in the front that open.   apparently all those other windows along the side don't open.  tragedy!!!  other than that, the thick cut toast with butter and jam was delish.  service was fairly friendly, but a bit slow.  it just doesn't have the charm as the kiosk on linden.
author: Betsy K.

description: That's twice now that I've made the hike to this location only to find that they've stopped doing siphon pots at some arbitrary time during the day with no explanation and nothing on their door or website to denote it.
author: Yod S.

description: My wife and I walk here and enjoy their New Orleans Iced Coffee on our day off together.  The coffee is always good, the staff is nice and the place has a nice atmosphere.  Their whole bean coffee is a little pricey, but it is worth it to treat yourself to some good home brew every once in awhile.  If you've never been then I highly recommend it.
author: Christopher D.

description: great coffee,  usually a line though which sucks, approach from the east to avoid crooks and stepping on crack pipes.
author: Brian R.

description:
apparently theres only one of these japanese filtering coffee machines in the country
and yes
the coffee and espresso here are damn good..

i sipped my cappuccino watching rainfall 
like i had nowhere to be.
(until i started bouncing off the walls)

they dont settle 
even 
their imported jam is exquisite 

there are newspapers to stir the morning thought
as well as a motivated business crowd

back here soon.
author: Maria M.

description: Just got back from a beautiful bike ride through SOMA and a quaint brunch at BBC. The wait wasn't long, we got seats in front of the Japanese evaporation coffee maker. Order up was poached eggs on toast and cassoulet. Both were delicious. I love the thick toast, it reminds of breakfast in Japan. Everything was simple, filling and delicious but not too much waste. The chef was sweet and talked to us about his menu and the staff making the coffee was helpful explaining the Japanese evaporators. One star lost, due to the fact the half and half was curdled and we had to get a new coffee. I loved the decor, atmosphere, and space. I will SURELY come back often.
author: Tricia G.

description:
as my friend drove down this small backstreet in SF, i was wondering "where in the world are we going?  i don't see a coffee shop anywhere..."  we pulled over and i was trying to imagine what kind of place this was going to be.  then i walked into blue bottle: clean interior with wooden tables and stools, a clear view of their siphon set ups, and a very simple, straight forward menu.

i ordered the new orleans iced coffee: hands down the best iced coffee ever.  none of this starbucks watered down stuff--it was strong coffee.  on the side they offer liquid sugar, which was nice since i have often painfully tried to add granulated sugar to iced coffee.

my friend ordered a latte, and that was just as good and surprisingly strong.  if you got to SF, 66 mint st. should be your first destination you enter into your GPS for good coffee.  do it.
author: Adrienne I.

description: I come here on weekends, and it feels like Chelsea, but with more flavor and less attitude. The Kyoto iced and espresso con panna are amazing but just checking out the cool use of materials and fixtures in the space is worth the visit alone.
author: Margaret K.

description: Holy Mother! I have found the holy grail of lattes! I swear, this is the best damn latte I have EVER had. I now find myself making up excuses to head downtown just so I can get my BB fix. I laugh as I walk down the sidewalk seeing people carrying their Starbucks cups--they have no freakin' ideal! Seriously, it is a bit of a wait to actually get your drink, but it is SO worth it. Try it...if there is such a thing as a coffee orgasm, you'll have one! Ohhhh, get me some Blue Bottle baby!
author: Kim S.

description:
Blue bottle is known for taking coffee very very seriously.  I'm not sure why anyone is surprised that this place is so intense.

The down and dirty quality of the kiosk is simply because their attention was focussed on the coffee.  It's like meeting a mystic on the streets of mumbai who shines with an inner light of secret knowledge.

Given the chance to create the full experience they have naturally created a temple for the worship of coffee.  The high priests operate the siphon bar, creating an expensive gourmet coffee that will open you to possibilities you had never imagined, if only you are able to still your mind and experience the moment.

Nobody else in San Francisco has come close to this, nor is likely to anytime soon.

The only downside to the siphon coffee is that it will make everything else seem like battery acid by comparison.
author: robin b.

description:
Yes, the coffee is the real deal as expected.  The cafe is not as cold as some make out, in my opinion.  There are touches of a gray-blue in the cabinets and walls.  It's a very airy space and I would have stayed forever if it were not so crowded, hot and scene-y.    

Like any new establishment, the service was off.  Some of that was due to the traffic jam at the tables and the line out the door.  I waited patiently for a Kyoto iced coffee to-go.  Because I was not in a rush and trying to observe the new cafe anyways, I ended up waiting 30 minutes.  A barista finally asked me what I was waiting for about 25 minutes in because she noticed I was standing there like a dummy for half an hour.  I still managed to enjoy my cup despite the unpleasant waiting experience which is a testimony to the quality of the brew.

Will wait and return in a few weeks to see If the service gets better and the wannabe hipsters disappear.  If not, I'll just stick to the beans and grind at home.  In 30 minutes I could have made breakfast, coffee and washed the dishes...
author: Sarah C.

description: I'm not a coffee connoisseur but my buddy is and he really wanted to try their coffee during our trip to SF. And I also really like the Blue Bottle ice cream at Humphreys! Well I was expecting some ridiculously priced coffee, but the Latte I got was cheaper than Starbucks and super delicious. 5 stars!
author: Mike L.

description:
Okay, I can't remember the last time that I couldn't decide if something was absolute genius or the esssence of the world gone mad.  A guy in lab coat behind a series of glowing glass bubbles full of boiling water, next to a phenomenally cool-looking drip "machine" sitting behind glass that was stolen from a science museum...  It looked like some SNL skit.  All it needed was John Belushi wringing his hands like some mad scientist contemplating the destruction of the free world.

Look, I'm a "coffee guy" in more ways than I need to go into here, and I'm thrilled that the industry is being pushed forward by companies like Intelligentsia, Stumptown, and Blue Bottle (these ARE the best coffee companies out there) but this was so totally, unexpectedly over the top that it caught me off guard.  I'm just not ready for an $11 dollar cup of coffee.

BUT, having said all this, the place IS amazing...
author: Morgan C.

description:
coffee and patries here are very good and taste natural.
 feel like you drink coffee at a chemistry lab.
price is not that much more expensive than other existing "modern" / european like  coffee shops.

it's a different/unique coffee drinking experience....
author: Truc N.

description: Great aesthetics, amazing coffee that will kick you into high gear for a few hours and food rocks! Love it!
author: Yaz J.

description: Besides having great coffee there, they also serve food at this location.  I didn't see it on the menu but I saw they preparing waffle.  Hope to try it next time.
author: Pavee S.

description: I hear some people talk down about the mint plaza location because of the attitude that comes with the coffee - but I've never received attitude.  The baristas are here are rad, and they definitely play a part in why I come in.  I don't even have to mention how good the coffee is, I'm sure you know already.
author: Rochelle E.

description: While I am loath to rate a Blue Bottle at less than 5 stars, I just can't justify it. The espresso here is fantastic. This is without question or doubt. I expected the service to suck, but it was actually pretty good. Everyone was really pleasant. It was also great to drink a blue bottle latte out of a glass mug and not a paper cup. That being said, the brioche french toast was mediocre and bland at best. It looked awesome and pure maple syrup is what I expect, but everything else was less so. First of all it took twice as long to get the french toast as it did to get the latte, so probably about 15 minutes. It was one slice of toast cut in two. For $9 it should have been amazing. Instead it tasted like a piece of brioche bread, toasted and topped with white powdered sugar. It was just plain bland. Sorry guys, this just doesn't cut it. I'll be going to the Blue Bottle kiosk forevermore.
author: Erik S.

description: Tried a cup of the latte at the Ferry Building based on some reports that it's coffee nirvana.  And I'm happy to report it tastes like... Peet's coffee?!!?  Okay, I'm not a coffee expert or anything, but I wasn't blown away.    Sorry to be a hater.. blah.
author: Tim L.

description: Want to jump start your day? This coffee is pure rocket fuel!!
author: Doreen W.

description: I'm drinking a cup right now, and I must say, kinda tastes like ass. Why is this any better than picking up a coffee at McDonald's one block away? Aside from saying to your hipster-ass friend "this is from Blue Bottle", nothing.
author: K F.

description:
We know their espresso is extraordinary. Why else would we schlep there. I adore their soy milk so much that I often order a case from Whole Paycheck. Now, here is why they are being docked a star. The hipster who took my order had absolutely zero sense of humor. I amused myself with a comment and he looked at me like I was a giraffe texting on my blackberry.  

The real kicker is when he handed me my number on a stand (18) and then proceeded to enter another number (10) into their ordering system. So how in the world am I supposed to know that 10 is 18? Pay attention bub. I was made to feel like I was a dumb schmuck and I'm relatively secure.
author: Minou V.

description: Aside from the most gourmet hot cocoa I have ever consumed here, there is also quite a lovely vibe in addition to lovely natural lighting throughout. A must for any "grab a coffee" meet ups with others. Business, casual, or otherwise. Cheers!
author: Not U.

description: Coffee nirvana!!  Visited this place twice on a recent trip to San Fran and was blown away by the quality of the espresso, drip coffee, and hot chocolate. I took my drip coffee to go, and even the last cold sip at the bottom of the cup was delicious as I walked downtown.  My goal is to find something that approximates Blue Bottle in Milwaukee - could be difficult...
author: Laura M.

description: I love that they have tucked this place away in an alley. It was pretty hard to get a seat, but great for a few people to sit down.
author: Scott F.

description: WTF. People write "If the soup nazi, an art gallery and the owners of several speakeasies got together and decided to open up a coffee shop, Blue Bottle would be the result." and still rate this place 5 stars? On what planet is this too cool for you coffee bar worth 30 mins to get a latte. Maybe I'm looney tunes and all the trendoid wahoos here in SF think it's chic....
author: Jacob S.

description: The reviews on here seem to be either in the "***** coffee" or "* pretentious" mode. Though, admittedly, when I went here it was not very crowded, I can state clearly that this was the best espresso I've ever had. It was so good I considered licking the inside of the cup when I was done. Instead I just ordered another. If you like espresso, this is a MUST visit.
author: john g.

description: Best coffee ever, not so friendly staff and feels a bit chaotic when the least bit busy... that being said, I'm there for nothing else but the coffee!
author: Donna V.

description:
i don't like the drip but their americano is smooth and fucking prefect.

holy love!   only in the morning please or no sleep for me.
author: Noel J.

description:
Who do these guys think they are!

Every time I go into this place I get the worst customer service, so what if they brew their coffee in a glass ball. Their attitude is the worst. If I ask for modification on a drink they tell me they can't do it. I asked for my drinks after wait ing 20 minutes and they gave me attitude mocking me. 
Customers who were at the end of a long line were receiving their coffee for me. 

Just because they have good coffee doesn't give them the right to think they are better than. 

I mean come on. What are they making over there? minimum wage?  Maybe they should take their hipster selfs back to the mission or the haight.
author: mike C.

description: I love the coffee and the space feels more like an elegant bar rather than the cliche, shlumpy coffee house image that comes to mind when one thinks of artisinal coffee!  The cookies are cheap and crazy good!!!  the server was very welcoming though the cashier/ counter guy needed to lighten up!  I will go back again and again!
author: D. N.

description:
this place OWNS.

it's cramped but cleanly set up, and all the coffee equipment gets me excited! you must see coffee siphons for yourself. i usually opt to buy their beans online or ship them to my mother-in-law living in seattle.

i love the 100% yemen and the espresso temescal.
author: Vanessa D.

description: I LOVE their ICE coffee! organic fresh coffee beans made to order. you can find blue bottle coffee at the kiosk at Farmers Market near the Ferry Building (weekends only) and a store on Mint St in SOMA.
author: Oanh N.

description:
I hear the gripes about the too cool for school attitude among some of the employees at Blue Bottle.  It always makes me wonder how someone who works at a cafe can have superior attitude about the rest of us (oh, I forgot...they're really artists that are just working in a cafe until they make it big).  That's why they don't get star 5.  Anywhew...putting that little nuisance aside, Blue Bottle really delivers in nearly all of the ways that count.  First, the beans are freshly roasted, aromatic and perfectly finished.  None of that Peets or Starbucks overroasting that seems to be so popular.  Second, the drinks are made with meticulous care.  Espresso is perfect, and served with a small glass of water Italian style...a nice touch.  Cafe au lait is smooth and creamy...probably the best I've had.  Iced cafe is to die for.  So, here's my suggestion to the Blue Bottle people...keep making the great coffee (as it is truly outstanding), but just give us all a break...we're just your loyal customers.  

PS.  would love to buy the beans at a more convenient location, but the Blue Bottle web site doesn't seem to list where to buy them.  I always wonder why businesses don't make it easier to give them business.  Just a thought.
author: Ros S.

description: "Mmm... god damn, Jimmy! This is some serious gourmet shit. Me and Vincent would've been satisfied with some freeze dried Taster's Choice, (looks at Vincent) right?"--Jules Winfield
author: Maximillian M.

description: It took forever to get a latte and even longer for a friend waiting for a shot of espresso. If that's because they brewed it fresh, than it should have also been hot, but it wasn't.
author: Rachel B.

description: This coffee is no joke. Very effective in giving that *boost* to get you through the day, without a crash at the end. All natural, nothing artificial. Definitely better than Starbucks by a longshot. Service is sketchy, but I don't really care. I know I'm better than them and I choose to ignore the rudeness from the baristas. For this company to last though, I think the management should care what people think of their service...too many businesses fail due to lack of customer service...what a shame.
author: Ava C.

description: I went again and had an even better experience the second time around. Espresso was  at the balance of salty, sour, carmel and roasted. Must always be prepared for the pretentiousness of the patrons and the snobbiness of the baristas. Convenient location but just enough distance off the beaten path (one block).
author: John B.

description: This place is one of the reasons San Francisco takes the prize for having better food than Los Angeles.   Yes, I consider coffee as food. I'm very picky with my cappuccino but was really impressed with theirs.  I had to walk blocks to get to MInt street from Market but it was worth the walk because this coffee bar was nothing like I have ever seen before.  It reminded me of a really clean, sleek chemistry lab but only the place was filled with the artsy SF crowd.  I'm so glad I walked instead of settling for Starbucks which I'm ashamed to say is what I do most traffic induced LA mornings.
author: Andee T.

description: Delicious. Went here with my hubby a few weeks ago on a Sunday morning. We ordered a pot of the Chiapas coffee and it was fabulous - smooth and flavorful. It was a wonderful accompaniment to the two HUGE slices of Brioche bread we shared (complete with fresh jam & butter). I subtracted a star for lack of seating - it was surprisingly busy for a Sunday morning and we had to wait ten minutes for two stools. Other than that - so good!
author: Heidi B.

description: Great coffee.. but service could be better through. It is incredibly slow. If you order a latte, your food should be coming soon, not after you have been waiting for 15 minutes, and finished your coffee already. Kick it up a notch, and make it memorable on the service level as well.
author: Ann Marie D.

description: i cant believe my coffee craving has gotten to snobbish level status~thats what yelp does to u =x....wont even yelp review bout the one in the hayes valley since this is the spot i originally wanted to go to...jus cuz of the girbralter (kept me amped till early afternoon) hype & the type of toys they used @ this place to brew coffee...the menu was very surprisingly good/fresh tasty...had the beiche pastry wit cheese in it & veenie had the huge waffle...the trip was that there was a chef behind the counter bakin & heating stuff...a very professional coffee joint...we beat the sat morning rush n got here round 9ish...by the time our food came out the line was wrapped round the corner....ill make sure to go this location only next time
author: elmer d.

description:
i can't believe i am just NOW discovering this place. i feel like i've been in a cave!! 

i have cut back on the java but my husband is a complete addict.  i decided to surprise him one day and he was beside himself with how rich and flavorful the new orleans iced coffee was. after tasting his ice coffee, i had to try the latte. again, full of rich, bold flavor.

i am so glad i made the trip to the cafe location. i have never seen coffee made with steam pushing water up and through the grinds. fascinating!!! i may have to pick up java again so i can go and have a single pot in its own suspended glass carafe. where does one get one of those?  LOVE this place!
author: joyce l.

description: I like this place. It's funky and you see alot of interesting people. Their coffee is good, and yes I'm aware that it's one of the best in the city. My BF loves this place and he goes often. We usually go for a small breakfast on Saturdays and I get my usual cappuccino and he just gets a coffee. We've tried their food several times and it has been pretty good, but nothing to write home about, usually a waffle or toast and some yogurt. The staff is never very friendly, but you should def. check it out. It's worth it.
author: danae k.

description: This place has by far the best coffee in San Francisco and we've tried them all.  Per some of the other reviewes, this place may not be for those who aren't coffee aficionados - who could find it overpriced and a bit pretentious.  But for those who value the best, this is as good as it gets.  Also offers excellent pastries and sandwiches.  We live in San Diego so only get to frequent Blue Bottle on business trips and therefore purchase beans from their website.  The roast is consistently good.
author: Mishel F.

description: An odd bit of trivia that I learned -- they have to charge tax here but they don't at the one on Linden.  Anyway, the coffee's outstanding.  If you have the time, get one of the fancy cups that involve the chemistry set.
author: Leo C.

description: The espresso shots were really good. I wasn't too impressed with the machiattos. I'll have to come back to try different barristas. I want one of the vacuum pots so I can play mad scientist.
author: Shane B.

description: I love their lattes at all the locations but it was really nice to be able to sit down and have a light brunch. We ordered the poached eggs which come on these amazing thick and crispy pieces of toast and some peach, granola and yogurt dish that was so refreshing.  The food menu is short but everything on it looks pretty sweet so I don't think you can really go wrong.
author: shadi m.

description: Looks like Maureen B. has captured everything I wanted to say about Blue Bottle so I'm only going to say: "Ditto"!
author: Reza E.

description: great coffee, the cappuccino or any other coffee with milk is my recommendation, their coffee is high quality.  roasts are great and they steam milk the right way, their espresso can be fantastic or ok good depending on the barista.
author: Carl V.

description: I love a good coffee!  My wife recommended we try blue bottle.  We ordered latte which was presented in a bowl-size cup with nice decoration on the top!  The coffee was, oouh, very good!  It leaves a smooth lingering after-taste in your mouth, which I really like in my coffee.  Coffee portion is just right unlike the coffee tub they serve at the cafes with green logo!! Coffee here is not served very hot so if you like hot coffee, consume it quick.  I look forward to trying Blue bottle again on my next visit to city.
author: Yes G.

description: I'm rounding up from 3.5.  Great place - really cool watching how they make the coffee.  Impeccably clean with a friendly staff.  The coffee was good, but for me it really paled in comparison to Ritual or Philz.  Had an off bitter after-taste that lingered on the palate (person I went with observed the same thing, I had drip she had latte).  I'd say it's on par with Peets and certainly better than most.  BTW although I didn't partake, the food looked delicious.  In that neighborhood I would go back when I want coffee.
author: Al K.

description:
finally made it to this location:  lovely space, far fancier than i anticipated.

but let's not be swayed by aesthetics, people. the real star at blue bottle, as always, is the mothereffing coffee.  three words that will change your life are new orleans coffee.  order one, lap up the chicory, stay up to 3 a.m. and thank me later.

yummmmmmmmmmm.
author: nic f.

description: I have never been a coffee drinker until this popped up in SOMA, now we are moving to SOMA and I could not be happier. Just during renovations I have already had numerous trips there and back. The barristers are great and Will explain things to you if time permits, and they love my dog, but who doesn't. Yay Blue bottle. FTW!
author: Kennan S.

description: I really like Bluebottle Coffee. I don't normally drink coffee but I will make exception for Bluebottle. It's just so darn tasty.
author: Cindy L.

description: Lovely little cafe in a location perfect for a stop after spending time at the nearby museums, super friendly staffs and comfortable seats, the siphon brew instrument itself is an art form;  three stars for the coffee, plus one for the fun experience.
author: J S.

description: We came here for brunch after a hectic morning.  It took a while to order, the cashier was slow, but nice.  They ran out of toast, so out of an already limited menu of eight or so items, two items remained.  I don't understand how you run out of toast for a place that serves brunch.  I ended up having the belgian waffle which is tasty, but very light for a waffle.  Definitely not worth the $9 I paid for it considering there wasn't even fruit or whipped cream, just butter and syrup.  My friend had the salad (the other available menu item), which I must admit the dressing was very tasty and the soft boiled egg that came with it was yummy.  I might come back again, but only if I can get there early enough to actually have some choice in what I'm having for breakfast.
author: Joann C.

description: I'm a midtaster when it comes to coffee so the fact that I think it's good is somewhat useless.  I am however pretty picky about food and I totally approve of Blue Bottle's menu, particularly the waffle.  The only horrible thing is waiting in that stupid long line to find out at twenty past ten that they are running late and aren't serving food yet.  Boo for that.  Another boo for the annoying and loud hipsters that I willingly put up with in order to have a yummy breakfast at Blue Bottle.
author: Poppy C.

description: reminds me of a science lab slash espresso cafe LOVE their coffee its strong flavorful and fun to watch them brew with equipments that looks like it belongs to the science lab=)
author: Juhwi K.

description: Great coffee.  Don't mind the lines for a cup nor the higher prices.  Overpriced toast (srsly 8 bucks for toast?) but was really good toast.
author: Mary P.

description:
The coffee here is superb. A sip of their drip transported me to a cafe in Paris. I was longing to hop a plane and go back to the City by the Seine.

I have become a regular within a week of my first taste. I ignore the wishy washy but somewhat friendly service. It's too bad that the frequent buyers are potentially annoying. Still. The coffee is worth it.
author: Jenn L.

description: I know that some may love the hip urban vibe they get from ordering coffee from the garage space on Linden Street, and it can be nice to sit in Hayes Valley Park and sip away, but personally I had always wished for a Blue Bottle location where I could sit down and enjoy my delicious latte in a superiorly designed cafe equal to my superiorly concocted latte, and now I have that option. The Mint location has huge windows which let in a welcomed amount of natural light and the space is lovely during the slow hours... being a small place with great coffee it understandably gets uncomfortably packed on weekends, but there are orange patio chairs located across the St. outside of the galleries. Oh, they have table service, food, and accept credit cards!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Tucked in a newly renovated square, there is an air of calmness that surrounds the store front-uncanny for mid-day downtown SF.  The modern decor highlights the interesting Italian coffee siphons and massive espresso machines.  The whole place has a fresh, clean, and hip vibe.  Getting to the coffee:  delicious.  Must try a New Orleans iced-coffee the next time SF hits three digits. The baristas are impressive in their espresso making.  I thought the other counter-culture coffee people in the Mission made a darn good espresso... however, they have nothing on these guys here.  No lemon peels needed here!
author: Anne L.

description: Really good coffee -- similar in style to Ritual. Not much in the way of atmosphere, but it looks nice, and they have papers on sticks to read. The coffee is made one cup at a time, but you can't choose the beans like you can at Phil'z.
author: Adam Z.

description: Im a coffee fanatic and blue bottle coffee serves good quality which you can definitely taste. Tho a bit expensive, but hey your paying for a good quality cappuccino. They usually get crowded so take your coffee to go and sit outside. I cant wait for them to open their ferry building location.
author: Jay M.

description: Wow, what a hipster haven.  Beautiful people, all hanging out with coffee, having a good time on a Tuesday afternoon!  Well groomed guys and gals everywhere!  On a whim, we stopped in prior to a 2:00 p.m. meeting down the street at Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.  When I saw the line, I kind of new we'd be late for the meeting, but I did not care because I had to try this coffee.  It's obvious that they take making coffee seriously, thus be prepared to wait a bit.  The cashier was extra nice to customers and patient, so I think if you have time for great coffee, this spot is perfect.  My cappuccino was excellent.
author: Eileen P.

description: Amazing stuff!  Came across this place on a rainy Sunday and had the best cup of coffee in my life.  I'm a pretty big coffee drinker (at my worst - 5 cups a day) and this is just quality coffee on another level.
author: D S.

description:
I came, I saw, I drank some coffee (Ghostbusters anyone?). So yea, I came there like the SF bandwagon-foodie-chump that I am to try the  black gold liquid from the "Japanese machine". I actually arrived at 8:30am and it turned out they don't start serving until 9am so I hung out with the bums outside for 30 mins and came back just as the line started getting long.

I originally wanted to take the coffee back to my apartment and eat breakfast alone and in peace but BB (that's Blue Bottle) will not allow you to take-away their funny Japanese coffee so I ordered a waffle to prevent the coffee from eating through my stomach lining.

The coffee took about 15 mins to brew and the waiter explained to me what it was that I should be tasting. Much like the explanation of a fine wine, my eyes simply glazed over (I like figuring out flavors for myself) and after the waiter left, I just tried the beverage without any cream or sugar. I must say it was good. In terms of taste, somewhere between a regular cuppa joe and an espresso. Would I pay $6 again for this SOMA delight? Not likely. But its worth the experience considering that much like the famous pop adage of "If you build it...", "If you make a science of it, they will come".
author: Salil A.

description:
I used to love this place... This is my twitter from this a.m..

10 minutes to get a mocha made...  3 staff working counter and drinks...  One staff working the kitchen making poached eggs or waffles another is busing, and interestingly there's one women looking deftly into space while she cleans the glass on the master slow drip piece of functional art talking to her seated lesbian lover in dreads and a bowler hat. Okay, I'm only guessing she's a lesbian because well.. ..

Oh wait the line is getting backed out the door now.  

Isn't this a coffee place?  So slow. Even for good coffee....
Oh wait, the red head is coming to help?  Nope, she just there to look pretty.   Down economy? Easy working conditions. Maybe I can get a job here....

Did I call it or what? The two lesbian ladies are making out around the corner now -- that's hot.   I wonder if her co-workers care, poor girl behind the expresso machine, no one's really working that hard but her.

All this on my little blackberry pearl while I wait for coffee.  Never again, I'm going back to Peet's or trekking it to Spikes...
author: Jeremy S.

description: mmm.. new orleans style iced coffee
author: JUDY L.

description: My hot chocolate was lukewarm at best. Getting your drinks hot seems to be a basic necessity at a cafe
author: Nancy G.

description: We love Blue Bottle coffee and have been wanting to try the breakfast. Had the benedict and waffle....Delish!
author: Heather J.

description:
coffee: 5
service: 4
ambiance: 4

damn, the line for coffee 3 days post opening makes starbucks on Monday 8am look like kids play!

The 66 mint st is absolutely beautiful, very clean and classic. Beautiful vaulted ceiling and thoughtfully subtle colors. The seating area is effective given the limited space. The brewing machinery is impressive and not overly pretentious looking (hah standing in line for 20 minutes for a cup of brewed beans-- what's the basis of pretense??). Of course the coffee is boss which goes w/o saying. Unfortunately they were out of Kyoto iced so I settled for New Orleans which was not overly sweet.

Will have to try the siphon brewed coffee once the buzz dies down!
author: Miss C.

description:
Great coffee and lattes -- which is to be expected from blue bottle.

Tried the '11' dollar pot of coffee.  wow. really.. eleven bones for a pot of coffee.    i tried it once.. that was enough.  

Love the space.  Minimalistic with big windows .    loving the clientele, too.   Great eye candy.  I mean they were serving the real thing -- not some cheap imitation.  The coffee and the peeps.     

little sandwiches were tasty.   Delicious bread-rolls.   Haven't tried any of the other food, YET.
author: gabriel f.

description:
Went on the first Sunday it was open. They were working out a lot of logistical kinks and generally failing to cope with the number of people excited to be there; it took an hour to get my siphon pot coffee. Yes, really, an hour. No, not an exaggeration. My group's food was good but a little mild. I guess you could say a little mild but good, since the coffee's the point and really flavorful food would probably distract from that.

The cafe was offering three different coffees on siphon -- two Ethiopian, one Nicaraguan. My wife and I shared one of the Ethiopians ("Idido Valley" or something similar), and it was very good. We were given a taste of the Nicaraguan by somebody nearby at our very crowded table, though, and that was even better.

Are you wondering whether it can be worth spending $10 for a pot of coffee? It you think it sounds ridiculous, it's probably not for you. It is for me if the coffee's this good.

Went back on Thursday for a "Kyoto style" iced coffee, and I am trying to tamp down on my bias here, but I think it's the best iced coffee I've ever exchanged money for.

On coffee, even coffee for the prices they charge, I'd give this place five stars, but they're gonna have to prove the hour wait was a one time thing before I'm comfortable with that. I'll probably go a couple times a week.
author: Z F.

description: I heart coffee and even more so this coffee!  Amazing service, not to mention the most attractive men in the world not only work here but come here for their coffee.  The setting is great and it feels like a little piece of Soho right here in the city.  I have found my new favorite place.
author: Steven K.

description: So I finished my bag of beans and wanted to replenish my stash before tomorrow morning. I made the hike down after work. There was one person in front of me, then I was greeted by the barista and I asked for a soy latte and a bag of their signature Bella Donovan; however, they ran out and will not be available until Saturday. No worries, I'll just have the soy latte. After the first sip, I was giddy like a schoolgirl, grinning from ear to ear! I got some dirty looks walking down Market, back to my office. The latte is just absolutely perfect! It has a good consistency, smooth flavor, and finishes very clean. This place is a 'coffee mecca'! (I'm sure, someone has used this term before.)
author: Phillip T.

description: I tried the $10 coffee!  I totally enjoyed the experience, though I won't be splurging on that again anytime soon.  Ten bucks gets you almost four teeny cups of coffee, but the attention devoted to the hands-on brewing process sort of explains the price.  And the coffee was exceptional.  I love Blue Bottle's individual drip coffee, and this was like the ultimate purified version of that.
author: Janut B.

description: What more do you want?  Of course you have to stand in line...you have to stand in line everywhere in this city that is good.  The coffee is by far the best in the city....Ritual is good....but Blue Bottle for the win.  The food they serve is simple, fresh, good.  If I were to dream up a cafe Blue bottle would be the model.  The Clover coffee is really very good and fun to watch (it looks like a giant coffee science experiment), a little expensive I guess, but deal with it.
author: matt g.

description:
Hard to review this place, since I love the coffee and I would imagine that this accounts for at least 92% of my rating - thus completely causing my review of the establishment to probably be off balance.

I would say that the cafe itself is a bit small and that it's not really set up for a leisure morning crossword session, but I thought the service was amicable and efficient and they served me up an expected fantastic cup of coffee.
author: W. L.

description: This place is so wonderful, simplistic yet chic. Their coffee is unlike anything else I have ever tasted. I feel really lucky to work near this new outpost of their famous stand in Hayes Valley. They serve a few snacks as well, today they had proscuitto sandwiches on acme bread and white bean cassoulet as well as chocolate cake from Miette. I love how there are only a few options. The communal table takes up most of the space and you feel inclined to linger for awhile.
author: Laura Gardner S.

description: YUM.  I do like this place - you get your java with a smile.  The latte I ordered was just the perfect consistency - frothy and not runny.  The coffee is definitely good if you like it strong.  The location is a little out of the blue, but the number of people inside the place showed no sign of that.  I did like that it didn't feel like I was downtown.  You can have a conversation without feeling rushed to leave for the next patron.  There was a good number of people for a tuesday afternoon, making seating a bit harder for any party larger than one.  I did hope to try some of their food items that I've heard of but found no signs of a menu and thought i was wrong about the food service, but apparently its not an all day thing? Its a nice downtown place for coffee without the downtown hurry.
author: Kirstie R.

description: For coffee, this is as good as it gets. The espresso and drip both hit the mark and the care, attention to detail and quality can't be touched. The food is also excellent - we had the greek yogurt and fruit, and the waffle - both delicious.
author: Seann G.

description:
cofffffeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee...

coffffffeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee...

i'm an absolute zombie in the morning and a waste of my employer's money without coffee.

my friend puppy walked me over here one morning (it's really close to our job) and i got HOOKED.  their coffee is SUPER STRONG -- i mean, i got jitters, dude.

try the new orleans.  you won't even want to add any sugar.

i wish they had splenda, though.  coffee snobs.  HAHAHA

ohh... and the boy with the weezer glasses behind the counter is always a nice thing to look at in the morning.  HAHAHA... he's adorable.

the snacks and stuff look very foofy and high end and tasty but i've not had anything here other than coffee.  perhaps i'll give the tea a shot one day.  i love how the whole set-up looks like some crazy clinical meth lab.  HAHAHAHAHA...
author: Beccie F.

description: When I think of Blue Bottle, hipsters come to mind.  Hipsters aren't my thing, but when I saw that one recently opened on Union Street (in the midst of ChodeLand) I thought it's got to be more than hipsters and I should give them a chance.  I love what they're doing with the Mint Plaza, such a pleasant surprise and I see it turning into a real gem.  So in my opinion, it's a very smart location.  I was prepared to say that the coffee is all hype and not all that and a bag of chips, but it was quite the tasty beverage.  I think it could have been served a tad hotter, but I don't know if if the temperature has anything to do with their preparation of the beans.  I briefly glanced at the food menu after we place our order, and I thought it was a tad brand whorish (Acme this, Cow Girl that, etc.).  Maybe that's what they do to justify their prices.  So it was excellent, but I don't see myself giving up my home brewed Dunkin Donuts coffee anytime soon.  Although I will go back and try one of the infused (forget what its infused with) Snickerdoodles.
author: Amy Z.

description:
why is the staff void of any emotions. they stand there with blank looks on there face and seem completely apathetic to guest needs.
do you get a number? sometimes, sometimes not.
do they bring your drink to you? sometimes, sometimes not.
do they call out your drink by means of a whimper? sometimes, sometimes not.
Don't get me wrong i love this coffee shop and believe that it is one of the best in the bay area.
I would model my own after it, minus the imperious staff.
author: Steven M.

description: Okay, let's all chill a little here.  I mean this is afterall coffee.  Pretty good coffee I might add, individually brewed and served hot, but this ain't orgasmic.  Came in here with a burner of a hangover last weekend.  The taste of Jack -n-Coke still on my tongue and gunned down a cup of this Joe.  This stuff is thick and nutty with a creamy top.  It gave me the appropriate jolt.  I could have done without the phony bike messenger dude spewing in line about HTML or some crap.  After I finished my cup I stepped out into the morning sun, threw in a nice moist dip of Skoal and the day was better.   But, like I said let's not all get too crazy here about coffee.
author: Nick S.

description:
OK, I appreciate "artisan", small batch, specialty coffee. I have had good experiences with Blue Bottle in the past, but the last two times I have had a horrible cup of Bella Donovan at the Linden St. cafe and a poorly executed cappuccino at the Mint St. location.
Yeah, I know the line is usually 10 deep and out the door most of the day, but how many of these people actually know what a good cup of coffee or excellent espresso drink tastes like and is consisted of?
Most of the time, I hear and and see the "suits" get excited about the "little leaf" in their milk foam and see them take a picture of it on their iPhone. 
Great, if that's the kind of people you cater to, but don't expect to hand me an over-roasted Bella Donovan and expect me to drink it all straight up. (I had to add cream and sugar to it to make it even slightly bearable. And I never drink my coffee w/ cream and/or sugar)
And if I am paying $4+ for a capp. please make it with enough foam to make it qualify as a cappuccino, NOT a latte. And also, make sure the foam on the capp stays put longer than 30 seconds. And lastly, when someone orders a drink with soy, make it with SOY!
Out of the last 2 times to Blue Bottle, I have been 0 for 2.
I'll keep it at that and just give my business to other local specialty coffee shops.
Sorry Blue Bottle, you lost me.
author: George P.

description:
this place has darn good coffee! 

i admit, i was pulled into the trying the $20,000 super duper halogen coffee machine made in japan, but at $12 a pot, i don't know if i will be doing that again. the coffee was really delicious, but unless you are a heavy duty coffee connoisseur, i'd save the 12 bonz. though, i really liked that they gave you miette candy to go with your pot of coffee. i love miette, but that is another review...

since i tried the pot o' coffee, i've been back for the individual drip. the coffee is very good. i loved that it was the perfect temperature to drink, not to hot, not to cold. it also packed a punch. i think that i actually sprouted wings, because i was a buzz in the office. 

all in all, i would definitely recommend this place to all you coffee drinks out there.
author: Erika A.

description:
As a resident of the new federal building on 7th and mission,  leaving Peets and being left with Starbucks was painful.  I found myself just doing a french press in my office.  Then Blue Bottle opened up and I'm hooked.  I normally get just the drip to go and it's an impressive cup of coffee.  Made to order, clean without bitterness and complex flavors.  I have not had any of the espresso drinks so can't vouch for them.

Why not five stars?  The attempts at food should just be dropped. Overpriced and too small portions for a proper breakfast.  Also, the counter folks try to seem a little too cool. But have gotten better as time goes on.
author: Brian W.

description: It's a nice place without the massive display of trademark cups and candies. A minimalist place without the big sofas or extra-fancy types of drinks. Unfortunately they did not have decaf coffee when I placed my order. They gave me decaf Americano instead and charged me Americano. That's fine. But my Americano came out not hot enough and my friend's latte was lukewarm.
author: Bias W.

description: Worth the wait if you are a coffee snob and like simple appealing food. You can tell the staff were educated about their coffee, the process and wanted you to have the best coffee experience. Maybe a little too into their job because one of the baristas was obviously had an unstoppable runny nose although easy to understand given the lines out the door and the need to stay employed. We had the siphoned coffee experience and a different barista told us the step by step process and gave us good tips on places to visit in San Francisco.As he was engaging in conversation with us he was accurately  measuring the water temperature to ensure we would have the best coffee experience.  We loved it and would recommended going for people who are interested in coffee, atmosphere and being where it is happening. The decor was  neat and picture blog worthy.  In general a little overstated but still worth it.
author: Tasha O.

description:
So I may not be the first reviewer but Blue Bottle has the distinction of being my first review.  
I think the comments about the staff's cold attitude are a touch unfair.  As a veteran of the downtown retail world I speak with authority when I say that most shoppers/consumers of this aria are not the nicest people and if you work at an establishment that attracts as many coffee lovers as it dose people who saw a $20000 coffee maker on TV and are now pretenses enough to want to be a coffee lover and clam an affinity for blue bottle that has been going strong for years then you too may seem a touch distant.
I have gone almost every day since they opened and if you are a familiar face they defiantly warm up.  I have gotten nothing but good service and obvious some of the best caffeine around for the last few weeks.  James always makes a point to say hi, and Justin pulls just about the best macchiato I have ever had. 
I do think it could be a little more comfortable inside but that is my only qualm.
author: James M.

description:
Warning:  do not come here if you like weak Starbucks-like coffee.  This is only for the serious java-lovers.  

Coffee/espresso drinks, a couple of wine selections, a cool Japanese beer, brunch/lunch menu + desserts.  Order at the counter, find a bar/counter seat or venture outside.  

Kyoto-style Iced coffee is kick ass, like literally I think more than one of these and I'd be twitching my ass off.  Individual drip coffee always delish, Siphon pots are awesome too, great for sharing with one or two others. Also great to get a couple of different coffees in the Siphon pot to compare notes.  Imagine a glass globe heated with a heat lamp below, the water ventures up a tube through the filter and back down.  Totally cool contraptions, like the old-school stove-top espresso pots but Jetson-like coolness.  

I will be back to try their lunch/brunch menu of croque monsieur, and other goodies.  Ginger cake was yummy with coffee.
author: Haxter G.

description: Had a friend in town from Spokane who was dying to try BBC, so we headed over with high hopes.  It was surprisingly empty and we walked up to the counter immediately, which was great.  The siphon coffee was tasty and fascinating, but when my friend asked the guy who delivered it to explain the system he sighed heavily and begrudgingly spat it out.  While he was talking she tasted her coffee and then reached for the cream, at which point he stopped his spiel and told her that  a true connoisseur would never put cream in this coffee.  So, in all, the coffee was good, the service was elitist, and the creamy polenta tasted like soft cardboard.
author: Gwen S.

description: Terrific space and great feel, definitely a temple to coffee purists with a variety of siphon equipment, an impressive Japanese siphon apparatus and unique coffee including New Orleans Iced and Kyoto style iced coffee, which is smooth and bordering on alcohol in flavor.  Only downside is sometimes drinks are unavailable depending on time of day.
author: Peter L.

description: these people know how to make a mean cup of coffee. their belgian waffle aint to shabby either. since i don't live in SF the only thing i can do to come close to this perfection is ordering their beans online and brewing them in my own chemex or siphon. not the same, but what can ya do?
author: jen m.

description: this coffee will make your hair stand up and your teeth grind till 5:00am (in a good way). seriously, i have never had such strong coffee in my life...is this stuff legal? besides the caffeine levels, it's the best tasting coffee to be had outside of europe. if friends/family complain about crappy coffee in the city, send them here. it should shut them up.
author: Edward R.

description:
OK, now I have to downgrade to three stars. It's so expensive and takes so long. The coffee is very good, but it's always half an hour. The line are so slow. Then, when you get to the front and everyone seems to run away, so it's just you and the cash register. It's an iPad and flips toward you, so I guess I could just surf. I used to make special trips there, but since the latest price increases I've pretty much stopped going.

Update: OK, back up to four stars. So, true, I rarely go there now, because of the prices and the lines, but they seem friendlier now, and the drip coffee can be quite good, and when I sit down with my coffee and poached eggs on toast, life feels pretty darned good. I guess I've somehow grown fond of them.
author: Mike K.

description: I really wanted to give Blue Bottle 5 stars and their coffee is out of this world but there's a certain coffee snobbery there which prevents me from doing so. Other than that my experience was great. I actually enjoy the very cool decor and it's worth the wait.
author: Fern W.

description: Classy looking cafe, constantly busy, yuppie crowd. There's ample seating on the long, shared tables and the window-side counters. It's a nice place to grab a coffee before or after a meal at one of the nearby restaurants. Noticed the New York Times hanging on the newspaper rack so might be someplace to go in the morning to catch up on some news before work. It's not someplace I'd tote my laptop to and sit for long periods of time though.
author: Eric C.

description: Oh, where can I start! I went to Blue Bottle the first day it opened and received an oh-so-cold shoulder! Only thing worse than cold coffee is cold service. The girl who "greeted" me, barely whispered a hello and then when I ordered a coffee with a shot of espresso to go, I was told "we don't do that". Oh, OK! Stupid me! Being flexible, I said I would just have an espresso to-go. Again, I got the response "we don't do that either. Our espresso is so good, we don't serve it in to-go cups". Again, trying to go with the flow, I said I would be fine then to drink my espresso in the Cafe.I have to say, it was the worst shot of espresso I have ever had (and all this before 730am! Bummer!) Anyhow, decided to give it another go the next day and ordered just a coffee to-go, to avoid the disaster from the day before. I got my coffee, minus any friendliness once again, and walked across the street to my office, took a sip, only to find it was barely hot. I really, really, really want to love Blue Bottle Cafe, so decided that perhaps the 3rd time would be a charm. Barely hot coffee again and this time, I was literally brushed aside as the staff that morning were swarming around getting ready for the TV crew that was there to film.  So here's the deal. I dig Blue Bottle coffee, but now only order it at other places like Bittersweet or Pizzaiolo. They serve it the way I like it and with a smile. Is that too much to ask for? So disappointed with my experience and being in public relations for the largest business on the block, they've missed a huge opportunity with me promoting their business. They should consider a new name... Blue Balls Cafe, it suits them perfectly.
author: Corinne S.

description: As an out-of-towner, I'm glad I spent a lovely Sunday morning here, but Blue Bottle isn't a place I would frequent on a daily basis.  I wasn't blown away by the coffee, but I have different preferences.  The atmosphere was crisp & clean; I tend to lean towards the cozy & gritty.  But the people watching was fantastic!  During just one cappuccino, I saw a French couple with 2 small children enjoying the finer things in life, a drag queen posse getting their caffeine fix after a long night, the cutest geeky guy reading his hardcover novel who was a sweetheart and offered us the extra stool next to him, and a woman in a tutu with black fishnets.  Well, it was the morning of the Pride Festival, so it probably wasn't the most normal of Sundays, but I loved it!  But I'm getting off topic... the coffee was all about preparation.  The one thing that separates them from all the other coffee shops out there is the siphoned coffee, which was very popular.  My friend tried to order it, but the Siphoner was on break until 1pm.  They actually have a person whose only job is to siphon the coffee!!  Tripped me out.  But I'm cool with drip... I don't need my coffee to be "cleaner tasting."  It tasted clean enough to me prepared the regular way.  The food did look delicious... I was staring down everyone that had ordered the waffles, but I couldn't bring myself to spend $9 on one... even though it was covered with berries and looked positively scrumptious.  It does get pretty crowded in the place, but since it's at the end of a dead-end street, there is a small plaza just outside where you can sit on block type structures and enjoy the fresh air and sunshine... if you get that lucky!
author: Trina S.

description: went to blue bottle cafe for a quick sunday brunch. i don't do coffee so i got a hot chocolate instead, which was super chocolatey (michael recchiuti) and came with some pretty foam. probably wouldn't order it again unless it was dessert time. for the food portion, got the popeye eggs (two slices of acme thick toast with baked-in eggs and maple butter) and ate it all up. so simple but so good. i'd totally go back just for that. and watching the coffee being brewed on the siphon thingie was neat too.
author: spiff e.

description:
i'm not a coffee snob by any means, nor an addict, but i do have a soft spot in my heart for blue bottle coffee. i was extremely excited about the opening of their new cafe in the mint plaza, so my friend and i decided to check it out the weekend after they opened. this turned out to be a huge mistake. it was fun to share a pot of siphon coffee, but it was not fun to wait an hour for it after waiting half an hour just to order it. i also was not enthralled with their menu - it seemed like five variations on a toast-and-egg theme, which was kind of nice for its simplicity, but also just rather unremarkable.

however, in the last month or so, i've visited blue bottle cafe twice on weekend afternoons, and have been blown away both times. not only were there plenty of seats each time, but the food, while still simple and comforting, was also inventive and surprising, and came in quite large portions. my most recent visit had me enjoying a seemingly bottomless salad of purslane, mint, strawberries, and tomatoes, with two huge chunks of delicious cheese and a generous portion of bread. and of course, the quality and selection of coffee is a given. this is definitely going to be a regular weekend lunch spot for me.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Returned to BB coffee today to show my dad the amazing tricks they do with the milk froth to finish off lattes and cappuccinos. Normally my visit is early in the morning (before 8 am, if possible) so I have not experienced the weekend madhouse feeding frenzy that takes over this otherwise small and unassuming coffee joint. At 3 pm on Sunday, this place was PACKED. Packed to the brim, so crowded that you could not sit down, even if you wanted to. The line was nearly out the door, and once we ordered, it took about 20 minutes to get the coffee. Yes, 20 minutes to get the coffee. In the meantime, we devoured a small and airy hazelnut filled brioche while standing at the counter, packed in like a can of sardines with the rest of the coffee craving masses. So why you may ask, do I keep coming back to this place if the waitstaff has attitude and the crowds are horrendous? Well, I'll just blame it on the coffee, which in my opinion may very well be laced with crack. Today the latte came out, with the signature milk swirl as artistic and beautifully delicious as I had hoped.
author: Kate A.

description:
i'm now officially specializing in pointing out weird things at blue bottle.

i stopped in this morning and ordered the herbal tea. i know. i had a singing gig and just wanted some hot water, and a place to waste a half an hour.

so i was delivered a glass pot filled with boiling water, a sliced orange, and some relatively think round slices of whole ginger (skin on).

no herbs.

it was fine, it was what i wanted (hot water!) and i'm happy that blue bottle doesn't stock, say, tazo tea or something but herbal tea should have some herbs in it.

i'm just saying.
author: Wangston P.

description: OK: the product is excellent, whether we're talking beans or a cappuccino, and for that reason I've been a Blue Bottle advocate since the only outlet was a table at the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market BUT Blue Bottle is becoming a victim of its own success in terms absentee ownership and nobody recognizable as a manager if a customer wants to make a suggestion. As somebody else here noted, you're never going to get out of Blue Bottle quickly because they hand-craft each exquisite little beverage. That's ok if you know the deal and go there for a beverage--you want mass production, go to Starbucks--but James (the owner) needs an experienced expeditor/dedicated cashier so that if you just want to buy a half-pound of beans you don't have to wait through all that hand-crafting. Instead, all transactions are handled in real time and first-come-first-served and the cashier performs double duty making drip coffees as well as ringing sales and when dripping coffee, won't acknowledge you. In fact, it's not at all uncommon to approach the counter and have six people back there not acknowledge you in any way because that's apparently not in their respective job descriptions. That's crappy service and can ruin what should be a great experience. Don't assume putting money in the tip jar will be acknowledged either. It might be, depending on who's on duty, but it just as well might not. Same goes for getting a "you're welcome" out of some of the baristas--who admittedly have a high-pressure job I wouldn't want--when you thank them. James: If you're reading, please designate a manager for each shift and put him/her in a different uniform so your customers will know they have someone accountable to speak with, and take the necessary, simple steps to expedite the traffic flow. You've got a 90% beautiful thing going but it has structural flaws that anybody in the food and beverage business can spot.
author: David R.

description:
I am becoming a coffee snob, which probably ruins my enjoyment of more coffee than the experience is worth (there's not that much great coffee around).  The coffee here (both brewed and the beans) are easily the best I've found in the bay area. 

My only complaint (for the Ferry Plaza stand, and Mint Street, not for the Hayes Valley location, which is fine) is that I find their approach to customer service insulting.  I don't expect them to cut a single corner to speed things up; clearly, this place is all about the craft of making coffee, and I appreciate that.  Putting that aside, though, they are completely disorganized and neglect to do a lot of things that could speed things up (fully use their machines, keep things moving, etc...) that would not compromise quality.  I waited 30 min for a pot of the siphon coffee (which is pretty fantastic), and have waited 20 min for a cup at the ferry plaza location (that's painful for a morning coffee).  They have a great product, so I'll come back now and then anyway (and to buy beans sometimes, which is quick but really expensive), but the waits are just ridiculous (one guy demanded his money back after witing 45 min, and I couldn't blame him).
author: r h.

description: excellent experience overall again, bad thing is that many people know about them and there was l-o-n-g wait for the counter. come early otherwise you'll get to enjoy the outside curb, no excitement this time - during our last visit, we saw a homeless guy rob the entire tip jar!
author: Jesse W.

description:
g*dd*mnit.

this is THE place to go if you are a serious coffee drinker (i.e. you know that starbucks is not in the coffee business, they're in the do-you-want-coffee-with-your-milk? business).

the staff know what they are talking about.

they have instructional postcards for all the different ways to brew their coffee.

the prices are great, compared to what you get and what you pay for elsewhere.

but beware, there WILL be a line, a long one, at the linden street (alley way) location. always. and if there isn't one, there soon will be one a minute or two after you arrive.

they just opened a cafe on mint, off mission between 5th and 6th. go there for the siphon coffee service and the kyoto style iced coffee (linden only serves the new orleans style): exceptional. one time i was there a couple drove all the way from reno to check it out after they read about it in the ny times. reno. but really, what else are you going to do in reno besides waste an endless supply of nickels at the slot machines and chain smoke generic brand cigarettes? seriously. this is the sh*t. and i don't say that lightly.
author: Koshin T.

description: You wouldn't know that we're in the worst economic state since the Great Depression by standing in the never ending line at Blue Bottle.  Their little cups of gold are pricey, but oh so delicious.  If you go right at 7am there's no line, but at every other hour, there's a line.  Don't get the vegan mocha, it's not so fab.  Stick with the soy latte.
author: Shalom G.

description: I had a cappuccino, perfect! I had my son's hot chocolate, was that for real?? Amazing!! Loved it!
author: anca v.

description: OH MY GAWD...over the top. ok. it is just a cup of coffee. pahleesee--and after reading the ny times article. gees louis--you think i were drinking gold. A bit over the top. But hey, the suckers are paying for it.
author: Jack F.

description: i was running late for a meeting but didn't care 'cause I was on a quest to get some caffeine. alas, so was everyone else it seems that afternoon. the industrial chic of the Mint St. Blue Bottle - with its concrete walls, high ceilings and Brazil (the movie)-esque siphons and glass contraptions were all quite mesmerizing. so i continued to not care that I was running later and later for my meeting. the delicious cup of iced new orleans style coffee sealed the coffin on caring about punctuality. yup, thanks blue bottle for making me careless.
author: ray e.

description: Best coffee in the city (at least for lattes and cappuccinos). Their barristas really know what they are doing, through if you want food it is not the best place as the little food that they do have is very expensive.
author: David D.

description: Uber hipster; being the only non coffee drinker @ work I'm frequently marched to this place.  The lemonaide and hot chocolate are excellent.  Great waffle too, real butter, typical SoMa hipster pricing applies.
author: Matt P.

description: This is the Church of Coffee.  if you take coffee seriously, a visit to Blue Bottle (mint plaza) is akin to visiting Napa as a wine aficionado.  These people know their stuff. Do not suffer fools. Will go the extra mile every time to insure each cup is the best representation of the bean varietal possible for every customer without compromise. Lines can be a problem on weekends.  Seating is tight.  To-Go is often the ticket.  All-in-all you will be a happy, well caffeinated, repeat patron in no time flat.
author: Tom B.

description: delicious but pricy and super hip.
author: Cass M.

description: This place reminds me of a communal breakfast spot in Sydney...very chic yet unpretentious and probably the best coffee you will ever have. I can't wait to go back for more!
author: Rhea A.

description: Good coffee, but slow service and a little bit of an attitude.  In addition, they don't have their special coffees from the Japanese drip device at all times, nor food at certain times on Saturday or Sunday morning, but they neglect to post these times anywhere in the cafe, on the door, or on their website.  Best to call ahead if you plan to eat, otherwise just go to their Hayes Valley location.
author: F G.

description: I am having the craving for the New Orleans style iced coffee... smooth sweet chocolatey goodness..
author: Carrie F.

description:
They take some hot water and place it in a glass bowl, heat it up with a unique techie looking halogen lights that can dial in a heat temperature on a dime. The water bubbles through coffee and a cotton filter into an upper glass container... the barista stirs the heated coffee until it is ready and then serves it with instructions to let it cool a minute to bring out the flavor... Is this like letting your wine breathe ? Well, I usually drink my coffee "au laited"...or with a touch on non fat steamed milk... so I asked for a bit when I ordered... I got a look and then was told, that "we like you to take a couple of sips and then you can do whatever to it"...or she might as well have said..then you can F it up ...but she pleasantly said, it takes about 5 minutes to make so come back then and I can get it for you so it will be fresh...
See a video of the place @ http://sf-lunch.com/2008/02/05/blue-bottle-cafe-revolutionizing-the-coffee-bar/
author: SF Luncher z.

description: very busy and also  very efficient at making great coffee drinks and keeping it  moving along, I have not sampled any of the food, but what I saw others eating looked very tasty!
author: sammy o.

description: properly served coffee and $2 ... drink this philz ..............
author: tim y.

description: This place rocks.  Excellent food as well as beverage. Warm & efficient service for custom-made & exquisite coffee drinks. Room to sit at a community table.  What else matters?
author: A R.

description:
i've never actually ordered a regular cup of coffee here.  every time i come i get the new orleans style coffee.  it's iced and quite tasty.  i'm pretty positive it's the addition of milk that makes it so yum.  the wait's never been long for me, but that may be because i go at off times.

i've purchased whole bean coffee and it was pretty delicious.  i bought the chiapas and the colombian.  they were both really smooth and my coworkers agreed.  

a bit pricey, but what coffee place isn't these days?
author: H. G.

description: This is like the Neiman Marcus of coffee, sophisticated simplicity. The cappuccino was smooth, bold and strong. I made the mistake of adding sugar before trying it, (it didn't need it). One of the best cappuccinos I have had.The cafe is  modern and soothing. The minimalist decor allows the real stars to shine: Coffee and those Talented BARISTAS. We sat at the bar in front of the Siphon Barista- best spot in the cafe. It was like getting a coffee show, her movements were like a choregraphed dance. The Japanese siphon coffee was cool to watch, but just OK on flavor.  Kyoto iced coffee was AMAZING!!!!!!! the 20+ hours to prepare reflects in the flavor. It was like drinking a fine wine.
