Sophisticated flavor that is a must for anyone who loves and appreciates coffee. Blue bottle turns coffee  and it's preparation in to an art form.  The coffee from here will stimulate your senses: visual, smell, and taste in ways you never knew possible. When you go for the first time, make sure you give your self time to enjoy the whole experience.
author: Veronica B.

description: This place sucks. First time I went, they decided to stop serving food 'cause it was "too busy". Second time I went they decided not to serve food yet (it was 8:45 on Sat am). They charge you 2+bucks for a small cupa joe, cracked cup and no discount on a refill.  Yeah the coffe's good but the 'tude is terrible.  Never again.
author: Lisa H.

description: I love coffee.  Always seeking out the best coffee I can find.  The lattes here are wonderful!  On par with the best stuff from Italy.  The flavour is full but still subtle and the presentation is also exquisitte.  Would like maybe more outdoor seating and free parking, but still if you love coffee check it out!  The bread procioutto is great too.
author: Matsuo F.

description:
this is, by far, one of the best coffee places in soma.

cant go wrong with an individual drip, NOLA-style iced, or heart-topped latte.

haven't tried their siphon pots, but am always in awe of those that do.
author: E. R.

description: So, Blue Bottle seems to have become a brand name as much as anything else - you see it on restaurant menus, whether they're just serving it up in a french press or using it to make ice cream . . . I've had it and enjoyed it, but this was my first visit to one of their own venues - and it didn't disappoint! Friendly and knowledgeable girl behind the register, deft barista dealing out some very pretty lattes and cappuccinos (I'm a sucker for pretty coffee - I apologize, if I want plain Jane, I'll stay at home, thanks!). My best friend has long-talked about their New Orleans iced coffee, so that's what we had. Here is another example of great coffee theatrics - I think there are few things more pleasing to my eye than watching the milk getting poured into iced coffee, seriously, next time you have the opportunity, enjoy it. The iced coffee also TASTED quite yummy, so don't worry there. They also have another version, name is escaping me, that is made from a Wonka-esque contraption - we were told a batch takes something like a twenty-four hour period - wow. And they don't always have it - but it costs the same as the apparently low-brow New Orleans ($3.50). I am holding back a star because, although we enjoyed the large windows and high-ceilings, and stayed for a good hour to converse, it did lack a certain coziness - I wouldn't picture myself hanging out here solo, with a book perhaps, like I would at my favorite coffee places - but still, I would have absolutely no objection to going back!
author: Hannah D.

description: Blue Bottle coffee is beyond delicious. This location does have a bit of a homeless situation going on; however, both times I've gone it's been okay. Others have spoken of long lines and/or unfriendly staff; however, I have never encountered either. Perhaps I've been lucky w/ my timing. Both times, on my way home from the gym, I got a craving for Blue Bottle, zipped down Mission onto Mint and was lucky enough to get one of the 5 or so parking spots. And, I had less than a 1 minute wait to order and about a 1-3 minute wait for my beverage. Today I got one of the little sandwiches ($3.50) - it was a tiny little french roll w/ mortadella and butter. Very simple but really delicious and just the right size. I got a nice  seat by the window and was able to relax, read the paper and enjoy my coffee and sandwich. A line did form out the door while I was there, but it seemed to move quite quickly. I would not recommend driving here if possible - I've just had amazing luck with parking. Definitely walk/bike/muni/bart to get there. But, seriously, i thought I'd never say this as I'm quite picky with coffee, but Blue Bottle cappuccinos are seriously the best I've ever had anywhere in the world!
author: Maren P.

description: I went there on saturday with a friend. It was my first time there. She got a mocha and I got a latte. So she's telling me how good it is and I heard about Blue Bottle being very popular I got my latte. It was good, ok, but not outstanding. It was not really hot and I had to drink it quickly before it got cold. I had a little bit of my friend's mocha and I thought it was really good. Maybe I just picked the wrong drink for my first time at Blue Bottle. I would definitely go back and try it again. I'm not a coffee expert. However, I think Peet's coffee is as good as Blue Bottle.
author: Purple P.

description: i wish i could lead the backlash to the blue bottle obsession, but alas, it's just really really good coffee
author: Seiji C.

description: hands down the best coffee on earth.  literally all other coffee is mediocore in comparison.  plus all the cool coffee makers from japan are super dope.
author: Nicholas d.

description: I returned to the scene of the crime. Well, it hadn't been committed yet. I came, I saw, I took away a star. If I hadn't given four stars previously I would have given BBCC a two star based solely on this experience. Jammed full. Touristy. And three places at which I could have sat that had dirty dishes. So I sit down at the only spot without dirty dishes and I realize I'm sitting across from the really nice woman who brought me my food last time. Only this time she's sitting with her girlfriend. I think, well maybe she doesn't work here any more. (Someone wasn't working there, that's for sure.) This time I pick up my own espresso from the bar--I don't mind getting it myself, but which is it going to be? Table service or not? And when my poached eggs are ready--the woman from across the table brings them to me. Very cordially. But at this point I'm struggling. What is happening. Sure, it's all under the surface of passable, but it's a bit more like I remember our local Hardee's in Indiana. By the time I'm done, the places were cleared--it's pretty great to sit at the window near the Mint. Things are somewhat back to normal. Perhaps I hit it at exactly the wrong time. Eggs were good. Espresso was good.
author: Thomas R.

description: i like their individual drip coffee, it's strong.  although the first time i came here the coffee was excellent, the second time it was just good.  the crowd here is very hipster-esque.  the food items are made with good ingredients in a simple manner.  you mainly choose from different types and combos of eggs and toast.  the other menu items ran out by the time i got there, so go early for more menu variety.
author: Big e.

description: how come no one is mentioning the caramels? don't they come with everything, or was i just lucky? anyway, enough about the coffee, the decor, the hip factor, the food. yada yada; the caramel by kate, who is sometimes working at linden alley, is the best caramel in the world. the best caramel, IN THE WORLD. and if you sit for long enough waiting for your vacuum-sealed coffee, you will get caramel too. at least i did, and that made my day.
author: bonnie f.

description:
being the obnoxious soma snobs that we are... ooh... organic... gourmet coffee... ooh... didya check out da new spot... how can our wanna-be hipster gentrifying asses resist checking out this mythical blue bottle coffee place that was supposed to be totally the shiet.

a fellow foodie friend and i put on our best oh-my-gawd-i'm-so-jaded faces pretending we were too cool for the crowd behind our gaudy glasses when... bam... kaitin and her cute smile brought us our drinks and broke down our defenses. yes, they bring them to you...

she and her dimples gave us the whole spiel about the espresso machines, the food, organic this local that... blah blah... (doesnt that apply to like all food establishments in the city)  but what really caught my attention was the siphon bar. the star was a $20K piece of over-engineered japanese caffeine junky machinery  (featured in NYT today) that is allegedly the only such machine in existence in the US. they apparently ask you to sip it black first and each serving comes with a piece of candy. 

unfortunately, we already had the best most creamy fragrant (clover milk) and smoky (the great beans) lattes in our hand... but hey, gives me an excuse to hang out with kaitlin again and stalk the cute chef...

the poached eggs on thick toast that everyone had looked really delicious too.

GREAT lattes, cool space, siphon bar, great staff..
great addition to the 'hood!!
author: v d.

description: It could be a little steep for people not used to quality coffee but Blue Bottle's new cafe is super reasonable given the quality, gadgetry, atmosphere and amazing selection of so many good things made with coffee. I just added a full review on my manseekingcoffee blog so check it out there, but you should definitely make a detour to check this place out. Just keep in mind it's really a kind of high end coffee restaurant and not a study cafe.
author: Man Seeking C.

description: Coffee good, room nice, counter help nice, funny peopel sitting around me, definitely would go back again to try the food.
author: Becky R.

description: Blue Bottle rocks!   I  first fell in love with there smooth and creamy lattes about 2 years ago and when i found out that they were going to be just a few steps away from salon 801, i  was so excited to have  another amazing business join us in Mint plaza.  Thanks for all the great lattes and eye candy you bring to the plaza.   Cheers!
author: Lisa M.

description: Great coffee (best in city). Place has a nice buzz to it (social buzz, as opposed to caffeine type). The buzz can be a good or bad thing, depending on what you're looking for. The space has a very social vibe in its design (standing height and community-length tables, loud acoustics with large glass windows and cement floors, communal sugar/creamers at tables). As a result the volume can get quite loud. So, if this is your thing, you'll love it. If you're looking for a quite coffee-house spot to chill, this is not it. Because this is the best coffee in town and has gotten so much media buzz (there goes that word again...), the prices are high (25-30% premium above the overpriced coffee chains in town), the lines are long, and the wait to get a simple drip coffee is crazy. All that said, if you're in the mood and have the time, it's well worth the it. Enjoy! Oh yeah, forgot to mention that despite the somewhat chaotic atmosphere, the staff is super-chilled and friendly.
author: Joe C.

description: I gotta tell ya, I am one of those New York Times readers/suckers who really wants to try the million dollar coffee!  But to no avail!  I have gone three times --once after calling to see if they were open (answer:"Yup."  in truth: "Closing in 5 minutes.")  So by the time I arrived, of course, the drive was for naught.  Then, I came at 8:30 AM on a Sunday (opening time: 8:00 AM) and they said, "Ummm...yeah, we're not making that coffee right now, 'cause the cooks are prepping for brunch and we can't get to the machine.  Maybe...like in  in ten or twenty minutes."  So I went and did some grocery shopping, came back in an hour, and they were all, "Ummm...yeah...we're not making that 'coffee till like maybe ten, 'cause the cooks are prepping for brunch and we can't get to the machine..." Argh!  So, if you are hot and bothered to get that coffee, call ahead, make sure they're not closing in 5 minutes and make sure the cooks aren't blocking the machine.  And bring your twelve bucks!
author: Sally C.

description: Been meaning to visit the Mint Street location for awhile and was glad to finally make it.  Parking is near impossible given the proximity to the Westfield shopping plaza and the location is a bit hard to find (google maps failed me yet again).  Ordered the New Orleans iced coffee (served with half and half) and the Kyoto iced coffee (served black)... as I do not have a refined enough palate, I was unable to differentiate the different brew methods.  At $3.50 each, the price seemed steep but not outrageous given the pleasant, airy ambiance, and the care given to the roasting and brewing process.  I am not a black coffee drinker by any means, so me being able to drink the Kyoto black is a testament to how smooth and unbitter their coffee really is.  It has none of the burnt aftertaste of other coffeehouses, and it definitely will kick you into gear and maybe even into the jitters as it did to my companion.  Will definitely go back to try the siphon pot which I hear comes with delightful little caramels.
author: joyce h.
